## Page 27

1. GENERAL SETTING Kevin J. Shaunessy and David H. Jurney LOCATION AND DESCRIPTION The Superconducting Super Collider (SSC) project area is located entirely within Ellis County in north-central Texas (Figure 1.1). The project area lies ca. 18 mi (28.97 km) south and ca. 31 mi(49.89 km) southeast of the Dallas and Fort Worth metropolitan areas, respectively. It consists of a ring or "footprint'' ca. 54 mi (86.90 km) in circumference which completely encircles the city of Waxahachie, the Ellis County seat (Figure 1.2). Other communities adjacent to the SSC project area are (clockwise from the north) tb,e incorporat~d communities of: Oak Leaf, Red Oak, Pecan Hill, Palmer, Garrett, Ennis, Bardwell, Avalon, Italy, Maypearl, Midlothian, and Ovilla, and the unincorporated communities of Forreston and Bo7_ The latter of these unincorporated communities, Boz, was located within the southern portion of the West Campus, but is now razed. The project area, however, consists primarily of rural farmlands dispersed across portions of nine USGS 7.5' quadrangles (Figure 1.3). The term "footprint'' is used herein to denote both the fee simple land purchases (i.e., fee simple estate) and the subsurface fee land purchases (i.e., stratified subsurface fee estate) for the SSC project. The SSC footprint thus includes.· the East and West Campus areas, penetration shafts and supporting service facilities, and the subsurface areas for housing the tunnel proper ~d for the monitoring of muons (see Figure 1.3, "M'' areas). The sedimentary units which underlie the SSC project area belong to the Eagle Ford, Austin, and Taylor Groups (Figure 1.6), and are briefly described below, from oldest to youngest. It ranges in thickness from 30 m to 37 m (98.42 ft to 121.39 ft) and is overlain unconformably by the Austin Chalk. The Eagle Ford Shale, which outcrops in the westernmost portion of Ellis County (Figure 1.7), is most often exposed in the upper slope of the westward-facing White Rock Escarpment (Reaser and Collins 1988). About half of the project area is underlain by the Austin Chalk ( see Figure 1. 7). As soils-developed on this base typically contain abundant small chalk fragments (see Pedology, below) and exposures of the chalk bedrock are common, the western portion of the county has been referred to as ''whiterock prairie" and ''whiterock land" (Hill 190 I; Brooks et al. 1964). The Austin Chalk is subdivided into three parts. The upper and lower parts are lithologically similar, with generally thick resistant chalk beds interbedded with thinner calcareous clay and marl. Thin bentonitic beds are found locally in the lower part. The less resistant middle part consists of thin-bedded marl with inter~ds of massive chalk (Barnes 1988). The lower, middle, and upper parts are termed the Atco Chalk, Bruceville Chalk-Marl, and Hutchins Chalk, respectively (Corbett et al. 1987, cited in Reaser and Collins 1988). The Austin Chalk is more resistant to weathering than other sedimentary units in the project area. Its base forms a west-facing.cuesta along its contact with the underlying Eagle Ford Shale, producing a narrow belt of relatively rugged relief that is-atypical of the normally level to gently rolling Blackland Prairie (see Pedology, below). This feature is known as both the White Rock Escarpment and the Austin Escarpment.

8 Shaunessy and Jurney The Austin Chalk is overlain unconfonnably by the Ozan Formation or Lower Taylor Marl, which is the lowest unit of the Taylor Group. Most of the eastern half of the SSC project area is underlain by the Ozan Formation (see Figure 1.7). It consists of blocky calcareous clay with silt and sand content increasing upward (Barnes 1988). It is, in tum, overlain by the Wolfe City Formation, which consists of mar~ sand, sandstone, and mudstone (Barnes 1988). This sedimentary unit is, for the most part, outside of the SSC project area (see Figure 1.7). The Pecan Gap Formation is not present in Ellis County. The uppennost unit of the Taylor Group consists of the Neylandville Fonnation and Marlbrook Marl undivided and is exposed only in eastern Ellis County outside of the SSC project area. It, in tum, is overlain by Pleistocene deposits and Holocene alluvium of the Trinity River Trench. The Cretaceous strata descnbed above are broken by a series of steeply dipping en echelon normal faults that are part of the northeastern extent of the Balcones Fault Zone (Reaser 1961 ). Most of the mapped fault planes strike northeast to east-northeast, roughly parallel to the strike of the bedrock units (see Figure L7). Most likely, displacement along these fault lines took place dutjng the late Oligocene or early Miocene (Weeks 1945, cited in Reaser and Collins 1988). There is no evidence that Quaternary terraces or alluvium in the project area have been disturbed by faults or flexures in the underlying bedrock (Reaser and Collins 1988). Since the inception of the SSC project, subsurface drilling for site geotechnical characterization has substantially increased the number of mapped faults in the project area. All newly discovered faults continue to be either normal faults or grabens, and all are ancient and inactive (DOE 1990). A minor unconsolidated and discontinuous gravel deposit consisting of pebble-si7.ed to small cobble-sized quartz, quartzite, chert, jasper, limestone, and petrified (silicified) wood fragments is sporadically exposed throughout Ellis County. This gravel deposit occurs as a thin veneer mantling upland areas and has been identified in all but the Mountain Creek drainage (i.e., northwestemmost Ellis County) (Figure 1.8). These upland gravels were first described in central and south Texas by Hill (1891, 1901), who named the deposit Uvalde Gravel. The Uvalde Gravel is a culturally significant phenomenon in Ellis County as it provides the only locally available source of raw materials for the manufacture of flaked stone tools. As Byrd (1971 :5) notes, these gravels are often thought of as a soil component rather than as a mappable geologic unit They are generally considered to be remnants of a once extensive "blanket'' of channel-lag deposited by long-vanished eastward-flowing streams. The source of the gravels is most likely the Ogallala Formation of the High Plains and, ultimately, the southern Rocky Mountains of New Mexico (Byrd 1971; Me117.er and Slaughter 1971). Dating of the Uvalde Gravel is somewhat problematic. Most consider the gravels to be pre-Pleistocene in age (Byrd 1971; Hill 1901; Menz.er and Slaughter 1971), but the possibility exists that deposition continued into the early Pleistocene (Byrd 1971:29; Sellards et al. 1932:776). Byrd (1971:18-19) discusses the possible relationship of the Uvalde Gravel to other upland gravel veneers outside central and south Texas. In his interregional review of lithic sources Banks (1990:56) states that "Uvalde Gravel is an ubiquitous term that is applied to almost all relict gravel deposits on late Tertiary and Pleistocene terraces as well as upland interfluves left as erosional remnants of the retreating High Plains that once extended as far to the east as the vicinity of Fort Worth." He also suggests that redeposited "Uvalde" gravels may extend much further into northeast Texas and, possibly, into Louisiana, where he suggests a potential relationship to the Citronelle Gravel (Banks 1990:57). This posited relationship, however, is by no means certain. QUATERNARY DEPOSITS The distribution of Quaternary terraces is of great relevance to the location and potential preservation of archaeological sites dating to the Paleo-Indian stage (see Chapter 2). Many of the mapped Quaternary terrace units in Ellis County are outside of the immediate SSC project area, located to the east (along the lower portions of Red Oak and Grove creeks, along Walker and Village creeks, and along the main stem of the Trinity River) and to the south (along Chambers Creek). Within the area encompassed by the SSC footprint, Quaternary terraces have been mapped along Red Oak Creek, the middle portion of Grove Creek, the middle portion of Waxahachie Creek, and at the confluence of Mustang Creek with Waxahachie Creek, in the general area of present-day Lake Bardwell. The most extensive Quaternary terrace deposi~, apart from those adjacent to the Trinity River, occur along Chambers Creek. Some of these deposits fall within the southwestern portion of the SSC footprint ( see Figure 1. 7). Terrace deposits have been identified along the entire course of Chambers Creek, from its headwaters in Johnson County to its confluence with • Richland Creek in Navarro County. These "stranded" terraces may possibly be relicts of a pre-Holocene drainage that once occupied the underfit Chambers Creek valley (Billy Stringer, Soil Conservation Service, personal communication

14 Shaunessy and Jurney portions of the East Campus. These soils tend to have a surface layer of clay loam or fine sandy loam and a subsoil of dark gray, olive, red, or brown dense clay. The parent material may be either old alluvium or weathered clayey marl. Two areas in the extreme eastern portion of the county consist of rolling blacklands covered with clays of the Houston-Sumter association. Soils of this association, particularly the Sumter soils, tend to be pale olive to yellow eroded clays. The parent material is the underlying limey, weathered, clayey marl of the Taylor Group. This soil association occurs within the eastern portion of the SSC footprint, including the East Campus. . Two other soil associations are found in many parts oft he county. The Trinity-Frio association is most abundant along the eastern margin of the county within the Trinity River floodplain, but is present in the level floodplains of all major streams in the county. The parent material is mainly old calcareous alluvium washed from the blackland prairie. In places, the old alluvium grades to underlying stratified beds of water-laid sands and·gravels. Trinity soils are more common and are typi~y more clayey than Frio soils. The Burleson clay, terrace-Houston Black clay, terrace Lewisville association occurs along streams in all parts of the g>pnty except the whiterock area (see above). Typically, this association occurs on benches between sloping uplands and floodplains. The Houston Blaclc arid Burleson soils are dark heavy c~ys found on nearly level terraces. The Lewisville soils are silty clays and loams which occur on valley slopes and are formed from old alluvial deposits. Both of these soil associations occur within the southeastern portion of the SSC footprint HYDROLOGY Ellis County exhibits a well-defined dendritic drainage pattern and contains seven distinct watersheds within its boundaries (Figure 1.12). For the most part, Ellis County is located within the central Trinity River drainage basin. The northwestern comer of the county, however, is drained by Mountain Creek, which flows northeast and ultimately empties into the West Fork of the Trinity River. The ridge line of the White Rock Escarpment defines the boundaries of this watershed in Ellis County. The remainder of the county, including the SSC project area, is drained by numerous tributaries which flow southeast to the main stem of the Trinity River. The major drainages· of the Trinity River within Ellis County are Red Oak, Waxahachie, Onion, Chambers, Mill, and Village creeks. All of these streams have numerous tributaries flowing into them (see Figure 1.12). Data on streamflow within the greater Ellis County area are available from five permanent gaging stations and are presented in Table 1.2. In addition to natural surface waters, two large artificial reservoirs have been constructed within Ellis County. These reservoirs serve both for flood control and water supply. Lake Waxahachie was created in the 1950s and Bardwell Lake was created in the 1960s (see Figure l.12). Three hydrostratigraphic units which affect groundwater·o ccurrence and movement have been defined in the SSC project area (DOE 1990:3-32 to 3-46). The uppermost unit is a shallow, unconfined aquifer system which contains Quaternary alluvium and terrace deposits as well as weathered near-surface bedrock of Taylor Marl, Austin Chalk, and Eagle Ford Shale. The second unit is a regional confining system composed of thick sequences of shale within the Taylor Marl and Eagle Ford Shale and ofunweathered portions of the Austin Chalk. The lowermost unit is a regional confined aquifer system which contains the Woodbine, Paluxy, and Twin Mountains aquifers. CONTEMPORARY CLIMATE Most of the State of Texas is classified as having a Modified Marine Subtropical climate. This climatic type is the result of a predominant onshore movement of tropical maritime air from the Gulf of Mexico, modified· by intermittent seasonal intrusions of continental air as well as by a decrease in moisture content from east to west (Larkin and Bomar 1983). The western portion of Ellis County is classified as falling within a transitional belt between the Subtropical Humid and Subtropical Subhumid climatic regions ofTexas. Eastern Ellis County (i.e., east of Waxahachie) falls entirely within the Subtropical Humid region (Larkin and Bomar 1983:2). at The mean annual temperature Waxahachie is 66° F (l 8.9°.C) (Bomar 1983). Summers tend to be hot, with an average July monthly high temperature ·or %.9° F (36.1° C). Winters are typically moderate, with an average January low temperature of33.l F (0.6° C), and periods of freezing weather are short-lived. The average length of the freeze 0 free season is 243 days (Brooks et al. 1964). About 60% of the annual precipitation for Ellis County falls in the spring

The average annual precipitation recorded at Waxahachie is 36.25 in (92.08 cm) (Bomar 1983). Brooks et al. (1964:72-73) discuss how this climatic regime affects agricultural practices in Ellis County. They note four primary climatic influences: irregular seasonal distribution of effective rainfall; a fairly high rate of evapotranspiration; frequent periods of greater than 100° F (37 .8° C) temperatures for several days at a time in summer; and moderate winters with cold spells rarely lasting more than several days. Excessive amounts of rain in the spring often delay planting, keep the soil cold, and cause erosion. Due to the agricultural practice of clean cultivation (total plowing under of harvested plant stubble and potential ground cover), a large percentage of this rainfall ·is often lost to runoff. Conversely, if precipitation occurs in the form of light showers, most of the effective moisture-may be lost through evaporation. The wind also affects water retention. In spring, an especially strong westerly or southwesterly wind may blow. Wind direction and speed, temperature, and relative humidity all combine to produce a relatively high annual rate of evaporation. The average annual gross lake surface evaporation rate recorded for Ellis·County is approximately 65 inches (165.10 cm) {Larkin and Bomar 1983:66). • As noted above, the average freeze-free season is 243 days. This allows all general field crops to mature, and the winters are mild enough for cool-season crops such as wheat to grow. Freezing weather normally occurs only from December through February and freezing episodes are typically short-lived. Cold air masses, locally referred to as .. northers," move into the area from the north and bring sudden drops in temperature. When this event follows a warm and moist winter, it may result in what is known as "False Spring." Freezing associated with northers can cause severe damage to early crops and fruit trees as well as affect the growth of post oak and other species of trees (Stahle 1990). BIOTIC RESOURCES The State of Texas has been subdivided into a number of natural regions based on the interaction of local geological, edaphic, physiological, and climatic factors (see Figure 1.9). Ellis County is situated squarely in the middle of th~ Blackland Prairie biogeographic province within what has been defined as the Texan biotic province, a broad transitional ecotone between the pine and hardwood forests of the Austroriparian province to the east and the grasslands of the Southern Plains to the west (Blair 1950). In its natjve state, the Blackland Prairie vegetation consisted chiefly of tall-grass species which graded into mixed-grass and short-grass vegetation communities to the west (Kilchler 1964). The Tall Grass Prairie, although extensive, is thus merely one ofa number ofbiogeographic zones which collectively fonn an environmental mosaic known as the Prairie Margin (ARP 1982b; Bruseth, Raab, and McGregor 1987; Kochler 1964). Some degree of biological diversity exists, as will be s~n below, even within such seemingly homogeneous zones as the Blackland Prairie. Indeed, in his discussion of the greater Texan biotic province, Blair (1950: 101) states that "Recognition of this transitional region as a biotic province represents a fairly unsatisfactory disposition of the area,

Nevertheless, due to its central location:within the Blackland Prairie the SSC project area does not display the degree of ecological diversity that is encountered in counties further to the west, for ll1flt8nce, where alternating bands of prairie and oak-hickory savannah are present The SSC project area is also situated along the western edge of the East Texas zone of primary productivity in terms of plant biomass production (Collins and Bousman 1993:55-56; Owen and Schmidly 1986; Rosenzweig 1968). This east-to-west decline in primary productivity is the result of many interacting environmental variables, but is most clearly affected by the distribution of rainfall (see Contemporary Climate above). The present boundaries of the Tall-Grass Prairie probably began to be established ca. 1000-800 B.P. with the gradual onset of warmer and drier climatic conditions (see discussions of Holocene climatic change for the greater study area in Bruseth, Raab, and McGregor [1987] and Story [l 990a]). Presettlement Flora In Ellis County, virtually all native prairie and arboreal plant communities have been totally altered or eradicated as a result of cultivation, ranching, and development (however, see discussion of remnant stands of tall-grass prairie in Contemporary Vegetation and Land Use, below). Historic reconstruction of plant communities that were recorded through General Land Office (GLO) surveyors' notes taken during the distribution of Public Domain in Texas, Oklahoma, and the southern United S~tes have provided data on limited samples of native vege~tion communities (Bourdo 1956; Delcourt 1976; Delcourt and Delcourt 1974, 1977; Jordan 1973; Jurney 1987, 1988a; Schafale and Harcombe 1983; Weniger 1984). These notes provide fairly consistent and dependable data on arboreal species, and, in some cases, prairie/forest boundaries. The presettlement arboreal plant species present in the greater Ellis County area are summarized in Table 1.3. Based on the General Land Office surveyors' notes for Ellis County, the SSC project area encompasses three major • presettlement ecosystems: tall-grass prairies (uplands); brushy prairies adjacent to stream valleys (llplands and slopes); and riparian forests along streams such as Red Oak, Grove, Chambers, and Waxahachie creeks (floodplains). Since the beginning of the Historic stage (see Chapter 2), these original plant communities and physiographic settings have been altered by numerous human activities. For exampl~, fire suppression allowed trees and shrubs to encroach upon the prairie. In the eastern project area, gullying was noted along prairie/slope margins of Red Oak Creek during the initial GLO surveys. In heavily forested areas, native trees were cut for housing, fences and fuel. Settlers also planted seeds and saplings from "home," thereby altering the general landscape by introducing exotic species. Bois d'arc, Osage Orange, (Maclura pomifera) is one transplanted species which was not present in the native ecosystem west of the Trinity River (Jurney 1988). Due to its importance in fence building, building foundation piers, wagon spokes, etc., settlers planted this tree as a first priority, and today it has achieved a dominant status in some areas. Mesquite (Prosopis glandulosa) is also generally thought to be an introduced species, yet the GLO records indicate that large mesquite trees were already relatively numerous in the "native" prairies by the 1830s and 1840s (Jurney 1988a, 1994). The largest of the native plant communities was the upland tall-grass prairie which was dominated by little bluestem (Andropogon gerardi1), Indiangrass (Sorghastrum averuiceum), switchgrass (Panicum virgatum), sideoats gramma (Bouteloua curtipendula), tall dropseed (Sporobolus asper), and Texas wintergrass (Stipa /eucotricha) (DOE 1990). While this area consisted chiefly of grasses and forbs, a small number of trees such as elm ( Ulmus americana) , hackberry (Ce/tis spp.), and cottonwood (Populus deltoides) were also present in the form of saplings along the fringes of this environmental zone. ' The brushy prairies adjacent to stream valleys continued to be dominated by grasses, forbs and woody shrubs, although arboreal species were more common in this zone. Elm and mesquite were the most common trees, followed by hackberry and cottonwood. Minor tree species along the brushy fringes of the upland prairies included several types of oaks (Quercus spp.), "cedars" (Juniperus spp.), and fruit and nut bearing trees such as haws (Crataegus spp.), gum bumelia (Bumelia /anuginosa), and persimmon (Diospyros virginiana). · A riparian forest ecosystem would have been found within the stream valleys of Ellis County. This consisted of hardwood forests and occasional wetland prairies. Ehn,was the dominant tree, followed by hackbeny, Spanish oak (Quercusfalcata), and pecan (Carya il/inoensis), Other fruit or nut producers such as several varieties of oak, red haw, • walnut (Jug/ans spp.), and mulberry (Morus rubra) were also present. Much of the understory would have been I water-loving species such as cattails (Typha spp.) and bulrushes (Scripus spp.). 20 Shaunessy and Jurney surveyors' notes. Within the wetland prairies cottonwood was the dominant tree, followed by elm, hackberry, and mesquite. Again, numerous fruit and nut producers were also present, and the understory would have contained water-loving species. It is important to note that even within the stream valleys grasses and forbs were an important, if not dominant, constituent of the floral community. Both the brushy prairie and the riparian forest contained sufficient forage tree species to support a relatively high faunal population. Hardwood resources were extremely important to historic settlers. Although some oak species were present in riparian forests and along the slopes of major drainages, extensive oak forests were generally not present within the SSC project area. A relatively large oak forest, however, was located around the Tellico area to the east of Ennis. This forest was lumbered prior to and after the Civil War. A mortise and tenon frame church in Tellico which was built from locally sawn post oak lumber has been tree-ring dated to 1867 (Jurney 1988b) . A second expanse of post oak forest was present near Italy, but was not as extensive as the one at Tellico. Both of these areas, along .with the Red .Oak, Greathouse, and Chambe&:s. Creek valleys offered sufficient forest resources (primarily oak) to attract early settlers. The available hardwood resources were soon depleted and it became necessary to import hardwood lumber as well as pine lumber from East Texas. Post oak lumber was essential for horizontal log houses. Small oaks could be hewn and used in timber framing, but siding was needed to complete the structure. Larger oaks could be sawn, but due to their hardness and tendency to warp this species was not suitable for siding in most cases. Baldcypress (Taxodium distichum) and pine (Pinus spp.) siding and framing materials had to be imported overland from East Texas by wagon. After the introduction of the railroad, costs for imported lumber fell, and a wave of construction.began. Elm, pecan, and hackberry were second choices for construction but were generally not used for houses. Firewood was a commodity that further insured the disappearance of native forests, which were replaced by managed wood lots. Contemporary Vegetation and Land Use The SSC project area has been radically altered by the historic settlement of the region (see above; and Chapter 3). There are no known areas of pure native prairie remaining in Ellis County, although two small patches ofremnant native grasses have been identified in the county. The first consists of a small area ofnative meadow grasses mixed with imported flora such as Johnson grass (Sorghum halepense). It is located approximately I mile (I.61 km) east of Interstate Highway 45, near Ferris, on the south side of Route 660 (JJR 1991 ). The second and more extensive area consists of a ca. 30 acre (12.14 ha) tract near Ennis called the Katchina Prairie, which is being re-established as a native prairie preserve (JJR 1991; DOE 1992). In both of these areas, however, the present plant communities probably do not reflect the undisturbed ecosystem. Prior to the cancellation of the SSC project, an ambitious Prairie Restoration Plan had been proposed with its initial focus to be within the upper Baker Branch watershed on the West Campus (DOE 1992:56-58). The introduction of nonnative cultigens, grasses, and weeds, and frequent overgrazing by livestock have all contnbuted to the destruction of the native tall-grass prairie. Moreover, the supression of prairie fires and the placement of barbed wire fences across the prairies have fostered a grid ofhackberry and elm trees along the fence lines. Today elms and hackberries comprise a significant portion oft he arboreal vegetation in wooded areas that were once prairies. Finally, introduced arboreal species such as bois d'arc and mesquite (see Presettlement Flora, above) have become ubiquitous throughout the county. The current distribution of vegetation communities within Ellis County is summarized in Table 1.4. ' Presettlemeot Fauna The SSC project area, as noted above, was dominated by a tall-grass prairie ecosystem which probably began to assume its present configuration ca. 1,000-800 B.P. At that time, fluctuations in the boundaries between adjacent ecological zones probably resulted in the expatriation or reduction of some species and the introduction or increase of others in the immediate region. For example, based on the archaeological evidence, it appears that bison (Bison bison) did not constitute a significant portion of the fauna] population of the Blac1cland Prairie prior to ca. 800-750 B.P. (Huebner 1991 ; Lynott 1979; Thoms 1994). Riparian forests and stream valleys would also have supported a variety of small mammals, game birds, waterfow~ fish and shellfish. At the time of Euro-American settlement oft he SSC project area, the most important native animals of the tallgrass prairies were bison,jack rabbit (Lepus californicus}, and antelope (Antilocapra americana}. White-tailed deer, bear (Ursus americanus}, mountain lion (Fe/is conco/or}, bobcat (Fe/is rufas}, raccoon (Procyon lotor}, cottontail (Sylvilagus jloridanus}, squirrel (Sciurus spp.}, and wild turkey (Meleagris ga//opavo} were present along the wooded fringes of streams and in the forests of the bottomland. The accounts of early settlers record the presence of bison in the SSC project area in some abundance (see Chapter 3), yet over-hunting would eradicate the bison from the environs of Ellis County by about 1850 (Hornaday 1887:549). Human predation and competition for resources also effectively extiipated bear, deer, and wild turkey from the area by the tum of.the century. ## Page 49

General Setting 23 As noted above (see Presettlement Vegetation), the native vegetation communities of Ellis County have been extensively altered due to agriculture, ranching, and urban development, and this disturbance is reflected by the composition of the present-day mammalian faunal suite and by the reduced range of formerly extensive species. For .. instance, the most common "game" animal today in the forested area adjacent to Chambers Creek is reported to be feral hog (Sus scrofa) (Billy Stringer, Soil Conservation Service, personnel communication to D. H. Jurney 1989). Bison and bear have been extirpated, although bison have been reintroduced in the.form ofa few individual animals and at least one small herd maintained by private ranchers in the area. White-tailed deer were also extirpated during the late nineteenth century and have been reintroduced since World War II, although their numbers remain quite low. Wild turkey have also been reestablished in Ellis County, although, again, the range of this species is much reduced from ptesettlement times. Raccoon, opossum (Didelphis virginianus), armadillo (Dasypus novemcinctus), bobcat, and coyote (Canis /atrans) have been perhaps the most successful species in adapting to the modem landscape. So-called recreational and game species of waterfowl.and fish are fairly abundant in present-day Ellis County (]JR 1991), particularly since the construction of reservoirs for flood control and water supply. • ,,

2. PREIDSTORIC BACKGROUND Kevin J. Shaunessy and David H. Jurney INTRODUCTION This chapter summarius previous archaeological investigations in north-central Texas, generally, and Ellis County, specifically. The purpose for the presentation of this data is two-fold: first, it. is intended to provide a regional context for the archaeological investigations conducted in support of the Superconducting Super Collider (SSC); and second, it is from this data that the general prehistoric culture-historical framework (i.e., cultural chronology) for the SSC study area has been developed (see Cultural Chronology, below). When appropriate, extra-regional cultural chronologies are discussed, for comparative purposes. The SSC project area is situated within a geographical and cultural subdivision of Texas commonly referred to as north-central Texas. While the term ''north-central Texas" is commonly used in archaeological literature, definitions of exactly what constitutes north-central Texas vary greatly (cf. Lynott 1977; Story 1990b). We have chosen a fairly circumscribed area (i.e., definition), which for the most part, is located within what has.recently been defined as the Prairie-SavannaArcheological Study Region of the Eastern Planning Region ofTexas (K.enmotsu and Perttula 1993). We have, however, included the western portions of Van Zandt and Henderson counties, which are drained by the Trinity River and are not included in the Prairie-Savanna Archeological Study Region, into our definition (Figure 2.1 ). Thus, as herein defined, north-central Texas consists of a limited portion of the middle Brazos River drainage, the middle Trinity River drainage, and a portion of the upper Trinity River drainage (Figure 2.2) and encompasses 19 counties, in whole or in part. This area corresponds, in part, to the north-central section of the Gulf Coastal Plain study unit as defined by Story (1990b:357), although we have omitted the Red River drainage and south-central Oklahoma from the present review. Tue choice of specific areas to include in the following review was not an arbitrary one, nor was it governed solely by the criterion of geographic proximity to Ellis County and the SSC project area. As was discussed in Chapter 1, Ellis County is situated within a broad natural ecotone which essentially constitutes a transitional zone from the deciduous forests of the east to the grasslands of the west Tue same area, with Ellis County situated at its center, may be said also to represent a cultural ecotone which essentially constitutes a transitional zone evidencing cultural influences from the surrounding areas. It was with this concept in mind that the following review was structured. Much of the following discussion of previous investigations has been summariz.ed from data provided in recent synthetic work$ by Guy ( 1990) and Prikryl (1990). PREVIOUS INVESTIGATIONS Previous Archaeological Investigations Within North-Central Texas The earliest investigations of prehistoric phenomemrwithin north-central Texas apparently consisted of the fossil collecting activities of Jacob Boll ofD.allas. 28 Shaunessy and Jurney reconnaissance surveys which tl?,Ok place along its fringes in Grayson, Henderson, Kaufman, McLennan, Navarro, and Van Zandt counties between 1919 and 1935 as well as several site testing programs in Henderson and Van Zandt counties between 1930 and 1935. All of this work was conducted by the University of Texas under the overall direction of J. E. Pierce. Investigations conducted by avocational archaeologists in the 1920s and early 1930s provided most of the data collected within north-central Texas during this early period. Notable among the early workers along the upper Trinity River was R. K. Harris (1936, 1939, 1940), who was instrumental in the fonnation of the Dallas Archeological Society (DAS). Harris's counterpart on the Brazos River was Frank Bryan, a geologist from Waco who recorded many archaeological sites in Hill, Navarro, and McLennan counties and who developed one of the earliest projectile point typologies for the region (Bryan 1930, 1931, 1937). Bryan, together with Frank Watt and other avocational archaeologists working along the middle Brazos River, founded the Central Texas Archeological Society (CTAS) in 1934. Research conducted by avocational archaeologists within north-central Texas continued to be of paramount importance throughout the pre-World War Il years. Within the middle Braros River drainage, investigations conducted by CTAS members included surveys (Bryan 1936, 1937), comparative artifact studies (Watt 1939; Watt and Meroney 1938a), and testing of such sites as Chupek (41MIA4 [McLennan County]) (Watt 1941, 1953) and an unnamed prehistoric cemetery (Lux 1938; Meroney 1936; Turner 1938; and Watt and Meroney 1938b). An important result of the investigations at Chupek was the recovery of a number of Caddoan or Caddoan-like (see Cultural Chronology, below) ceramic sherds, which led Newell and Krieger (1949: 196) to list the Chupek Site as the most westerly component of the Caddoan Alto focus. Within the upper Trinity River drainage, DAS members conducted an extensive archaeological survey in the early 1940s that resulted in the recordation of 179 sites in Dallas County. This survey also included work in adjacent counties along the East Fork and Elm Fork of the Trinity River as well as the main stem of the Trinity River. Surface collections and test excavations at many of these sites were descn'bed in the DAS newsletter,- ™ Record (see primary sources cited by Prikryl (1990:21-22]). - Although major archaeological investigations elsewhere in Texas were funded by the Works Progress Administration (WPA) from 1936 to 1941, no WPA-sponsored work was conducted in north-central Texas, apart from some investigations along its easternmost fringes in Van Zandt and Henderson counties (Guy 1990:41). These latter investigations included work at the Malakoff Site (41HE60 [HEnderson County]) where carved stone heads of apparent Pleistocene age were recovered from a gravel pit in a terrace above Cedar Creek (Sellards 1930, 1941). This early candidate for a Pre-Clovis or Pre-Projectile Point stage (Krieger 1964) occupation in north-central Texas is discussed further in Cultural Chronology, below. By the late 1940s, DAS members had published trait lists for sites along the East Fork of the Trinity River, but, as yet, had provided no chronological framework for the region (Harris 1948a, 1948b; Housewright et al. 1948; Harris and Hatzenbuehler 1948; all cited in Prikryl 1990:22). The first major chronological framework for northern Texas was published by Krieger (1946). Since much of Krieger's synthesis depended on data collected as a result of WPA sponsored investigations, which were lacking for north-central Texas (see above), his brief discussion of the upper Trinity River drainage drew heavily on the work ofR. K. Harris. Krieger (1946:135) noted the presence of two ceramic culture complexes within the upper Trinity River drainage, one with western affiliations and the other related to northeast Texas Caddo, a distinction previously made by Harris (1936). Krieger (1946:135) equated the complex with western affiliations to his newly-defined Henrietta focus (see Cultural Chronology, below). Despite the importance of this seminal work, it largely dealt with areas outside of th~ present area of consideration. Large-scale professional archaeological investigations in north-central Texas essentially began with the postwar boom in reservoir construction (see Figure 22). Surveys were conducted by the Austin office of the Smithsonian Institution River Basin Surveys (RBS) within the Brazos River drainage at Lake Whitney (Stephenson 1947, 1949a, 1970), and within the Trinity River drainage at Benbrook Reservoir (Stephenson 1949b), Lake Grapevine (Stephenson 1948), Gaaa-Little Elm Reservoir(Lake Lewisville) (Stephenson 1949c,1950a), and Lake Lavon (Stephenson 1949c, 1949d, 1949e). In both drainages, Stephenson made extensive use of the previous research of members of the CTAS and DAS. As a result of the Lake Whitney survey, important exc~ avations were conducted at the Stansbury Site (41Hl9 [HIii County]), a historic Wichita village, as well as at both open sites and rocksbelters which contained stratified Archaic through Late Prehistoric (see Cultural Chronology, below) deposits. The rockshelters appeared to have been more heavily utilized in the Late Prehistoric and small quantities of Caddoan ceramics were recovered (Stephenson 1970).

Subsequent investigations included excavations at the Ham Creek Site (41JN2 [JohNson County]) by members of the Tarrant County Archeological Society (TCAS) (Forrester 1964). Forrester concluded that the cultural affiliations of this Archaic s_ite lay more to the south in central Texas than with north-central or east Texas. Prikryl and Jackson (1985: 18) suggest that ''the opposite is true. .. Members of the TCAS and DAS also participated in the re-excavation of three rockshelters previously investigated by Stephenson (41HI54, 4llll22, and 41H123) (Long 1961). Finally, the Texas Archeological Salvage Project (TASP) conducted excavations at the Kyle Site (41Hll), a stratifi_ed rockshelter which, together with the Blum Rockshelter, provided definitive stratigraphic evidence for the temporal separation of the Austin and Toyah foci of the Central Texas aspect (Jelks 1962) (see Cultural Chronology, below). Other investigations which took place within the middle Brazos River drainage in the years following Stephenson's survey of Lake Whitney included a survey conducted by TASP as a result of the enlargement of Waco Lake (Duffield 1959). Many of the sites recorded by Duffield had previously been identified by members of the CTAS (Guy 1990:66). Duffield concluded that surface collections from many of the sites at Waco Lake indicated closer cultural affiliations with north-central Texas than with central Texas during the Archaic period (Duffield 1959:16, cited in Prikryl and Jackson 1985:20). TASP also conducted test excavations at the deeply stratified Baylor (41ML35) and Britton (41ML37) sites (Story and Shafer 1965). CTAS investigations in the area continued and test excavations were conducted at the Asa Warner Site (41ML46) (Watt 1956), the Clark Site (41ML39) (Watt 1965), the Ballew Site (41HI68) (Watt and Agogino 1968), the Waco Indian Village (41ML95) (Watt 1969), and the Lookout Point Site (41ML33) (Watt 1968). On the western periphery of north-central Texas, a survey of the Lake Granbury area (formerly the De Cordova Bend Reservoir) in Hood County identified 51 prehistoric sites which spanned the time from the late Paleo-Indian through the Archaic and into Neo-American (Skinner 1971; see Cultural Chronology, below). Cultural affiliations of these sites appeared to lie to the west and south in central Texas, rather than with north-central Texas. • The surveys conducted by Stephenson for the RBS in the upper Trinity River drainage (noted above) produced mixed results. No archaeological sites were identified at Benbrook Lake in Tarrant County and only 10 sites of apparently short-term occupation were recorded at Grapevine Lake in Denton and Tarrant counties. No further investigations were recommended at either reservoir (Stephenson 1948, 1949b). Twenty-five sites, however, were recorded as a result of the survey conducted at Lake Lavon in Collin County (Stephenson 1949c, 1949d). Eight sites were tested with the assistance of DAS members during both the initial survey and subsequent intensive investigations. These included the Hogge Bridge Site (41COL1 [COLiin County]) (Stephenson 1949c, 1949d, 1949e,1952a, 1952b), the Campbell Hole Site (41COL10) (Stephenson 1949c, 1949d; Marmaduke 1975), and the Branch Site (41COL9) (Marmaduke 1975). Based on the results of both the investigations at Lake Lavon as well as previous DAS investigations along the East Fork of the Trinity River ( e.g., Housewright et al. 1947 ; Wilson 1946), a Late Prehistoric cultural complex termed the Wylie focus was defined by Stephenson (1952a). Among its supposedly diagnostic traits was the presence of large circular pits with built up rims. Stephenson's (1949c, 1950a) survey at Lake Lewisville (formerly Gana-Little Elm Reservoir) in Denton County recorded 27 sites, again with considerable assistance from th~ DAS. Seven sites were recommended for further work. Stephenson subsequently tested three of these sites (the Ledbetter Site [41DN5 {DeNton County}], the Lake Dallas Site [41DN6], and the Bob Pierce Site [41DN12]), but never published an account of this work (Prikryl 1990:24). The archaeological survey of Lake Lewisville was later augmented by a paleontological survey of the proposed reservoir (White 1952). , In the same year that Stephenson defined the Wylie focus to.characterize ceramic period sites along the East Fork (see above), Crook and Harris (1952) defined the Trinity aspect of the Archaic stage, based on data collected from non ceramic sites along the Elm Fork and the upper main stem of the Trinity River. The Trinity aspect was subdivided into an early (Carrollton) focus and a late (Elam) focus. These two publications together provided the first formal cultural chronological :framework for the Upper Trinity River Basin (see Cultural Chronology, below). · · Numerous archaeological investigations undertaken hy members of the DAS in the upper Trinity River drainage were published throughout the 1950s and 1960s (see summary discussions in McGregor [1988a:29] and Prilayl [1990:24-29)). The most highly publicized {and certainly the most contr9versial) of these investigations was the excavations at the Lewisville Site (4IJ?N72) on the Elm Fork of the Trinity River. The site was originally discovered during White's (1952) paleontological survey of the Lake Lewisville area on an alluvial terrace above the Elm Fork of the Trinity River. The site was exposed following the excavation of a deep borrow pit for fill to be used in construction of the Lake Lewisville dam. 30 Shaunessy and Jurney members over a period of six years led to the eventual identification of21 burned clay hearths, an extensive "Upper Pleistocene" faunal assemblage (much ofit found burned within the hearths), and a small number oflithic artifacts. The latter included a Clovis-type projectile point which was recovered, apparently in situ, from Hearth 1. Most importantly, radiocarbon dates of"more than 37,000 years old" were obtained from the site, one ·of them from charred material in close association to the Clovis projectile point in Hearth 1 (Crook and Harris 1956, 1957, 1958). The site continued to be a source of controversy (e.g., Heizer and Brooks 1965; Heizer 1974) following its inundation by the rising level of Lake Lewisville since the radiocarbon dates indicated a human presence in the area that was far more ancient than that generally accepted for Clovis populations (see Cultural Chronology, below). Additional investigations took place in 1979 and 1980, during a drought which re-exposed the site, and are described below. Important investigations also took place on the East Fork oft he Trinity River within the ooundaries of present-day Lake Ray Hubbard (formerly Forney Reservoir). The TASP, in association with the DAS, conducted a survey of the area which recorded 33 sites, many ofw hich had previouslJc.been collected or tested by DAS members (Harris and Suhm 1963). Archaic through Late Prehistoric occupations were identified. The TASP conducted excavations at the Upper Rockwall (41RW2 [Rockwall County]) and Glen Hill (41RW4) sites (Ross 1966), and SMU excavated the Lower Rockwall Site (41RW1) (Lorrain.and Hoffiichter-1968). These investigations were noteworthy in that they raised doubts about the validity of the Wylie focus as a culture-historical construct (Bruseth and Martin 1987:268). The TASP was also active in the upper middle Trinity River drainage at this time. The TASP conducted a survey of Joe B. Hogsett Lake (formerly Cedar Creek Reservoir) in Kaufman and Henderson counties and recorded 30 sites (Davis 1961). Three sites were subsequently excavated by Story (1965). Archaic through Late Prehistoric components were identified at the Lacy Site (41HE70), the Gossett Bottoms Site (41KF7 [Kaufman County]), and the Wild Bull Site (41HE61). Additionally, a Paleo-Indian component was tentatively identified at the latter site. A survey was also conducted by the TASP in the Navarro Mills Reservoir, Navarro County (Duffield 1960), which is located only ca. 38.14 km (23.7 miles) to the south ofthe·ssc project area. Subsequent excavations were limited to a small midden at the Strawn Creek Site (41NV6 [NaVarro County]) which contained mixed Archaic and Late Ptehistoric deposits. (Duffield 1963). Finally, the first systematic archaeological investigations to talce place within Ellis County itself occurred. This work consisted of the 1963 TASP survey conducted prior to the construction of Bardwell Lake (Shafer 1964) and is described separately below. The late 1960s and early 1970s saw the enactment of a number of pieces of environmental and historic preservation legislation that resulted in a greatly increased volume of archaeological work in north-central Texas as elsewhere. "Cultural resource management'' (CRM) investigations began to be required under the new state and federal laws and continue to be a major methodological focus of many ·archaeological projects today. CRM projects have tended to place a greater emphasis on survey and testing or "cultural resource inventory and assessment," in contrast to earlier projects (Gqy 1990:87). As a result of this shift in emphasis, several broad-based overviews of the archaeological resources known within the Trinity River Basin were published in the 1970s (e.g., Sciscenti 1972; Richner and Bagot 1978). These investigations included the first systematic characteriz.ations and assessments of historic cultural resources within north-central Texas, and historic research began to be routinely included in CRM reports. Other important methodological developments noted by Guy (1990:88) were the increasing use of the interdisciplinary approach and the collection ofpaleoecological data. Early examples of large-scale applications of this approach within north-central Texas include the work conducted by the Archaeology Research Program (ARP) ofSMU at Lakeview Lake, later renamed Joe Pool Lake, (Archaeology Research Program [ARP] 1982a) and Richland Creek Reservoir (ARP 1982b) , two important projects which essentially "bracket'' the SSC project area. Due io the dramatic increase in the sheer numbers of archaeological investigations in the 1970s and 1980s, only a brief summary of the more important projects in north-central Texas is provided below. More detailed summaries may be found in Guy (1990:87- 125) and Prikryl (1990:29-38). Many of the archaeological investigations within north-central Texas at this time continued to be performed in response to the construction or enlargement of reservoirs. · For instance, within the middle Brazos River drainage the ARP began additional investigations of prehistoric sites at Lake Whitney in Bosque and Hill counties in response to plans to raise the level of the lake (Skinner and Harris 1971; Skinner and Gallagher 1974). An archaeological survey of the Squaw Creek Reservoir in Hood and Somerville counties resulted in the identification of27 sites (Skinner and Humphreys 1973). Extensive investigations were conducted at Aquilla Lake in central Hill County, beginning with a survey undertaken by the ARP in 1972 (Skinner and Henderson 1972). This survey was followed by subsurface testing programs in 1975 (Lynott and Peter 1977), 1977 (Skinner at al. 1978), and 1978 (Brown 1987). The subsequent

• Prehistoric Background 31 mitigation of significant sites in the Aquilla Lake project area was undertaken by TAS (formerly TASP) (Brown 1987). The ARP conducted an archaeological survey of Hog Creek in Coryell and Bosque counties (Larson et al. 1975) and subsequently conducted test excavations at two sites, both rockshelters (Larson and Kirby 1976). In 1976, the Texas Historical Commission (TIIC) surveyed the Tehuacana Creek drainage in McLennan and Hill counties (Mallouf 1981; Mallouf and Baskin 1976). Additional work was also conducted at Waco Lake in McLennan County in response to plans to raise the conservation pool there (Collins and Holliday 1985; Prikryl and Jackson.1985; Prikryl and Prewitt 1984). Along the Elm Fork of the Trinity River a preliminary reconnaissance survey was conducted by SMU within a portion of present-day Lake Ray Roberts (formerly Aubrey Reservoir) in Grayson, Cooke, and Denton counties which . identified one historic and 25 prehistoric sites (Bousman and Verrett 1973). A more intensive survey was subsequently conducted for the entire proposed reservoir which resulted in the identification of only 117 sites with prehistoric components out of a total of 355 recoi:ded sites (Cliff et al. 1982). Further testing was performed at 19 prehistoric sites and six of the tested sites underwent additional excavations (Baird et al. 1982; Skinner and Baird 1985). The authors concluded that the upper Elm Fork of the Trinity River, relative to nearby areas such as the lower Elm Fork and the East Fork of the Trinity River, represented a marginal territory. It was further hypothesized that the prehistoric occupation of the Lake Ray Roberts area was seasonal and occurred in the fall for the-purpose of gathering mast resources which would have been found in some abundance within the Eastern Cross Timbers (Skinner and Baird 1985). An important geoarchaeological reconnaissance of the upper Trinity River Basin was conducted by Ferring for the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers in 1985 (Yates and Ferring 1986). Portions of the Elm Fork of the Trinity River, Denton Creek, the West Fork of the Trinity River, and the main Trinity River channel were investigated. Ferring (1986) argued that deep alluvial deposits within the floodplains represented areas of high potential for the preservation of prehistoric sites. He identified a buried soil horizon, termed the West Fork paleosol, for which a radiocarbon date of 1510±100 B.P. (Beta-14904) was obtained. The paleosol was identified at localities on both the West.Fork and Elm Fork of the Trinity River. In fact, it was this data, on the potential for deeply buried floodplain sites, which was utilized in the development of the deep testing strategy proposed as part of the research design foe the SSC project area (see Chapter 4). Subsequent investigations in the Lake Ray Roberts area included the excavation of 41CO141 (COoke County), a stratified prehistoric site where a Late Archaic component was identified in the lower part of the West Fork paleosol (Prikryl and Yates 1987). Recently, an important site was discovered on the Elm Fork of the Trinity River floodplain below the Lake Ray Roberts dam. The Aubrey Clovis Site (41DN479) is a Paleo-Indian campsite which is situated in stratified Late Pleistocene sediments 7 to 8 m (23 to 2§25 ft) below the present surface of the floodplain _(Ferring 1989:10). . Apparent Clovis-age lithic artifacts and well-preserved faunal remains haye been recovered, but a final report for this site has not yet been published. . Investigations continued on the lower Elm Fork of the Trinity River as well. As a result of a proposed enlargement of.Lake Lewisville, additional areas were surveyed and 60 sites were recorded. Thirty-four of these sites were recommended for some further level of assessment (Nunley 1973:65). In 1979 and 1980, during a drought which re exposed the Lewisville Site (4 1 DN72; see above), the Smithsonian Institution conducted further excavations. Although no diagnostic artifacts were recovered, it was demonstrated that the "charred material" previously used to date the site was in fact lignitic coal rather than charcoal and the previously claimed early date of>37,000 B.P. for the site was discounted (Stanford 1982, 1983; Schiley et al. 1985). An additional survey of the Lake Lewisville shoreline, which represented the most intensive survey effort in this area to date, was undertaken by the University ofNorth Texas (UN1) in 1986 and 1987 in response to plans to raise the level of the lake (Lebo and Brown 1990). Twenty-three prehistoric and 16 historic sites were subsequently tested. As a result of the testing program, five prehistoric and three historic sites were recommended for additional work (Brown and Lebo 1991). Finally, a recent work by Prikryl (1990) provides an excellent synthetic discussion of previous investigations within both the Elm Fork and East Fork of the Trinity River drainages. More importantly, PJjlayl has redefined certain long-held culture-historical concepts regarding the archaeological record of the lower Elm Fork of the Trinity River (see Cultural Chronology, below). Along the East Fork of the Trinity River, additional investigations were undertaken at Lake Lavon by SMU as a result of the enlargement of the reservoir. Excavations were conducted at several sites including the McGuire Site • (41COL26) and the Dugger Mound/Upper Farmersville Site (41COL34). Both Archaic and Late Prehistoric components were identified at these sites and a Wylie focus pit was partially excavated at Dugger Mound (Dawson and Sullivan 1973). 32 Shaunessy and Jurney (Lynott 1975a: 129). He also perfonned controlled surface collections and limited testing at the nearby Sister Ridge Site (41COL58) (Lynott 1975a). Based on the results of the excavations at Sister Grove Creek, he proposed that the Wylie focus pits "represent open air feasting centers where ritual feasts were conducted by the entire community, or at least large segments of the community. The pit also served as a burial area for high status individuals, or individuals who were linked to the pit structures and the ritual feasts" (Lynott 1975a:39). No further investigations of Wylie focus sites were conducted until the extensive investigations of the Richland Creek Archaeological project in the middle Trinity River drainage (see below). Mention should be made here of the paucity of infonnation that is available regarding prehistoric utili7.ation of the western portion of the upper Trinity River drainage. As noted above, Stephenson (1948) identified only l O sites of apparently short-term occupation at Grapevine Lake in the lower portion of the Denton Creek drainage. Years later, a subsequent survey at Grapevine Lake conducted by SMU identified o~y two sites (Ferring 1975). The archaeology of the West Fork of the Trinity River drainage is also very poorly known. Stephenson (1949b) failed to identify a single.._ site in his survey ofBenbrook Reservoir in Tarrant County. Few systematic investigations within the West Fork of the Trinity River drainage, either avocational or professional, have been undertaken since (Douglass et al. 1986: 134; Lynott 1977:89-92, 1981:107). Notable exceptions include the work by Prikryl (1990) and Whitsett and Fox (1979, 1980) along Big Bear Creek in Tarrant County. Test excavations were conducted by members of the TCAS at 41TR56 (:TaRrant County), which contained both Archaic and Late Prehistoric components, and which was subsequently inundated by Lake Arlington (Johnson 1956, cited in Prikryl 1990:27). Two small CRM projects have recently recovered in situ buried cultural material in apparent association with Ferring's (1986) West Fork paleosol (Peter 1987; Shaunessy et al. 1994). The most impOrtant investigations within the western portion of the upper Trinity River drainage, however, are those which were recently conducted within the Mountain Creek watershed, a subsidiary drainage of the West Fork of the Trinity River, at Joe Pool Lake (Peter and McGregor [editors] 1988). The Joe Pool Lake investigations are discussed below. Important investigations were conducted by SMU from 1974 to 1977 in the middle Trinity River drainage for the proposed Tennessee Colony Reservoir (Richner 1982; Richner and Lee 1976, 1977). The proposed reservoir was to impact portions of Navarro, Freestone, Henderson, and Anderson counties. The survey recorded a total of 326 prehistoric and historic sites and limited testing was conducted at 14 of the prehistoric sites. Paleo-Indian through Late Prehistoric components were identified. The Tennessee Colony project was subsequently canceled but a portion of the project area was later included in the Richland Creek Archaeological project (see below). Other research in the middle Trinity River drainage at this time included the investigations by SMU along the eastern periphery of the Trinity River drainage in Henderson and Van Zandt counties. More than 80 prehistoric and historic sites were recorded with several of the prehistoric sites subsequently tested. Archaic and Caddoan components were identified (Guderjan 1981). In the 1980s, two important sets of intensive investigations which essentially bracket Ellis County and the SSC project area were undertaken by SMU. The first, which took place from 1980 to 1984, consisted of extensive prehistoric and historic archaeological investigations within the Richland/Chambers Reservoir (Richland Creek), located ca. 48.28 km (30 miles) south of the SSC project area in the middle Trinity River drainage in Navarro and Freestone counties. A portion of this reservoir had been included in the previously proposed Tennessee Colony Lake project area (see above). Within the ca.19, 222.54 ha (47,500 acre) Richland Creek project area, 234 prehistoric sites, 213 prehistoric localities, and 463 historic sites were recorded (Bruseth 1987:3). Of the prehistoric sites, 43 subsequently received some fonn of testing {ARP 1982b:27) and extensive data recovery programs were conducted at 15 of them {Bruseth 1987:3-5; Bruseth and Martin [editors] 1987; McGregor and Bruseth [editors] 1987). ' Relatively little evidence was found within the Richland Creek project area for Paleo-Indian or Early Archaic \ occupations apart from those identified from surface collections and mixed subsurface contexts (Bruseth, McGregor, and Martin 1987:233). Occupational evidence from the succeeding Middle and Late Archaic and Late Prehistoric was relatively more abundant Indeed, as a result of the Richland Creek investigations, Bruseth, McGregor, and Martin (1987:240-247, 255-256) proposed a refined chronology for the project area wherein the Late Prehistoric was subdivided into three distinct phases (see Cultural Chronology, below). A number of culture-historical and processual hypotheses were developed following the survey and testing phases of the Richland Creek project (Raab and Moir-1982) which were refined during the subsequent mitigation phase. Obviously, a complete review of the ·results of this intensive project is beyond the scope of this report, yet a brief mention of one hypothesis and its implications is relevant to the present regional overview.

Archaic stage sites in the Project area can be subsumed taxonomically within the Carrollton and Elam foci of the Trinity aspect. and the Late Prehistoric period sites within the Wylie focus ofNorth Central Texas [rather than within the La Harpe aspect to the east, and the Gibson and Fulton aspects (Caddo) to the east . and north, respectively) [McGregor 1987a:16; Raab and Moir 1982:203]. · McGregor and Braseth (1987) evaluate the part of the hypothesis which pertains to the Archaic. They note the area difficulties in making comparisons between the Richland Creek project and the upper Trinity River drainage, as the Archaic is still insufficiently documented in both areas. They also note questions which had been raised by other researchers (e.g., Hofinan 1978:312; Richner and Bagot 1978:52) regarding the stratigraphic and contextual integrity of Trinity aspect sites, particularly with regard to the earlier Carrollton focus. They conclude that ''there seem to be few specific similarities in artifact traits between sites of the Carrollton and Elam foci and the Archaic sites in the [Richland Creek] project area. Shared traits are also common to Archaic perio4.sites in other regions. If cultural ties are to be defined on the basis of artifact similarities, then the [Richland Creek] j>roject area Archaic shows closest affinities to the La Harpe aspect of central East Texas" (McGregor and Braseth 1987:184). Extensive field effort and subsequent multidisciplinary analytical studies were devoted to the investigation of Wylie focus pits identified in the Richland Creek project area. Braseth and Martin (1987a) summarize the work conducted on so-called Wylie focus sites since Stephenson.( 1952a) first proposed the Wylie focus as a culture-historical · construct (see above). They compare the East Fork sites to four sites within the Richland Creek drainage where large pit features were identified. The latter sites consisted of the Adams Ranch Site (41NV177), the Bird Point Island Site as (41FT201 [FreesTone County]), and the Irvine Site (41NV182), all of which were investigated part of the Richland Creek project; and the Strawn Creek Site (4 1 NV6), which had previously been tested by the TASP ·(Duffield 1963). It was concluded that " ...t he concept of the Wylie focus is obsolete and should no longer be used for the classification of sites in North Central Texas. The complex of identifymg traits associated with the Wylie focus, as defined by • Stephenson (1952a), is very broad and mixes artifact types that are now known to represent both Archaic and Late Prehistoric occupations ... As a result, its usefulness as a classificatory tool is dubious" (Braseth and Martin 1987:284). These conclusions are further discussed in the following section (see Cultural Chronology, below). The second set of investigations which are most relevant to the SSC project area were undertaken by SMU at Joe Pool Lake (formerly Lakeview Lake) in Tarrant, Dallas, and Ellis counties. Within this ca. 5,058.56 ha (12,500 acre) project area, 17 prehistoric and 25 historic sites were recorded (Skinner and Connors 1979). Of the prehistoric sites, 16 were subsequently tested (ARP 1982a). As a result of the testing program, extensive data recovery programs were conducted at six of the sites from 1984 to 1986 (Peter and McGregor [editors] 1988). Joe Pool Lake impounds a tri-county portion of the Mountain Creek drainage, which is a southern tributary drainage of the West Fork of the Trinity River. The southernmost portion of the project area extends into northwestern Ellis County (see Figure 1.12). Only one site, 4 IEL29 (ELiis County), was identified in Ellis County as a result of the_ -initial archaeological survey for Joe Pool Lake (Skinner and Connors 1979:46). The combined survey and testing phases at this site recovered four flakes, one biface, one retouched flake, one dart point fragment, and several hematite fragments. All were recovered from surface contexts, despite the emplacement of a 1 m x I m (3.28 ft x 3.28 ft) test unit and a backhoe trench. This led Raab et al. (1982:38) to suggest-that "it is most probable that the artifacts are being washed in from the terrace area to the south." Permission to examine this terrace area was denied by the landowner. A tentative Archaic occupation was ascribed to the site on the basis of the fragmentary dart point and no further work was recommended. · The initial survey of the Joe Pool Lake project area identified not only a low number of sites, but also low densities of artifacts within sites, relative to other areas within the upper Trinity River basin such as the Elm and East forks. Archaic sites tended to be located upstream, whereas the later Neo-American (Late Prehistoric) sites were located downstream. Skinner and Connors (1979:49-53) tentatively suggested that the Joe Pool Lake area represented what had been, prehistorically, a marginal territory which lacked a resident population. The earlier materials recovered by them suggested that Archaic intrusions were from the central Brazos River region to the west, based primarily on the high percentage of chert, as opposed to _quartizite, in the flaked stone artifact assemblage. Conversely, the Neo-American (Late Prehistoric) material indicated an intrusion of Gibson aspect populations from the Caddoan area of east Texas. • The subsequent intensive investigations carried out by SMU from 1984 to 1986 (Peter and McGregor [editors) 1988) involved the excavation of six sites. Primarily Late Archaic material was recovered from sites 41 DL 189 (DaLlas County), 41DL184, and 4IDL199. Late Prehistoric occupations were chiefly represented at the Cobb-Pool Site

Although these investigations supported the thesis that prehistoric use of the Mountain Creek drainage had never been very intensive, they did result in some revisions to the original interpretations of prehistoric utilization of the area. Peter and McGregor (1988a:363) concluded that "Skinner and Connors (1979) were right about the westward orientation of the Archaic inhabitants of the Mountain Creek basin; however, their portrayal of the Archaic inhabitants as intrusive from the Brazos River drainage is probably inaccurate. A resident population of the West Fork of the Trinity River drainage most likely used the Mountain Creek valley during their seasonal rounds." Indeed, they further note that, based on the results of a lithic source survey conducted as part of their investigations, "throughout [a ll] the time periods represented by the Joe Pool Lake sites, the prehistoric inhabitants appear to have favored the exploitation of the gravel sources along the Trinity/Brazos divide, even though usable quartzites were available from closer sources located to the north" (Peter and McGregor 1988b:281). The investigations of Late Prehistoric components at Joe Pool Lake, particularly at the Cobb-Pool and Baggett Branch sites, led to the definition of three temporal subdivisions of the Late Prehistoric which reflected changes in both material culture and subsistence practices (see Cultural Chronology, below). Significanf changes in· subsistence strategies were documented at the Cobb-Pool Site where the earlier hunting and gathering lifeway began to give way to a sedentary or semi-sedentary lifeway supported, at least in part, by the introduction ofm aize horticulture around AD. 1100-1300. Three structures as well as associated features were identified at the Cobb-Pool Site from this time period, and the macrobotanical remains recovered were overwhelmingly dominated by maize. It was suggested that "the selection of[the Cobb-Pool] site location was determined by access to arable land suitable for maize agriculture, rather than by access to the natural resources oft he forest and river" (Martin 1988:348). Another shift in subsistence strategies was indicated around AD. 1500 at the Baggett Branch Site, which was the only site investigated where the recovered faunal assemblage included significant numbers of bison elements. Interestingly, only very limited amounts of maize were recovered. The following interpretation of the Baggett Branch data was offered: This shift in the utilization of natural resources parallels a regional climatic trend toward drier conditions. Therefore, it seems that bison first became available along Mountain Creek in sufficient numbers to contribute significantly to the diet during the latter part of the Late Prehistoric period. .. The evidence from Baggett Branch indicates that maize may have been less significant in the diet than it was during the occupation of Cobb-Pool. It is possible that the drier conditions associated with the arrival of bison made maize agriculture less reliable. However, it is also possible that the bison remains at the site reflect a short-term processing episode and that the major occupation occurred at another location. Under these circumstances, maize may not have been taken to the site in quantities representative of its true importance. No firm conclusions can be made concerning the utiliz.ation of maize during the latter portion of the Late Prehistoric period on the basis of the Joe Pool Lake data [Martin 1988:349). Peter and McGregor (1988a) discuss the possible origins of the populations who are responsible for the chang~ in subsistence strategies and material cultural remains at Joe Pool Lake during the middle and late phases of the Late Prehistoric. They suggest that, despite the apparent abruptness of the appearance of Caddoan-like house structures, ceramic motifs, and maize horticulture at the Cobb-Pool Site, these similarities are too generalized to indicate more than an indirect east Texas Caddoan influence. They also note (as discussed above), the continuing predominance of chert in the flaked stone artifact assemblage, which indicates that the Late Prehistoric inhabitants utilized the same western lithic raw material sources as their Archaic predecessors. They argue that "an intrusive Caddoan group would have brought more quartzite tools with them and would have utiliz.ed the quartzite sources along the Trinity River drainage" -(Peter and McGregor 1988a:366). Finally, they suggest that middle phase Late Prehistoric sites such as Cobb-Pool at Joe Pool Lake and Bird Point Island in the middle Trinity River drainage (see above) represent «a series oflocal adaptations to the regional environments" (Peter and McGregor 1988a:366). These adaptations were likely brought about by a number of factors which included population pressure and increasingly dry climatic conditions. Peter and McGregor (l 988a:367) also note several lines of evidence, notably from the Baggett Branch data set, which suggest that in the latest phase·o f the Late Prehistoric occupation there were increasing Southern Plains influences from the north and west on the inhabitants of the Joe Pool Lake area. They cite the apparent increased emphasis on bison hunting, the presence of steeply chipped "Plains" style "endscrapers," and the apparent predominance of shell tempered ceramics. The ceramic wares are similar to the Nocona Plain type of the Henrietta focus sites to the west and

Previous Archaeological Investigations Within Ellis County As was the case with north-central Texas, the earliest investigations of prehistoric phenomena within Ellis County were, apparently, paleontological, rather than archaeological. Green (1970) records that Judge 0. E. Dunlap (see Chapter 3), a prominent local citizen whose many passions included an avid (if somewhat amateurish) interest in natural science, identified a mastodon tooth during the excavation of bridge pilings along Waxahachie Creek, iri Waxahachie, in 1912. This was when I had taken the job with Stone and Webster Construction Co... We had to dig down twenty feet for a bridge tier. When we had reached ten feet I dug up a rock that looked like it was polished. It weight [sic] about ten pounds. I had planned to take it home with me. While I was holding it looking at it a man called to me who was a bystander, which there were many just viewing the work. He said: Let me see that rock. Send it up. I look up to see who he was. He was a big man with a mustach [sic], look much like President Taft [i.e., Judge Dunlap]. He was taller than the president I climb the ladder and handed it to him. He looked at it for a moment, then said to me: You have dug up a mastodon tooth that is at least a million years old. I will put it in the Sims library. Thank you, my boy. .. People gathered around him as he explained to them fossil history. I went back to work [Green 1970:156]. Unfortunately, an examination of the Judge Dunlap collections at the Sims Library in Waxahachie failed to identify this • fossil. Still, the presence of deeply buried Pleistocene fauna! remains within the SSC project area remains an interesting, if unexplored, possibility. During the early days of the DAS investigations in the upper Trinity River drainage (described.above), little effort was apparently expended within Ellis County, although Thomas Gwin did record several prehistoric sites in the northwest portion of the county in 1940 (Texas Archeological Research Laboratory [TARL] files). These sites, however, did not receive official state trinomial designations until much later (Table 2.1), following the TASP survey of Bardwell Lake (see below). Prior to the TASP survey, only a single site had been officially recorded in Ellis County (see Table 2.1, 41EL1). This was the Bristol Site, recorded in 1955, which apparently consisted of a midden deposit containing material ranging from "late archaic through pottery stages" (TARL files). Unfortunately, the same trinomial designation was later assigned to the Trinity City Site, an abandoned mid nineteenth century Anglo American settlement (Richner and Bagot 1978). Further confusing the issue was the fact that both 41EL1 sites [see Table 2.1, 41EL1 and 41ELI(b)] were located at the confluence of Red Oak Creek and the Trinity River (TARL files). Several avocational archaeologists had recovered artifacts and information from prehistoric sites within Ellis County prior to the TASP survey. C. K. Chandler, a former resident of Ennis and now a Texas Arcbeological Steward residing in San Antonio, recorded a number of prehistoric sites in southern Ellis County (TARL files). He made extensive collections, provenienced at least to the site level, during the course of more than a decade of informal survey at a many of these sites. A portion of these collections have recently been analyzed by Tomka et al: (1996) and the data are presented in Appendix A. Portions of three other private collections made by Charles Barton in th~ Maypearl area in western Ellis County and by both Charles Oates and Edwin Lott from die Bardwell Lake area have also recently been analyzed by Prewitt (1991). These data are presented in Appendix B. The first systematic archaeological investigations to take place within Ellis County consisted of the 1963 TASP survey conducted prior to the construction of Bardwell Lake (Shafer 1964). The survey identified 15 -sites (see Table 2.1, 41 EL2-4 l EL 16), nine of whicti were undifferentiated prehistoric sites with light scatters of lithic debitage. Of the remaining six sites three contained Archaic materials and three contained Archaic and Neo-American (Late Prehistoric) materials. Unfortunately, due to theoretical and procedural biases of that tirpe, historic arcliaeological sites were not recorded during the Bardwell Lake Sl;ID'ey. Recommendations were made for limited testing at three sites (41EL3, 41EL8, and 41EL12) and intensive excavations at two sites (41EL6 and 41ELI 1) (Shafer 1964:19).

Although the taxonomic cultural units discussed by Sorrow (1966) have been subject to various degrees of revision or redefinition since he described the site, the following thesis remains valid: In comparison, the archeology of the surrounding counties is much better known. The geographic location of Ellis County would place it on the marginal area of three other general archeological areas which are better understood. To the west the Edwards Plateau Aspect and the Central Texas Aspect form a continuum from Archaic to Nep-American times (Suhm, 1960: 84-85). To the north is the Archaic, Trinity Aspect defined by Crook and Harris (1952: 7-38), and the Henrietta Focus (Krieger, 1946: 87-159) and Wylie Focus (Stephenson, 1952[a]: 209-312), which represent the Neo-American Stage. To the east the Archaic Stage is represented by·the La Harpe Aspect (Johnson, 1962: 268-284), and the Neo-American Stage is represented by the Gibson and Fulton aspects (Suhm, Krieger, and Jelks, 1954: 151-227). Johnson suspects that the Carrollton and Elam foci of the Trinity Aspect are a westward extension of the La Harpe Aspect (I 962: 270). The Pecan Springs site ( 4 IELI 1) is located in a central position in relation to all of these areas and apparently received influences from each [~orrow 1966:1].
