A complete review oft his important site is obviously beyond the scope of the present report. Nevertheless, because the results of the Pecan Springs investigations are directly relevant to the characterization of the prehistory of the SSC project area, it is worthwhile to repeat here Sorrow's concluding remarks regarding the temporal and cultural utilization of the site. In summary, Pecan Springs is geographically peripheral to three areas in Texas which are characterized by different artifact. assemblages. The earliest occupation is characteriud by dart points which are diagnostic to the central Texas Archaic, Edwards Plateau Aspect. The next occupation is characterized by dart points which·are common to the late Archaic of both east Texas, the La Harpe Aspect, and central Texas, the Edwards Plateau Aspect The latest occupation, the Neo-American, is characterized by traits. which are common to east, .entral, and north Texas. The arrow points are probably linked closest with central Texas, but some forms have a rather wide distribution and are found in all three areas. The pottery can be traced on the basis oft emper, shell tempering being characteristic of north Texas and sherd tempering being an influence from east Texas [Sorrow 1966:63). A number of small cultural resource management projects have been conducted in Ellis County since the investigations at Bardwell Lake. These investigations include: Soil Conservation Service projects (Cole 1978, 1981; Kahlden 1983a, 1983b, 1984a, 1984b, 1984c, 1984d, 1984e, 1984f; Marks 1978, 1981; Soil Conservation Service 1978; Warren 1975); State Department of Highways and Public Transportation (SDH&Pl) projects (SDH&PT 1975, 1976a, 1976b, 1976c, 1976d, 1976e, 1976f, 1976g, 1976h, 1979, 1983); U.S. Postal Service projects (1978, 1984); Environmental Protection Agency/fexas Department of Water Resources projects (Ferring 1983; Fox 1979; Lynott 1975b; Nunley 1975); Economic Development Agency projects (Read 1983); and a single U.S. Army Corps of Engineers project dealing with surplus lands around Lake Bardwell (Derven 1982). All of these surveys, somewhat surprisingly, yielded negative results. In contrast to the studies listed above, several other small projects have yielded positive results. A survey of a 38.62 km (24 mile) transect for the Richland/Chambers pipeline identified two prehistoric and six historic sites·along the portion of the pipeline right-of-way which was located within Ellis County (Jurney and McGregor 1985). Two historic sites were identified during a survey of a pipeline corridor from Waxahachie to Ennis (Espey, Huston & Associates 1985). Two historic sites were identified during a survey of the proposed Midlothian/Waxahachie Airport (Westbury 1986, 1989), one of which (41EL35) lies within the SSC footprint but was not recommended for further investigation. Four historic sites were identified as a result of a pipeline survey for the Rockett Water Supply (Anthony and Brown 1990), including one site (41EL57) which falls within the SSC Footprint (see Figure 2.3). Finally, a proposed solid waste treatment facility and waterline were surveyed along Red Oak Creek, and although the initial investigations failed to discover sites (Jurgens et al. 1988), subsequent investigations have indicated that deeply buried prehistoric cultural deposits associated with bison remains are present within this project area (see Chapter 5, Waxahachie Quadrangle, 41EL151). This system consisted of, from most localized to most general, five major subdivisions: focus, aspect, phase, pattern,

40 Shaunessy and Jurney and base (McKem 1939). Krieger's (1946) seminal chronological frarneworlc for northern Texas, briefly mentioned above, was constructed according to this system, as was Stephenson's (1950b) subsequent summary of cultural chronologies in Texas as a whole (Figure 2.4). Although the MTS is seldom employed today, its influence is still pervasive in the archaeological literature, as the following discussion illustrates. A detailed review of the development of taxonomic systems used in Texas (and any accompanying theoretical and methodological problems) is beyond the scope of this report and the reader is referred to discussions in·Story (1990b:163-175) and Johnson (1987). Much of the archaeological database for north-central Texas, as indicated above, derives from work conducted in association with reservoir construction projects along the upper and middle Trinity River and its adjacent drainages and along the middle Brazos River (see Previous Investigations, above). The prehistory of both drainages can be divided into three broad stages: Paleo-Indian ( originally tenned Paleo-American); Archaic; and Late Prehistoric or Neo American (Suhm et al. 1954:16-21). Stages are defined as primary chronological subdivisions of prehistory based upon major changes in lifestyles which can be documented archaeologically. These stages are subdivided into perio~~r fixed. horizons. Periods, as subdivisions of a stage, tend to be more loosely or subtly defined and more temporally Horizons as subdivisions of either stages or periods represent "short-lived" material culture-oriented entities. As the term is employed here, horizons represent prehistoric populations and their associated lifestyles, which exhibit a particular archaeological trait, or combination of traits ( e.g., the use of a particular type of projectile point, ceramic style, or burial practice). The chronological framework that will be employed in the following summary is loosely based upon that proposed by Prikryl (1990) (Figure 2.5), but it is not completely consistent with his. Where appropriate, aspects of other cultural chronologies developed from north-central Texas archaeological databases such as the Joe Pool Lake and Richland Creek projects are included in the discussion (see Figure 2.5). General comments on chronologies from adjacent regions such as central and northeast Texas are also offered (Figure 2.6) in keeping with the point made in the previous · section-that is, that the SSC project area esse1;1tially represents a marginal area that is peripheral to, and was subject to cultural influences from, several adjoining areas which are much better known archaeologically. References to temporally diagnostic artifacts such as projectile points also generally follow the sequence proposed by Prikryl (1990) (Figure ·2.7). A Pre-Clovis stage has been added to Prikryl's general framework, more as a reflection of general theoretical concerns than as a reflection of the archaeological record of north-central Texas. The taxonomi~ scheme and culture-historical sequence employed in this summary thus represents a mixture of several theoretical constructs already established in the regional archaeological literature. The archaeological database from north-central Texas reveals considerable bias towards the Late Prehistoric stage, with little data to demonstrate firm artifact associations, settlement patterns, subsistence patterns, or general "lifeways" for the earlier Archaic and Paleo-Indian stages. There is also a paucity of sites relating to Historic stage Indian occupations, possibly due to lack of recognition or discovery, as well as low density or mobile settlement patterns. Protohistoric, Contact, and Historic Indians represent a transition from prehistory to history, but, because these occupations are poorly documented in north-central Texas, regional chronologies generally do not incorporate specific temporal and cultural subdivisions which deal with them. This is in contrast to adjacent areas such as northeast Texas where these occupations are much better represented in the archaeological and ethnohistorical records (Perttula 1993; Thurmond 1990). Accordingly, these culture-historical stages are discussed within the context of an informal transitional period at the end of this chapter. The following summary discussion of the temporal and cultural "subdivisions" that have been defined within means north-central Texas is intended only to provide a brief characteri7.ation of each stage and is by no exhaustive. More detailed discussions of the prehistoric cultural chronologies of north-central Texas may be found in several recent synthetic works (Bruseth and Martin [editors] 1987; Bruseth and Moir [editors] 1987; McGregor an,d Bruseth [editors] 1987; Peter and McGregor [editors] 1988; Prikryl 1990, 1993; Story 1990.b) . Finally, the degree to which each of these stages is represented in the archaeological record of Ellis County and the SSC project area will be dealt with in subsequent chapters and the appendices to this report. Prehistoric Background 45 12,000 years ago, as manifested by the Clovis horizon. This is due largely to a handful of sites ''that will not go away" (Adovasio 1993). A discussion of these sites. all of which are geographically far removed from the present study area, is not relevant to the present report and the reader is referred to several recent reviews of the evidence for pre-Clovis populations in the New World (Adovasio 1993; Gamble 1994; Meltzer 1994). No viable candidates for a pre-Clovis occupation of north-central Texas are presently known. Two sites discussed in the previous section, the Lagow Sand Pit in Dallas County and the Lewisville Site in Denton County, were each demonstrated to be much younger in age than was initially supposed, although the Lewisville Site is now generally regarded as an important Clovis-age campsite (see Previous Investigations, above, and below). 1bree anthropomorphically carved stone boulders were recovered from gravel pits which also contained extinct Pleistocene fauna near Malakoff in Henderson County (Sellards 1930, 1941, 1952). The antiquity of1he so-called "Malakoff heads," however, has also been generally discounted (Agogino 1966, 1987; Guderjan 1981), and, as Story (1990b:176) notes, their significance "remains largely aJ!).3tter of opinion." The Paleo-Indian Stage (ca. 10,000-6550 B.C.) The majority of Paleo-Indian sites which have been identified in north-central Texas consist of isolated projectile points from either surface contexts, or from within mixed associations with later occupations (Lynott 1981:100; Meltzer 1987:27; Story 1990b:178). Unfortunately, as Richner and Bagot (1978:51) note, "one of the most striking characteristics of the Paleo-Indian stage in north-central Texas is the extreme rarity of sites exhibiting Paleo-Indian cultural materials." The Paleo-Indian stage is subdivided into three ho~ns; Clovis, Folsom, and Plano (see Figure 2.5 and below) .. These three entities are defined as techno-cultural horizons mainly on the basis of widely distributed projectile point types, each of which is assumed to have been used over a relatively short period of time. These projectile points constitute the most distinctive trait of Paleo-Indians, sharing common attributes with some spatial and temporal variability (Story 1990b: 177). Projectile point types associated with north-central Texas Paleo-Indian sites are basally ground, lanceolate forms that probably were used either as projectiles or knives. Lithic' raw materials used in their production are typically of high quality and frequently of extralocal origin. Paleo-Indian populations appear to have led highly mobile hunting and gathering lifestyles focused on: the exploitation of broad regions for plant foods and lithic raw materials; and the hunting of both migratory and resident animal populations. The Paleo-Indian stage is characteriz.ed by low-density human populations which slowly increased through time. Some Paleo-Indian sites elsewhere in Texas have produced evidence of big game hunting, with a perceived trend for the association of mammoth kills with Clovis sites and the association of bison (Bison antiquus and Bison bison) hunting with sites dating to the subsequent Folsom and Plano horizons. Clovis sites in north-central Texas, however, have produced clear associations with bison kills and with the exploitation of a number of smaller faunal species (see below). Indeed, in inost portions of North America, generally, and north-central Texas, specifically, evidence is lacking for a Paleo-Indian subsistence strategy based solely on big game hunting. Instead, a generalized hunting and gathering lifestyle is considered more likely for Paleo-Indian populations (Meltzer and Smith 1986). As mentioned above, most of the extant Paleo-Indian archaeological data derives from surface finds, although several professional excavations have been conducted. Notable sites in north-central Texas from which Paleo-Indian material culture remains have been recovered in stratified contexts include the Lewisville (41DN7,l) and Aubrey (4 IDN479) sites within the upper Trinity River drainage and Hom Shelter No. 2 ( 41BQ46) in the middle Brazos River drainage (see Previous Investigations, above, and below). Generally, Paleo-Indian sites have been recorded in both larger stream valleys and minor tributaries, with specific exposures within the "second terrace deposits of the Trinity River and its major tributaries" (Skinner and Connors 1979:9). Data from these sites show the existence of small, highly mobile groups (possibly composed of related nuclear families) using dispersed transitory campsites. Moreover, the settlement pattern of these groups appears to focus to some extent on primary and sometimes far-removed sources of certain valued lithic raw materials (e.g., the Edwards Plateau, the Ouachita Mountains, and the west Texas Alibates quarry) (see discussion of Clovis-age caches, below). •

## Page 72

46 Shaunessy and Jurney Clovis Horizon (ca. 10,000-9200 B.C.) The Clovis horimn is represented by lanceolate projectile points with short basal flutes and prismatic blades. A flute is a semi-concave flake scar having parallel sides extending from the base toward the tip of the specimen, "produced to allow special hafting" (Crabtree 1972:66). It is also .known as a channel flake. Other typical Clovis artifacts include laurel-leaf shaped bifaces, "end scrapers," and smooth bone or ivory cylindrical shafts (Lynott 1981:101). Most of the Clovis finds identified to date in north-cenJral Texas occur as isolated or low density finds located on upland, non-aggrading landforms, erosional cuts, or gravel quarries. The vegetation during this period was becoming more open due to decreased rainfall and warmer temperatures with persistence of forest in the eastern portion of north-central Texas (Lynott 1981:101). The distribution of Clovis projectile points suggests that all major environmental zones were exploited (Meltzer 1987:32-42;·Story 1990b:178). It is generally thought that Clovis populations were highly mobile and traveled over great distances in small bands (Jo~on 1989; Lynott 1981: IOI). A-. paucity of good archaeological sites in north-central Texas leaves many questions unanswered about this horizon, including several posed by Meltzer (1987:27-28): "What kinds of adaptive strategies produce an archaeological record that comprises largely scattered, isolated projectile points? Why no other tools? What implications does this have for Clovis subsistence strategies?" Despite the general lack of Clovis horizon sites occurring in contexts amenable to answering the above questions, Clovis projectile points have been recovered from a few buried and/or stratified localities. One such site, the Aubrey m Site (noted above), is a Clovis camp and bison kill locality which is situated adjacent to a relict spring and pond a deeply buried context in the floodplain of the Elm Fork of the Trinity River. This site is interpreted to represent two brief encampments following a bison kill and butchering episode, with material culture remains exhibiting evidence of tool kit refurbishing, tool use, and tool discard activities. Smaller game animals are also represented in the faunal assemblage (Perring 1989). Story (1990b:182-184) reviews the evidence from the Lewisville Site (Crook and Harris 1957; Stanford 1983) (see Previous Investigations, above) and concludes that the site represents a camp, rather than a kill or butchering site, and a that the animals exploited by the occupants consisted primarily of box turtles, and, to lesser degree, deer, small mammals, birds and their eggs, reptiles, and mussels. No definitive evidence for the consumption of large mammals such as bison, horse, or mammoth is apparent at the site. No tool manufacturing activities apparently took place at the site, apart from some minor edge refurbishing of tools made from extralocal raw materials. Finally, the large munber of hearths at the site suggests either several visits by a small group or a single very brief visit by a moderately large group. Story (1990b:185-187) goes on to discuss the evidence for Clovis occupation from the lower levels of Horn Shelter No. 2 (Redder 1985; Redder and Fox 1988; Watt 1978), a stratified rockshelter within the middle Brazos River drainage, and compares the data to those obtained from the Lewisville Site. She concludes that the "Hom Shelter and the Lewisville site have much in common: (1) hearths are relatively frequent, (2) finished tools and chipping debris are infrequent, (3) large land turtles may have been a favored food ... and, (4) small animal remains make up a significant part of the faunal inventory. Moreover, the artifact inventories from the two sites are similar'' (Story 1990b:187). Another apparent Clovis site in north-central Texas is the Davis Blade Cache ( 41NV659). These blades, ascribed to the Clovis horizon on technological grounds, were recovered in the Richland/Chambers Reservoir from a context less than 50 cm (19.7 in) below the present ground surface (Young and Collins 1989). The blades are made primarily of Edwards Plateau chert, although three blades are made from an unidentified extralocal chert. All were heavily utilized, and the archaeological context suggests that Paleo-Indians practiced long distance transport with strategic placement of caches. The closest raw material source for these blades is the Edwards Plateau near Georgetown, Texas, located ca. 177 km (109.98 mi) from the location of the cache (Mike Collins, personal communication to D. H. Jurney 1989). Similar caching behavior with Edwards Plateau chert was reported at the Brookeen Creek Cache (4IHI86), also of possible Clovis ascription, in the Brazos River drainage (Mallouf 1981; Malloufand Baskin 1976). Overall, the available database suggests a settlement 'pattern for Clovis horizon populations which is focused on upland settings and along tnbutary streams. It should be noted, however, that these localities probably represent areas where sites are most likely to be pn;served or discovered {Story 1990b: 182).

## Page 73

• Prehistoric Background 47 Folsom Horizon (ca. 9200-8500 e.c.) The Folsom horizon is far better represented in the Rocky Mountains and western Great Plains than it is in north central Texas (Story 1990b:189). Indeed, Folsom sites in north-central Texas are even less common than the earlier Clovis sites. The Folsom horizon may have developed out of the antecedent Clovis horizon, but with a possible gap ofs everal hundred years (o r several generations) and an apparent absence of an intermediary projectile point style (Story 1990b: 189). Some workers, however, have recognized possible "intermediate" forms in the central Rio Grande valley ofNew Mexico (Judge 1973) and in the Northwestern Plains of Wyoming (Irwin 1968; Irwin-Williams et al. 1973) and Montana (Frison 1986). Intermediate forms may also have been recovered from sites in the Southern Plains of northwest Texas and southwest Oklahoma (Hofman 1989). Beginning ca. 9200 B.C., a dry climate dominated, increasing open grassland environments. Hunting of bison (Bison antiquus and Bison bison) increased while mammoth (Mammutbus sp.) and mastodon (Mammut americanum) became extinct. If, as is generally supposed, the Folsom populations were largely dependent on the hunting of grassland species such as bison, then the paucity of Folsom horizon sites in north-central Texas is not surprising. The open grasslands to the west of the present area of consideration would have supported a much higher density of large grazing animals (Lynott 1981:101; Story l990b:l89). Thus far, no evidence has been found to indicate a significant change in social organization from Clovis to Folsom times. Presumably, "small bands of aggregated families with high degrees of mobility continued to move over vast areas, and population density in the region was still quite low" (Lynott 1981:101). Flaked stone tool assemblages at Folsom sites include both channel-fluted and non-fluted projectile point forms (Turner and Hester 1985:99). As with Clovis horizon flaked stone tool~ high-quality lithic raw materials were employed, implying long-distance travel or trade. Other Folsom artifacts include bifaces in various stages of reduction, scrapers, choppers, perforators, hammerstones, abraders, bone needles, and, possibly, bone gaming pieces (Story l990b:l89). Tools manufactured from • bone are much more common in Folsom horizon artifact assemblages than in. the earlier Clovis horizon assemblages (Hofman 1989). Eight Folsom projectile points are listed by Story (l990b:180-181) as having been'recovered in north-central Texas. A single specimen has been reported from surficial or culturally mixed deposits at each of five individual sites (41DLl48, 41HE61, 41HE134, 41KF47, and 41NV6). Three Folsom projectile.points were recovered from good stratigraphic contexts, however, at Hom Shelter No. 2 (41BQ46), in the middle Brazos River drainage. Interestingly, the faunal assemblage recovered from one of the Folsom horizon levels at this site included, in addition to bison and deer bones, an "enormous number" of small animals (R~der 1985, cited in Story 1990b: 190). Plano Horizon (ca. 8500-6550 B.C.) . Plano represents "a general term used to refer to a number of potentially distinct cultural groups recognized by distinctive unfluted, lanceolate projectile points which are known or assumed to be of post-Folsom or late Paleo-Indian age" (Hofman 1989). It was during Plano times that a marked transition from glacially-influenced to essentially modem environmental conditions took place. An increase in population during the Plano horizon is inferred from the recovery of greater numbers of projectile points relative to the previous Clovis and Folsom horizons. It has also been speculated that a slight reduction in group (i.e., closely related nuclear families) mobility occurred in north-central Texas at this time as a response to this apparent increase in population density (Lynott 1981: 101-103 ). Like the earlier Clovis and Folsom, most Plano horizon artifacts in north-central Texas have been recovered from surficial or culturally mixed contexts. The notable exception, where diagnostic projectile points have been recovered from good stratigraphic contexts, is, again, Hom Shelter No. 2 in the middle Brazos River drainage. As indicated above, the primary constituents of the Plano horizon are distinctive projectile point types, the most common of which are the Dalton and San Patrice types which appear to represent the transition between Paleo-Indian stage and Archaic stage flaked stone tool technologies. The Dalton projectile point is a lanceolate style (sometimes fluted) which technologically repr~sents the evolution of an eastern form _of Clovis (Goodyear 1974:101; Story 1990b: 190). The projectile point form is often recycled through several stages; and the tool kits contained end and side • scrapers, gravers on flakes, gravers on end scrapers, "true blades," unifacial modifications to blades and blade-like flakes, bipolar cores, and wedges (Story 1990b: 190). An important technological innovation in the Dalton tool kit is a bifacially flaked stone adz.e (Goodyear 1974:102; Morse and Goodyear 1973). Dalton projectile points are relatively

Angostura projectile points are included by some authors ( e.g. McGregor and Bruseth 1987: 178; Story l 990b:217; Turner and Hester 1985:66) in the late Paleo-Indian stage, but have recently been described by Prikryl (1990:52) as being "oft he same general age as local Early Archaic types, although they probably represent the end of the Great Plains Paleoindian tradition." t The Archaic Stage ( ca. 6SS0 B.C.-A.D. 700) As Story (1990b:211) points out, the term "Archaic" has been widely used to describe cultural developments in the Eastern United States and Great Plains, but not always to the same end nor according to consistent standards. At different times and according to various researchers, the term Archaic has been defined as: a developmental or evolutionary stage or interval between Paleo-Indian and Woodland cultures, later extrapolated to designate New World "migratory hunting and gathering cultures continuing into environmental conditions approximating those of the present'' (Willey and Phillips 1958: 107, cited in .Story l 990b:21 l ); a generalized way of life or tradition focused on small game, fishing, and plant subsistence; and simply a temporal designation. This report employs the term Archaic to designate hunter and gatherer populations in north-central Texas from ca. 6550 B.C. to ca. A.D. 700. The beginning of this stage, in particular, is a somewhat arbitrarily assigned one for, as Story (1990b:213) notes, the differences between the material culture traits and inferred lifestyles of the Late Paleo-Indian and Early Archaic populations are largely ones of degree rather than kind. Early Archaic Period (ca. 6SS0-40S0 B.C.) During this period, a clearly marked climatic change toward warmer, drier conditions occurred. This change was accompanied by the opening of additional upland prairies and the retreat of hardwood forests to floodplains, which in tum resulted in new adaptive requirements for the region's Archaic populations (Weir 1976; Lynott 1981:103). Generally speaking, the Early Archaic period marks the end of the Paleo-Indian lifestyle and the incipient adaptation to a fully modem (although fluctuating) environment and climate. There appear to have been a variety of cultural responses to these new ecological systems, and the period witnesses the emergeoce of a broader variety of projectile point types, more variable artifact assemblages, and greater interregional variability between tool kits (Story 1981: 143). Compared to Paleo-Indian artifact assemblages, Early Archaic flaked stone tools, as Story (1990b:213) notes "tend to be more functionally varied but more cheaply produced (both in terms of manufacture time and raw material

The general evolutionary trend in projectile point manufacture throughout the latter part of the Paleo Indian stage and the Early Archaic period is toward shorter, comer-notched triangular projectile points. The Early Archaic period, however, also appears to witness a cultural continuation of Paleo-Indian flaked stone technology as demonstrated by the persistence of the lanceolate projectile point form and the presence ofbasal grinding on many Early Archaic projectile point types. Basal and lower edge grinding on Early Archaic projectile points has been seen as a common trait throughout eastern North America (Coe 1964:64-68; Gardner 1974:18), although in his study of projectile points from north-central Texas Prikryl (1990:51) states that "it is important to note that stem grinding is not necessarily the most significant trait in many of these [Early Archaic] specimens, since this feature also occurs on Middle and Late Archaic dart points." Apart from the Angostura projectile point (noted above), other Early Archaic projectile points include a variety of forms having split stems and exhibiting basal grinding which Prikryl (1990:51) groups together into an "Early Split-Stemmed" category. The best archaeological data for this period derive froin sites in central and southwestern Texas (Brown 1987; Prewitt 1981; Weir 1976). In north-central Texas the Early Archaic period is a very difficult entity to define due to the lack of well-documented, temporally unmixed cultural deposits and the use of inconsistent or otherwise nonstandard artifact typologies (Story 1990b:217). To date, few sites with discrete Early Archaic components have been identified or investigated in north-central Texas. While it is debatable whether population size was increasing or decreasing during this period, the small number of possible Early Archaic sites identified in north-central Texas suggests that the population density essentially paralleled that of earlier times. "Maximum-sized social groups were probably loosely structured bands that often changed size and composition, mostly in response to fluctuations in food resources" (Story 1981:144). . The subsistence patterns of Early Archaic populations are believed to have been broadly similar to those of the earlier Paleo-Indian populations. Like the Paleo-Indian populations, Early Archaic peoples were probably nomadic seasonal hunters and gatherers, except that the geographic area covered in their annual range may have been reduced in comparison to the earlier groups. Prikryl (1990:71), however, notes that "overall, the resemblanc"e of Early Archaic diagnostics from the [Lower Elm Fork] study area to those occurring to the south in Ce~tral, South, and Southwest Texas, to the east in East Texas, and to the north in Oklahoma suggests a broad cultural pattern and lack of regionalization. As with the Paleo-Indian period, it is probable that human groups were very mobile and ranged over large areas with little in the way of recognized territorial boundaries." Finally, any scenarios which include more intensive or specialized use of plant resources by Early Archaic populations remain largely speculative as material cultural evidence for such adaptive responses does not appear in the archaeological record until somewhat later in the Archaic stage. Middle Archaic Period (ca. 4050-1550 B.C.) ·The Middle Archaic period can be viewed essentially as a continuation of Early Archaic period lifestyles, and, in north-central Texas, generally suffers from the same lack of well-documented, temporally unmixed cultural deposits as the preceding period. Previously defined cultural units which incorporated this period consisted of two "aspects" which were defined according to the conventions of the Midwestern Taxonomic System (see Chronology and Taxonomy in North-Central Texas, above). The Trinity aspect (see Previous Investigations, above, and below), which contains the early Carrollton focus and the later Elam focus, was centered in north-central Texas where the upper fo~ of the Trinity River join the main stem in Dallas County (Crook and Harris 1952, 1954a, 1954b; Crook 1952). The Carrollton focus was seen as broadly conforming to the Middle Archaic and the Elam focus to the Late Archaic (Crook and Harris 1952:38; Lynott 1977:82). The La Harpe aspect was subsequently defined by Johnson (1962) as an inclusive Archaic complex which extended in a wide band along the woodland/prairie boundary from southeast Texas to east-central Oklahoma. Johnson (1962:270) saw the Trinity aspect ~ typologically intermediate between the La Harpe aspect of east Texas and the central Texas Archaic, and suggested that the Elam focus, in particular, might be included within the La Harpe aspect Although he suggested some preliminary areal subdivisions and temporal phases (Johnson 1962:269- 270), the La Harpe aspect is too geographically and tempt>rally inclusive to be of use as it is presently defined (Story • 1990b). Crook and Harris (1952:7-9) extended the general region of the Carrollton focus from its center in Dallas County (see Previous Investigations, above) to the north along the Elm Fork and to the south ''to include the mid-reaches of the Trinity, Chambers Creek in Navarro County, Aquilla Creek in Hill and McLennan Counties, and west to the Brazos near

Within the middle Brazos River drainage and central Texas, Weir (1976::26) postulated two Middle Archaic subdivisions or phases, Clear Fork (3050-2050 B.C.) and Round Rock (2250-650 B.C.), whereas Prewitt (1981:75) distinguished four Middle Archaic phases: Clear Fork (2650-2050 B.C.); Marshall Ford (2050-1450 B.c.); Round Rock (1450-650 B.C.); and San Marcos (650-300 B.C.) (see Figure 2.6). Recently, however, Prewitt's cultural subdivisions of the Archaic stage have been criticized {Ellis 1994; Johnson 1987; Johnson and Goode 1994). The central Texas Middle Archaic is characterized by ubiquitous features referred to as "burned rock middens," which presumal,ly reflect an intensification of specialized food gathering (Prewitt 1981 :73). The northernmost of such sites, the Ham Creek Site (41JN2) (Forrester 1964), is located in Johnson County, to the west of the SSC project area The absence of burned rock middens from the upper Trinity River drainage may indicate that distinct regional groups with different adaptive lifestyles occupied central and north-central Texas by 2550 B.C. {Prikryl 1990:73). At Joe Pool Lake (see Previous Investigations, above), only two sites (4 lDLl 84 and 4 IDLl 99) contained Middle Archaic artifacts, although "the multicomponent nature of these mixed assemblages makes it impossible to assign materials other than the diagnostic projectile points to the Middle Archaic components of these sites" (Peter and McGregor 1988a:362). It was further suggested that the paucity of Middle Archaic diagnostic cultural material suggested a transient occupation at these sites. Within the Richland/Chambers Reservoir (see Previous Investigations, above), more substantial Middle Archaic occupations were identified at four sites ( 41FT200, 41 NV96, 4 lFf l 58, and 41 NV 160), although at the latter two sites the Middle Archaic cultural material was mixed with material from later occupations (Bruseth, McGregor, and Martin 1987). Prehistoric Background 51 Late Archaic Period (ca. 1550.B.C.-A.D. 700) Significantly more stratified and single-component Late Archaic period localities have been identified and intensively investigated than is the case for any of the preceding periods or horizons discussed above. Thus, more detailed information on prehistoric lifestyles, environmental adaptations, and demographic patterns exists for the Late Archaic in north-central Texas than for any preceding temporal division. In general terms, the evidence points toward a shrinking of cultural territories and an increase in population. Toe La Harpe aspect, as noted above, incorporated Late Archaic period components and was thought to show strong cultural ties with areas to the north and east, and to be represented chiefly by contracting stemmed dart points, the most typical of which was the Gary type (Johnson 1962:268). It was also suggested that the Elam focus of the Trinity aspect might properly be included within the La Harpe aspect (Johnson 1962:270). Toe Elam focus, also mentioned briefly above, was seen as a direct outgrowth of the Carrollton focus (Crook and Harris 1952:23). Toe most common projectile point of the Elam focus was thought to be the Ellis projectile point, followed by the Yarbrough and Elam types (McGregor 1988a:31). The morphologies of these projectile points are stemmed and/or shouldered and barbed (Crook and Harris 1952:27). Additional artifact types from sites ascribed to this focus include a drill made on a thick, leaf-shaped knife and "scraping and cutting flakes." Side scrapers and quartzite hammerstones and choppers continue to be used, as on Carrollton focus components, while gouges become very rare. Compared to the earlier Carrollton focus, the Elam focus was characteri7.ed by a considerably higher percentage of flaked stone tools made from locally obtained quartzite (Crook and Harris 1952:24). Prikryl's reanalysis of the collections on which Crook and Harris (1952) had based their definition of the Carrollton and Elam foci indicated that the Gary type was the most common projectile poin~ type for the Late Archaic period. Other Late Archaic projectile points included the Dallas and Trinity types (both previously assigned to the Middle Archaic) and the Ellis, Edgewood, Elam, Godley, and Yarbrough types (Prikryl 1990:74). Like Johnson (see • above), Prikryl (1990:74) also thought that these Late Archaic projectile point types evidenced strong cultural affdiations to areas to the north and east of north-central Texas. The conclusions originally made by Crook and Harris (1952:24-27) that the Late Archaic period in north-central Texas witnessed a much greater: exploitation of locally available quartzites for the manufacture of flaked stone tools, presumably as a result of shrinking cultural territories and reduced access to extralocal cherts, appear to be valid, at least for the eastern portion of that area, as evidenced by Prikryl' s reanalysis of the collections noted above (Prikryl 1990) and the investigations conducted at Richland Creek (Braseth, McGregor, and Martin 1987; McGregor 1987a). As noted in the preceding section (see Previous Investigations, above), however, the limited data set from Joe Pool Lake indicates that Late Archaic populations in the northwestern portion of the present area of consideration continued to exhibit a ''westward orientation" which included the continued use of extralocal cherts for the manufacture of flaked stone tools (Peter and McGregor l 988a:363). The environment may have shifted to slightly wetter conditions during the Late Archaic period (Bruseth, Raab, and McGregor 1987; Ferring 1986). With more available water, it is expected that the density of all floral resources increased, resulting in expansion of the woodlands. This increase in biomass would have resulted in an increase in plants and animals available for human consumption (Prikryl 1990). The subsistence strategy at this time is thought to have depended heavily on the exploitation of riverine faunal and floral resources, particuiarly in the prairie and crosstimbers where "subsistence was directed toward intensive exploitation of local bottomland resources" (Lynott 1981:104). If this general environmental reconstruction is correct, it would provide one explanation for the apparent increase in population within north-central Texas at this time, as indicated by the considerably greater'number of sites with Late Archaic period occupations, relative to the preceding periods (Bruseth, McGregor, and Martin 1987; Peter and McGregor 1988a; Prikryl 1990). Although there is evidence for the development of horticulture elsewhere in North America during this period, Late Archaic populations in north-central Texas are thought to have continued to pursue what essentially rema~ed a hunting and gathering lifeway (Lynott 1981:105; Martin and Bruseth 1988:33). Recent investigations across the Southeastern United States show that mound building began during the Late Archaic, indicating radically different lifeways and social organization than previously assumed by archaeologists (Russo 1994; Saunders et al. 1994), There are, however, no known Archaic mounds in north-central Texas. Some of the best evidence for Late Archaic occupation of north-central Texas comes from the deepest layers of fill within large manmade depressions at the Bird Point Island and Adams Ranch sites in the Richland/Chambers Reservoir (see Previous Investigations, above, and below). These depressions, termed "Wylie focus pits," are problematic features which may indicate group aggregation and ceremonialism beginning sometime between ca. 200 B.C. and AD. l (Bruseth and Martin :.,

The pits appear to have been constructed during the Late Archaic period and not, as had been previously supposed, during the succeeding Late Prehistoric stage (Bruseth and Martin 1987). Known Wylie focus pits occur along the East Fork of the Trinity River, and along Richland Creek in Navarro and Freestone counties. The SSC project area is situated between these two loci of Late Archaic activity; and it is possible that portions of Ellis County may have been occupied or used by these populations. The ideological importance of the Wylie focus pits is demonstrated by their inclusion of human burials, although the mortuary role of these features appears to have been secondary to their role as large scale, communal food processing and roasting features (Bruseth and Martin 1987:282- 283). These pits suggest that not only are roasting activities more common than in the preceding Middle Archaic period, but, also, that there was an increased reliance on plant resources as compared to animal resources (Bruseth, McGregor, and Martin 1987:239). As noted in the previous section, the investigations conducted as part of the Richland Creek project conclusively demonstrated the time-transgressive nature of the Wylie focus (which had previously been suggested by Ross (1966] andLorrain and Hoffiichter (19681), and, thus, the basic uselessness of this cultural unit, as it had been previously defined (see Late Prehistoric Stage, below). In the middle Brazos River drainage, there is also considerable evidence for increased occupation during this period (Skinner at al. 1978; Brown 1987:5-8). Sites were investigated as early as the 1930s by members of the CTAS and DAS, and extensive excavations were performed confirming this intensive presence (Blaine et al. 1968; Forrester 1964; Lynott 1978, 1980; Lynott and Peter 1977; Skinner and Henderson 1972; Skinner and Gallagher 1974; Stephenson 1970; :Watt 1978; Watt and Agogino 1968). Although Brown (1987:5-8) has suggested that the Godley projectile point type appears to represent a localized tradition in the middle Brazos River drainage, Prikryl (1990:55) lists the Godley projectile point as a common type in Late Archaic sites of the upper Trinity River drainage. The burned rock middens found on Middle Archaic sites of central Texas do not persist into the Late Archaic period in the east (i.e., the western periphery of north-central Texas as herein defined) but do continue in the western portions of the central Texas region (Prewitt 1981:73). The generally accepted end of the Late Archaic period is marked by the appearance of the bow and arrow and ceramic manufacture. The appearance of the small, expanding stemmed arrow points (particularly the Scallorn type) in north-central Texas by ca. AD. 700 implies introduction of the bow and arrow by this time (Story 1990b:213, 217). This shift in projectile point types may also indicate the adoption of individual hunting strategies (i.e., stalking prey) over group hunting strategies (i.e., surrounding prey). Ceramics may have appeared even earlier in north-central Texas, based on a small number of shell-tempered sherds recovered at the Adams Ranch Site (4 INVI 77) in the Richland Creek project area from a context which was radiocarbon dated to between AD. 200 and 700 (Bruseth, McGregor, and Martin 1987:238-239; Martin et al. 1987:244). Story (1990b:217), however, prefers a more conservative date of ca. A.D. 800- 900 for the appearance of ceramics, which is more in keeping with their occurrence at other sites in the Richland Creek project area At any rate, the appearance of ceramics in north-central Texas clearly postdates their first occurrence in northeast Texas where the Ceramic stage begins ca. 200 e.c. ## Page 79

Prehistoric Background 53 Creek project was the "sinking" of the Wylie focus as a useful culture-historical unit (Bruseth and Martin 1987). The Wylie focus was originally defined as a "distinct cultural complex on the western edge of the Caddoan area and on the eastern edge of the southern extension of the Plains area" (Stephenson 1952a:305). It was tentatively assigned a temporal duration of from ca AD. 1300-1600, although Stephenson (1952a:312) suggested that subsequent research would likely result in a compression of this chronological period. Quite the opposite has proved true, however, and subsequent investigations of Wylie focus sites resulted in increasingly lengthier time spans being assigned to the Wylie focus (e.g., Lynott 1975a). The temporally mixed nature of Stephenson's (1952a) original c.omplex of diagnostic traits also became apparent (Brusetb and Martin 1987; Lorrain and Hoffiichter 1968; Martin and Bruseth 1988; Ross 1966). For instance, the single most useful of the diagnostic traits of the Wylie focus, large cultural features known as "Wylie focus pits" _which apparently served both economic and mortuary purposes, are now known to date from the Late Archaic on the middle Trinity River (see above). · Data from palynological and alluvial stratigraphic studies jndicate that alternately dry/moist episodes have taken place during the Holocene. The latter part of the Late Archaic period (see above) was apparently a time of relatively greater moisture in north-central Texas, but by ca AD. 950 (if not slightly earlier) drier conditions began to prevail and subsequently to intensify through the Late Prehistoric stage (Bruseth, Raab, and McGregor 1987; Ferring 1986; Hall 1988; Peter and Jurney 1988). This drying trend apparently resulted in the expansion of grassland environments and a concomitant retreat of the post oak savannah. Indications ofhow this climatic change affected the Late Prehistoric populations of north-central Texas were forthcoming from several sets of investigations which are described below. Prilayl (1990) has subdivided the Late Prehistoric stage of the Upper Trinity River Basin into two distinct periods (i.e., Late Prehistoric I and Il; see Figures 2.5 and 2. 7) on the basis of changes in projectile point morphology, raw material utilization, and artifact assemblage composition, all of which presumably reflect socioeconomic changes within the Late Prehistoric populations of north-central Texas. These periods are essentially temporally equivalent to the Austin and Toyah phases of the central Texas Neo-American stage ( or Neo-Archaic stage, sensu Prewitt 1981, see Central Texas: The Austin and Toyah "Folk," below). The Late Prehistoric I period is distinguished,by the appearance ' of arrow points, notably the Alba, Scallorn, Steiner, and Catahoula types. There is strong cultural continuity between the Late Archaic and the Late Prehistoric I periods in terms of site distn"bution and lithic raw material utili7.ation (Prikryl • 1990:79). Earlier Late Prehistoric I projectile point types-Scallorn, Catahoula, and Steiner-tend to be manufactured more often from quartzite than from chert, while the slightly later Alba type is more often manufactured from chert. The Late Archaic contracting stemmed Gary dart points, commonly made from quartzite, persist into the Late Prehistoric I period, but probably were not manufactured after ca AD. 950 when the percentage of chert used for projectile point manufacture becomes very high (Prilayl 1990:77-79). The first evidence for the remains of houses and for the practice of horticulture date to the Late Prehistoric I period (see below). Ceramics are also generally thought to have been introduced into north-central Texas at this time, although limited data from the Richland Creek project ( discussed above) suggests a slightly earlier (i.e., Terminal Archaic) appearance, at least in the upper middle Trinity River drainage. Diagnostic projectile points of the Late Prehistoric II period include Fresno, Harrell, Maud, Perdiz, and Washita types (Prikryl 1990:60-61 ). The Late Prehistoric II period is distinguished not only by the appearance of these new projectile point types per se, but, also, by a significant increase in the use of extralocal cherts in their manufacture, the presence of a "Plains Indian tool assemblage," an .apparent shift in site distributions to the crosstimber/prairie boundaries, and, possibly, a heavier reliance on the exploitation of bison (Prikryl 1990:79-82). The increased use of chert at this time suggests a return to a previous level of group mobility, or, at least, increases in trade connections (Prikryl 1990:83). The intensive investigations which were conducted in the Mountain Creek drainage at Joe Pool Lake, a small portion of which extends into the northwest comer ofE llis County (see Figure 1.12), have been described in the previous section (see Previous Investigations, above) and will only be briefly summarized here. Peter and McGregor (1988a) subdivided the Late Prehistoric stage into three phases (Early, Middle, and Late) which reflected the identified changes in material cultural remains and apparent subsistence and settlement practices at the Joe Pool Lake sites (see Figure 2.5). The Early phase (AD. 700-1000) was thought to be characterized by a hunting and gathering lifeway which was essentially the same as the preceding Late Archaic period; Use of the bow and arrow is evident from the presence of Scallorn projectile points which McGregor (l 9~8b) described as stylistically distinct from specimens from both the middle Trinity River drainage and the Brazos River drainage. No evidence of cultigens or semi-sedentary occupations •. was recovered from the Early phase components.

Late Prehistoric Stage Developments in Adjacent Regions Brief mention should be made here of three regions adjacent to north-central Texas which, broadly speaking, also underwent important Late Prehistoric culture-historical developments, and which may have been, to a greater or lesser extent, the sources of intrusive cultural influences and/or populations into north-central Texas at this time: northeast Texas; central Texas (see Figure 2.6); and the Southern Plains. Only very brief comments are provided here for: comparative pwposes. More detailed overviews of the development of cultural chronologies for northeast Texas may be found in Kenmotsu and Perttula (1993) and Story (1990b), for central Texas in Black (1989) and Ellis (1994), and for the Southern Plains in Hofman et al. (1989). Northeast Texas: The Caddoan Area As indicated above, ceramic vessels appear in the archaeological record somewhat earlier in northeast Texas than they do in north-central Texas. These earliest northeast Texas ceramics are related to ceramic traditions of the greater Southeast, especially the Lower Mississippi Valley (Story 1990b:246). For instance, Thurmond (1990) dates the beginning ofh is Early Ceramic period in the Cypress Creek Basin to 200 e.c. (see Figure 2.6) with the appearance of ceramic wares such as the grog-tempered Wiliiams Plain. During this Early Ceramic period important socio-cultural developments took place among the populations of northeast Texas, including the beginnings of a trend toward greater sedentism and nucleation in settlement patterns and the appearance of more complex social and ceremonial behavior. Toe latter is evidenced by the construction of the first large earthen mounds and increased mortuary ceremonialism. Conversely, available evidence for subsistence practices at this time indicates a gradual intensification of essentially Late Archaic foraging strategies (Story 1981: 146). This 11:aving been said, the remainder of this brief discussion of the culture history of northeast Texas will concentrate on the period from ca. AD. 800-1680, when interactions between northeast Texas and north-central Texas become more apparent in the archaeological record. "This period. . .is synonymous with the florescence of the Caddoan tradition" (Story 1990b:320), and is temporally more or less equivalent to the entire Late Prehistoric stage of north-central Texas. · Schambach (1970, 1982) describes the coalescence of Caddo and Caddo-related speakers of a large portion of the Trans-Mississippi South as being the most significant and complex cultural development to occur in the Late Prehistoric stage west of the Mississippi. A number of geographical and cultural subtraditions apparently existed within the greater Caddoan sphere and each area has its own internal chronological sequence (see, for example, Figure 2.6). A revised version of the general chronological framework for the entire Caddoan area was proposed by Story (1990b:334) and consists of: Formative Caddoan, or Caddo I (AD. 800-1000); Early Caddoan, or Caddo II (AD. 1000-1200); Middle Caddoan, or Caddo ill (AD. 1200-1400); Late Caddoan, or Caddo IV (AD. 1400-1680); and Historic Caddoan, or Caddo V (A.O. 1680-1860). Toe first three periods (Caddo I-Im thus span most of the time period formerly, defmed by the Gibson aspect and the latter two periods (Caddo IV and V) together are more or less temporally equivalent to the Fulton aspect (see Figure 2.4). The Caddoan settlement pattern is characterized by habitation loci, more ephemeral special purpose camps, burial grounds, and community or ceremonial centers (Story 1990b:334). Most Caddoan habitation loci appear to be farmsteads or hamlets, with village sites being less common until the Late Caddoan period (Anderson 1972:122). Of particular note are the large artificial earthen mounds, some of which contain burials with relatively lavish funerary offerings, which together indicate a fairly complex (politico-religious?) stratified social system with higher status individuals. No such structures exist in north-central Texas. . Distinctive Caddoan ceramic vessel forms include carinated bowls, bowls with rim peaks, and long-necked bottles. • Decorative treatments may be engraved, incised, punctated, or polished, and exhibit interlocking scroll, swirl, and concentric circle motifs (Davis 1970; Hoffman 1970; Krieger 1947; Webb 1961; Wyckoff 1971). Pinched ridges, brushed-incised designs, red-filming, and applique fillets are also common decorative motifs. Tempering materials

Bone and grog tempering are generally associated with the Early Caddo period, whereas shell tempering appears to be associated with the Late and Historic Caddo periods (Orr 1952; Skinner et al. 1969). Shell tempering is apparently not an indigenous Caddoan trait and may have been adopted from either adjacent Plains Village populations or from the Lower Mississippi valley. Reconstructions of the subsistence practices ofCaddoan populations derive from the analysis offaunal, floral, and human skeletal remains from archaeological sites as well as from "ethnographic" research conducted by the French and Spanish from 1687 to 1772 (Anderson 1972:133). Caddoan subsistence appears to have focused upon a mix of wild resources and cultivated crops. Maize was the main domesticated staple, followed by beans and squash (Anderson 1972:133). White-tailed deer has been most frequently encountered in faunal assemblages, but squirrel and rabbit, various birds, and fish also supplemented the Caddoan diet (Story 1990b:343). It is important to note, however, that although maize was apparently present from earliest Caddoan.tiQ:ies, it did not become a major contributor to the diet until somewhat later, and that beans and squash appeared later than maize. Wild plant resources such as nuts, sumpweed, and goosefoot would have also contributed substantially to the diet (Perttula and Bruseth 1983:17). Story (1990b:343), summarizing the results ofBurnett's (1990:393-399) bioarchaeological synthesis oft he Red River drainage in Late Prehistoric times, states that "by Middle-Late Caddoan times, the adaptive efficiency (as measured by nutritional status, incidence of infectious disease, and mean age of death) of both the subadults and adults was comparatively good, only to decline in the Late Caddoan period." To summariz.e, the Late Prehistoric Caddoan tradition of northeast Texas may be characteriz.ed by the presence of distinctive ceramic vessel morphologies and decorative motifs, sedentary villages, a reliance (ranging from light to intensive) on maize agriculture, large ceremonial or mortuary mounds, ranked societies, and complex exchange networks. "Circular houses with interior support posts, certain clay pipe forms, and shaft-like burial pits with elaborate offerings" are other archaeological traits which have been recognized as characteristically Caddoan (Story 1978:57). The extent to which archaeological investigations have identified Caddoan incursions and/or cultural influences in north central Texas (Figure 2.8) has already been briefly mentioned above within the context of the investigations at Joe Pool Lake and Richland Creek and will be touched upon again below in the discussion of the NCO:Ameri~ stage within the middle Brazos River drainage. Central Texas: The Austin and Toyah "Folk" The northeast periphery of the central Texas culture area, as it was defined by Prewitt (1981:72), overlaps with the southwestern portion of the present area of consideration (see Introduction, above, and Figure 2.1) along the middle Brazos River drainage. The post-Archaic occupation of central Texas was initially characterized according to the criteria of the Midwestern Taxonomic System (see Chronology and Taxonomy in North-Central Texas, above) and was termed the Central Texas aspect (Krieger 1946). This aspect was divided into two foci, Austin and Toyah, which were originally thought to be coeval (Kelley 1947a, 1947b). Subsequent investigations, notably the excavations at the stratified Blum (4llll8) and Kyle (41Hll) rockshelters in Hill County, demonstrated the proper chronological relationship between the earlier Austin and later Toyah foci (Jelks 1953, 1962). Temporally, these two central Texas foci or"phases" (Prewitt 1981) are more or less equivalent to the north-central Texas Late Prehistoric I and II periods (Prikryl 1990) discussed above. Story (1990b:364), however, has suggested that within the middle Brazos River drainage there exists an intermediate period between the Austin and Toyah phases (see below). • The term Neo-American was later proposed for the post-Archaic stage of central Texas in lieu of Central Texas aspect (Suhm et al. 1954) and has remained in common usage, despite a number of other proposed designations for this culture-historical unit For instance, Prewitt (1981 :68) has argued "that the term Neoarcbaic be used to identify those cultures wherein ceramics and/or the bow and arrow were adopted but in which agriculture was never practiced or in which agriculture did not emerge as·a dominant economic 'pattern. It is proposed that the term Neoarchaic be applied to the Central Texas archeological region and that it be used specifically to identify the Austin and Toyah phases of Central Texas." Neoarchaic woul<t thus distinguish cultures which adopted the bow and arrow, yet maintained an essentially Archaic lifestyle, from agriculturally based cultures such as the Caddoan groups of east Texas which achieved a "Formative stage" of development (sensu Willey and Phillips 1958: 144-I 47). A.I>. 1519 to ca. 1839) Unfortunately, as is the case in much of North America, there is no clear-cut demarcation between the prehistoric and the historic eras in Texas. Typically, the historic era is taken to begin at the first "contact'' between the Native American populations of a given area and Europeans. Yet, it is clear that European influences on aboriginal societies in such diverse fonns as manufactured trade goods, disease, or native population displacement often pre-dated the actual • physical contact between aboriginal inhabitants and the first European explorers. The historic documentation of first contacts also varies considerably in both degree of accuracy and the level of "anthropological" data recorded. The question of exactly how to define culture-historical divisions during this transitional period is further complicated by

The labels "Protohistoric" and "Historic" Indian are often used to divide this transitional period, again using the criterion of the first documented contact as an arbitnuy means of division. We have chosen to summarize this informal transitional period within a separate subsection of this report as it incorporates events from both the prehistoric and the historic eras. The beginning and ending dates used above are wholly arbitrary. The year AD. 1519 represents the first sighting of the Texas coast by European explorers and 1839 represents the expulsion of most of the native populations from eastern Texas (see Chapter 3). As such, this transitional period includes both the latter part of the Late Prehistoric stage (discussed above) as well as the first periods of the Historic stage (discussed in Chapter 3). Along the northern boundary of north-central Texas, archaeological materials of this transitionai period appear to be related to the Washita River phase emanating out of Oklahoma. Sometime around AD. 1450-1500, many of the Washita River phase sites in Oklahoma appear to have been abandoned, possibly as a result of population pressure from nomadic groups such as the Apaches, Comanches, Osages, or Kiowas, all of whom were apparently moving into the Southern Plains (Wedel 1961:131-148; Bell 1973:185; Schroeder 1962; Brooks and Drass 1984:33). This influx may have been caused, in part, by climatic stress and/or environmental changes. By ca. A.D. 1550, these groups appear to have coalesced into fewer and larger villages, ·and some sites begin to yield occasional European trade goods. These villages were located on river terraces, mainly along the Red River (Skinner and Gallagher 1974:8). Most Wichita phase sites were agricultural villages supporting from 100 to 600 people. Dwellings consisted of large circular houses made of upright poles with grass thatching. Some villages may have been fortified. ·W ichita subsistence was based .on a nomadic, bison hunting, Plains lifescyle, which was amplified by the addition of the horse (Richner and Bagot 1978:68). The remnants oft he Hernando de Soto expedition, led by Luis de Moscoso, may have passed through north-central Texas to the east of the SSC project area in 1542 (see Chapter 3). Diseases introduced by this group may have spread through native populations residing in the SSC project area as has been documented for elsewhere in North America (Dobyns 1983; Ramenofsky 1987, 1990). Alternatively, there is strong evidence that some native societies were pre adapted to ethnic mixing and that periodic social collapses occurred prior to contact with European pathogens (Dye and Brister 1986; Peebles 1990:29). · Other native groups utilizing portions of north-central Texas during this transitional period probably included the Wichitas, the Tonkawas, the Wacos, and the Caddos (i.e., Bidais and Anadarlcos). Apparently there was extensive trade from Spanish settlements along the Rio Grande to East Texas Caddos, carried on by Jumanos as well as the Caddos themselves (Kelley 1955, 1986; Jurney and Young 1995a, 1995b). "The presence of East Texas ceramics in Toyah phase [see Central Texas: The Austin and Toyah "Folk," above] sites indicates direct or indirect contact with the Caddoan groups of that region (Jelks 1962: 19; Krieger 1946; Watt 1953)" (Brown 1987:5-9) and it is presumed that this exchange increased with the advent of the horse, ca. 1690 (Schambach 1993). Native American groups, such as the Jumanos, utilized trading and travel spheres throughout the region. During the period from 1683 to 1692, Jumano movements from their heartland ~ong the Rio Grande River in Mexico to the Pueblos of the Southwest, the Wichitas and Apaches of the Southern Plains, and the Caddos of East Texas were documented by Spanish and French correspondence relating to Juan Sabaeta, the Jumano and Cibola chief who guided many early Spanish explorations and missions and French trade expeditions (Kelley 1955:981-995, 1986). The interregional cultural bases for these trade connections are thought to have existed long before European contact (Kelley 1955:981-995). The Toyah phase (see Central Texas: The Austin and Toyah "Folk," above), as reptesented by the Perdiz arrow point type dating from AD. 1300/1320 to 1600/1650 (Johnson 1994:258), is presumed to represent the direct cultural ancestor of the Jumanos, and the distribution of this archaeologically recognized culture suggests that long-range mobility was practiced prior to the introduction of the horse by European explorers (Kelley 1955:992-993). The extensive slave and deer hide trading system established by the Spanish, French, and English among Native Americans in the southeastern United States also indicates the influence of aboriginal systems of communication and trade (Henri 1986). Some trade fu horses, slaves, salt, and bow wood (i.e.; bois d'arc or Osage orange [Maclura pomifera]) appears to have originated in the north-central Texas and extended into the Southeastern United States as well as onto the High Plains and into the Southwest (Swanton 1942:31-32; Ki;_ieger 1947:207; Schambach 1993; Jeter et al. 1994). Creel (I 991) discusses th~ widespread exchange networks in the Southern Plains and adjacent areas that were documented by early Spanish explorers and the importance of bison hides as trade items. He suggests that beveled knives and end scrapers which occur in archaeological assemblages after ca. A.O. 1300 reflect the importance of bison hides in Late Prehistoric exchange systems.

Prehistoric Background 61 By the time of extensive European contact in the late 1600s, the dominant Native American groups in north-central Texas were tribes of various Wichita-speaking peoples. These included the Tayovas, the Wichitas proper, the Y scanis, and the Tawakonis (Story 1990b:363). This region was also occupied by the Kitsais, Osages, Caddos, and Apaches as -(story 1990b:363). The Wacos, Caddos, and Wichitas proper survived relatively coherent cultural entities until well into the nineteenth century in north-central Texas, yet "many groups may have disappeared or had their cultural patterns heavily altered by the massive depopulation and cultural disintegration brought about by the advent of the European settlers" (Anthony and Brown 1990:9). . Some of the native peoples of Texas encountered by the remnants of the de Soto expedition (noted above) were apparently Caddos of the Hasinai Confederacy, which consisted of at least nine and possibly as many as 11 Caddo speaking tribes. French and Spanish observers recorded the customs of the Hasinais during the years 1687-1772 (Anderson 1972:133). This period is marked by massive demographic changes which in part may be the result of the introduction ofthe.Jiorse by the Spanish in 1690 (Schambach 1993), or even earlier (Anderson 1972:133). With the use of the horse, the Late Caddoan residence pattern changed from sedentary forest hamlets to seasonal scheduling of nomadic hunting forays onto the Plains, particularly to hunt bison. This change, however, also brought about warfare with the Osages, Kiowas, and Comanches who claimed the Plains hunting grounds. The SSC project area would likely have been a principal zone of conflict between these groups. The subsistence pattern information gathered for the Caddos between 1687 and 1772 indicates the hunting (an exclusively male activity) of deer, ducks, geese, and prairie chicken in winter. Bison were hunted year-round, with major hunts occurring in the far-flung reaches of the High Plains in the winter. A large concentration of bison bones, m some with stone tool butchering marks (Johnson 1983), found in the Richland Creek channel Navarro County was radiocarbon dated to A.D. 1760±120 (SMU 1944, dendrocalibrated) and suggests a potential presence of Caddo or Wichita bison-hunting groups immediately to the south of the SSC project area. Most agricultural work (planting, harvesting, cleaning, and storage of cultivated crops) as well as the gathering of wild plants was con.ducted exclusively by females, although males were responsible for clearing and breaking the soil for planting. During the period from 1772 to 1781 there was a severe drought (Stahle and Cleveland 1988:59-74) whicp may have prompted the abandonment of agriculture and, concomitantly, encouraged the shift to bison hunting as a major subsistence activity. In the late eighteenth and the early nineteenth centuries, Indian groups including the Cherokees, Chickasaws, Delawares, Kickapoos, Choctaws, Koasatis, Alibamus, Muscogees, and others immigrated to the area from the eastern United States (Skinner et al. 1978:28) under pressure from the expanding Anglo-American frontier (Drinnon 1972, 1980; Henri 1986). The presence of trade goods, mixed within Native American material culture remains, has generally been interpreted as the key indicator for so-called "Protohistoric period" sites; however, Historic stage sites of immigrant Native Americans, particularly the Koasatis, Delawares, and Cherokees, have been shown to contain material culture remains which resemble those of European American frontiersmen (Jurney and Perttula 1995; Perttula 1994).

3. HISTORICAL BACKGROUND David H. Jurney with Contributions by Michael Harris and David C Paul INTRODUCTION The Historic Stage for Texas can be, and has been, subdivided in numerous ways. In the context of this discussion it is generally defined as beginning at A.D. 1519 on the basis of the first recorded European writing of the area containing what would eventually become the State of Texas. It is then subdivided into "periods" on the basis of local events and governmental rule. The following discussion provides a synthesis of data obtained from archival research and informant and landowner interviews that relate to the specific historic archaeological sites and communities within and around the Superconducting Super Collider (SSC) project area. The discussion begins with initial European exploration of the an portion of the Gulf Coastal Plain which would eventually become the State of Texas. It then turns to overview which places the development of the SSC project area within broader currents of Texas history, generally, and the development of Ellis County, specifically. It proceeds with a detailed summary of the historic events and persons associated with farms and communities directly affected by SSC construction. It concludes with several vignettes written by a former resident of the SSC project area, which have direct relevance to the archaeology of the SSC. EXPLORATION PERIOD: 1519-ca. 1750 Spanish-colonists from Hispaniola (Haiti) "discovered" the North American mainland during the course of three voyages along the Atlantic and Gulf coastlines which took place between 1513 and 1519. Alonso de Pifieda, in the service of Francisco de Garay, sailed along the Texas coast in 1519. It was not until 6 November 1528, however, that a boatload of survivors of the Narvaez expedition (extraction and colonization attempted) was cast ashore near Galveston Island, marking the first European footfalls in Texas (Castaneda 1936). The major European activity for north-central Texas during this period was confined to cursory and brief crossings of the region rather than true exploration. The region may have been traversed by early Spanish explorers such as Luis de Moscoso, who led the tattered remnants of Hernando de Soto's expedition (extraction and colonization attempted) through nortp-central Texas from the Mississippi River in 1542, attempting to reach Mexico by an overland route (Reese et al. 1986:154). Intriguing, but circumstantial, archaeological evidence that the Moscoso group may have passed southward through the Blackland Praire near the SSC project area has been recovered in areas to the immediate north, in Dallas and Denton counties. This evidence consists of: an East Indies Tabar (a hatchet-like lance), a medieval halberd, and a cache of native pottery ofa type made on the St. Francis River ofA rkansas (inferentially brought here by de Soto's men), all of which were found along the south side of the Trinity River, and a sixteenth century silver alloy gauntlet found on the Elm Fork of the Trinity River (Crook 1988; Hanna 1940; Harris 1951; Kenmotsu et al. 1993). A review of this evidence by Braseth (1992), however, favors a route considerably farther to the east. _ Subsequent Spanish expeditions into the North American interior included de Luna (1559-1561) and Pardo (1566- \ 1568) in the Southeast and Espejo (1582) and Onate (1598) in the Southwest (Haley 1985; Hudson 1987; Hudson, et 63

Following these expeditions, there is a gap in the written record until 1679, when French and Spanish competition for dominion prompted additional explorations into the North American interior, including north-central Texas (Galloway 1982; Habig 1934). Several later French and Spanish expeditions (extraction and colonization successful), such as that of Athanse de Mezieres (Castaneda 1945:2-3), passed through eastern Texas, south of the SSC project area As noted in Chapter 2, some of the native peoples encountered by the remnants of the de Soto expedition were apparently Caddos of the Hasinai Confederacy, and later French and Spanish explorers recorded the customs of the Hasinai between 1687 and 1772 (Anderson 1972). As was also noted in Chapter 2, the early trading systems utiliz.ed by the Spanish, French, and English in the southeastern United States were likely based on preexisting native trade systems. SPANISH AND MEXICAN COLONIAL PERIOD: ca. 1750-1836 In 1756, the Spanish presidio San Augustin de Ahumada and the mission ofNuestra Senora de la Luz were established on the banks of the Lower Trinity River (Bolton 1914; Foscue 1960). Also, by the mid-eighteenth century, both Spanish and French traders had expanded existing exchange networks with Native Americans residing in Texas. These Native Americans included the Wichitas, Wacos, Tehuacanas, Tonkawas, Tawakonis, and the Caddos (i.e., the Bidais andAnadarkos). The social, economic, and political changes wrought on native societies in the southeastern United States during the late eighteenth century led to increased immigration and long-term use of Texas and other regions west of the Mississippi for hunting forays (i.e., procurement of deer and bison hides and bear oil for trade) by southeastern Native American groups such as the Choctaws as early as 1766 and the Cherokees and Alibamu-Koasatis in the early 1800s (Clarke 1971:13-15; Flores 1985; Holley 1965:44, 100; Kinnaird and Kinnaiid 1980:349-370). As a result of these early incursions into the Trans-Mississippi South, there occurred conflicts between .. indigenous" (Tenuacanas, Caddos, Tonkawas, Wacos, and Wichitas) and "immigrant'' Indians. During the late eighteenth century and for the first three decades of the nineteenth century, immigrant and indigenous Native Americans formed a buffer between the cores of European and American settlements which were clustered primarily along the Red River Valley ofnorth Texas, southeast Texas, and the Gulf Coast (i.e., Austin Colony), Mexican settlements extending from the Rio Grande River through east Texas into Louisiana, and the predatory Plains groups equipped with horses (e.g., the Osages, Apaches, Comanches, and Kiowas). Despite this "buffer," during this period Yankee filibusters, such as Philip Nolan, began infiltrating across the Spanish colonial borders to capture wild horses. Nolan and his party were attacked by a Spanish patrol on Battle Creek in Hill County on 22 March 1801 (Jackson 1938:354-355). Despite the presence ofEuropeans and Native Am.ericans,however, there is no direct evidence for settlements in the SSC project area dating to this period, which are hypothesized to be light, short-term encampments with little material culture remains. · Although the Spanish system of land grants was designed to provide land only to Spanish citizens of the Catholic faith, some Americans began to take advantage of this system by immigrating into Spanish territory. In 1797, for example, Moses Austin immigrated into Spanish Louisiana (i.e., present-day Missouri), renounced his American citi7.enship, adopted the Catholic faith, and developed a strong relationship with Spanish officials (Haley 1985:9). After the Louisiana Purchase, Moses Austin began to plan trade missions to Spanish Texas. In 1819, follo'\\'.ing a financial panic, he followed Spanish requests to immigrate into Texas to secure an Anglo-American Colony, with himself as empresario. This land allocation system allowed the empresario to charge fees from settlers while still obtaining land in compensation for encouraging settlement Following the Mexican Revolution in 1821, Moses and Stephen Austin gained the opportunity to persuade the new goverfil!lent to allow the planned settlement of Texas, which was approved with a new coloni7.ation law in 1823. According to this law, each settler received a maximum of one league (4,428.40 acres (1,792.11 ha]) for ranching and one labor(177.ll acres [71.67 ha]) for cultivation (Haley 1985:17). An important feature of Spanish civil law, subsequently incorporated into Texas civil law, provided for the community system of property rights between husband and wife (unrecognized~in English commop law), which led to important roles for women in the distribution of Texas' p~blic domain (Hicks 1967:56). The public domain in what became present-day Ellis County was first distributed during the Mexican colonial • .. period. This includes 11 leagues (48,712.40 acres [19,713.18 ha]) granted to Raphael de la Pena and eight leagues (35,42720 acres [14,332.81 ha]) granted to Thomas J. Chambers.
