Historical Background 65 who were attempting to talce advantage of the liberal Mexican land policies and who were in direct competition with indigenous and immigrant Native Americans for land grants in Texas. Following the entrepreneurial spirit of Moses and Stephen Austin, Chambers, then a 24-year-old immigrant from Virginia, went to Mexico to study its language and laws in 1826. By 1828, he had been appointed Surveyor General of the State ofCoahuila and Texas and was promoted 'to-State Attorney in 1834. For his services, Chambers received 35 leagues (over 154,994 acres [62,723.75 ha]), including the above-mentioned eight leagues (Glaspy 1981; Jurney and Glaspy 1987:40). This land acquisition along the Upper Trinity River was achieved by a consortium including Nathaniel Townsend (Rafael de la Pena's attorney), Jose Manuel Bangs, Ira Lewis, and Isaac Dunahoe, all of whom resided in Leona Vicario, the State ofCoahuila and Texas. Rafael de la Pena transferred his I I leagues (48,712.40 acres [19,713.18 ha]) ofland to Nathaniel Townsend on 13 July 1830 (witnessed by Thomas J. Chambers) and the tract was surveyed by J. G. W. Pearson on 23 October 1834 (General Land Office, Austin, Texas 1834, Archives and Records: Spanish Collections 130:17). Although land speculation and surveying is doc~ented for the SSC project area during the Mexican colonial period, no known settlements were made. The only potential archaeological sites dating to this time could be temporary camps of the land surveyors (see Chapters 5 and 6, Palmer Quadrangle, 41EL99), the actual land tract comer monuments (posts) that were emplaced, or witness trees that were observed to mark the land parcels. During this same time, both indigenous and immigrant Texas Indians were skillfully denied land rights in the same region, primarily through diplomatic maneuvers such as those of Joel R. Poinsett, United States Ambassador to Mexico, who prevented Richard Fields (principal civil [white] Chief of.the Texas Cherokees) and Johll Dunn Hunter from securing the Cherokee Land Grant in east Texas (Drinnon 1972:xvi). Through intrigues with Stephen Austin and approval of their tribe, both Fields and Hunter were assassinated by Di Wali, The Bowl, commonly known as Bowles or Colonel Bowles, military (red) Chief of the Texas Cherokees, who was made a Mexican Colonel as a reward for these assassinations (Starr 1917, 1921). Generally speaking, the indigenous and immigrant native groups residing in Texas at this time were seen as unwelcome competitors for Mexican lands desired by European Americans. Conversely, land surveyors and speculators were seen as direct threats to Native American lifeways and homes. · • • I THE REPUBLIC OF TEXAS: 1836-184S On 1 March 1836, Texas declared its independence from Mexico and through armed revolution won its independence on 12 May 1836 (i.e., Treaty ofVelasco), retaining that independence for a decade (Haley 1985:48, 84). As a fledgling nation, Texas was without any financial structure. In order to fill the coffers of the Treasury, Texas sold its only commodity, land. From 1836 to 1838, Texas organiz.ed a system of public land allocation which was based on a network of land districts (Figure 3.1). This system, among other benefits, allowed veterans of the war for independence from Mexico, or their heirs, to be paid for their services through land grants. Recent immigrants could also receive land at minimal cost. An empresario system modeled after the Spanish/Mexican colonial system was established to encourage settlement. This f"rrst land grant system (metes and bounds measured in varas [ l vara=3 l-34 in [78.74-86.36 cm]) allowed individual selection of tracts and encouraged the empresario contract system which promoted wholesale grants to citizens. Interestingly, Texas did not adopt a uniform surveying code standardizing the vara (1 vara=33.34 in (84.67 cm]) until 1919 (Shine 1969). The frrst land grants were given from land districts in the cores of settlement along the Red River, east Texas, and along the Gulf Coast. Available land there rapidly became depleted, particularly the most desirable tracts along rivers. Moreover, the sizes of the grants were such that not all of the grant's acreage could be contiguously placed within the boundaries set by original grants in the cores of settlement. Many of the 183 8-1850 surveys in Ellis County were performed for untiled grants from other land districts or to make up for the balance remaining from the original grant filed and surveyed elsewhere (Figure 3.2). This complicated division of public domain in Texas to some extent represents the cultural division between the northern and southern United States. The northern United States employed a rectangular grid system which was arbitrarily divided according to standard acreage increments (i.e., 640 acres [259.00 ha], 320 acres [129.50 ha], 160 acres [64.75 ha], etc.) despite the choice oflandforms and,available resources within each grant. In the southern United States a metes and bounds system ·was employ~d which allowed a settler to -choose the landscape features he desired, • if they were not already claimed and ~arked by other settlers. In 1840, the Republic of Texas adopted the common law of England and repealed all Mexican laws in force in Texas except those relating to land grants, colonization, and minerals (Hicks 1967:56). In the early 1840s, the Republic of Texas entered into a number of empresario contracts to speed up the distribution of public domain. The Ellis County area was divided between the Peters Colony (i.e, the Texas Emigration and Land Company [W. S. Peters and Investors, Louisville, Kentucky]) and the Mercer•s Colony. The Mercer•s Colony included the southern two-thirds of Ellis County. The Peters Colony extended into the northern third of Ellis County. Within the Peters Colony, the land grant to each head ofa family was ~O acres (259.00 ha) and 320 acres (129.50 ha) to each single man. Every other section (640 acres (259.00 ha]) of land was to go to the Peters Colony in return for its services. The Peters Colony was widely advertised in the United States and Europe ancj attracted ca. 3,000 settlers to northern Texas, mainly from the states of Illinois, Missouri, and Tennessee (Connor 1959). In Ellis County land surveying began in earnest during the period 1836-1839, increased substantially during the period 1840-1849, and peaked during the period 1850-1859 (Figure 3.3). The surveys were performed primarily by surveyors from the Robertson Land District, the Peters Colony, the Mercer•s Colony, and Ellis County (Samuels and Knox 1980:5-10). The Nacogdoches Land District, located to the east of the SSC project area (see Figure 3.i), used a grid oriented 45° west of north. The Peters Colony, an empresario contractor comprised ofW. S. Peters and numerous investors from Louisville, Kentucky, used a north-south oriented township-and-range baseline meridian system modeled after the United States system of surveying to divide land grants in the northern portions of Ellis County, where their contract boundary ended (Figure 3.4). The Robertson Land District and the Mercer•s Colony used a grid oriented 35° west of north in the remainder of Ellis County. There is no apparent reason why the Nacogdoches and Robertson systems follow these declinations. All of these socio-political and cadastral systems intersected in the SSC footprint and Ellis County in the 1840s and 1850s. The citizens of Texas who had been receiving land through the Nacogdoches and Robertson•land districts, some of whom had settled on Mercer•s or Peters Colony Lands, were upset with the land distribution procedures (McCaleb 1906), the failure of the Peters Company to provide promised services, and confusion over deed titles.· In 1851, the Texas legislature paid off the Peters Company (i.e., the Texas Emigration and Land Company [W. S. Peters and Investors, Louisville, Kentucky]) and began to issue clear titles to the settlers through the county courts (Connor 1959). The mounting opposition to the Peters Colony in north-central Texas, however, led to a popular revolt on 15 July 1852, called the Hedgecoxe War, when all Peters Colony files and deeds were confiscated and destroyed by a mob, thus ending the first and only township and range system in Texas (Connor 1959:136-152). Also at this time, the Legislature passed a revised Homestead Act allowing settlers to occupy, improve, and claim land that remained in the public domain as well as protecting a household from seizure for most debts-another divergence from English common law (Hicks 1967:56). A substantial number of the early land surveyors were instrumental in the evolution of local entrepreneurial systems based on land acquisition. B. J. Chambers (the son of Thomas J. Chambers, discussed above), who surveyed Ellis County during the period 1838-1839, also controlled land in Freestone County to the south (Jurney 1992) and in 1867--along with W. F. Henderson, the lone survivor of the 1838 Kickapoo battle (see above}--founded the town of Cleburne in Johnson County (Block 1970; Glaspy 1981; Jurney and Glaspy 1987:40). Other surveyors prominent in Ellis County include D.R. Mitchell, J.E. Patton, and G. W. Cunningham. In 1847-1848, Henry 0. Hedgecoxe, the Texas administrator/surveyor for the Peters Colony identified James E. Patton and David R. Mitchell (Robertson Land District) and A. G. Walker (Nacogdoches Land District) as the chief trespassers on Peters Colony lands (Connor 1959:89). The Peters Colony immigration would probably have failed, were it not for the natural expansion of the American frontier through this area of Texas which aided in their quofi!. achievement (Connor 1959:90). 72 Jurney In the fall of 1845, the United States stationed a small ranger force at a camp near the head of Richland Creek in northeast Hill County, commanded by Thomas I. Smith (Jackson 1987:6-6; Reese 1961:44). The ranger station was named Fort Smith in honor of its Captain, Thomas I. Smith. The Ranger's duties were described by one of them, Buck Barry: We have but two positive orders from our Captain. One was that each squad should patrol its section of our line every day, running near and along the lower edge of the cross timbers, and to see that no Indians took the settlements by surprise. In case we discovered Indians or their trail going toward the settlements, it was our business to beat them there and notify the minutemen of their coming. Every settler was a minuteman. In fact every man in Texas was a soldier, organized into minute-companies and required to keep 40 rounds of ammunition and to be ready to start at a moments notice ... The other special order we had from Captain Smith was to get into no fight or conflict with Indians, as he trul)(..Said no deadman could make a report to the minutemen. Never more than three ofus ever went on patrol at the same time, and sometimes only one was sent. [Greer 1932:24-25] In 1845, Polly Rawlins (later married to Madison Moultrie Miller) wrote to her relatives in Green County, Illinois, describing the natural abundance of resources and the bountiful agricultural yields of the 1840s frontier settlers, We have as good a place as there is in Texas or any other place. These prairies are covered with grass and flowers of every kind. We have some wild fruit here. We have mulberries, dewberries, blackhaws, plums and grapes in abundance. We have 20 acres of the best sod com that any ofus or perhaps you ever saw. We have pumpkins, watermelons, cucumber, beans, peas, and sweet potatoes growing in abundance. We have had a very seasonable spring. It has rained just when we needed it. Very good crops are raised here. Those that had old ground have raised tolerable plenty. Com is one dollar per bushel. New\vheat is one dollar fifty cents. There is game here in abundance. Deer can be killed almost anytime one wishes to kill them. Six men started last Saturday after buffalo. They are very fat now and their hiaes command a good price. [Miller 1973:5-6] Despite bountiful yields of game, crops, and wild plant foods the health of these frontier settlers suffered. In January 1846, Polly Rawlins (Miller) reported "all have ague and fever not one of them excepted" (Miller 1973 :7). She also reports that Dallas in 1846 consisted of only 39 people and a half dozen buildings. By 1846, the town of Taos, or Porters Bluff, located at the junction of present-day Ellis, Navarro, and Henderson counties, had become an important community for riverine packets and small steamers up the Trinity River (Jester 1944; Jurney and Glaspy 1987:43). There was optimism that the Trinity River would become a major transportation route into the interior of Texas. Roads connecting this town to the hinterland and other communities were constructed by 1848. One road passed through the eastern portion of the SSC project area (near the modem City of Ennis), leading through Lancaster to Oak Cliff and on to Dallas. At its peak, Taos had a 20-room hotel, several homes, a blacksmith, a sawmill, a boat landing, several warehouses, and a ferry (Richner and Bagot 1978: 196). Taos was extensively damaged by floods in 1866 and again in 1878, when it was finally abandoned. On 16 February 1846, the United States fell into a war with Mexico (Haley 1985:131-146). When this war ended in 1849, the United States constructed a line of forts along the frontier, including Fort Graham on the Brazos River just north of the Anadarko village led by Chief Jose Maria (Jackson 1987:6-5). These forts marked the end of Indian dominion in Ellis and Hill counties. King Cotton The entire region of central and northern Texas, including the blackland prairie, witnessed a decade of growth prior to the Civil War. From the 1850s on, the center of cotton production and tn1de shifted from the Gulf Coast into the blackland prairies. Cotton began to displace the more traditional yeoman agriculture (e.g., com, wheat, rye, oats, barley, and hay) and animal husbandry (e.g., cattle, hogs, and horses) practiced by the original settlers (Bizzell 1924:157-158; · Jurney and Glaspy 1987:42-44). In 1859, on the eve of the Civil War, Texas ranked fifth in the United States for cotton .. production. In 1860-1861, script grants (i.e., land given in compensation for expenditures or labor) granted to various •

## Page 99

• Historical Background 73 railroad companies in Ellis County indicate that the railroad was considered an important mode of transportation which had to be developed in the region. The war, however, delayed railroad construction in Ellis County and halted development of the cotton industry. Also during the 1860s, Texas underwent the most prolonged drought in the last 300 years (Stahle and Cleaveland 1988:66), which greatly depleted the agricultural economy. Texas did not again match its 1859 cotton production, probably due to the drought and the realignment of the labor force, until 1875 (Agelasto et al. 1922:331). By 1879, Texas was the largest cotton producer of all states in the union, and remained so into the twentieth century. During this period, Ellis County was within the peripheral boundaries of the developing area of capitalist agriculture, existing as an upland region where a small, land-owning elite controlled labor _costs through serfdom, slavery, and debt peonage (Hugill 1988:77). Numerous overland routes had-been established by 1850, but seasonal floods often prevented travel across the Trinity River. The Old Springfield (Missouri) Road from Houston through northern Texas was one of the main routes that was used for driving cattle. It_passed through the SSC project area. The majority of immigration to this area at this time was originating from the southern States (Lee 1982), including a high proportion of slave owners (White 1940:904). The influx of settlers into north-central Texas from the .upper southern States and the Midwest, pro,mpted by the Peters Colony, continued. Slave holding was an essential part of cotton production, but the intensity of this practice was never as great in north-central Texas as along the Gulf Coastal Plain east of the Mississippi River. John Billingsley (1885:218) recalled that "from the year 1848 to 1851 there were great changes in the country ... people were moving in more each year, the water courses were being lined with settlements, farms and houses began to dot the prairie, dry goods and grocery stores were established in Dallas and a few in the country at different points." Madison Moultrie Miller, who married Polly Rawlins, established a mercantile in Lancaster, Dallas County, at this time and was one of the most prominent mercantilists in the region (Miller 1973). Miller procured his goods on buying trips to New York during the 1850s, where exchange of commodities was initiated (Miller 1973). He traveled by stage • to Galveston, and went by ship to New York. • The Civil War halted the settlement and economic growth of Ellis County, although a gunpowder mill was present in Waxahachie and a small arms arsenal in Lancaster, Dallas County. The Rockett Springs area along Red Oak Creek in Ellis County was apparently a mustering ground for several Texas military units (Ellis County Geneaological Society [ECGS] 1972). Most of the agricultural production offarmers was donated to the Confederate cause. The only public domain which was surveyed during this period was script to individuals who contributed to the war effort. After 1865, however, land surveying rapidly recommenced and the entire region again attracted settlement. · The principal labor source for cotton production, slavery, was lost after the Civil War. African Americans had a brief taste of social equality in the late 1860s and early 1870s due to the radical Republican influence over southern legislators. Fraternal organizations and some governmental positions were now available to African Americans; however, the "public" demand for self rule in Texas and white supremacy resulted in the 1868 reinstatement of the political and economic milieu that had existed prior to the war (Butterfield and Rundlett 1875:36; Jackson 1987). The abolition of slavery necessitated development of a new production system for cotton agriculture. Prior to this time, tenant farmers (i.e., croppers, renters, or otherwise) had been present in the early agrarian frontier, but were not prominent in the cotton agriculture labor force. To a certain extent, tenant farming largely replaced slave labor in the cotton belt and-developed 3li both an ei;.onomic system and a social institution in the late nineteenth ~d early twentieth centuries. This aspect of American social history has been examined in greater detail during cultural resources investigations conducted in north-central Texas (Jurney et al. 1988; Jurney and Moir 1987; Moir and Jurney 1987a, 1987b; Saunders 1982). The introduction of the railroad also aided in the shift toward cotton agriculture and farm tenancy in rural areas. Essentially, goods transported by rail facilitated the rapid growth of the cotton industry in the blackland prairie. Farmers were now able to ship their products to manufacturers wi\ile at the same time manufactured goods could be imported to rural communities and households. Additionally, cotton ginning and pressing machinery could be imported to railroad centers, thus facilitating the development of farming co-operatives and businesses which could greatly increase the efficiency and profits to be realized from cotton agricuTture. This period aJso marked the end of British hegemony • over the world economy and the rise of America, "Germany, and Japan as challengers in industrial development. Local merchants and cotton dealers acted as local "banks" administering the distribution of capital, first from Liverpool, then New York, and finally Houston (Buenger and Pratt 1986: 13; Hugill I 988:79, 81).

## Page 100

74 Jurney The Railroad As noted above, active development of the railroad in north-central Texas began in 1860-1861, was halted during the Civil War, and recommenced in 1866. The Houston and Texas Central Railroad (H&TC), had reached Millican, Brazos County,just 10 mi (16.09 km) north of Washington-on-the Brazos when the war broke out, but moved rapidly north after the war, creating the cotton towns of Navasota, Grimes County, Bryan, Brazos County, Hearne, Robertson County, and Calvert, Robertson County (Hugill 1988:79). The H&TC was completed in 1871 and connected Houston with Dallas. This line joined the Missouri Kansas & Texas Railroad at Denison, Grayson County to complete the rail line from Houston to St. Louis (ECGS 1972:51; Hardy-Heck-Moore, Inc. [IIl-lM] 1990:45). Towns along this line, established following a general railroad program of placing towns every 20-50 mi (32.19-80.47 km) with switching stations where needed, developed into regional business and labor centers following the completion of the railroad. On the local level, the presence of the railroad allowed fanners and co-operatives to reach higher levels of cotton production and processing and provide additional capital for local development of the agricultural base. Oil and bale presses at local gins (e.g., 41EL134; see Chapter 5, Boz Quadrangle) allowed greater efficiency and cost-benefit when products were sold. The railroad provided the means to tie households to national markets. The late nineteenth century marked the beginning of a major change in lifeways, from self-sufficient farms to cash crop agriculture. The Climax and Decline of Tenant Farming: 1900-1945 By 1900, America (particularly the northern states) was beginning to add military to economic strength and the Texas cotton region experienced a significant upturn in wealth (Hugill 1988:80). This wealth stimulated the development of new steam and electric railroads and the electric and gasoline-electric interurban railroads. The social organization also developed, with the addition of middle and artisan classes in urban settings. Added to this, the year 1900 was one of the great years for cotton, showing that upland farms (usually small, owner-operated, and white) had greater advantages over lowland farms (usually sharecropper-operated and African American). As long as blacks continued to be disenfranchised, upland towns with large numbers of white farmers (e.g., Waxahachie and Ennis) controlled· local politics and favored the development of local banking centers; redistributing capital from middle order banks in Houston (Hugill 1988:82). Also in 1900, researchers at the Texas Agricultural and Mechanical College learned that by growing quick-maturing "short season" cotton rather than the old "long season" cotton, the boll weevil could be controlled. This in tum reduced the acreage of land that could be worked by a family and thereby reduced the competitive success of the tenant-operated farm (Hugill 1988:82). The practice of tenant farming increased steadily in the United States between 1880 and 1930 ( Cauley 1930; Vance 1929; Wise 1937), with the most precipitous increase occurring between 1910 and 1930 (Sanderson 1937). This period also saw the development of the County Farm (i.e., Poor Farm, Prison Farm [e.g., 41EL58; see Chapter 5, Waxahachie Quadrangle]) system of indigent welfare and prison labor; which at the county level was used for maintenance of the road system as well as producing cash crops for the county and food for the residents. In Texas, the percentage of tenant farms increased from 37.5% in 1880 to 60.9% in 1930 (Cauley 1930; Sanderson 1937). Many displaced citizens found that the frugal welfare system that had evolved was insufficient. The Great Depression, combined with soil exhaustion, the shift in the type of cotton grown, and the cotton market crash culminated in the end of tenant farming as a major agricultural strategy, although it presently remains in various forms, particularly where large units ofland are available (e.g., the blackland prairie). The late 1930s and early 1940s witness~d an extensive population shift from rural to urban areas, and increased representation of middle and artisan social classes. Post-1945 Rural Development The rural portions of north-central Texas have undergone a considerable decrease in population since World War 11, most of which has occurred in the 20-25 year age group (Lee 1982). Towns and cities such as Waxahachie, Ennis, and Dallas, on the other hand, have grown. As traditional farms became influerced by developments in technology and federal land programs, rural lifeways_h ave focused on a cash economy and the use of consumer goods. The most significant aspect of this trend has been the mass consumption of goods (i.e., foods as well as commodities and manufactured goods, etc.). To a large extent, yeoman agriculture and the small family farm have been replaced by agribusiness and large corporations (Richner and Lee l 977; Lee 1982).

Early Settlement Three centers of initial 1840s settlement are present within the SSC project area: along Red Oak Creek from Ovilla to Red Oak; along Chambers Creek from Howe (Forreston) to the Old Highs Spring; and along Waxahachie Creek from Reagor Springs to Hawkins Spring. ## Page 102

76 Jurney Following the Civil War, the rural landscape continued to develop. E. M. Brack and P. C. Sims built frame houses, a church, and a school in 1872 near Bethel (Merkord 1988). The original families multiplied and fissioned. Prominent families in the Bethel/Boz area included T. J. Hines, Jr. (his first wife Margaret A. Winn, his second wife Mary M. Tidwell); B. F. Forrester, Sr. and his wife Fannie Green (see Chapters 5 and 6, Boz Quadrangle, 41EL77); Charles Nelson and his wife Emma Forrester; B. F. Forrester, Jr. and his wife Dahlia A. Ezelle; J. F., J. R. and 0. B. Dunaway; 0. B. and W. P. Sims, W. T. Bearden and his wife Ella Hollabaugh (see Chapters 5 and 6, Boz Quadrangle, 41EL128), and W. F. Timmins and his wife Mary F. Hines. Many communities in the project area underwent several stages in their evolution during the nineteenth century. The Bethel/Boz community is typical of this evolutionary pattern. Early settlement began around springs in the forested areas of the Chambers Creek valley and Greathouse Branch. After the end of the 1850s drought (the year 1855 was the worst in the last 400 years), settlement expanded onto the prairies upstream on Baker Branch to the "present" (see Chapter 1) seat of.the Bethel/Boz community. With continued agrarian development, farms extended onto the prairies in the 1870s and 1880s. The last decade of the nineteenth century and the first two decades of the twentieth century witnessed the in-filling of the rural landscape, primarily by tenant farmers who grew cash crops for the large estates that had been developed by the pioneer families. Large landowners built palatial homes in Waxahachie, Midlothian, Italy, or Ennis, leaving·their rural property in the hands of younger family members or hired overseers. The shift from relative self-sufficiency to a cash-based economy had repercussions in the case of indigent and/or invalid individuals, who had heretofore been cared for within the home. As early as 1869, Texas realized that county poorhouses were necessary and that workfanns were a means of exacting labor from petty criminals as well. Texas, as other states, drew upon the poor laws of Elizabethan England, and created a Spartan system of health care; one that was "careful not to create comfort, yet avoided starvation" (Cottrell 1989:171). This attitude was reinforced in the new Texas Constitution of 1876, which maintained a provision for establishing county poorhouses and workfarms. Often jaii trustees were used to provide heavy labor, while indigents, mentally ill patients, and the elderly did less strenuous work. The Etlis County "Poor" Farm (see Chapters 5 and 6, Waxahachie Quadrangle, 41EL58) was established in 1882-1883, indicating that a social need had developed with the advent of the railroad and tenant farming. The Ellis County'Farrn became a productive asset to county revenues, due primarily to the efforts of 0. E. Dunlap (Green 1970). General Land Office Surveys An examination of 185 land tracts in association with the SSC footprint yielded information of the land division of the area (see Figure 3.3). The Robertson Land District administered and surveyed 123 (66.42%) of these grants, although not all grants were issued from the Robertson land district For example, the San Augustine, Harrison, Bowie, Rusk, Montgomery, Van Zandt, Kaufinan, and Hunt land districts granted 57 (30.78%) of these tracts in the Ellis County GLO assemblage. These were followed by the Mercer's Colony (30, 16.20%) and Peters Colony (18, 9.72%). The high. incidence of secondary relocation from other land districts indicates that the Ellis county public domain had been substantially depleted prior to the onset of the Ellis County administration of the public domain; which surveyed an additional 62 (33.48%) tracts after 1850. The lag effect from the secondary location of parcels remaining from the Republic of Texas land certificates continued until 1869. From 1870 onward, most grants were from Ellis County or the General Land Office and were administered through Ellis County and surveyed by its own surveyors. A substantial number of the early land surveyors were instrumental in the evolution of local entrepreneurial systems based on land acquisition. B. J. Chambers, for example, also controlled land in Freestone County (Jurney 1990), helped found Cleburne, Johnson County, in 1867 (Block 1970), and laid out grants along Chambers Creek (named for ~is father T. J. Chambers) for E. H. Tarrant and other prominent pioneers (ECGS 1972). D.R. Mitchell, J. E. Patton, and G. H. Cunningham all received land within the SSC footprint, both as direct grants and as pay for services rendered. · The Railroad In 1871, the Houston and Texas Central Railroad (H&TC RR) connected Ellis County with St Louis and the Gulf of Mexico. In 1872, after the completion of the H&TC RR, the Town of Ennis was incorporated as a regional business and labor center for the railroad. This line is just east of the SSC project area and stimulated the development of

• Historical Background 77 Alsdorf, Ferris, Palmer, Trumbull, Garrett, and Alma. Ferris and Palmer, for instance, became centers of brick production. The marly bedrock of the Oz.an Formation, or lower Taylor Marl (Barnes 1988) in eastern Ellis County provided an excellent raw material for the manufacture of brick, beginning with the Ferris Pressed Brick Company in 1895. By 1929 eight brick plants (Atlas Pressed Brick Works, 1895-1918; Diamond Pressed Brick Company, 1910- 1923; Ferris Pressed Brick Company 1901-1923; Globe Press Brick Company, 1904-1923; Lone Star Press Brick Company, 1905-1923; Texas Press Brick Compnay, 1909-1923; and two unidentified manufacturers in 1921) had been formed (ECGS 1972; HHM 1990:39). The farmland around these towns received an influx of immigrants frpm eastern Europe (i.e., Bavaria, Germany, Czechoslovakia, etc.). The success of one immigrant was passed back to the homeland and informal networks were established that promoted subsequent immigration (Stollregen 1973). Nationally, a surge in immigration began around 1900, and many immigrants arrived in Ennis aboard the H&TC RR, such as Joe and Josie Dolezal from Bavaria (see Chapters 5 and 6, Ennis West Quadrangle, 41EL119). In order to share the economic boons of the .fl&TC RR, Waxahachie built the Waxahachie Tap Railroad in 1875; which was finished in 1879. This line cut through prime cotton lands, joining the H&TC RR at Garrett, Ellis County. The Ellis County Farm was established in 1882 on the Waxahachie Tap, just east of the Waxahachie city limits. The Waxahachie Tap Railroad was joined by the Texas Midland Railroad in 1928, providing a connection through the Blackland Prairie cotton belt to Paris, Lamar County, Texas. The latter line was abandoned in 1943 because of severe washouts along the Trinity River (ECGS 1972; HHM 1990). The Gulf, Colorado, and Santa Fe Railroad (GC&SF RR) was built across the northwes~ comer of Ellis County in 1882 (ECGS l ~72; HHM 1990). Although it is not located on the SSC footprint, the GC&SF RR contributed to the development of Midlothian as an industrial center. The Fort Worth and New Orleans Railroad (FW&NO RR), part of the old Buffalo Bayou, Brazos and Colorado (or Trinity Brazos Railroad [BBB&C RR]) reached Waxahachie from the southeast in 1882, passing through the center of the project area. Some communities such as Bardwell moved (see Chapter 5, Ennis West Quadrangle, 41 ELl55) in • order to take advantage of rail access . The Missouri, Kansas & Texas Railroad (MKT RR), which connected with the H&TC RR at Denison, Grayson County, was extended south from Dallas, generally following the Shawnee (or Chisolm)'trail and the 1850 Military Road (today's U.S. Highway 77). It reached Sterrett in 1889 and Milford in 1890. The communities of Red Oak, Waxahachie, Forreston, and Italy in the SSC project area benefited greatly from this rail line. The MKT RR was subsequently joined by the International and Great Northern (I&GN RR) in I 902. The I&GN RR extended up Chambers Creek near Boz, and passed through Maypearl and Venus to Fort Worth. The final rail system which influenced the development of the SSC project area was the Interurban System or electric railroad which enjoyed a monopoly on passenger service since it vastly undercut the price of steam or rail passenger service, offering more frequent service, and convenient stops in addition to lower fares. The interurban lines for Ellis County were financed by the Texas Traction Company and began with a line from Dallas, Dallas County to Sherman, Grayson County, in 1908. This line reorganized as·the Southern Traction Company in 1912 and extended the line to Corsicana, Navarro County, in 1912, and to Waco, McClennan County, in 1913 (Jackson 1981; Reed 1981). Thu~. Ferris, Trumbull, Palmer, Garrett, Ennis, and Alma on the east and Italy, Forreston, Waxahachie, Sterrett, and Red Oak on the west were tied to Dallas by commuter rail systems until ca. 1948 when the automobile and economic circumstances combined to eliminate ~lectric rail transit. Another industry associated with the railroad was introduced into Ellis County in 1920, the Texas Oil Products Company (Tucker 1980:5-9). This company was from Detroit, Michigan, and opened a southern office in Waxahachie. The oil refinery was established on the existing Magnolia Petroleum Company's eight inch (20.32 cm) pipeline which connected Bartlesville, Oklahoma with Port Arthur, Texas and the Plateau Oil Company's wells in Breckinridge, Texas. TENANT FARMING, KING COTTON, AND DIVERSIFIED FARMING OF THE SSC STUDY AREA AS PROVIDED BY INFORMANT DESCRIPTIONS Michael Harris Informant interviews were conducted with over ten Ellis County citizens of western and eastern European and African extraction who lived in the SSC project area. Six communities; Boz, Beth61, and Buena Vista (West Campus, unincorporated); Garrett and Ennis (East Campus, incorporated); and Crisp (East Campus, unincorporated) were represented. Specific and relevant information was transcribed from these interviews and is presented below. The methodology used for informant interviews utilizes an "emic" approach, that is, the attempt is made to present much of the material from the informants• own points of view (Malinowski 1922; Spradley 1980). Oral history is dependent not only on a familiarity with facts which occurred over time, but is also a function of memory. Thus, it should be borne in mind while reading these interviews that some of the dates, time periods, and specifics cited by informants are only of general validity. The important result of this research, however, is not historical validity, but a reflection of the perceptions and lives of the people within the SSC project area (cf. Langness and Frank 1981). While the informant interviews are transcribed verbatim, other subsections presented below (i.e., A History of Boz, etc.) are a synthesized compilation of information from numerous interviews. The Boz and Bethel Communities Two individuals, Monnie Bratcher and Jacob Polk, provided informative histories of Bethel/Boz, which is supplemented with information from Merlene Coker, Mary Frances Dow McGregor, Roger and Nancy Williams, Johnnie Boy Sims, Mr. and Mrs. Stanley Murdock, and other former residents ofBoz. Monnie Bratcher's story is an illustration of some of the history of Boz: I was born Monnie McCready on 7 August 1908,just across the branch on the same farm where I live now [see Chapters 5 and 6, BozQuadrangle, 41EL188]. I married when I was 18 years old. After two years of marriage we moved over to Greathouse, and then after a year we moved over near Maypearl. Outside of that I've lived here [Boz] in this house 55 years. My mother lived in Alabama and Tennessee. Her mother's family began to drift in here during the 1880s, and she came to Texas in 1887, after her mother and father were settled. Daddy was already here, he was from Alabama too. They didn't know each other there. His mother died when he was 13 years old and his daddy remarried about a year later. Daddy began to drift and wound up here working. He happened to be working and living with my mother's sister's husband. It was over by the field off of Ganaway [Dunaway] Road, on what used to be the Nelson farm. That's where they met. They married in Boz in 1899 in the middle of August. In the meantime he enlisted and spent three years in the Spanish-Ametjcan War. Before they lived at their house, they worked land for the Dunaways and Cunninghams. They worked sharecrop. In 1904, my daddy bought the farm [see Chapters 5 and 6, Boz Quadrangle, 41EL137] right across the branch from where I live now. Daddy bought the Whitefield place, that's where we got the history because the old Whitefield lady was still living. They bought this place in 1932 from the Maxwell's. In 1913 it belonged to the Jennings, then the Lyons, then Mr. Maxwell ca.-1917-1918, then my daddy. This front part of the house is 150 to 170 years old. This was used for slaves. They came twice a year and gave food to the slaves. This was called the commissary. a During the depression they'd let you go over there and pick that cotton but you couldn't sell it. But you could make a mattress out of it. I did that. When I married in 1926 I made a mattress. I still have it. In 1936 they killed the cattle. I seen them drive the cows down here and shoot them and cover them up.

A History ofBoz In the old days, the community ofBoz was the midway stagecoach point between Dallas and Waco (by-passed by the railroad through Forreston in the 1880s) and was a bustling tum-of-the-century village with three small general stores (one with a post office and a blacksmith's shop (see Chapter 5, Boz Quadrangle, 4IEL148), a barber, and a Doctor (Dr. Sims [see Chapter 5, Boz Quadrangle, 41EL169]). Just across the creek was the cotton gin (see Chapters 5 and 6, Boz Quadrangle, 41EL134). The stores were owned by Graves, Clayton, and Rumsey: One qfthe stores was later owned by Mr. Self. There were two lodges (see below) in the village, Rebeccas and Odd Fellows. Odd Fellows lodge was held above Mr. Graves store once a month. As Monnie Bratcher says: "We did all our shopping there. Momma sold her butter and eggs there. Bought our ice there. Bout twice a year we went to town. The mail was brought in once a week by Tom Allen on a mule. We voted in the store where the post office was. We voted until 20 years ago and then it moved over to Five Points" (see Appendix C, Boz Quadrangle, 41EL142). Similarly, Clayton's store and the blacksmith shop also moved to Five Points during the 1930s. Merline Coker (see Chapters 5 and 6, Boz Quadrangle, 41 EL 172) tells how her father, Albert Jenkins, "witched" water for people; a gift that she also has. Her father found the first community well using the forks of a peach tree (the best for water witching). "The fork is held straight up and when water is sensed the fork bends down to the ground." Ms. Coker told of the seven year drought in which the only well that didn't go dry in the community was the one owned by J. H. Sims. "He let everyone get drinking water." Still, many people had to haul water for cattle from Forreston, and one man, Pud Maxwell, "would sell water." The Maxwell (see Chapter 5, Boz Quadrangle, 41EL140) name is one m·ost commonly mentioned by Boz residents as one of the large landowners of the community. Pud Maxwell is remembered more frequently and less kindly, however, as the one who sold off his land ta;a developer. The lots are the sites of trailer houses and government houses in Boz. The Boz school (see Chapters 5 and 6, Boz Quadrangle, 41EL165) had four rooms with a hall down the center and was located near Monnie Bratcher's place. In the early 1900s the school had close to 100 students and had two or three teachers at different times who taught from elementary through high school. During the 1930s the number of children dwindled to between 50-60. The school disbanded right after World War II and the building was sold in 1952. Students from Boz were shifted to Forreston. Half of the old school was moved behind the Bethel Church (see Appendix C, Boz Quadrangle, 41ELl41) and is today used for a recreation center; the other half was apparently moved to the Pigg/Styles/Welch farm (see Chapters 5 and 6, Boz Quadrangle, 41EL139) and reused as a barn. A school for African Americans was located across the road from the old Cunningham place, which also briefly served as an African American church (see Chapters 5 and 6, Boz Quadrangle, 41EL84). The Bethel Church is located to the south ofBoz, and consists of the Methodist Church, a fellowship or recreation hall, a parsonage, and a tabernacle (see Appendix C, Boz Quadrangle, 41EL141). The present site is the third in its history. The Bethel cemetery is located just to the south of the church. The church, cemetery, and tabernacle were used in the filming of Places in the Heart. The Bethel church was the first church in the area to start an annual "Lord's Acre Sale" in 1952; a method of raising church revenues. In the beginning, farmers and ranchers put a woo~en cross in one of their fields thus denoting that an acre of the harvest would be sold at church auction. Women offered quilts and canned goods. Near the tabernacle there used to be a corral in which cattle were auctioned during the sale. The tradition continues today; however, the farmers now bring a pledge rather than an actual crop. The sale is accompanied by a free barbecue lunch and entertainment. Boz Social Composition In the mid-1800s, slaves were the major form of labor on the cotton farm. When slavery ended, some former slaves remained in rural communities and worked for their former masters. A number of African American families continued to live and work in Boz into the 1950s. For example, Aunt and Uncle Hayes continued to do the washing for many people in the community. Tootsie became a maid for the Beardens (see Chapters 5 and 6, Boz Quadrangle, 41EL128). Today there are no African American families in the community. There are at least two reasons that most of these families left Boz. First, the mechanization of cotton production in the late 1930s reduced the ne_ed for physical labor on the farm. The cotton planting, pulling and chopping, and picking had been done largely by African Americans, poor whites, and Mexicans. The cotton economy lost its impetus following World War II because of cheaper foreign cotton; the decline of yields due to soil exhaustf&l, and the invention of synthetic fibers. One African American man, Jacob Polk, continued to work in Boz, although he now lives in Waxahachie. Jacob is a preacher for the Church of Christ and has a Sunday Morning radio show. He currently (1992) tends the Bethel cemetery grounds, work which is provided by descendants of the Sims family. In the years prior to World War II, he worked as a sharecropper and hand for J. H. Sims (see Chapters 5 and 6, Boz.Quadrangle, 4IEL147), one of the largest landowners and overseer of much of the land owned by lanllowning families nQt residing in Boz. J. H. Sims moved Polk and his family to 8oz in the back of his pickup truck: When work for Sims was slow, Jacob and his family would pick cotton in the area. The pattern is quite common. The sharecropping household used family production for the crops and hired themselves out during the chopping and harvesting seasons. According to Jacob Polk: :.,

The Czechoslovakian Communities of Garrett, Ennis, and Crisp Listings of Czechoslovakian and eastern European immigrants are extremely fragmentary, with at least four ports of entry mentioned in the Ellis County District Court Records: New York; Baltimore; New Orleans; and Galveston. In Texas, Czechoslovakian immigration began in the 1840s, first concentrated in Austin County, with the.greatest influx after the Civil War (Baca 1983:25-26). In Ellis County, Czechoslovakian settlement clustered in the Garrett-Ennis-Crisp area and immigration occurred from the 1870s to the early 1900s, primarily since this was one of the best regions in Texas for cotton agriculture (Svrcek 1974). Jerry Dolezal, born 13 October 1913, provided detailed information relating to Czechoslovakian immigration into eastern Ellis County, generally, and_t he two-generation DQlezal farm (see Chapters 5 and 6, Ennis West Quadrangle, 4IELI 19), specifically. Between 1878 and 1929, 79% of those 457 persons naturalized in Waxahachie (county seat of Ellis County) were of Austrian-Czechoslovakia nationality (Ellis County Courthouse, Waxahachie, Texas 1917: Ellis County District Court Files, Petition and Record oflmmigra1ion and Naturalization), and the Garrett/Ennis area was the center of their resettlement. Jerry Dolezal's voice· still carries the lilt of his Czech heritage tinged with a Texas drawl, and he can speak Czechoslovakian "better than English." He didn't speak English until he began school, where he completed the seventh grade; "At that time everybody was farmers and it wasn't like it was now."

86 Jurney Joe and Josie Dolezal, Jerry's parents,arrived at New York's Ellis Island in 1902 on a boat from Bremen, Germany. The couple, Austrian citizens of Bohemian (Czechoslovakian) descent, ultimately made their way to Ellis County, Texas, where all five of their children were born; Joe Jr. (1 October 1907), Rosa (20 January 1909), Emma (15 May 1911), Jerry (13 October 1913), and Agnes (8 April 1916). Joe Sr. began farming 70 acres (28.33 ha) of cotton land less-than a mile west of 4IELl 19, at the southern terminus of the SSC's East Campus, until their move to that property in 1919-1920. The family farmed both places up through the 1940s when, upon returning from the army in 1944, Jerry and his brother Joe Jr. farmed together for four years while their parents moved to Ennis. Jerry and Joe received $65.00 a month from the GI Bill for going to agricultural school in Palmer, Texas. According to Jerry, "Bout the only thing I know from there was $65 a month. In those days that was something. A farmer showed us how to build a tractor." In 1950 the brothers split up, Jerry took the 70 acre (28.33 ha) original family farm, while his brother stayed at the second farm (see Chapters 5 and 6, Ennis West Quadrangle, 4IEL119), and marrie~ (Albina Makovy of Elm, Texas, who he met while in the army). In contrast, Jerry remained-Jifelong bachelor. They farmed separately until 1969, when Jerry sold his place and moved onto his brother's farmstead. His brother's new wife (Mrs. Mitchell) lived closer to Ennis and didn't want to move out to the country. In exchange for the use of the house, Jerry watched his brother's, which later became his brother's son-in-law (Robert L. Mitchell) cattle until ca. 1988. In 1990 the SSC acquired the land and Jerry Dolezal moved to the Odd Fellow's and Rebecca's Home in Ennis. Jerry's memories stret~h back to when the family moved to 41ELI 19 (see Chapters 5 and 6, Ennis West Quadrangle). There was a house already there and his father added another room to it in 1922. In 1924 they built a barn and an implement shed. The community of Garrett at the time consisted of three general stores, one of which held a post office; a cotton gin that closed in 1960; a school; and a couple of churches. Major supplies, however, were purchased in nearby Ennis. Farm life was marked by the daily round of rising early, feeding the hogs and chickens, and doing the milking. Work in the fields was until the noon lunch break, then back out into the fields until dusk. During the winter months, when there was less field work, the animals still had to be fed. Entertainment consisted of visiting with other Czech neighbors (e.g., Laceks, Vranas [see Chapters 5 and 6, Ennis West Quadrangle, 4IELI99], and Prachyls), and, perhaps playing 42, a dominoes variant. Later, as Jerry grew older, Saturdays or Sundays were spent at one of the dance halls in Ennis. ' The 1920s, with the exception of a very dry 1925, were good for farming. In the Garrett area cotton was the crop. According to Jerry, "If you didn't make cotton you were in bad shape." The cropping pattern consisted ofa major cotton crop with com and hay. Com, or maize; sorghum, or red maize; and hay were used for animal fodder. The acreage devoted to crops other than cotton depended on the number of horses, cows, and hogs that were being raised at a time. The 170 acres were typically divided as follows: 120 acres cotton, 20 acres pasture, and 10 acres each to com, sorghum, and red maize. The animals kept on the farm generally numbered about four hogs, six horses, four cattle, and 15-20 chickens. The Dolezal cotton schedule: From the early 1900s through 1942, the Dolezals planted with a single row cotton planter drawn by two horses. "The cotton planter opens a bed, drops the seeds, while two blades at the back of the planter cover the seeds with dirt. The cotton was then chopped two to three times during the early growing season to leave individual cotton plants ca. IO inches apart. By mid-September the cotton begins opening. Picking begins at the end of September and continues into October." The Dolezal com schedule: "Planting about the 10th of March. Plow it in the same manner as cotton. Chop it and leave the plants about one yard apart. In August the com should be dry in the fields. Pull it by hand." The Dolezal sorghum schedule: "Broadcast the field on April I. Plow the field and cover up th'e seed. Cut it down in July." The Dolezal's farming system is interesting in that it changed little from the time Jerry's father began in the early 1900s to when Jerry quit in 1969. According to him, the crop mix changed hardly at all, while the proportions of crops planted responded to outside factors. The proportion of cotton planted was the result of government programs from the 1930s onward. Such programs were·meant to limit cotton production by paying farmers not to grow a large crop and by controlling the acreage devoted to its production. During the first year, in 1933, farmers plowed under land already planted in cotton and were paid $10-1.2 per acre. After that 'JThey figure out how much you were allowed. They come around and measure it then." Still, Jerry thinks the programs were beneficial because they kept the market high. The farming system did change over time, however, in response to labor requirements and technological advances. For example, in 1942 when Jerry and his brother left for the army, their father purchased a double row cotton planter that required four horses. In this case, the shortage of family labor led to technological change. Upon returning from

• Historical Background 87 the war in 1946, Jerry's parents moved into Ennis, leaving their sons to farm. In response, the brothers purchased a tractor. The effect of the tractor not only reduced labor time in.plowing, planting, and harvesting, but also led to a decline in fodder crops since fewer working horses were now required on the farm. Family labor availability from the 1920s through the 1940s was one of the keys to having a successful small farm. Among the Dolezals, all children and both parents were able to work in the fields, especially during those times requiring maximum labor output. Typically, chopping out and picking cotton were the most labor intensive periods. Additional labor was sometimes hired during peak chopping and picking times. African American labor on cotton lands overall was important to the area because of its relatively low cost Yet for the Dolezals, family labor played a much greater role than hired labor from 1920-1942. When family labor was in short supply, however, Afi:ican American laborers were hired. For example, when the brothers left for the army, more laborers were needed. Similarly, with only Jerry and his brother farming the land from 1946 to 1950, they had to rely on a greater number of laborers, typically hiring six or seven people when necessary. When Jerry began farming indiv.idually in 1950, his outside labor requirements often necessitated five to six people for chopping and picking cotton. The cotton market gradually collapsed during the post-war years, fueling the trend towards larger farm sizes and the resulting economies of scale. Some farmers in the Garrett/Ennis area, however, continued their small holdings with cotton and the same cropping patterns developed by their fathers. Jerry can be viewed, perhaps, as a representative of this type of farmer; those who neither expanded nor took advantage of new farming techniques (Jerry claims to have never used fertilizer), and who were ultimately squeezed out of the market as times changed. Successful area farmers expanded acreage, began full-scale fertilization, utilized ever larger farm equipment, and practiced new cropping patterns designed to lessen the need for chopping cotton. (Thus reducing dependence on the African American labor market; and thereby depriving them oflivelihood.) During this time, most farmers also began leaving greater numbers of acreage in pasture, as the area's economic focus shifted from agriculture t<? livestock production as the most steady cash-generating farm resource . • TENANT FARMING IN THE BUENA VISTA COMMUNITY As indicated above (see Buena Vista), Jennie Ruth (Paul) Tucker's family had resided in the community of Buena Vista for many years. Her brother, David C. Paul, authored (1989) a series of vignettes describing his childhood in the community of Buena Vista. These vignettes, among other things, describe the digging of wells in the "chalk rock," the seasonal depletion of water and hauling water to fill cisterns, planting and harvesting, and philosophical observations on life in the Buena Vista community as a Depression era tenant farmer. Three of these vignettes are directly relevant to 41 EL 167 (see Chapters 5 and 6, Boz Quadrangle) and by inference, undoubtedly to other sites within the SSC project area and are presented below. About Wells and Cisterns DavidC Paul Often by the end of the summer, we had a shortage of water. That meant moving the pump from the well at the barn to the well at the creek. We made that move before the water was all used up so that if the well at the creek went dry we would still have enough water for emergency use in the well at the barn. We had two kinds of wells. Both were hand dug down into solid, hard limestone. The well at the barn and another at the house were actually cisterns. They were jugs hewed out of solid rock with powder and pick. The first layer of ground was soil, more or less a foot deep; then came a foot pr two of relatively soft limestone shale, and after that a layer of hard limestone so thick that as f~ as I know no one ever dug through it by hand. The upper part of a cistern was a vertical shaft about four or five feet in diameter. At a depth of about ten feet the cistern began to take on the shape of a bell. The deeper it went the wider it. got until it reached a diameter of about twenty to thirty feet At that point the diameter remained constant as the cistern got deeper and deeper, often reaching twenty-five or thirty feet from ground level. We heard of a cistern that was said to be so large in diameter at the bottom that a wagon and team could drive in circles in it. Naturally, that claim was never verified in practice.

## Page 114

88 Jurney The cistern filled during rainy seasons by seepage from the top soil and the layer of shale. I used to enjoy looking down into the cistern and watching the water as it dripped in from all sides of the vertical shaft. In some instances people directed water into the cistern by gutters from the roof of the house or barn, but we preferred ground water because it was filtered by dirt and shale on its way into the cistern. The obvious disadvantage of a cistern was that it held a limited supply of water and that it would not be replenished until the next season of rain. The well at the creek was different. It was about the same depth, but it was not belled out at the bottom and therefore it was not a cistern. While it would fill to near ground level during wet weather, in dry weather the water level receded until there was only about five feet of water in the well. Each time we pumped, the water level would go down, but after a few hours it would come back up to where it was before we pumped. That meant that the bottom part of the well was in connection by cracks or crevices with an underground natural reservoir. But where was that reservoir? How much water did it have in it? Which other wells, if any, were also getting water from it? How did the water get into the reservoir? Where did that water fall to the earth in the form of rain, or maybe even snow? If the dry spell lasted __ _ long enough, the water level in our well at the creek got lower and lower, and eventually there was none. On some farms in our area, the well never went completely dry no matter how long the drought lasted. There was an uninterrupted supply of water for years and years. Evidently such wells were getting water from a better source. The whole matter of those underground reservoirs was a mystery and a puzzle. We knew nothing for sure about underground sources of water. A dry summer could mean moving the pump twice, first in early summer to the well at the creek and then in late summer or fall back to the cistern at the barn. No chore was more difficult nor required more all out effort and concentration. First, I would harness a team of mules and hitch them to a wagon, back up to the engine platform and move the engine over into the wagon bed, the sideboards having been removed. Although the engine was all iron and very heavy this was not too hard to do because the wagon and the engine platform were near the same height. By far the most arduous part was talcing the pipe out of the well. It was two and a half or three inches in diameter. Inside the pipe there was a sucker rod and at the lower end of the pipe there was the pump cylinder.• All this came out as a unit. The first step was to attach a hemp rope around the pipe by means of several half hitches. My brother Eugene would go once around a tree or a post with the rope so that when the time came he could hold the pipe and keep it from falling out of control to the bottom of the well. Taking the position to disjoint the pipe seemed like looking down into the mythical abyss. The joint in the pipe which I must talce apart was but below ground level. It was a T, the side opening of which connected to the mainline going to the water tank. The top of the T screwed on to the pipe coming down from the pump jack, and the bottom of it connected to the vertical pipe coming up from the pump cylinder. I had to get down into the shaft of the well, big pipe wrench in hand, and find a suitable rock ledge on each side to put my feet securely on, so that I would be in a position to break the joint. Facing the T joint at just below shoulder height, I placed the pipe wrench so that the handle was to my right, and I pulled with all my strength, making sure to avoid slipping and falling into ~e well. We did all this without a safety belt or even the thought of one. The first pull was the hard one. The remainder of the turns of the pipe were easy. When the pipe joint separated, the pipe fell about six or eight inches and exposed the sucker rod joint. The sucker rod prevented the whole thing from falling to the bottom of the well. With two wrenches I unscrewed the sucker rod joint and the pipe fell a little further and dangled by the rope Eugene was holding topside. Then came the most difficult part of all. Still precariously perched in the shaft of the well with my feet lodged on protruding rocks, I lifted the pipe, sucker rod and cylinder, all together, straight up by main strength, hand under hand, up and out of the well until I could lean the top 'of the pipe on an overhanging limb of a tree. After that, Eugene and I working above ground took the pipe and put it on the wagon with a long part of it sticking out in the back of the wagon. We removed the pump jack and placed it on the wagon, and headed for the well at the creek, not caring whether the mules hurried or not. There we did the reverse procedure, putting the engine in place on its platform, the pump jack on the well cover and the pipe with the sucker rod and cylinder into the well. lt was a little bit easier to put the pipe into the well than to talce it out. However, reconnecting the sucker rod and the pipe were more difficult because I had to pull upward lifting the entire assembly while at the sam~ timing starting the threads. I did it by ~ain strength and awkwardness, as Papa would say. It was a hard days work, but it actually took probably about three hours. If the dry weather lasted and the well at the creek went dry that meant bringing the pump and engine back to the cistern at the barn, and hauling water and dumping it into the cistern. This would have to continue until the next rainy season. But hauling water is another story.

• Historical Background 89 Digging a Well I never believed in water witches. But Papa did, at least enough to give it a try. Moving the pump from the cistern at die barn to the well at the creek and back again so many times and hauling water from the South Prong of the Waxahachie Creek during especially dry summers made water-witching seem more believable, at least to Papa. In about 1939 or 1940, he engaged a water witch, a man about his age or a little older, to come to Grandpa's place, where we lived at that time, and witch for water. He paid him fifteen dollars, as I remember it Papa showed the man the general area in which he would like to have a well. The location was -in the pasture, down the hill from the house and about fifty to seventy-five yards from the creek. The man brought with him a fresh cut fork of a peach tree limb, each branch about two and a half feet long. Holding it tightly but awkwardly in his fists and bending the branches so as to create tension ~ them, the man walked about somewhat like a bird dog searching for the scent. The area he covered approximated a circle ofabout seventy-five to one·hundred feet i1!9iameter. He walked with the main configuration of the "y" shaped peach limb in a horizontal plane. After a while the forked stick went down as if to point to a specific spot The water witch declared that there was water in.t he ground there. That was the place to dig a well. Papa paid the man, and he left. I never saw him again. Not many days later Uncle Roy and I begain to dig a well at that spot. We got down to twenty feet or more, and there being no sign of water, no change of the rock formations, no cracks or crevices, Papa decided that was going to continue to be a dry hole. We stopped digging there, but Papa arbitrarily, without consulting the water witch or another water witch, chose another location about fifty or more feet away. There we dug a second well. This time we dug water. The main hand tools for digging a well in solid limestone are a pick, a shovel, and an auger. Also essential are a windlass, some black blasting powder, and some fuse. This was my first (and only) experience of digging a well. I • knew about digging into limestone because I had dug fence post holes into the solid rock with a crowbar. We did not use blasting powder for fence post holes, so therefore, I had no first hand knowledge of the uses of black powder. But uncle Roy was acquainted with the technique. I wish I knew whether he had ever dug a well before this, and if so when and where. Long before 1940 nearly every farm was equipped with wells and cisterns, usually a cistern at the house and another at the barn. Also, long before this time a good many farms had machine dug wells. Those wells were much deeper and went into different strata from hand dug wells. It may be, it is very likely, that the well Uncle Roy and I dug was the last hand dug well in that entire region of Texas. To dig such a well as we dug, you begin with a pick and a shovel. Loosen the ground with the pick in a circle about five feet or more in diameter. Throw the dirt out with the shovel. At our location we were soon into shale. The shale required more effort with the pick, but as yet there was no need for blasting powder. By three feet down we were into solid rock. Time to start blasting. The technique was to drill ;i hole with an auger, put in powder and fuse, light it with a match, get out of the well in a hurry and wait for it to go off, then get back into the well with pick and shovel and remove the loosened rock. · It was important to shorten the radius of the wall by about four inches all around once we reached a suitable level of solid rock so as to leave a ledge on which to rest the first course of bricks. The bricks could be put in place without mortar up to near ground level. This was the foundation of the curbing, which would be made after all the digging was completed. But more about that later. The use of the rock auger and the setting of the charge of powder deserves description. I did nearly all of this part of the operation. The rock auger was made of iron. It was about three and a half feet long, and it had a wooden handle about eighteen inches long, and it formed a "T' at the top. It was operated by twisting it clockwise with both hands while at the same time pressing down on it. Each motion was of 180° . ., -To set off an effective charge> I drilled a hole in the solid rock about-eighteen inches deep, frequently removing the auger from the hole so as to keep the hole clear of rock debris. This augering required about twenty to thirty minutes of very hard work. When I reached the desired depth, Uncle Roy sent down the powder, some fuse and some newspaper. I used about one and one half cupfuls of powd~r. First I poured about half or less of the powder in the hole I had drilled, and then I inserted the end of a two foot section of fuse, poured in the remaining powder and stuffed in a wad of newspaper. Then with an iron bar, I tamped rock dust and debris in around the fuse a little at a time, until it was full. The wad of newspaper was to keep the powder from being mixed with the rock dust and debris. Tamping in

I lit the fuse with a match, stepped into the bucket and held on to the rope with my hands, and Uncle Roy lifted me up with the windlass We both ran to a safe distance and sat down on the ground and waited. Soon, it went boom! Ifithadnotgone off we probably would not have gone back into the well until the next day. But I do not recall ever having a charge fail to explode. · As we proceeded downward with our digging, I placed the charges about six to ten inches inside the intersection of the wall of the vertical shaft and the existing floor. These charges were about 60° apart. The force of the explosion was contained by the firm, undisturbed rock of the wall and the floor. The least resistance was offered on a vector line formed by the vertical wall and the horizontal floor. I seldom had to set a charge in the middle of the floor because the force of the explosion usually reached that far. In placing the charges, I had to pay some attention as to whether we were descending on a perpendicular line. This factor was nol:.difficult to judge, however, because the rope and the rock bucket, coming and going time and again, made a excellent plumb line. We set these charges of black powder off one at a time because it would have been difficult and hazardous to try to coordinate multiple charges. Had we used dynamite and electric detonators, we would have been up to date in our technology, and we could have set off as many as six charges at a time (all around the shaft at once), but I doubt that procedure would have been better in our particular operation. When I look back and assess hazardous occupations, I put digging that well near the top of the list. Handling the blasting powder was safe as long as we followed the correct procedure and also provided I got out of the well in time. Perhaps a greater danger was that something might go wrong with the windlass while Uncle Ray was raising a bucket ofrocks. I always stood to one side while he was taking it up, but there was not enough room in that well to be certain of being out of the way if the rope broke, or something went wrong with the windlass, or Uncle Roy lost coordination of his hands and feet or had a heart attack. (One hazard we did not have was a cave in, and that for obvious reasons) Digging that well was just one among many dangerous jobs on a farm. Driving a tractor and operating at threshing machine or a hay baler offered many possibilities for being seriously hurt of even killed. By common sense we knew better than to go back down into the well while the rock dust and powder smoke were still present. It would linger for a long time unless we forced it out. We had an ingenious way of getting it out. We held a wagon sheet down into the well. This sheet was about fourteen by six feet, and after the well got deeper we fastened two of them together end to end. We held it so that three or four feet ofit was above ground. We turned the side of it to the wind, and if there was even as much as a slight zephyr, this technique cleared the well of bad air in no time at all. The wind (even far less than it would take to fill a ship's sails) built up pressure on the windward side of the sheet and forced the smoke and dust down and then out on the leeward side. I enjoyed watching that marvelously effective and inventive procedure. And to this day any such clever way to do something is a thrill to me. I recall that we made about two feet per day (maybe three). When we reached a depth of about twenty-five feet we came to a variation in the rock. There was a crack in the rock and a vein of open space big enough to get my hand in. No one would ever know how far that vein extended. It ran horizontally and quartz lined one side of it. (I have always wondered if the quartz was geologically significant.) [It is likely that the quartz referred to here was actually crystalline calcite.] There was moisture present and a little wet clay. But there was no water. Ifwe were going to get water, this should have been it! This was an emotion producing occasion. There was disappointment - as if we had a chance to get water and missed it through no fault of our own. There was a loss of hope and expectation. Why go on digging? Why not call the whole thing off? We continued to dig for a day or two more. Maybe we would yet find water. Since we did not know what to do, we could just keep on digging until a choice became clear. Finally, at a depth of twenty-seven or thirty feet (for some reason I remember both of those numbers but I don't know which) we quit. I never went do~n to the bottom of that well again. We took away the windlass and carried all our tools and our gear up the hill to the shop. That was sometime in November in •J 939 or 1940. We closed the book on the well, never to dig again, and went about other chores. There was no rain during November, none in Decemeer, but some time in late January or early February it rained for days and days. It was the kind of r~in that soaks the earth as far down as ~ater can go. After several days of rain I went to brave a look at the new well. It was brim full, level to the top of the ground, but I knew that this meant nothing in itself. It just seemed so strange after climbing in and out of that dry hole so many times. Saving the Soil The soil in the part of Ellis County, Texas, where·we grew up was shallow and the terrain was rolling. In less than a hundred years the top soil had nearly all eroded away, at least in places. The land was almost new when great Grandfather Paul settled there around 1870. It was still good enough during the working life of Grandpa Lawson Paul for him _to become a moderately successful farmer. But Papa was born too late to prosper. Too much soil had washed away and too little was left. There were places in the fields where there was scarcely enough dirt left on top of the solid limestone to sprout seed, and certainly not enough dirt left to grow a crop. • Places such as these were almost always at the edge of the field and bordering on a small, dry tributary to a branch ofa creek. By the end of the 1930's (and even before that time) there was simply no use i,n plowing and planting that kind of ground. Papa determined to put fences around those areas and include them in the permanent pasture. Native grass soon re-established itself there, and although the soil was nowhere near as good as it had been before it was first plowed, such grass as did begin to grow there was worth at least a little. . This fencing off what had been crop land and turning it into permanent pasture took place on Grandpa's farm not long before World War II. We had moved there in the fall of 1938, following Mamma's death in August of that year. The fences we put up were of three stands of barbed wire, and we used home-grown bois d'arc posts. Raymond Carter and I put up several hundred yards offence. We cut the posts ourselves. We used the largest, straightest ones for the comers and the smaller ones for line posts. A comer post required a hole about 12 to 15 inches in diameter and no less than 20 to 24 inches deep (more if the ground was all dirt and no rock). Often this meant digging into solid limestone, and there was only one way to do it -chip away the stone with a crowbar, and take out the debris by hand, alternately pounding with the crowbar and stopping to take out the broken and shattered rock. An eight to ten inch bois d'arc post set in such a hole had a life expectancy of 50 to 75 years or maybe more. The sap wood around the outside edges of the post would decompose, especially at near ground level, but the heart wood was incredibly hard and durable. We used one of Papa's innovations on those comer posts. Instead of bracing the comer post in the usual way with another post pushing against the tension of the wires, Papa had us use~ guy wire. We made the guy wire of several strands of plain wire (no barbs) and anchored it to a dead man. The dead man was four of five inches in diameter and a piece ofbois d'arc about 12 to 15 inches long. We buried it in the ground about 15 inches deep. This technique is commonly employed in the construction of electric poles and line. The dead man and guy wire arrangement was definitely superior as far as anchoring the comer post was concerned. But the comer post was often needed to support a gate, an~ the guy wire was in the space where the gate needed to be. We never overcame the disadvantage of having the guy wire in the way. All things considered the conventional style of fencing is better. But in any case, fencing eroded land and putting ir into permanent p~ture was, and is, recommended by soil • scientists. Papa's program was a good one, although Grandpa Paul seemed only half-hearted in his approval of it. The fencing project was good, but to make an obvious pun, it only touched the edge of the problem. The larger expanses of the fields had eroded very badly. Not only was much of the soil already lost for ever, large gullies had
