## Page 118

92 Jurney formed, some of which were deep enough to be impassable with a plow. To continue to plow and plant fields in this condition meant additional erosion, and at an ever increasing rate. Also, it meant ever decreasing yields. The answer was contour terracing. Almost every field on every farm in the entire area needed to be terraced. However, all of the farmers for miles around rejected the idea. It meant running the rows parallel to the contour lines rather than making them straight and parallel to one side of the field. Long before my time straight rows had come to be regarded as virtuous, and crooked rows meant lack of character. A good farmer made his rows straight in just the same moral reference as he told the truth. A "good" farmer was a man who was effective at fanning, and he was one whose straight rows revealed his true character. This was a Victofian concept, and like some other 19th Century ideas, it continued to have a powerful influence long after it was known to be misleading. Grandpa never endorsed terracing, although I never heard him appeal to the· claim that good· character was manifested by making straight rows. He remained indifferent to the value of terracing even after we made them and the benefits had become evident He refused to acknowledge the fact that terracing saved the soil and thaLwhereas the gullies had been getting deeper and wider, they were now filling up with dirt Also, on the top part of the terrace ridge where the soil was deeper (because it had been piled up in the terracing process) the cotton or com was noticeably more productive. But Grandpa Paul said that advantage was canceled out by the fact that in the channel of the terrace where the dirt had been excavated to make the ridge the plants were less productive. That was true, but Papa was much chagrined because Grandpa had missed the whole point. No other farmer in our neighbor and few in the entire region terraced his land. It meant having crooked rows, and besides that it meant extra work. Also, it required some of the skills of surveying. Papa got instructions and encouragement from the county agent. We did our first terracing on the Hawkins place [41ELl67; see Chapters 5 and 6, Boz Quadrangle] in the mid- 1930's. I helped Papa run the contour lines and helped him build the terraces as-well. The technique for running the contour lines was not so difficult to learn. A little math, some common sense and a will to make it happen were all that was needed. We borrowed a level from the county agent, one I presume he had for the purpose of fending. I vaguely remember that it was called a transit level, which is the instrument of civil engineering and land surveying. But this instrument was simpler than a transit level. It consisted of a telescope on a swivel base, which had three leveling screws. This telescope was mounted on a tripod. It was about the same kind as those used on a deer rifle, having cross hairs and a power of about 4 or 6. The idea was to set up the instrument and adjust the three screws so that the telescope was level in all directions. Anything in the cross hairs in any direction, 360 degrees, was level with the end oft he telescope. The procedure we followed to layout the first terrace was about as follows. First we determined that the best place to empty the water was into the road ditch on the north side of the field. Next we chose the spot along that ditch where we wanted the first terrace to end. We drove a stake into the ground there and set up the tripod of the level several yards away. I set the elevation rod on the ground at the stake and adjusted it so that the target was in the cross hairs of the telescope. (The target was a disk of wood about six or eight inches in diameter, divided into quadrants, which were painted alternately red and white.) Then I adjusted the elevation rod (which was calibrated in inches and feet) to make the target four inches closer to the ground and walked a hundred feet away from the first stake to the place where I guesed the next stake should go. I faced the telescope and held the elevation rod upright and resting on the ground. Papa viewed the target through the telescope. Then he motioned with his left or right hand to move me laterally (keeping about 100 feet from the first stake) up or down the slope until the elevation target was in the cross hairs of the telescope. This point was four inches higher than the first stake. There I drove another stake into the ground and moved on another 100 feet. When we reached the border of the field with the last stake, we came back to the 'road ditch and moved down a suitable distance and laidout the next terrace, and so forth. The stakes marked the course of the terrace. The terrace was a wide channel made by excavating the dirt and putting it on the down-slope side of the channel to make a continuous ridge. The channel and the ridge were of such dimensions that four rows cou~d be planted between the ridge top and the bottom of the channel, and four rows could be planted on the down-slope side of the ridge. Such a contoured terrace left all the ground cultivable. The water was made to run down hill at only four inches of fall per I 00 feet, and that was slow enough to prevent erosion. In the nature of the case the terraces were more or: less parallel to each other. They were close enough to each other to prevent any large accumulations of water, but no closer than was needed. I helped Papa build those terraces with mule power and a small primitive grader. I have one particular field of about 60 acres in mind as I write this.

4. RESEARCH DESIGN David H. Jurney and J. M. Adovasio with Contributions by M Raymond Buyce, David R. Ped/er, Kevin J. Shaunessy, and Joseph L Yedlowski INTRODUCTION This chapter describes the development of the formal Research Design utilized to guide the cultural resource investigations undertaken in support of the Superconducting Super Collider (SSC) project. The SSC Research Design was an evolving concep~ ultimately incorporating specific ecological, culture-historical, and "middle range" research questions as well as explicit surveying and testing methodologies. As such, this chapter also represents, by default, a history of the SSC Archaeological project. The development of the Research Design is therefore discussed within the framework of a series of more or less chronological stages. The Secretary of Energy identified the Ellis County, Texas site as the preferred alternative foi; the location of the • SSC on 10 November 1988. The site-selection process culminated with the Department of Energy's (DOE) decision to proceed with the SSC and to formally select the Ellis County site in its Record ofD ecision: Superconducting Super Collider (6450-01) (54 Federal Regulations 3651, 18 January 1989). Initial ground-disturbing activities within the proposed SSC footprint took place in 1989 in the form of geotechnical borings (geotechnical boreholes or "geobores") and trenches which were excavated in order to provide geotechnical characteri7.ation of the SSC site. Prior to the initiation of these ground-disturbing activities, it was necessary to conduct a cultural resources survey to ensure that the proposed construction activities would not inadvertently impact any prehistoric or historic resources potentially eligible for nomination to the National Register of Historic Places ~). Protection against adverse impact of potentially eligible NRHP resources is required under several federal laws and regulations, including, but not limited to: the Antiquities Act of 1906 (P.L. 59-209; 34 STAT. 225; 16 USC 431-433); the Historic Sites, Buildings, and Antiquities Act of 1935 (P.L. 74-292; 49 STAT. 666; 16 USC 431-433); the Archaeological and Historical Conservation Act of 1974 (P.L. 93-291; 88 STAT. 174; 16 USC 469); the National Historic Preservation Act of 1966 (P.L. 89-655; 80 STAT. 915; 16 USC 470) and subsequent amendments; the National Environmental Policy Act of 1969 (P.L. 91-190; 91 STAT. 852; 42 USC 4321-4347); Executive Order Number 11593 of 1971 (36 CFR 9821); and the Archaeological Resources Protection Act of 1979 (P.L. 96-95; 94 USC 2987) and subsequent amendments. PRELIMINARY RESEARCH DESIGN • Although incorporated more by reference than by specific discussion, the preliminary Research Design submitted to DOE (ARP 1989a) stipulated that the assessment of identified archaeological resources was to be based on the criteria for inclusion in the NRHP. The significance criteria for archaeological or architectural properties, usually at least 50 years old, state that the quality of significance may be embodied in property types such as a building, structure, district, site, object, or artifact that possesses integrity of location, setting, feeling, association, and: Criterion A. that are associated with events that have made a significant contribution to the broad patterns of history; or Criterion B. that are associated with the lives of persons significant in our past; or Criterion C. that embody the distinctive characteristics of a type, period, or method of construction; or that represent the work of a master; or that possess high artistic values; or that represent a significant and distinguishable entity whose components may lack individual distinction; or Criterion D. that have yielded or may be likely to yield information importani-in prehistory or history (36 CFR 60.4). The evaluation of the NRHP eligibility of archaeological and architectural sites requires consideration of all four criteria of significance. As such, historic properties as defmed in 36 CFR 60.4 include both prehistoric and historic archaeological and architectural sites as well as bridges, cemeteries, roads, and river crossings. The evaluation process involves going beyond simple archaeological or architectural considerations to include historical factors and other contextual data. While significance evaluations of prehistoric sites remain essentially an archaeological exercise, the evaluation of historic sites requires the integration of several very different disciplines. On the other hand, it is just as important to also apply all four criteria to prehistoric sites, not just Criterion D, as is common practice. Consequently, an archaeological site is assessed not only for its buried contents but also for its association with significant events or and • broader patterns of events important to local regional history as well as for the notoriety or importance of the ; persons who occupied it For prehistoric archaeological sites, Criterion A could include sites which represent specific population movements from the Brazos River drainage to the Trinity River drainage (see Chapter 2). This report, following the Council ofTexas Archaeologist's (CTA) Guidelines for Professional Performance Standards (CTA 1987:Performance-l through Performance-3), included an expanded Research Design that was much more comprehensive than the "bare-bones" version initially submitted to DOE (ARP 1989a) as it provided a focused series of research questions specifically relevant to the cultural resources which had been identified within the SSC project area up to that time (see below). The architectural evaluation of buildings within both fee simple and stratified subsurface fee estates (i.e., the HSMP) was completed through the combined efforts of DeLara Almond Architects and the ARP (DeLara Almond Architects/ARP 1992). This work included the assessment and evaluation of38 sites containing over 70 buildings. Eighteen buildings were recommended. as eligible for the NRHP and various levels of documentation were recommended according to the Historic American Buildings Survey (HABS) standards (Athearn 1990; Bums 1989; NPS n.d.a, n.d.b, 1985, 1986) and standards for moving of eligible buildings (Curtis 1979). The report defined a Historic _ Context (Agricultural Settlement, Farming. and Building Traditions in Rural Ellis County, Texas, .4.D. 1850 to 1945), which, although written for the evaluation of architectural resources, also bas relevance to historic archaeological resources. The 18 buildings noted above were thus evaluated according to their association with the agrarian culture of rural Ellis County. Subsequent HABS mitigation of these buildings was undertaken by the consortium of ArchiTexas/Solamillo/Hardy-Heck-Moore (1992). · The fmal report has not yet been published. Archaeological investigations of some of these architectural sites, even those deemed insignificant for architecture, were independently conducted by DOE as part of the investigations being reported herein (see Chapters 5 and 6). So-called "fast track'' archaeological investigations had occasionally been required since the inception of the SSC project for untested archaeological sites and previously unsurveyed land parcels within high priority construction rones. The DOE requests for rapid cultural resource clearances of SSC construction rones became more frequent in 1991 and subsequent years. Since shovel test probing and artifact collection were not authorized in the iI\itial stage of investigations (see Initial Survey, above), it was necessary to revisit many areas in order to suffici$lntly document the presence or absence of potentially significant cultural resources (see Chapters 5 and 6). A Task Order approach for individual construction tasks was ultimately operationalized which typically required the g«:neration of individual letter reports of cultural resource investigations (fable 4.1). This approach allowed DOE to both meet its construction schedules and its obligations to the compliance process and the THC. This task order approach ultimately resulted in the production of 31 letter reports of investigations. Several attempts were made to reduce the redundancy of effort which this "piece-meal" approach entailed. For instance, in 1991 the THC allowed DOE to proceed with the drilling of proposed geobore loci in advance of the submission of letter reports which documented only negative results from the cultural resource investigations. This initial attempt to expedite the compliance process was subsequently extended to other small-scale infrastructure projects such as the Vertical and Horirontal Survey Monument program. Ultimately, as funding permitted, DOE began to request cultural resource clearances for entire fee simple land parcels, rather than for just construction zones of immediate priority. In 1993 the THC allowed DOE to proceed with construction in areas of impact ofless than 35 acres (14.16 ha) in advance of the submission ofletterreports which documented only negative results from the cultural resource investigations. · By early in 1992, the bulk of the fee simple estates in the SSC project area had been subjected to Phase I survey and a number of recorded sites awaited Phase II testing to determine their NRHP eligibility status. At the request of the THC, an updated draft Research Design was produced which proposed a specific theoretical and methodological approach to the testing of the archaeological properties which had been identified within the SSC project.area. A revised version of this Research Design was accepted later that year (ARP 1992a) and elements oft he methodology were further refined the following year with the submission of the Archaeological Data Recovery Plan/or the Superconducting Super Collider Project Area, Ellis County, Texas (Ye dlowski 1993). The Research Design for the site testing phase (Phase II) of the SSC Archaeological project articulated a series of research questions which, as a result of the paucity of prehistoric cultural resources ide~tified up to that time~ were heavily biased in favor of prehistoric research. The research questions proposed for the historic resources in the project area essentially represented a reworking of the Historic Questions previously articulated in the interim report and discussed above (see Development of the Interim Research Design). Why is this information useful for interpreting Texas prehistory, specifically, and what implications does this information have for archaeological research in general? · Primary Research Context · One of the primary research topics for the SSC archaeological and historical investigations is focused on human adaptations and human ecology of the Blackland Prairie in north-central Texas. In its simplest form, it is focused on better understanding of the local culture history of this part of Texas. Several major studies of the counties in and around Ellis County have recognized the somewhat unique prehistoric cultural complexes or phases of this portion of Texas [see Chapter 2]. The nearest definitive culture-historical study of direct consequence to the SSC project area is the research conducted for the Richland/Chambers Reservoir (Richland Creek) by SMU (e.g., Bruseth and Martin [editors] 1987; McGregor and Bruseth [editors] 1987). The latter volume is aptly titled Hunter-Gatherer Adaptations along the Prairie Margin. Recovery of data from 15 key prehistoric sites in this reservoir provided a strong outline of local culture history and technological change just south of Ellis County along a primary tributary Qf the Trinity River • for the past 4,000 years. Various analytical techniques have isolated five cultural periods/phases within three major environmental periods that have occurred since ca 3000 B.C. Lithic industries, settlement patterning, population indices, ceramics, subsistence emphases, and territoriality were reconstructed from the large-scale excavations and resultant data sets. The data presented in the Richland Creek prehistoric volumes offer a strong local data set useful for investigating the peculiar settlement patterning and culture-historical dynamics within the SSC project area The peculiar cultural development of this same area in the Historic period adds further data for understanding the interplay between humans and their local environment Ellis County developed a heavy focus on cotton agriculture in the second half of the nineteenth century and eventually out-produced the cotton yields of some entire states. The Blackland Prairie soils, coupled with specific technological developments, combined to steer Ellis County toward cotton dominance. The tum of the century mansions still standing in Waxahachie and Ennis are vestiges of the wealth accumulated under a socially disparate cotton-based economy. Consequently, human ecology is an especially important factor in the cultural development of Ellis County between 1850 and 1950. The human ecology theme crosscuts prehistory and history. While this framework for site significance evaluations encompasses a broad array of prehistoric and historic archaeological contexts, it does not eliminate the role that the NRHP criteria play in helping to identify significant sites. Instead, the human ecology research framework provides the fabric upon which individual sites gain greater importance in our understanding of past peoples, places, periods, and events. As regards the SSC study area, human ecology operates at two different geographical scales. First, the physiography and ecology of Texas provides a natural laboratory for studying variation in human settlement and exploitation over the landscape. The dynamic regional interplay, or even stasis, between groups living on the southern terminus of the High Plains and those adapted to the Eastern Woodlands would involve transitional areas that include the Blackland Prairie in Texas. On the other end of the scale, the differences within Ellis County [see Chapter l] provide a fmer level of spatial analysis useful to studying human ecology. The valley bottom environments in comparison to broad upland ridges and prairies offer different microenvironments and resources for exploitation. The microhabitat between the East Campus and the West Campus offer some research variables possibly useful for studying minor but • important differences in prehistoric and historic· settlements and sites . :..:

## Page 140

114 Jurney and Adovasio Marginal Versus Non-Marginal Resources Based on the research conducted to date, it is our opinion that the SSC study area is, in every sense of the term, marginal both prehistorically and historically (i.e., during the pre-railroad/pre-l 870s period). Unfortunately, the term "marginal" has assumed negative connotations in CRM planning where none are actually implied by that label sui generis. We stress that we are employing the term "marginal" in a non-pejorative, strictly archaeological sense and are referring to a state or condition in which the apparent prehistoric and historic record of.the study area is simply outside of, or, more accurately, peripheral to, the mainstream of socio-cultural developments for adjacent portions of Texas. Put another way, marginality of and by-itself is neither "good" nor "bad," "significant" nor "insignificant" It is the condition or state in which a vast majority of the world's archaeological and historic sites exist, yet marginality per se · is a poorly studied phenomenon. In the specific context of the SSC study area, marginality describes a condjtion or set of interactive e,onditions. in which both the archaeological manifestations and the geoarchaeological settings in which they occur are different in degree and kind from their counterparts to the north and southwest and east. The sites, as noted above, are ephemeral and seem to reflect ( on the basis of surficial materials) transient utilization by highly mobile groups for short periods of time. Moreover, the array of distinct behavioral sets reflected by these sites seems, again on the basis of surface remains, to be highly circumscribed. Comparative Studies in Marginality The importance of small, surficial, and other marginal prehistoric sites is unquestioned in the archaeological exploration ,of the full dimensions of past human experience. Small sites often repr~nt short moments in archaeolQgical time (Moseley and Mackey 1972) where assemblages may be relatively pure and unmixed by subsequent occupations. In these situatiQns, limited activity sites may be helpful in delineating culturally meaningful assemblages useful toward the study of larger more complex sites. Other examples of investigations of small, plowed, or other types of marginal. sites indicate that meaningful information and important data can be recovere4, from careful field examinations (see Binford et al. 1970; Leeds 1974; McManamon 1976; Robertson 1976; Roper 1976; Talmadge and Chessler 1977). In many areas oft he United States where large stratified sites simply do not exist-except within valley margins-small, seemingly insignificant upland sites may be used to understand the broader settlement system and cultural adaptations (Dancey 1974). It is absolutely necessary that small, marginal, plowed sites be carefully considered in the development of cultural resource management plans and research designs and not simply dismissed a priori when conducting cultural resource studies (Cowgill 1975; Asch 1975; McManamon 1976; Schiffer 1976). We believe the lesson from these studies in the present context is obvious. It is our contention that the SSC area is at least as marginal as any of those discussed above. Moreover, it is equally apparent that careful scrutiny of selected sites within the SSC area-if properly executed--could provide substantive data on the phenomenon of marginality similar to any othe.r study conducted to date. Through focusing on the issue of marginality, investigation of selected prehistoric and historic sites in the SSC study area will also yield data on more conventional issues in local Texas prehistory. . Preliminary Orientation of Prehistoric Research Resolution of the prehistoric research questions for the SSC project area and the broader issue of marginality is presently hampered by the lack of surface collections or detailed stratigraphic data from SSC sites. Moreover, there is a distinct possibility that buried archaeological sites with no surface components exist in portions of the study area where aggradation has demonstrably occurred. To date [i.e., as of September 1992], none of these localities has been invasively probed either to delimit sites, buried paleosols,' or episodically stable surfaces [see Chapters 6 and 1O ]. As a result, our present site sample must be considered unrepresentative of the full suite of archaeological resources which may exist in the study area. • As of this writing [i.e., Septembe_r 1992), 24 prehistoric sites and eight multicomponent prehistoric/historic sites had been recorded in the SSC project area. These sites range from isolated finds to light scatters of chipping debris and broken tools. Artifacts noted include broken dart points and tools made from non-local cherts. Bas~d on the

Finally, some lithic materials are definitely of non-local origin. The use ofnon-local cherts suggests that: (I) groups (or bands) were engaged in long range movements which took them to sources of cherts such as the Red River or Brazos River, or (2) non-local cherts and possibly tools were being exchanged as a part of broader regional systems ofreciprocity involving several groups (bands) who most likely (but not necessarily) spoke similar languages. Research questions have been included for further comparison of prehistoric archaeological sites, but further information will be necessary to evaluate each site's potential to address those questions. Sites in depositional settings which may have protected archaeological remains include 41EL96, 4 IEL97, 41 EL99, and 41EL110. These areas have received alluvial and/or colluvial deposition and stratified deposits may be present. Also historic land modification processes may have buried the original prehistoric landscape. Additionally, a systematic geologically and geomorphologically-based deep testing plan should be initiated to address the identification of buried sites in specific SSC contexts threatened by construction impacts. The distnoution of prehistoric sites will be evaluated against the presettlement vegetation for Ellis County. Sites which may potentially contain paleobotanical information include 4 IEL96, 41 EL97, and 4 lELI 27. Since the vegetation greatly influences the animals available for subsistence and material goods, the paleoenvironmental information has great relevance to past human activities and settlement strategies. As noted above, some sites appear to represent short-term uses of strategic landforms. Veneer gravels of Ogallala quartzites are one type of strategic resource, which may also have attracted prehistoric activity. The scientific value of such limited activity upland sites in north-central Texas is enhanced by the fact that no previous studies have been conducted on them. Historic Sites Research The following is excerpted, with minor modifications and additions, from the Research Design for Testing of Archaeological Properties in the SSC Project Area, Ellis County, Texas (ARP 1992a). The majority of the historic archaeological data base is derived from households, a basic unit of analysis (Deetz 1982:717). Household behavior is idiosyncratic, and material culture assemblages reflect that idiosyncrasy (Henry 1991: 11 ). In order to determine how well any household ·or site serves as a typical example of any socio-economic or ethnic group, the parameters, norms, symbols of membership, and life styles of that group must be defmed. Archaeological, architectural, archival, and ethnohistorical data for an aggregate of individual households can then be • used to define local, regional, and natjonal trends in consumer behavior at a given point in time and/or through time. Some archaeological studies of rural farmsteads and light industrial sites in north-central Texas have provided an empirical model of historic site structure and formation processes. A model of the aboveground features, yard areas, and fannstead layout of a typical Texas farmstead dating from the mid-nineteenth to the early twentieth centuries has

116 Jurney and Adovasio been modeled after the Richland Creek and Joe Pool Lake archaeological projects (Moir and Jurney 1987b; Jurney and Moir 1987; Jurney et al. 1988) [see Chapter 2). This model is also applicable to some SSC sites. The archaeological remains left from daily activities, foodways and subsistence societies, and other domestic chores form a broadcast "midden" of artifacts which demarcate the former landscape. These artifact middens tend to ring the locations of dwellings and some outbuildings. Their distributional patterns reflect some types of activities such as food processing, laundry, repair/remodeling of structures, and use areas around wells, privies, and cellars. Except for the current work on the SSC, studies of upland historic sites have been relatively limited in North Texas, with the reservoir projects noted above accounting for most large-scale investigations. Smaller scale investigations in several open pit lignite mines, have recently contnbuted data on a limited number of historic farmsteads (Espey, Huston & Associates, Inc. 1986a, 1986b, 1986c; Jurney [editor] 1992; Jurney and Green 1993). Few historic sites had been recorded in Ellis County prior to the SSC project; and none had received excavations or int~nsive investigations [see Chapter 2). To date [i.e., as of September 1992), in excess of 112 new historic sites (including dwellings, cotton gins; churches, schools, farmsteads) and six multicomponent prehistoric/historic sites have been recorded. These sites provide the opportunity to study some aspects of settlement patterning in upland settings. The upland settings of the SSC project were used in the pre-railroad Historic period for overland transportation, free-range husbandry, and row crop agriculture. With the construction of railroad lines, Ellis County was linked to major regional markets, involving Dallas-Fort Worth, Waco, Cleburne, Corsicana, and Kaufinan. The distribution of the Public Domain and land speculation greatly influenced the settlement of Ellis County. Many of the General Land Office and Ellis County surveyors such as B. J. Chambers, J. E. Patton, G. W. Cunningham, R. A. Davis, and R. M. Wyatt surveyed land within the SSC project area, and several actually owned some of the tracts which will be affected by the project [see Chapter 3). Also several early settlers (E. M. Brack, J. M. Dunaway, Samuel and John Billingsley, Peter Stout, 0. E. Dunlap, P. C. Sims, and B. F. Forrester) developed relatively large estates which contained a number of the cultural resources described in this report. Historic sites located on tracts belonging to land speculators and entrepreneurs may yield archaeological and archival evidence of their influence •on settlement, and include 41EL137 (E. M. Brack), 41EL75 (J.M. Dunaway), 41EL77 (B. F. Forrester), 41EL80 and 41EL81 (G. W. Cunningham), 41EL93 and 41EL95 (Peter Stout), and 41EL104 (a homestead which involved atypical activities ofR. M. Wyatt). The residential-occupation of sites may contain archaeological evidence of the material possessions as well as technological innovations of early settlers. Sites which could potentially address this question include 41EL59, 41EL62, 41EL75,41EL77,41EL79,41EL80,41EL81,41EL82,41EL84,41EL88,41EL109,41EL120,41EL121,41EL124, and 41EL135. Archival and informant information for all of these properties can provide many further details OQ land use and the material culture that circulated through the household. Economic and settlement responses to the introduction of the railroad may be addressed by sites dating prior to andaftertherailroad{l866-1872) and include41EL59, 41EL84, 41EL93, 41EL109, and41EL134. The railroad caused a major shift in the economic practices that the occupants of these sites followed. For example, cotton agriculture was not a major enterprise prior to the railroad because of the high costs for transportation. Instead, livestock grazing and subsistence agriculture were preferred. The East Campus area near Ennis was the first to be reached by the railroad ( ca. 1871 ), and fanning practices shifted to cotton growing much earlier there than in the West Campus area, which did not obtain a railroad until the early twentieth century. Farm success and failure can be measured by both long occupations and short occupations of sites, and information relative to this question could be provided by sites 41EL59, 41EL61, 41EL67, 41EL68, 41EL69, 41EL72, 41EL73, 41EL77, 41EL80, 41EL82, 41EL88, 41EL90, 41EL93, 41EL95, 41EL120, 41EL121, 41EL124, and41EL134. The relative success of a farm can be obtained not only through the archival record by examining tax and deed records, but also by farm abandonment ratios and examination of artifact assemblages to determine influx of new goods. Marriage patterns also greatly influenced the community fonnation and the structure offarms in Ellis County, with many women inheriting farms and·maintaining them during their lives. Sites which may address the implications of this Research Question include 41EL69, 41EL75, 41EL77, 41EL79, 41EL81, 41EL95, and 41EL100. For instance, Sarah Brack, the daughter of Judge ;E. M. Brack (41EL13 7), married J. M. Dunaway and together they fanned one of the most extensive estates (41EL75) in the West Campus area. Subsequently, several descendants intermarried with the Forrester family (41EL77). Several descendants and relatives still live in the area [i.e., as of 1993) and provide cultural continuity from initial frontier settlement to the present day.

The Two-tiered Approach to Site Testing In conjunction with the expanded research questions summarized above, the 1992 Research Design also proposed a two-tiered approach to Phase II investigations (i.e., site testing) for the SSC Archaeological Project. As noted above (see Development of the Site Testing Plan), Phase I investigations (i.e., the site survey or identification phase) were almost complete by this time, but further investigations were still required for many sites in order to adequately address the question ofNRHP eligibility. The proposed testing plan also included a geomorphological assessment of areas within the SSC footprint which bad the potential to contain deeply buried cultural resources. The two-tiered approach to site testing initially proposed in the 1992 Research Design (a lso articulated in the Archaeological Data Recovery Plan for the Superconducting Super Co/lider Project Area, Ellis County, Texas [Yedlowski 1993]) is sumrµarized below. Tier I Investigation Tier 1 site testing consisted of the excavation of shovel test probes (STPs) at ca. 20 m (65.62 ft) intervals along individual STP transects. Transects themselves were emplaced at ca. 20 m (65.62 ft) intervals with the STPs in consecutive transects staggered on 10 m (32.81 ft) cent~rs. For those sites which would benefit from closer interval STPs, STP and transect intervals were reduced to ca. 10 m (32.81 ft) centers with the staggered offset maintained. In some instances ( e.g., where a site·w as particularly smalt or where previou~ STPs indicated that a smaller sampling interval was potentially more productive), the probe and transect intervals were further reduced to ca. 5 m (I 6.41 ft). The amount of closer interval shovel testing performed depended on the particular site being tested. Shovel test probes measured ca. 50 cm (19.69 in) in diameter and were excavated to various depths below ground surface which were determined by the local depositional environments. Excavation was conducted via natural

Fill from all probes was dry-screened by arbitrary level through 6.4 mm (¼ in) hardware cloth (i.e., wire mesh). Data collected during the field portion of these Tier 1 investigations consist of stratigraphic descriptions including sediment characteristics, Munsell soil color designations, and stratigraphic sequences per shovel probe. These data were recorded on standard field forms. It was proposed that this Tier I level of investigation represented the most cost effective manner with which to begin to adequately address the question of a given archaeological site's eligibility for inclusion in the NRHP. Indeed, assess as a result of the Tier l investigatory process, it was possible to quickly and provide recommendations ofNRHP eligibility (i.e., eligible or not eligible) for many archaeological sites within the SSC project area, via a series of brief letter reports, to the DOE and the lHC (see Table 4.1 and Chapters 5 and~- For those sites whose status could not be adequately evaluated by this level of effort or which appeared to contain potentially significant archaeological deposits, a second tier of investigation (i.e.,..:Uer 2) was proposed. Tier 2 Investigation Tier 2 site testing was to consist of a more intensive level of investigation and was to be conducted where either: Tier I investigations had resulted in the identification of potentially significant deposits requiring a more intensive level of scrutiny than that afforded by Tier I, or/ the Tier I field methodology would be inappropriate ( e.g., as in the case of extensive surface artifact scatters or deeply buried sites). In certain situations, where the surficial scatter of materials is suggestive of minimal disturbance, it was proposed that surface artifact concentrations be mapped via an electronic total station as a matter of cotJrse. Though piece-plotting is normally prohibitively expensive when done with conventional optical survey equipment, the great speed and accuracy of an electronic total station allows for rapid and economical mapping of virtually any size surface scatter. Extensive studies have shown that in both prehistoric and historic site contexts, plowing and vertical displacement of artifacts--even in permafrost and soil creep situations-have only minimal effects on the horizontal distribution of artifactual materials. In comparative studies ( e.g., see East et al. 1989), piece-plotting has proven to be both economically viable and significantly more informative than controlled surface collections. It was stressed, however, that piece-plotting was not necessarily recommended for all SSC surface artifact concentrations and, should this strategy not prove to yield meaningful data, it could be discontinued. Similarly, it was proposed that if the local geology and geomorphology permit, the characteraation of subsurface cultural phenomena even on small open sites could also be productively augmented by the use of portable resistivity meters with on-board data loggers. In such cases, a grid can be superimposed on a suitable site and readings taken at Im intervals. Currently available third-generation geonic devices can "read" at 50 cm (19.69 in) intervals down to a maximum depth of 5 m (16.40 ft) with very high resolution. It was expected that the application of the techniques detailed above would allow for the deletion of a substantial · number ofs ites from further consideration. It was also deemed likely that a small proportion of the sites so tested would require further eligibility investigation. For all such sites, it was proposed to apply a ·uniform testing methodology based on the Drennan Sampling Model. The essence of the Drennan Sampling Model for site testing is avoidance of statistically invalid interpretations of a site's potential NRHP eligibility. This model has been thoroughly tested in a wide variety of site contexts in the Eastern and Western United States, and has demonstrated its usefulness in avoiding the pitfalls of making unsubstantiated statements of eligibility or non-eligibility. Furthermore, this testing model has been shown to actually save money by avoiding unwarranted mitigation of sites inadequately "sampled" using far less precise methods. The two principal, simultaneous goals of the Drennan Sampling Model are: to establish the presence or absence in a given area of intact subsurface features; and to elucidate the integrity and character of subsurface deposits. As Drennan (1990) notes: Our approach has been ti;> concentrate on the psesence or absence, in a given area, of in situ features. Clearly, the only way to be absolutely certain that no in situ features exist in a given area is to excavate the entire site. No matter how large a· sample is excavated, if there is one square meter left out, there is always some possibility that there could be a feature in it This situation is unavoidable. Nevertheless, it is intuitively obvious that the more you excavate without finding any features, the more confident you can be about acting :.•

If you dig 50 squares and find none you can be much more confident about making such statements (although you can still not achieve complete certainly without complete excavation). It is also intuitively obvious that if there are many features in a site, you are much more likely to encounter some of them in a 50 square sample than if there are very few features in the site. To apply these principles to the task of establishing Phase II sample sizes requires only deciding what level of confidence such statements must be made at and how few features is few enough to risk overlooking [sic]. In all ofour projects, the standard has.been to speak at the 95% confidence level. (That is, we establish sample sizes sufficient to enable ·us to make statements about features in a site with only 5% chance that these statements are erroneous. These statements, then are statements of probabilities rather than certainties - because certainties can only be achieved with complete excavation.) In regard to numbers offeatures, we have treated features occurring in 5% or less of the one-meter squares in a site as a small enough number of features to risk overlooking. Ifwe make a rough guess that the "average" feature will show up in three one-meter squares (some will be bigger, some smaller), then this standard means we risk overlooking distributions as sparse as about 17 features in an area of 1000 square meters ((.051(1000]/3). In other words, our sample sizes are calculated to enable us to make the following statement about a site, if no in situ features are encountered in the sample: "We are 95% confident that there are Jn situ features in fewer than 5% of the one-meter squares in this site." If, on the other hand, evidence of in situ features is found in the sample, the standard statistical approaches to estimating the number of features in the entire site can be applied, although no guarantee can be made in advance about the confidence level at which such estimates can be made from a given sample. · · The sample sizes required to achieve this goal are as follows: •. The Potential for Deeply Buried Cultural Resources In conjunction with the expanded research questions summariz.ed above (see the 1992 Research Design), the 1992 Research Design also proposed a program for locating deeply buried, alluvial and colluvial sites within the SSC project area. The proposed program included a geomorphological assessment of areas within the SSC footprint which had the potential to contain deeply buried cultural resources and which were scheduled for direct construction impact The deep testing initially proposed in the 1992 Research Design was also articulated in the Archaeological Data Recovery Plan for the Superconducting Super Collider Project Area, Ellis County, Texas (Ye dlowski 1993) and is summariz.ed below. In addition to the sites identified via pedestrian reconnaissance and/or subsurface probing/coring, a geomorphological reconnaissance was conducted to determine areas where deeply buried sites might occur. The entire footprint was examined for deeply aggraded areas with potential for the preservation ~f archaeological sites. This detailed field scrutiny identified a total of72 upland and lowland loci which exhibit deep (i.e., > 1 m [3.28 ft]) sediments, and hence, potential for the preservation of deeply buried archaeological sites. All 72 loci are situated within the SSC footprint (Figure 4.1 ); however, only 42 of these localities were scheduled to receive direct impact from construction-related activities (Table 42). Each of the 42 loci to be impacted was assessed in terms of the following group of parameters: apparent depth of deposits; type and configuration of associated landforms; bedrock geology; apparent width of aggraded deposits; proximity to recorded prehistoric and historic period sites; and contiguity to Uvalde gravel veneers, which are potential sources of raw materials for flaked stone technology (see Chapter 1, Bedrock Geology). Applied against these criteria, 21 of the 42 loci to be impacted were initially recommended for deep testing (see Table 4.2). It was proposed that the deep testing operation would initially address the discovery of deeply buried sites utilizing backhoe trenching or, where relatively shallower deposits permitted, the hand excavation of test units. It was further proposed that conductivity surveys might be useful in the detection of subsurface anomalies and, thus, be used in lieu of, or in adjunct to, these invasive testing methods. · Finally, it was proposed that the total number of test units to be excavated during the deep testing operation be determined on a site-by site basis. As it turned out, however, the single locus to undergo deep testing (No. 67 in Table 4.2) was investigated via the "drilling" of a series of 3 in (7.62 cm) diameter continuous push cores along linearly continuous transect segments (see Chapter 6, Palmer Quadrangle, East Campus Connector Road Deep Testing). This revised deep testing methodology was judged to be more cost effective, expedient, and safer than that which was originally proposed. A list of the proposed SSC deep testing loci which still required cultural resource clearances due to planned rnc construction impacts was submitted to the in April of 1993 (Table 4.3). At that time these remaining loci were reevaluated according to their potential to provide information relevant to the research questions discussed above (see Geological and Ecological Research Questions) and a revised priority for deep testing investigations was 'atso submitted to the THC (Table 4.4). IMPLEMENTATION OF THE RESEARCH DESIGN The following chapters document the results of our cultural resource investigations in support of the SSC project. Numerous sites received Tier I investigations and many were determined to be.not eligible for inclusion on the NRHP; however, it was also determined tha~ several sites contained information that made them potentially eligible for nomination to the NRHP. Although concurrences for additional archaeological investigations (i.e., Tier 2 investigation) at these sites were received from the SHPO, no additional work was performed prior to the Congressional termination of the SSC project in October of 1993. A discussion of the ultimate success (or failure) of the SSC Research Design must await the final synthetic chapter of this report.

Jurney awd Jackie McElhaney INTRODUCTION Between the initiation of the Archaeology Research Program's (ARP) involvement with the Superconducting Super Collider (SSC) project in August 1989 and the Congressional termination of the project in October 1993, the entire SSC footprint received some form of archaeological survey and 154 sites were recorded (fable 5.1 ): 110 located within the SSC footprint; 24 partially within the SSC footprint; 19 entirely outside the SSC footprint but on stratified subsurface fee estate in close proximity to the footprint; and one on both fee simple and stratified subsurface fee estates but outside the actual footprint ( 4 IEL58). These sites include prehistoric, historic, and standing structures (i.e., bridges). As indicated in Chapter 4, field investigations were conducted on a priority basis in relation to construction activities. Thus, certain areas of the SSC footprint, specifically certain fee simple estates, received thorough investigations while other areas, specifically stratified subsurface fee estates, received little or no investigations beyond initial non-invasive pedestrian reconnaissance. As a result, field investigations recorded sites on seven of the nine USGS 7 .5' quadrangles on which the SSC footprint (see Figure 1.3) falls. Six additional sites which were recorded during the course of the project, but which are located well outside the SSC footprint, are described in Appendix C. As the title of this chapter indicates, the primary intention here is to provide brief locational and descriptive data for the 154 localities which were assigned trinomial site designations during the course of the archaeological investigations conducted in support of the SSC. Additionally, brief background narratives are provided for many sites in order to provide both historical context and a point of reference to the discussions of early settlers and agrarian development within Ellis County which were presented in Chapter 3. Finally, the types of investigations which were conducted at each site are indicated, although the results of all investigations subsequent to the initial non-invasive pedestrian reconnaissance (i.e., Tier I investigation and deep/mechanical testing [see Chapter 41) are presented separately in Chapter 6. The archival data presented below have been summarized from data previously presented in the Draft Interim Report (Jurney et al. 1990) and/or in various letter reports of investigations submitted to the U.S. Department of Energy (DOE) between September 1991 and June 1993. No formal archival research or informant interviews were conducted following the Congressional termination of the SSC project in October 1993. Consequently, the land-use histories of all sites were not researched equally. · A number of cartographic resources were utili7.ed to provide background information for historic sites. The oldest map currently available is the 1852 Hedgecoxe map of the Peters Colony, which depicts roads and some land grants (see Figure 3.3). A more refined map ofland grants has been compiled from original General Land Office (GLO) surveys dating from 1834 to 1888 (see Figure 3.2). Data for many of these GLO tracts were collected, and provide important baseline information about initial land ownership, and, in· some cases, residency patterns. A 1901 map of Ellis County depicts the roads and voting districts in the county at that time (Ellis County Commissioners Court [ECCC] 1901 ). This map, unfortµnately, does not show the location of farmsteads or other buildings, although community structures sucq as churches and schools, bridges, and industrial facilities such as 127

132 Yedlowsld, Jurney, and Shaunessy quadrangles site descriptions and discussions follow in ascending numerical order according to Texas Archeological Research Laboratory (TARL) trinomial site designation. All verbal site locations are reckoned relative to public transportation routes with distances given in cardinal directions. In all cases these cardinal directions are relative rather than absolute (i.e., directional vectors) and are either parallel or perpendicular to the given transportation route. For example the location of 41EL121 reads: "41EL121 is located ca. 1,676.40 m (5,500 ft) east of the intersection of Honeysuckle Road with Skinner Road and ca. 640.08 m (2,100 ft) north ofHoneysuckle Road." In actuality this site's location relative to these points of reference is east by northeast of the intersection of Honeysuckle Road with Skinner Road and north by northwest of Honeysuckle Road. All distances given are to the approximate site center, unless otherwise indicated. As a final note, and as is discussed in Chapter 11, the 1990 registration of certain sites (e.g., 41EL106, 41EL108, 41EL113, 41EL118, and 41EL180) within the SSC project area as prehistoric components whose boundaries corresponded to the maxim~xtent of contemporary surface exposures of Uvalde Gravel veneer deposits was done in error. These "components" were defined solely on the association of Uvalde Gravel veneer deposits with fractured chert nodules adjudged to be ''tested cobbles". The moratorium on artifact collecting imposed by the Texas National Research Laboratory Commission (INRLC) during the initial SSC archaeological survey (see Chapter 4) prevented the laboratory analysis of these ''tested cobbles" to determine whether.they were in fact anthropogenic. Subsequent subsurface testing at some of these components identified only minimal material culture remains while similar testing at several others did not identify bona fide flaked stone artifacts (see Chapter 11). Based upon these data, the Texas Historical Commission {THC) recommended that the sites in this latter group have their site numbers de-assigned. To this end, 41EL106, 41EL108, 41EL113, and 41EL118 have been de-assigned since subsurface testing in the immediate vicinity of these "sites" yielded no material culture remains. The remaining "Uvalde GraveVtested cobble site," 41EL180, was not de assigned since no subsurface testing was conducted at this locality in conjunction with the SSC project. At this juncture it is impossible to re-evaluate the size of any of the "Uvalde Gravel/tested cobble" components. WAXAHACHIE QUADRANGLE A total of nine archaeological sites were recorded on the Waxahachie 7.5' Quadrangle (Figure 5.1). Six of these sites are located within the SSC footprint, two totally and four partially. Two are located entirely outside the SSC footprint, but on stratified subsurface fee estate in close proximity to the footprint. A single site, while located entirely outside the SSC footprint, is located on both fee simple and stratified subsurface fee estates. 41ELS8 Location and Description 41EL58 is a site with both prehistoric and historic occupations/utilizations encompassing ca. 216.87 ha (535.89 acres) in the drainage ofan unnamed tributary of Mustang Creek. The site is located ca. 3.65 km (2.27 mi) east of the Waxahachie city limits along Texas F.M. 878. The site extends from the north side of Texas F.M. 879 in the south to just south of Broadhead Road in the north and in an east-west direction for an average of ca. 1.06 km (0.66 mi) along Texas F.M. 878 (Figure 5.2). The exact boundaries of the site correspond to the estate boundaries of the former Ellis County "Poor" Farm (see Figure 5.2). •.. Site Locations and Descriptions 135 0.014 ha [0.035 acres]) cemeteries, still in the possession of Ellis County. The remaining ca. 212.56 ha (525.24 acres) of the site served as agricultural fields. Since only limited subsurface investigations were conducted at this site (see Chapter 6) it is likely that other unrecogniz.ed and, consequently, undefined "special use" areas exist across the site. The central complex is located immediately south of Texas F.M. 878 at the western margin of the site (see Figure 5.2). When donated to 1NRLC the central complex consisted of one small barn, one large barn, one steel-reinforced brick 'jailhouse," one large brick and wood building, and one cement foundation. All of these features were at least partially standing when documented (see Chapter 6). The marked cemetery, located in the extreme southwest comer of the site (see Figure 5.2), covers ca. 2,500 m1 (26,909.75 ft2), based on the area delimited by an iron pjpe fence. The number of graves associated with this cemetery is unknown, although iron pipes are reported to have been originally · emplaced.to mark each grave. These markers are no longer visible; however, at least 73 individuals were interred at the County Fann (see below). The first of the unmarlced cemeteries is located in the southeast quadrant of the site (see Figure 5.2). The number of graves associated with this cemetery.J& unknown and therefore, the siz.e of this cemetery is, very tentatively, estimated to be ca. 92.90 m1 (1,000 ft2). The second of the unmarked cemeteries is centrally located within the site just south of Texas F.M. 878 (see Figure 5.2). A sandstone "marker" is present in this area and may indicate the location of at least one grave associated with this cemetery. Since the exact number of graves associated with this cemetery is unknown, the siz.e is, very tentatively, estimated to be ca. 46.45 m1 (500 ft2). The prehistoric occupation(s)/utilization(s) of the site consist of two discrete areas of dispersed Uvalde Gravel veneer deposits (see Figure 5.2). The first area is located in the northwest quadrant of the site and covers ca. 2.43 ha (6 acres) (see Figure 5.2). This portion of the site is located in an area of Houston Black clay, 1 to 3 % slopes. Elevation in this portion of the site ranges from ca. 167. 64 m ( ca. 550 ft) to ca. 170.69 m ( ca. 560 ft) above mean sea level. The second area is located in the southwest quadrant of the site and covers ca. 14.16 ha (35 acres)" (see Figure 5.2). This portion of the site is located in an area of Houston Black clay, 0 to 1 % slopes. Elevation in this portion of the site also ranges from ca. 167.64 m (ca. 550 ft) to ca. 170.69 m (ca. 560 ft) above mean sea level. At this time it is not known • if these two areas represent: two spatially and/or temporally discrete occupations/utilizations•( i.e., two separate archaeological sites); or two spatially discrete occupation/utilization areas of a horizontallY. continuous site (i.e., single archaeological site). Field investigations (see below) were insufficient to accurately define either the limits (i.e., a single site or multiple sites) or the nature of the prehistoric components. Therefore, they have not been assigned separate T ARL trinomial site designations from the distinctly historic component, the County Farm. Archival and Informant Data The County Fann was created following the acquisition of ca. 348 acres (140.83 ha) within the J.B. and Ann Adams Survey by Ellis County from J. F. Dunlap in 1882 (Office of Ellis County Clerk, Waxahachie, Texas [ECC] 1883:Deed Book [DB] 35:47-49). The farm was expanded in 1885 when ca. 51 acres (20.64 ha) in the adjacent W. T. Dunn Survey were purchased by the county from William and Lizzie Burnett (ECC 1883:DB 37:226). The circumstances under which county poorhouses and work farms in Texas were created for the care of indigents, mentally disturbed individuals, and convicted petty criminals are briefly discussed in Chapter 3. Oscar E. Dunlap, who was also mentioned briefly in Chapter 3, was elected County Judge in 18.82. In that capacity, he was instrumental in the creation of the County Farm. Dunlap settled in Ellis County in the 1860s, fanned for several decades, and was a self-taught lawyer and jurist. (lhis·was the same Judge Dunlap who allegedly identified a ''mastodon tooth" from sediments along Waxahachie Creek in 1912 [see Chapter 2].) An autobiography written by Dunlap's servant, Ely Green, who lived in the Waxahachie area from 1912 to 1919, sheds additional light on Dunlap's association with the Ellis County Farm in the 1910s. Apparently Dunlap maintained complete records (possibly in association with the Commissioners Court) on the operation of the County Farm, including crop yields and deaths (Gr~en 1970:251). . A review of County Death Records and Commissioners Court minutes provided the identities of 63 of the (at least) 73 people who died or were interred at the County Farm (Weston et al. 1990a:Table 7-3). Deaths were first recorded in the 1890s and continued to be recorded until 1946. Tltere is a significant.period (from 1906 to 1915) when death records are not present which coincid~ with the period when Judge Dunlap apparently encountered problems with the administration of the farm (Green 1970:218-251). Twenty-nine individuals who died were African American, twenty-three were Anglo-American, and three were Hispanic Americans. The ethnicity of 18 individuals was not

Causes of death included murder, suicide, senility, heart failure, Bright's disease, syphilis, malaria, burning, and paralysis (Weston et al. 1990a:7-5 to 7-6). The Report of the Superintendent from 9 May 1893 provides a representative sample of the crops that were produced, and the types of activities that occurred on the farm (ECC 1890-1894: Minutes of the Ellis County Commissioners Court, Volume K). Stock included 25 mules, one horse, 40 hogs, and 33 head of cattle. Crops included "20 acres of wheat sown, not good; 43 acres oats, good; 120 acres com, good; 13 acres millet; 7 acres sorghum" (Jurney et al. 1990:B-6 to B-7). Recorded activities included "Graded 16 miles Dallas-Marfa Road and 9 mi. graded and filled 17 culverts on Ennis-Corsicana Road" and "Paid $10 to Linda Bowman for attendqig sick pauper Mrs. Mary White. Paid $10 for ticket to Galveston for sick pauper Smith" (Jurney et al. 1990:B-7). · A list of County Farm residents in the Commissioners Court minutes that was dated 10 May 1898 noted that 10 "paupers" were "on hand," 8 paupers had been discharged, 9 "lunatics" were "on hand," and one lunatic had died (Jurney et al. 1990:B-8). On 10 August 1890, tbe..list of residents included five lunatics, and ten paupers, and further noted that one pauper had died and five had been discharged. The Report of the Superintendent on 14 November 1898 stated "62 convicts discharged and 30 convicts on the farm" (Weston et al. 1990a:7-5). Information regarding the early configuration of the County Fann is fragmentary and somewhat contradictory. A single large building is depicted on the 1901 Ellis County Map (Ellis County Commissioners Court 1901) in the present position of the central complex and likely represents a stylized depiction of at least several buildings. The marked cemetery which is located in the extreme southwest comer of the County Farm property (see Figure 5.2) is not depicted on the 1901 map. The 1941 Ellis County highway map (fexas State Highway Department [TSHD] 1952) also depicts only a single large building, but the cemetery is depicted with its long axis oriented roughly north-to-south. The 1955, 1959, and 1964 highway maps (fSHD 1957, 1961, and 1973) depict either four or five buildings with the positions of the buildings relative to one another varying somewhat from map to map. The marked cemetery is depicted on all of these post-1941 maps, but the long axis of the cemetery is oriented roughly east-to-west Green (1970:254) describes a visit to the farm, mentioning a gate and stockade office. At present, this is the earliest'known (ca. 1914) first-hand account of the configuration of the County Farm. The 1936 WPA survey indicates that 4 acres (1.62 ha) were reserved for the central complex, 10 acres (4.05 ha) for the garden, 285 acres (115.34 ha) were in cultivation (184 acres [74.46 ha] in com and oats, the remainder in cotton), and 28 acres (11.33 ha) were in pasture. The central dwelling (apparently the "pauper house") was a 80 ft x 100 ft (24.38 m x 30.48 m) brick building built in 1921. Other buildings extant at that time included: four frame residences (40 ftx24 ft [12.19mx 7.32m])whichhadbeen built in 1885; another32 ftx 18 ft(9.75 m x 5.49m) frame residence which had been built in 1912; one 20 ft x 40 ft (6.10 m x 12.19 m) brick residence which was used for storage; and another brick residence which was used to house prisoners. There were also five barns and four sheds. The plat map indicates that the central dwelling was located in the same place as the pauper house which was built in 1937 (see below) and that there was a cluster of buildings to the east of the pauper house on the tributary of Mustang Creek. Informants report that this area contained both the molasses mill, where sorghum was processed, and the "pest house," which was used to house those with contagious diseases (Ray McCullough, personal communication to D. H. Jurney 1990). The County Farm was closed in 1964. It was described in several Waxahachie Daily Light articles in 1974, when Ellis County attempted to sell the property (Weston et al. 1990a:7-4). A commemorative cornerstone dated 1937 was described for the extant pauper house, which had apparently been rebuilt on the same location as the central dwelling constructed in 1921 (see above). This stone; set in the southeast comer of the buil~g, has since beeq destroyed. A small brick building that current infonnants could not identify was termed a ''milkhouse" in the newspaper articles. The information gleaned from a variety of archival and informant sources allowed the function of many of the buildings which were still extant in 1989 to be determined (see Chapter 6). Therefore, ca. 182.11 ha (450 acres) surrounding the central •. complex was investigated by means of a non-invasive pedestrian reconnaissance. The portion of this parcel located within the East Campus and on which 4 IEL92 is located had fee simple rights purchased (i.e., fee simple estate), on behalf of the DOE, for the SSC project The site is located in an area of Houston Black clay, 0% to 1% slopes, at an elevation of ca 143.26 m (ca 470 ft) above mean sea level. The site was recorded in 1990 as a result of the initial SSC footprint archaeological survey and consisted of concrete foundation piers from a fonner building of unknown function, corrugated sheet steel, unidentified machinery and/or machine parts, and a dense scatter of artifacts. Archival and Informant Data The site appears to straddle the boundary between the 280 acre (113.31 ha) Buffalo Bayou, Brazos, and Colorado Railroad (BBB&C RR) Company Survey (east line) and the 150.66 acre (60.97 ha) R. A. Davis Survey (west line). The BBB&C RR Survey was granted to the rail company on 19 June 1860 in compensation for the laying of tracks. The R. A. Davis Survey was granted by the State of Texas in 1861 and was patented in 1871 (ECC 1886:DB 44:513). The BBB&C RR Survey was transferred by the railroad on 25 June 1860 to the firm ofW. H. Getzendaner, which, in tum, transferred it to R. A. Davis. Davis had it surveyed in 1861 and patented in 1869 (Office of Ellis County Clerk, Waxahachie, Texas [ECC] 1886:Deed Book [DB] 44:512). In May 1878, R. A. Davis obtained the 320 acre (129.50 ha) John Burnett Survey, which abutted his survey and the BBB&C RR Survey on the south, for $24.46 at public auction (ECC 1878:DB S:513). The addition ofth~se two surveys to Davis' 150.66 acre (60.97 ha) survey and a second R. A. Davis Survey which abutted the John Burnett Survey on the west and the BBB&C RR Survey on the south, resulted in the creation of a major {c a 900+ acre [36422+ ha]) landhol~g. · R. A. Davis immigrated to Texas in 1851. He settled first in Collin County and moved to Ellis County in 1854 (Lewis Publishing Company 1892:490-493). He served as Ellis County Surveyor from 1857 to 1860 and was a prominent financier and land entrepreneur. In 1878, Davis, together with J. D. Anderson and W. M. Ralston, formed the Davis Gin Company (ECC 1878:DB T:345) and built a temporary cotton gin on ''the RA. Davis Fann," which may have been located at 4 IEL92. This facility consisted of a "Gin Stand, Power, and Press" (ECC 1878:DB T:345). nie gin was apparently constructed to service the highly productive cotton lands ofR. A. Davis and the adjacent Stout fanns, since they were rather· remote from the extant gins and transportation was poor in the area Indeed, R. A. Davis contributed articles to Ellis County newspapers in which he called attention to the need for a secure cash economy and all-weather roads. He noted that roads were often impassabl~ to both wagon traffic and travellers on horseback for three months each year due to bad weather (Lewis Publishing Company 1892:493). In the 1889 partition oftheR A. Davis Estate (ECC 1889: Will Records 2:120), granddaughters Alma Browning George and Mary Browning Ackley-inherited 142.66 acres(57.73 ha) from the R. A. Davis Survey and 141.25 acres (57.16 ha) from the BBB&C RR Survey. Alma and her husband, John B. George, partitioned a share of this estate to their daughter Quincy and her husband, J. L. Gammon (ECC 1906:DB 163:251-253). Alma Browning George and Mary Browning Ackley subsequently divided this farm in 1915 (ECC 1914-1915:DB 214:499-500).

As noted briefly in Chapter 3, Peter Stout was an important early landholder within the SSC project area Stout was a Peters Colonist who lived in Tarrant County in 1850 (Connor 1959), but had moved to Ellis County with his wife, Eli7.abeth, and four children by 1860, according to the census records. Peter Stout or his descendants may have resided at either41EL91, 41EL93, or 41EL95, although Weston et al. (1990a:7-45) considered it most likely that the original Peter Stout farmstead was located at 4 IEL95. Although Stout was granted the tract containing these sites in 1850 and had it surveyed in 1851, he did not have clear title. A legal suit in 1860 between Stout and Randolph Townsend, who was the heir to the vast Rafael de la Pena Survey (see Chapter 3) through Nathaniel Townsend, ended in a judgement in Stout's favor (Office of Ellis County Clerk, Waxahachie, Texas [ECC] 1860-1862:Deed Book [DB] E:625). Stout did not patent the land, however, until 1870 (ECC 1870-1871:DB 1:92). Stout's final land purchase in Ellis County consisted of the 640 acre (259.01 ha) Wright Edmondson Survey in 1874 (ECC 1873-1874: DB M:487). The Peter and Elizabeth Stout Estate was again disputed by heirs and plaintiffs in May 1875, and at least two jury trials were necessary before his affairs could be settled. The probate of the Stout Estate was perfomied by the Ellis County Commissioners Court on 22 September 1876. The estate was divided among M. S. Stout (administrator), Sarah D. Stout, I.E. Stout, Jane A. Stout Hancock (see 41EL189, below), and the heirs ofS. D. Stout(ECC 1876: Probate Minutes, Volume D:296-299). A farmstead is depicted at this location on an early twentieth century postal route map (USPS ca. 1905-1915) and the 1941 and 1955 Ellis County highway maps (Texas State Highway Department 1952, 1957), but not on subsequent cartographic sources. The WPA files for land tracts within the Stout Survey have apparently been destroyed. No additional background research was conducted for this site prior to the Congressional tennination of the SSC project Field Investigations No additional archaeological investigations were conducted since the site was located on stratified subsurface fee estate and no surficial disturbances were planned in conjunction with SSC construction. 41EL96 Location and Description 41EL96 is a prehistoric site encompassing ca. 1.06 ha (2.61 acres) in the Grove Creek drainage. B. Archival and Informant Data The site is located in the Claiborne Garrett Survey, which is described above (see 41EL116). A 100 a~e (40.47 ha) tract of the Garrett Survey was acquired by Jefferson D. Roberts for $550.00 in 1880 (Office of Ellis County Clerk, Waxahachie, Texas [ECC] 1880: Deed Book [DB] X:464). The f"JJ'St building at 4 IEL 119 was apparently erected at about this time (ArchiTexas/Solamillo/Hardy-Heck-Moore 1992a). J.-D Roberts and his wife, Mary, subsequently sold the entire farm to W. P. Slater for $12,000.00 on 6 January 1913 (ECC 1912-1913:DB 198:513). The considerable increase in property value suggests that the fann had been substantially improved by J. D. and Mary Roberts. W. P. Slater and his wife, Winnifred Stevenson Slater, sold the 100 acre (40.47 ha) farm to Joseph Dolezal for $15,250.00 on 28 November 1917 (ECC 1917-1918:DB 231:316). Joseph Dolezal and his wife, Josie, were immigrants from Bechyne, Bohemia, who arrived in New York City in 1902. They ultimately made their way to Ellis County, Texas, where all five of their children were born. Jerry Dolezal, born in 1913, is the subject of one of the informant interviews presented in Chapter 3, and additional information regarding the history of 41EL119 may be found there. The 1937 WPA survey lists the 100 acre (40.47 ha) tract owned by Joe and Josie Dolezal, who'still resided there. In all, 1 acre (0.40 ha) was reserved for the home, 1 acre (0.40 ha) for the garden, 88 acres were in cultivation (15 acres [6.07 ha] in com and oats and 73 acres [29.54 ha] in cotton), and 10 acres (4.05 ha) were in pasture. The dwelling measured 32 ft by 36 ft (9.76 m by 10.97 m); a shed measured 12 ft by 14 ft (3.66 m by 4.27 m); and a barn measured 30 ft by 34 ft (9.14 m by 10.36 m). All were in good condition. Joe Dolezal, Jr. inherited this farm and he lived there with his first wife, Albina, from 1949 to 1979. Upon Albina's death, Joe married the widowed mother of Robert L. Mitchell. Joe transferred the land to Robert Mitchell in 1979, and Mr. Mitchell sold the property to the State of Texas in 1992. Jerry Dole2:al (see Chapter 3) operated the farm for Robert Mitchell until it was sold to the State of Texas. Field Investigations In 1991, the buildings, farm machinery, and historic artifacts (i.e., agriculturally related hardware and implements) associated with the site were scheduled for removal. Cunningham, mentioned briefly in Chapter 3, was an important surveyor for the Robertson Land District and one of the largest landholders in Ellis County in the late nineteenth and early twentieth centuries. Leta Mae Cunningham and her new husband, G. Howell Hight, leased the Cunningham farmstead to a series of tenants. In 1966, the Bights, who lived in Bexar County, Texas, conveyed the property to their son and daughter-in-law, Roger and Roxanna Hight (ECC 1966-1967:DB 515: 165, 632). The site was recorded in 1989 as a result of the initial SSC footprint archaeological survey. It consists of the former Boz cotton gin complex and consisted of the former Scales House, located south of Greathouse Road, and the foundation of the later cotton gin (see below), located north of Greathouse Road. This complex was documented by Hardy-Heck-Moore, Inc. (1990) and ArchiTexas/Solamillo/Hardy-Heck-Moore (1992a). Archival and Informant Data The site is located in the northern of two Walter M. Turner surveys in the present-day West Campus. It is located on a 113.50 acre (45.93 ha) tract which was surveyed and patented in 1870. As noted in Chapter 3, the years following the Civil War saw a considerable boom in cotton production in Ellis County. Henry L. Wilder built a steam-powered gin at 41EL134 ca. 1880 to provide processing facilities to the many cotton farmers in the area (Ellis County Genealogical Society 1992). The cotton gin was instrumental in the subsequent development of the community of Boz. Henry Wilder and his wife, Jane (the daughter of Walter M. Turner), sold the parcel containing 41EL134 in 1897 for $1,100.00 to a local firm composed ofG. W. Maxwell (see 41EL140, below), J. L. Patterson, and J. J. Self(Office of Ellis County Clerk, Waxahachie, Texas [ECC] 1897:Deed Book [DB] 98:372). G. W. Maxwell and Ira Green subsequently bought out Patterson and Self in 1899 (ECC 1899-1900:DB 115: 177). Background research conducted by the consortium ofA rchiTexas/Solamillo/Hardy-Heck-Moore (1992a) indicates that the Scales House was built shortly after the gin was acquired by the Boz Gin Company for $3,500.00 in 1910. The Boz Gin Company was another locally organized firm that included prominent landowners such as B. F. Forrester, Sr. (see 41EL77, above) and W. B. Sims. The original steam-powered gin was apparently in use until 1921, when the Boz Gin Company dismantled it after constructing a more efficient electrically powered gin on the north side of Greathouse Road (ArchiTexas/Solamillo/Hardy-Heck-Moore 1992a). With the decline of the cotton business in the 1930s, the Boz Gin began to suffer financial difficulties. It closed in the early 1940s. Three buildings were present at this location (one north of and two south of Greathouse Road) when the Waxahachie 7 .5' Quadrangle was compiled in 1960. Metes and bounds information for the G. W. Maxwell estate (see 41EL140, above) indicates that the 10 acre (4.05 ha) tract containing sites 4IEL165 and 41EL178 (see below) was deeded to the trustees of the M. E. Church in 1907 (Waxahachie Title and Abstract Company 1907: Abstract 47,603; G. W. Maxwell Estate). According to informants, the Boz school had four rooms with a hall down the center. In the early 1900s the school had almost 100 students and had two or three teachers at different times who taught the elementary grades through high school. During the 1930s the number of children had dwindled to between 50 and 60. The school disbanded immediately after World War II, and the building was sold in 1952. Students from Boz were shifted to Forreston. One-half of the school was moved behind the Bethel Methodist Church (see Appendix C, 4IELi41) and was subsequently used as a recreation center (Merkord 1988). A school for African Americans, (apparently defunct by World War II) was located elsewhere, reportedly across the road from the former G. H. Cunningham estate (see 41EL80, above). Field Investigations In 1992, the portion of SSC Parcel 344 containing,the site was included in the area to be impacted by the construction of the Arrowhead Road Ext~nsion and additional archaeological investigation were conducted (see Chapter 6).

Wyatt (a surveyor for Ellis County) stated in an affidavit dated 3 January 1878 that Isaac and Ann Newton were tenants on the tract for Smith, but that Ann Newton was attempting to claim the property. The dwelling at the site appears to have been constructed ca 1885-1900 (DeLara Almond Architects/ARP 1992). The 1936 WPA survey indicates that the original Agee survey had been divided into three tracts which were joined to farms in adjacent surveys.
