• 6. RESULTS OF SUBSURFACE INvESTIGATIONS Joseph L Yedlowskl and Kevin J. Shaunessy with Contributions by David H. Jurney and Sharon G. McHa/e INTRODUCTION Between the initiation of the Archaeology Research Program's (ARP) involvement with the Superconducting Super Collider (SSC) project in August 1989 and the termination of field investigations in September 1993, 76 archaeological sites, in whole or part, and 49 project areas encompassing ca. 1,314.31 ha (3,247.53 acres) received subsurface archaeological investigation. This subsurface investigation consisted of Tier 1 shovel test probing (see Chapter 4), mechanical testing (i.e., backhoe or coring [s ee Chapter 41), and/or a combination of these techniques. In all but those investigations specifically associated with the geotechnical boring program all of the acreage and all of the sites investigated were located on fee simple estate (see Chapter I) or land that was scheduled for fee simple purchase. • All investigations were conducted to determine whether any significant cultural resources potentially eligible for ' inclusion in the National Register of Historic Places (NRHP) were present Th.is chapter presents the results of the subsurface archaeological investigations, both "positive" (i.e., where material culture remains were recovered) and "negative" (i.e., where no material culture remains were recovered). These investigations were conducted under numerous purchase orders and task orders as well as infrastructure investigations (see Chapter 4). Presentation of these results proceeds in a clockwise direction around the SSC footprint by 7 .5' quadrangle starting at the northern "apex" of the footprint. On the individual quadrangles descriptions and discussions of these investigations are presented first by archaeological sites investigated, in numerical order, and then by specific SSC construction project/task order, in a clockwise direction. As a result of strikingly similar stratigraphic sequences encountered/defined throughout the entire SSC footprint, despite the variation soil types encountered (see Chapters I and 5) only generalized stratigraphic discussions are provided with one exception: the East Campus Connector Road bridge deep testing. Complete stratigraphic descriptions and discussions are provided in this instance. FIELD METHODOLOGY As indicated above, all subsurface archaeological investigations were specifically designed to determine whether potentially significant cultural resources eligible for inclusion in the NRHP were present within a given project area. These investigations, however, varied depending upon the immediate characteristics of each project area and can be broadly classified into two categories: shovel test probing; and mechanical testing. A third, highly specialized variant of mechanical testing, deep testing, was implemented when a very rigidly defined set of geomorphological circumstances were encountered (see Chapter 4). · In many instances non-invasive pedestrian reconnaissance augmented the subsurface investigations. Since surface visibility in a given project area.varied from excellent (ca. >75%) to minimal (<10%), non-invasive pedestrian • reconnaissance was not applied unif<~rmly or with the same "weight'' and was employed only as a supplement to the subsurface investigation. 253

254 Yedlowslci and Shaunessy Any given investigation began by subdividing the project area into low and high priority zones. This approach was deemed to be the most cost effective methodology based on the size of the individual project areas coupled with the fact that agricultural activity was often restricted to limited portions of a particular project area resulting in limited applicability of a total coverage, non-invasive pedestrian reconnaissance. Toe prioritized subdividing of a project area began with background research. This background research focused on inspection of the 1950 aerial photographs and the Works Progress Administration (WPA) survey data for Ellis County. In all cases (i.e., with no regard for site chronology [prehistoric vs. historic]) low priority zones consisted of previously terraced portions of agricultural fields and side slopes. High priority zones, however, differed with regard to prehistoric vs. historic sites. In the investigation for prehistoric sites, high priority zones consisted of previously non-terraced uplands and stream valley bottom/floodplain topographic settings. In the investigation for historic sites, high priority zones consisted of areas immediately surrounding and between standing buildings and/or wells/cisterns, or areas where the background research indicated were fonnerly occupied by buil~. Regardless, all field activity was confined to high priority zones within individual project areas. This prioritized approach to the subsurface archaeological investigations was only partially applicable to geotechnical boreholes and fiducial monuments. In these situations investigations were confined to high priority zones. across access and egress routes, while the actual borehole/monument locations more than likely received shovel test probing. Close interval (ca. 5 m [16.40 ft]) non-invasive pedestrian reconnaissance was conducted only when surface visibility was greater than 50%. Upon identification of material culture remains a controlled surface collection was performed. This controlled surface collection consisted of a closer interval (2 m [6.56 ft]) non-invasive pedestrian reconnaissance. At this time surveyor's pin flags were emp laced to indicate the location of all observed surface material culture remains. Upon completion of the flagging each artifact was collected and assigned a Field Specimen (i.e., FS) number. This FS number was affixed to the surveyors pin flag as well as the individual artifact (i.e., each artifact along with a numbered tag was individually bagged). This methodology resulted in a readily visible distribution pattern of the material culture remains either, prehistoric, historic, or both. On sites with both prehistoric and historic material culture remains this artifact distribution infonnation allowed for the immediate infield identification of horizontal stratification, or lack thereof. This methodology also allowed for the future surface plotting, via electronic total station, of the individual artifact locations without the risk of the actual artifact being subsequently lost. Toe assigned FS number would allow each flag location or provenience to be correlated •to the appropriate artifact. Finally, this methodology allowed for the immediate identification of"gaps" in the distribution pattern which would be investigated via shovel test probing. While the methodology for the excavation of shovel test probes {STP) remained constant (see below), the methodology for their emplacement varied considerably. These methodologies can be generally classified into three categories: radial; linear; and iron cross. The choice of any given shovel test probe emplacement methodology was governed by the particular project area under investigation. Toe radial method for shovel test probing was employed were background research indicated a building had fonnerly stood. The approximate location of the building was located and shovel test probe transects were excavated outward from this location. Toe distance that any transect extended was determined by the immediate environs (i.e., geomorphology, topography, etc.). The linear method for shovel test probing was divided into two basic subcategories: systematic linear; and staggered linear. The systematic linear method was employed when standing architecture was present on historic sites. Shovel test probes were emplaced at ca. 10 m (32.81 ft), 20 m (65.62 ft), or 30 m (98.43 ft) intervals along linearly continuous transects. When warranted, however, variation from this "fixed" interval shovel test probing occurred. Shovel test probe and transect intervals were detennined by the immediate topographic and physical characteristics (i.e., the location, size, and number of standing buildings and other structures) of the individual project area. Shovel test probes within adjacent transects were emplaced in a systematic pattern which covered the project area in either a grid of square or rectangular shovel test probes. · Toe staggered linear method for shovel test probing was employed when investigating large open expanses for prehistoric site presence and whe~ the radial method was deemed inappropriate for historic sites where standing architecture was not present. Shovel test probes were again emplaced at ca. fo m (32.81 ft), 20 m (65.62 ft), or 30 m • (98.43 ft) intervals along linearly continuous transects. When warranted, however, variation from this "fixed" interval shovel test probing occurred. Shovel test probe intervals were determined by the immediate topographic and geomorphological characteristics of the individual project area. Transects themselves were emplaced at intervals

The iron cross method for shovel test probing was employed exclusively when investigating geotechnical borehole locat!on~. A single shovel test probe was excavated at the location of the borehole and four additional shovel test probes were excavated around the borehole location, one in each of the "cardinal" directions, at a 5 m (16.40 ft) interval. Regardless of the methodology of ~mplacement, each shovel test probe measured ca. 50 cm (19.69 in) in diameter and was excavated to a maximum depth below ground surface determined by the local depositional environment. Excavation was conducted via natural stratigraphic units (as defined in the field) and 10 cm (3.94 in) arbitrary levels within strata of sufficient thickness. All fill was screened through ¼ inch (0.64 cm) hardware cloth (i.e., wire mesh). As with many aspects of any multi-year project, data collection techniques were refined through time. Prior to July 1991 subsurface investigations were few and confined to small project areas (e.g., geobore locations and their ..access/egress routes, etc.). These investigations generally always resulted in negative data. Therefore, data was typically not collected from individual shovel test probes. After July 1991 subsurface investigations became increasingly more common and involved larger and larger project areas (i.e., Tier 1 investigation; see Chapter 4). At that time it was deemed prudent to begin collecting data from individual shovel test probes. Shovel test probe data collected thenceforth consisted of stratigraphic descriptions including sediment characteristics, strata thickness, Munsell soil color designations, and stratigraphic sequences per shovel test probe. When material culture remains were recovered they were collected and bagged by locus (i.e., Texas Archeological Research Laboratory [fA RL] trinomial site designation if from a previously recorded site or temporary site designation if from a newly located site}, alphabetically designated transect, numbered shovel test probe within the transect, stratum, and arbitrary level within each stratum. As indicated above, mechanical testing was only employed when a very specific set of geomorphological circumstances were encountered. While 72 loci of"aggraded sediment'' were identified within the SSC footprint (see • Chapter 4) several areas with "thick deposits" were also identified during the course of shovel test probing ( e.g., SSC Parcel 103ABC; see Boz Quadrangle, below). As discussed in Chapter 4, several forms of~eep testing were considered and ultimately employed: backhoe trenching; and continuous push coring. Subsurface investigation consisted of the hand excavation of52 shovel test probes (STPs) emplaced at ca IO m (32.81 ft) intervals along nine transects. Shovel test probes were excavated to a minimum depth of ca. 20 cm (7.87 in), and a maximum depth of ca. 40 cm (15.75 in). Two strata were identified. The basal stratum consisted of Austin Chalk bedrock. The surficial stratum consisted of very dark grayish brown (IOYR3/2) clay. Of the 52 shovel test probes excavated, 34 yield material culture remains (see Figure 6.1). The most extensive distribution of material culture remains was in the yard between the pauper house and the jail (see Figure 6.1). Subsurface features which were identified consisted of a brick walk adjacent to the former jail (N70 EIO0) and a water pipe from the jail's water tower (N70 E90). Unfortunately, constraints on the collection of artifacts during the initial stage of the SSC archaeological investigations (see Chapter 4) precluded the retention of the recovered artifacts, which consisted primarily of architectural remains (n=304), and they were reburied in the backfilled shovel test probes. In May 1992 two additional sets of subsurface investigations were conducted within the estate boundaries of the County Farm in conjunction with the Vertical and Horizontal Survey Monument program. Toe first subsurface investigation was in the construction area of Fiducial Monument 17 and the second was in the construction area of Fiducial Monument 29. These investigations consisted of the hand excavation of more than 56 shovel test probes at ca. 10 m to 20 m {32.81 ft to 65.62 ft) intervals along more than 17 transects (see Figure 5.2). Two strata were identified. Of the shovel test probes excavated in the construction area of Fiducial Monument 17, 3 7 yielded material culture remains, all but one of these remains was recovered from the surficial stratum. This specimen was recovered from the uppermost IO cm (3.94 in) of the basal stratum. No material culture remains were recovered from the construction area of Fiducial Monument 29. Tier 1 Summary, Recommendations, and SHPO Response In 1989 a total of52 shovel test probes was excavated within the central complex of the foriner County Fann. Although portions of the central complex appeared to have been disturbed as a result of livestock activity and/or the removal of some structures, the recovered (but reburied, see above) material culture remains, nevertheless, suggested that intact archaeological deposits dating to the 1880s might be present. Further investigations were recommended (Weston et al. l 990a:7-6 to 7-7). Toe apparent prehistoric components/occupations identified elsewhere on the County Farm did not receive any form of subsurface testing; however, further investigations were also recommended for these components/occupations (Weston et al. 1990b:6-3). Toe State Historic Preservation Office (SHPO) did not concur with these recommendations in correspondence to the Department of Energy dated 11 February 1991 stating: Historic site 41EL58, the County Poor Farm, is an interesting site affording an opportunity to study material aspects of a late nineteenth-early twentieth century institution for the care of indigents, mentally disabled persons, and prisoners. However, it is our understanding that this site will not be disturbed by construction of the SSC or any support facilities. If this site falls outside of the Area of Potential Effect, then no further work will be required. Otherwise, limited testing should be conducted. In 1992 in excess of 56 shovel test probes were excavated to investigate the construction areas for two Fiducial Monuments, 17 and 29. Thus, there appeared to be little or no potential for these areas to contribute data pertinent to the SSC research questions (see Chapter 4) or for the presence of significant buried cultural resources. • Results o/Subsurface Investigations 263 Results of Investigations In March 1992 limited subsurface investigation of a portion of the N40 Service Area was conducted in conjunction with the geotechnical boring prognun. Therefore, this investigation was confined to areas of the service area to be directly impacted by the access and egress of the drilling equipment and the drilling of the boreholes. As a result this investigation was confined to the immediate vicinity of an extant barn (Figure 63). Informant information indicated that the entire area surrounding the barn had been extensively graded and had fill added. The excavation of two shovel test probes {STPs) confirmed this information. No material culture remains were identified and no fur$er shovel test probes were excavated. In July 1992 subsurface investigation of the previously uninvestigated portions of the N40 Service Area was conducted. This investigation consisted of the hand excavation of 22 shovel test probes emplaced at ca. IO m to 20 m (32.81 ft to 65.62 ft) intervals along four transects (see Figure 63). Two transects (Transects.A and C) were emplaced in the upland portion of the service area, with the remaining two transects (Transects B and D) emplaced in the floodplain portion of the service area south of Red Oak Creek. Shovel test probes along Transects A and C were excavated io a minimum depth of ca. 30 cm (11.81 in), a maximum depth of ca. 40 cm (15.75 in), and a mean depth ofca. 39.50 cm (15.55 in). A single stratum was identified, consisting ofa very dark grayish brown (10YR3/2) clay. Shovel test probes along Transects B and D were excavated to a minimum depth of ca. 60 cm (23.62 in), a maximum depth of ca. I rn (1.09 ft), and a mean depth of ca. 92.50 cm (36.42 in). Two strata were identified in all but shovel test probe DI where three strata were identified. The basal stratum in STP DI consisted of a light reddish brown (2.5YR6/4) silt The basal stratum in all other Transect B and D STPs (and the intermediate stratum in D 1) consisted of a brown (IOYRS/3) silt. The surficial stratum consisted ofa very dark grayish brown (IOYR3/2) clay. Of the 22 shovel test probes excavated, two yielded material culture remains (see Figure 6.3), all ofw hich were recovered from the uppermost 20 cm (7.87 in) of the surficial stratum. Tier 1 Summary, Recommendations, and SHPO Response A total of 22 shovel test probes were excavated within the N40 Service Area. Two historic material culture remains were recovered (Table 62 and Appendix E). They were interpreted as isolated finds and not related to an extensive archaeological site. Thus,there appeared to be little or no potential for the upland topographic setting of the service area to contribute data pertinent to the SSC research questions (see Chapter 4) or for the presence of significant buried cultural resources. The floodplain portion of the N40 Service Area, however, contained a deeply aggraded sediment locus, 72, identified for possible deep testing (see Chapter 4). This coupled with the presence of prehistoric cultural resources (flaked stone debitage [see Chapter 7, 41EL151], hos/bison bone [see Chapter 9 and Appendix F], and charcoal flecks [see Chapter 101) known to be buried up to ca. 4 m (13.12 ft) below ground surface at an archaeological site (41EL151, see Chapter 5) located ca. 304.80 m (1,000 ft) north of the N40 Service Area boundary lead to the determination that there existed a high potential for buried cultural resources in this portion oft he service area. Therefore, in SSC Letter Report 14 (ARP 1992e) construction clearances were recommended only for the upland portion of the N40 Service Area, which contains the proposed N40 access road, ventilation shaft, worlc staging area, and magnet delivery shaft. Deep testing was recommended for the floodplain portion of the N40 Service Area prior to construction activities. The floodplain portion of the service area was def"med as all land north of (i.~., elevationally lower than) the 530 foot contour line (see Figure 6.3). In principle the State Historic Preservation Office (SHPO) concurred with this recommendation in correspondence to the Department of Energy dated 18 August 1992 stating: The authors conclude that no archeological deposits eligible for inclusion in the National Register of Historic Places will be affected within the upland portion of ~e area, but recommend that deep testing be conducted within the floodplain, where nearby prehistoric deposits have been found in the bank of Red Oak Creek at a depth of 4 m .... N4S Service Area Location and Description The N45 Service Area is located on a portion of SSC Parcel 202AB (see Figures 5.1 and 5.3). The project area is located in an upland topographic setting (i.e., high priority) on the south side of the Red Oak Creek/Brushy Creek drainage divide and encompassed ca. 19.45 ha (48.07 acres). It is wholly contained within the drainage ofan unnamed tnbutary ofRed Oak Creek. Elevation ranges from ca. 160.02 m (ca. 525 ft) to ca. 169.16 m (ca. 555 ft) above mean sea level. Soil types located within the service area consist of: Houston Black clay, 0% to 1% slopes; Burleson clay, terrace, 1% to 3% slopes; and Lewisville silty clay, 3% to 5% slopes, eroded (Brooks et al. 1964). An upland veneer deposit of Uvalde Gravel subsumes virtually the entire N45 Service Area. This veneer gravel deposit represents a portion of an expansive deposit located on the uplands forming the Red Oak Creek/Brushy Creek drainage divide and has been defined as an archaeological site, 41EL158 (see above). Two subsurface investigations of the N45 Service Area were conducted. Results of Investigations • In February 1992 subsurface investigation ofa portion of the N45 Service Area was conducted •in conjunction with the geotechnical boring program. Therefore, this investigation was confined to areas of tl\e service area to be directly impacted by the access and egress of the drilling equipment and the drilling of the boreholes. This investigation consisted of the hand excavation of26 shovel test probes emplaced at ca. 10 m to 20 m (32.81 ft to 65.62 ft) intervals along three transects (Transects A, B, and C in Figure 6.4). Additionally, 15 shovel test probes were excavated at three geobore locations; one at the geobore itself and one each at ca. 5 m (16.40 ft) intervals in the four "cardinal" directions around the geobore. Shovel test probes were excavated to a minimum depth of ca. 25 cm (9.84 in), a maximum depth of ca. 50 cm (19.69 in), and a mean depth of ca. 41.10 cm (16.18 in). A single stratum was identified, consisting of very dark grayish brown (10YR3/2) clay. Of the 41 shovel test probes excavated, one yielded material culture remains (see Figure 6.4), all of which were recovered from the full extent of the identified stratum. In August 1992 subsurface investigation of the previously uninvestigated portions of the N45 Service Area was conducted. This investigation consisted of the hand excavation of73 shovel test probes emplaced at ca. 10 m to 20 m (32.81 ft to 65.62 ft) intervals along four transects (see Figure 6.4, Transects D, E, F, and G). Shovel test probes were excavated to a minimum depth of ca. 30 cm (11.81 in), a maximum depth of ca. 60 cm (23.62 in), and mean depth of ca. 30.68 cm (12.08 in). A single stratum was identified, consisting ofa very dark grayish brown (10YR3/l) clay. Of the 73 shovel test probes excavated, one yielded material culture remains and a faunal remain (see Figure 6.4), all of which were recovered from the uppermost ca. 40 cm (15.75 in) of the identified stratum. Tier 1 Summary, Recommendations, and SHPO Response A total of 127 shovel test probes were excavated within the N45 Service Area. Two historic material culture remains and one faunal remain wer:e recovered (see Chapt~r 9 and Appendices E and F). Despite the fact that virtually the entire service area is subsumed by the defined limits of a prehistoric archaeological site the total absence of recovered prehistoric material culture remains within the N45 Service Area indicates that there is little likelihood that 41EL158 (see above) actually extends this far south and east The historic.material culture remains recovered were an interpreted as isolated finds and not related to extensive archaeological site or occupation(s)/utiliz.ation(s). Thus, there appeared to be little or no potential for this project area to contribute data pertinent to the SSC research questions (see Chapter 4) or for the presence of significant buried cultural resources. No further archaeological investigations and full construction clearances were recommended in SSC Letter Report 16 (ARP 1992f). The State Historic Preservation

East Campus Connector Road Bridge Deep Testing Location and Description The East Campus Connector Road (ECCR) bridge project area is located on SSC Parcel 211. The project area consists of the Bone Branch and Grove Creek stream valley/floodplain crossing, a right-of-way (r-o-w) ca 304.80 m (1,000 ft) north-south by 60.96 m (200 ft) east-west. This corridor essentially corresponds to the area of the ECCR bridge r-o-w between the southern and northern terminal anchors of the bridge approach ramps (i.e., station l 64+o0 to station 177-t-OO). Elevation ranged from ca 123.75 m (ca 406 ft) to ca 132.89 m (ca 436 ft) above mean sea level. Soil types located within the project area consist of: Houston clay, 1% to 3%, slopes; Houston clay, 3% to 5%, slopes, eroded; and Trinity clay, frequently flooded (Brooks et al. 1964). This area had been identified as Locus 67-68 of aggraded sediments within the SSC footprint (see Chapter 4). The project area had previously received shovel test probing in conjunction with the geotechnical boring program and cultural resource clearance of the ECCR r-o-w (see above). This investigation was specifically conducted to determine whether deeply buried (i.e., beyond the limits oftpe shovel test probing) cultural resources potentially eligible for inclusion in the National Register of Historic.Places (NRHP) were present within the proposed construction area. • The methodology employed to make this determination consisted of extracting 3 in (7. 62 cm) diameter continuous push cores every ca. IO ft (3.05 m) along linearly continuous transect segments. The choice of a ten foot center for the

Results ofS ubsurface Investigations 293 "drilling" of the cores was to facilitate the correlation of the core locations to construction survey stations (e.g., station 164+oo). Additionally, a closer interval would have resulted in redundancy of data and cost inefficiency, while a wider interval would not have provided the degree of resolution required to adequately evaluate the geomorphologic history of Bone Branch and Grove Creek stream valleys as it relates to prehistoric cultural resources. As a result of the . coincidental timing of the cultural resource evaluation of the project area and the commencement of the actlJal construction of the East Campus Connector Road, the decision was made to off set the core transect segments west of the bridge centerline in an attempt to create as little conflict as possible between the activities of the construction contractor and our deep testing. North of Bone Branch and south of Grove Creek the transect segments were off set ca. 90 ft (27.43 m) west of the bridge centerline. Between the two streams the transect segment was off set ca. 65 ft (19.81 m) west of the bridge centerline. Fortuitously, inclement weather postponed actual bridge construction until after the deep testing had been completed. The entire project area was densely overgrown with trees, many of which were of considerable size, and underbrush. Therefore, mechanical defoliation was required prior to the initiation of the coring. This mechanical defoliation resulted in the "disturbance of approximately the upper 10 cm to 20 cm (3.94 in to 7.87 in) of the sediment profile; however, this "zone" had received previous shovel test probing which identified no material culture remains (see above). As a result, the surface topography was not mapped along the coring transect segments. Rather, one foot contour maps of the project area were employed to produce a topographic surface map. The methodological approach to the data recovery was predicated on the coring itself. Three inch continuous push cores are "drilled" via two foot (0.61 m) hollow tube sections, the core itself is then mechanically extruded from the tube. After extrusion the individual core sections were laid out end to end in their proper sequence to form a composite continuous core. The core sections were then "sliced'' in half vertically to provide a clean profile for inspection and data recording. The maximum depth to which the cores were pushed was predicated on data obtained from the geotechnical borings conducted in conjunction with the ECCR planning, specifically geotechnical boreholes ECR~8 through ECR-11. The boring logs from these holes indicated that an average 22.96 ft (7 m) of sediment overlaid the calcareous shale identified as the Taylor Marl. This is the same data which was used in the decision making process which selected coring over backhoe trenching. A backhoe trench excavated to explore a sediment profile ca. 23 ft (7 m) in thickness would have required a stepped excavation ca. 30 ft to 50 ft (9.14 m to 15.24 m) wide at ground surface or specialized shoring of a continuous vertical face, to meet the Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) safety guidelines. The coring process, both the pushing and the extruding of the individual sections, results in minor amount of compaction of the resultant core segments. Although, this distortion precludes the exact location of any phenomena encountered, it does provide an approximate location as well as a highly accurate representation of the stratigraphic profile. It is for this reason that the stratigraphic depths below ground surface and strata thicknesses provided below are approximate rather than exact measurements. Additional data collected during the deep testing consisted of stratigraphic descriptions including sediment characteristics, Munsell soil color designations, and stratigraphic sequences per core. Results of Investigations In July 1992 subsurface investigation of the area immediately surrounding the buildings at 41EL119 was conducted in conjunction with the cultural resource clearance ofh istoric sites with standing buildings. This investigation consisted of the hand excavation of63 shovel test probes (STPs) emplaced at ca. 10 m (32.81 ft) intervals along 12 transects (Figure 6.22). Shovel test probes were excavated to a minimum depth of ca. 15 cm (5.91 in), a maximum depth ofca. 60 cm (23.62 in), and a mean depth ofca. 39.95 cm (15.15.73 in). Two strata were identified. The basal stratum consisted of olive brown (2.5Y4 /4) clay. The surficial stratum consisted of very dark grayish brown (10YR3/2) clay. Of the 63 shovel test probes excavated, 33 yielded material culture remains as well as faunal and floral remains (see Figure 6.22), all of which were recovered from the uppermost ca. 30 cm (11.81 in) of the surficial stratum. In June 1993 subsurface investigation of the remainder of Parcel 304 was conducted in conjunction with the cultural resource clearance of the East Campus. This investigation was specifically conducted to ev.aluate the extensive prehistoric occupation(s)/utiliz.ation(s) which had been previously defined for 41EL119 (Weston et al. 1990b:6-15 through 6-16), but was subsequently obscured by heavy vegetation. It consisted of the hand excavation of 84 shovel test probes emplaced at ca. 10 m to 20 m (32.81 ft to 65.62 ft) intervals along 11 transects (Figure 6.23). Two strata were identified. The basal stratum consisted of light olive brown (2.5Y5/4) clay. The surficial stratum consisted of very dark grayish brown (I0YR3/2) clay. Of the 84 shovel test probes excavated, none yielded material culture remains. Tier 1 Summary, Recommendations, and SHPO Response A total of 63 shovel test probes were excavated within the immediate vicinity of the standing buildings at and 41ELI 19. Two prehistoric and 132 historic material culture remains as well as 32 fauna} one floral remains were recovered (see Table 6.1, Chapters 7, 8, and 9, and Appendices E, F, and G). Additionally, 29 human remains in the form of teeth were recovered. These specimens were not recovered from archaeological contexts, but rather were found in a small jar which was part of the items left in the house when it was abandoned. These items attest to the fact the "immigrant east European (Czechoslovakian) farmers throw away nothing" (David H. Jurney, personal communication to J. L. Yedlowski 1995). The prehistoric material culture remains recovered were interpreted as isolated finds and not related to an extensive archaeological occupation(s)/utiliz.ation(s). The historic material culture remains recovered, for the most part, constitute a mixed assemblage resulting from serial occupations. The historic material culture remains · recovered from the area to the west of the outbuilding complex (see Transects I and Jin Figure 6.22), however, indicated that undisturbed cultural deposits relating to the initial, ca. 1880-1890, occupation/utili7.ation of 41EL119 were preserved in that portion of the site (see Chapter 8). Therefore, it was recommended that the removal of the structures be allowed to proceed, but that Tier 2 investigation (see Chapter 4) be conducted in the western portion of the site, specifically in the area of Transects I and J (see Figure 6.22), in SSC Letter Report 15 (ARP 1992j). In principle the State Historic Preservation Office (SHPO) concurred with this recommendation in correspondence to the Department of Energy dated 19 August 1992 stating ''that Tier 2 investigations would not be warranted unless direct impacts to the western portion of the site could not be avoided." · A total of 84 shovel test probes were excavated to the north and west of the central historic complex at 41 EL 119 to determine the integrity of the prehistoric deposits associated with the previously observed surface manifestations at the site (see Figure 6.23). Although the extensive nature of the previously recorded Uvalde Gravel veneer was confirmed, no material culture remains were recovered. Thus, there appeared to be little or no potential for the "prehistoric component'' of the site to contribute data pertinent to the SSC research questions (see Chapter 4) or for the presence of significant buried cultural resources. As a result of the Congressional termination of the SSC project, however, the above results and con~lusions as well as recgmmendations for further archaeological investigation have not been previously reported to the Department.of Energy or the State Historic Preservation Office (SHPO). • No disturbance of the area recommended for Tier 2 investigation occurred and no further archaeological investigations were conducted at 41EL119.

Results of Investigations In February and March 1993 initial investigation the S15 Service Area was conducted. The northern portion of the service area located on Parcel 172 had excellent surface visibility. Therefore, the initial investigation consisted of a non-invasive pedestrian reconnaissance of the northern ca. one-half of the service area at ca. 5 m (16.40 ft) intervals. During the course of this pedestrian reconnaissance both prehistoric and historic material culture remains were observed in an overlapping horizontal context Upon realization of the quantity and distribution of these materials, a controlled • surface collection was conducted. This controlled surface collection consisted of a closer interva{( i.e., ca. 2 m [6.56 ft]) non-invasive pedestrian reconnaissance of the area. Surveyor's pin flags were emplacep to indicate the location of all observed surface material culture remains. All but one of the prehistoric material culture remains were recovered from within the defined limits of 41EL182. This specimen was recovered within close proximity of the northern extent of the defined limits of the site (see STP 16 in Figure 6.27). Given the disturbance of this site by plowing and terracing it is wholly apparent that this specimen is attributable to 41EL182. The prehistoric material culture assemblage consisted exclusively of flaked stone debitage and while recovered from a single defined site were recovered from widely dispersed shovel test probes. This coupled with the fact that the entire service area had been terraced resulted in an interpretation that the site represented a low density, ephemeral occupation(s)/utilization(s). The historic material culture remains were recovered from shovel test probes • in close proximity to Texas S.H. 34, generally, and an existing electrical easement, specifically. Tofs coupled with the fact that archival data and other sources of historical information (i.e., aerial photographs, informant interviews) did not in indicate this area to be the locus of a former residence or other related occupation resulted an interpretation that these specimens represented typical highway and/or construction debris. Thus, there appeared to be little or no potential for this project area or site to contribute data pertinent to the SSC research questions (see Chapter 4) or for the presence of significant buried cultural resources. The basal stratum consisted of Austin Chalk bedrock. The surficial stratum consisted of very dark grayish brown (10YR3/2) clay. Approximately 80% of the shovel test probes were excavated to bedrock. Of the 133 shovel test probes excavated, none yielded material culture remains. • Tier 1 Summary, Recommendations, and SHPO Response A total of 133 shovel test probes were excavated within the N20 Service Area. No material culture remains were recovered. Thus, there appeared to be little or no potential for this project area to contribute data pertinent to the SSC research questions (see Chapter 4) or for the presence of significant buried cultural resources. No further archaeological investigations and all construction clearances were recommended in SSC Letter Report 6 (ARP 1992v). The State Historic Preservation Office (SHPO) concurred with these recommendations in correspondence to the Department of Energy dated 11 March 1994. N25 Service Area Lo~tion and Description The N25 Service Area is located on a portion of SSC Parcel 235BD (see Figures 5.23 and 5.25). The project area consisted of upland and valley bottom/floodplain (i.e., high priority) and side slope (i.e., low priority) topographic settings and encompassed ca. 24.62 ha (60.83 acres) on the drainage divide of two unnamed tributaries of Waxahachie Creek. Elevation ranges from ca. 198.12 m (ca. 650 ft) to ca. 213.36 m (ca. 700 ft) above mean sea level. Soil types located within the service area consist of: Eddy gravely clay loam, 1% to 3% slopes; Eddy soils, 3% to 8% slopes, eroded; Stephen-Eddy complex, 1% to 3% slopes, eroded; Stephen silty clay, 1% to 3% slopes; and Broken alluvial land (Brooks et al. 1964). A single subsurface investigation of the N25 Service Area was conducted. In March 1992 the portion of SSC Parcel 235BD to be impacted by the construction of the N25 Service Area was investigated and 41EL136 was recorded. The site consisted of a welVcistem surrounded by a dispersed scatter of artifacts in a heavily overgrown portion of the parcel. 7. PREIDSTORIC MATERIAL CULTURE REMAINS Kevin J. Shaunessy and Joseph L Yedlowski INTRODUCTION Three hundred thirty-seven (337) prehistoric material culture remains were recovered as a result of the archaeological investigations conducted by the Archaeology Research Program {ARP) in support of the Superconducting Super Collider (SSC) project These artifacts consist almost exclusively of flaked stone (n=330). The remaining seven artifacts consist of five hammerstones, one minute shell-and sand-tempered ceramic sherd, and one ground stone bead. The distribution of these recovered prehistoric material culture remains is presented in Table 7.1. • FLAKEDSTONE Kevin J. Shaunessy with Contributions by Joseph L Yedlowski Analytical Methodology Each flaked stone specimen recovered during the course of the archaeological investigations conducted in support of the SSC project was individually examined. The technomorphological system of flaked stone analysis was employed here, primarily to estimate reduction strategies, or, at least, stages of reduction. The use of functional typologies has been intentionally avoided in this analysis, although, wherever possible, artifacts have been assigned to named types to facilitate comparison with previously published data. Preliminary sorting was conducted to separate the artifacts from each site into four major categories based primarily on a series of technological attnoutes. These major categories are: cores and core fragments; worked/formed implements; utilized flakes; and unmodified debitage. Artifacts within each of these major categories were further subdivided into technomorphological subcategories or ''technotypes" (see Analytical Categories, below) based upon discrete technological, morphological, and, to a lesser extent, functional attributes following Crabtree (1972) and Callahan {1979). The analysis of all artifacts from each technotype recorded data such as artifact shape and configuration, the extent and character of manufacture-related reduction processes, and raw material. Specific attributes recorded for specimens within each technotype are detailed below (see Analytical Categories). Metric data, to the nearest 0.01 mm, were collected for all cores, worked/formed implements, and utiliud flakes using a Fowler Max-Cal digital vernier caliper. Specimen weights were measured to the nearest 0.01 g on an Ohaus digital balance. Edge angles were determined with a Finescale magnifying comparator and a 360" radial reticle (#123). Recorded edge angles in the following artifact descriptions represent a mean "combined" edge~ angle formed by the intersection of the dorsal and ventral surfaces. Measurements of attributes.on fragmentary specimens were obtained as available. Raw material • was identified macroscopically with co-Ior determinations made employing a standard Rock-Color-Chart (1980), unless otherwise indicated in which case Munsell Soil Color Charts (1992) were employed. The raw material classification schema employed was developed by Prewitt and Associates, Inc. for their analysis of the Chandler Collection (see Appendix A). It was "mirrored" in this analysis to allow for comparability of data. This schema identifies 11 raw material types: local fine-grained chert; nonlocal fine-grained chert (from central Texas); Bigfork chert; Pisgah Ridge chert; fine grained quartzite; coarse-grained quartzite; silicified wood; novaculite; agate; quartz.arenite; and sandstone (see Appendix A for a description of each raw material type). One caveat must be added regarding the flaked stone raw material identification. The macroscopic identification of raw materials is often difficult, a result of a defined "range of variation" for any given raw material type. When dealing with specimens of limited surface exposure, as was the case with this analysis, the identifications become even more difficult and somewhat tenuous. Finally, thermal alteration (i.e., heat treating) of raw material was determined macroscopically on the basis of crazing, pot-lidding, surface luster (ie., a waxy or glossy appearance), and, to a much lesser extent, color. Color was never the sole criterion employed to determine apparent thermal alteration. The edges of all flaked stone specimens were examined macroscopically (i.e., by unaided visual scrutiny) to determine if edge use-wear or attrition patterns resulting from utilization were present. Specimens which exhibited possible use-wear were subsequently examined under low power magnification. No attempt was made in this analysis to differentiate between types of use-wear or to determine the functional origin of observed wear patte~. Use-wear was simply noted as "present'' or "absent'' and its location on the specimen was recorded ( e.g., bifacial vs. unifacial; lateral vs. distal margin; etc.). The degree of use-wear was also recorded on a comparative basis between all specimens (i.e., light, medium, or heavy). The following narrative and tabular presentations of the results of this analysis employ standard flaked stone and ground stone nomenclature following Cambron and Hulse"(l975), Crabtree (1972), Callahan (1979), and Turner and Hester (1993). Additionally, definitions for many of these terms are provided, for the lay reader, in Appendix D . •

## Page 447

Prehistoric Material Culture Remains 421 Analytical Categories ("Technotypes") Introduction As indicated above, the technomorphological system of flaked stone analysis was employed. This system of analysis places an emphasis on the technology which created an implement, rather than the function of the implement As a result of this approach, and the analytical device of dividing the lithic reduction process into discrete "stages" (see below), several related concepts regarding aboriginal behavior come into play. Two such concepts warrant brief mention prior to the discussion of our technotypes: primary versus secondary technology; and expedient versus curated tools. The distinction between primary and secondary technologies was first employed by Bradley in his analysis of Paleo-Indian flaked stone artifacts from the Hanson Site (Frison and Bradley 1980)and the Agate Basin Site (Frison and Stanford 1982). Primary lithic technology refers to core reduction strategies used for the production of flakes and blades. Secondary lithic technology treats the intentional modification of flakes and blades into finished formed implements (e.g., projectile points, bifaces, and specialized implements). Included in the latter category are all manufacturing techniques employed to resharpen and refurbish the functional edges of stone tools. Consideration of primary and secondary technologies promotes an understanding of how core reduction and flaked stone tool production processes differ and the extent to which each can be represented at archaeological sites. These concepts are also helpful for understanding the nature and character of the human occupation of prehistoric sites. Regarding expedient versus curated tools, utilized flakes are generally considered to be expedient tools in the analysis of prehistoric flaked stone artifacts (Binford 1976). As such, these tools are products of a primary lithic technology that were used for immediate tasks and then discarded. No care was taken to modify or preserve the • morphology of these artifacts. Utilized and minimally modified flakes are, in a functional sense, intermediate between unmodified debitage and worked/formed implements. Projectile points, bifaces, and specialized implements may be considered to be aboriginally curated tools, which, as products of secondary technology, were intentionally shaped and retained as long use-life tools (Kelly 1988). Curated tools were intentionally abandoned only when broken or when so deformed that they could no longer be maintained as functional implements. Cores and Core Fragments Cores are pieces of lithic raw material ranging from totally unprepared parent material and specimens with few flake scars to those that bear numerous flake scars and established striking platforms. Cortex may or may not be present, depending on the specimen's stage of reduction. Platfonn preparation (dragging, faceting, and/or grinding) techniques may be used to remove any dorsal surface overhang and to facilitate the detachment of additional flakes. The following attributes were recorded for each recovered core and core fragment: type of flake removals (i.e., unidirectional, bidirectional, or multidirectional); number of striking platforms; number of flake scars ( exclusive of those resulting from platform crushing); percentage of cortex remaining; presence or absence of platform preparation; maximum length, width, and thickness (mm); and weight (g). The resultant combination of attnoutes was then used to assign each specimen to one of the sequent reduction stages descn"bed below. Core reduction systems intended for the production of flakes can be best understood as a technological continuum. Dividing this continuum into various stages, however, conceivably aids in the interpretation of an assemblage in that it allows one to establish the point in the flake removal continuum at which a core was considered by its knapper to be exhausted and, perhaps, the point at which it was discarded. The strategy of dividing percussion core reduction into various stages is not one that traditionally has been used in lithic analyses. Generally, staging has been confined to secon~ technology and to the bifacial thinning process (Callahan 1979). Lately, however, Kelly (1988) has shown bifaces that probably served three purposes in prehistoric lithic technology. They were not only the by-products of the shaping or thinning process, but also served as long use-life,tools and cores. Bifaces, as cores, thus can also be included within primary technology. From this perspectiv~ Callahan's (1979) concept of staging can also be applied to elements of primary technology. The stages employed in the present analysis are described below. Procurement (Stage 1): In this stage, the lithic raw material is obtained. This material can be in the form of a cobble, nodule, flat rectangular slab, etc. No modification of the raw material takes place during this stage. Consideration of raw material procurement is an important elem~~t in understanding prehistoric lithic technology, since

## Page 448

422 Shaunessy and Yedlowski the original form of the procured lithic material (e.g., thin, tabular sheets; nodules; etc.) influences the choice of reduction strategy (i.e., core or biface) and the subsequent process of flake removal (Bucy 1974:5). Testing, or Embryonic Cores (Stage 2): In this stage, the initial testing or examination of the parent mass is conducted by the knapper. One to several flakes may be removed to "check" the suitability of the raw material for further reduction. If the piece is determined to be acceptable on the basis of its homogeneity, lack of internal flaws, etc., flaking will normally continue into the next reduction stage. If the piece is unacceptable, it will be discarded and is classified as embryonic. Technically, parent material passed over or discarded by the knapper in the embryonic stage may be classified as a form of debitage, since it is considered a waste product of the reduction process. Primary-Reduced Cores (Stage 3): In this stage, proper core morphology is established for further reduction. Large flakes are removed from the core to eliminate cortex and any external flaws that may hinder the subsequent removal of flakes. One or more primary striking platforms are usually established during this stage. The core shows several large flake scars, and,1111ost likely, ~t least 50% of the surface area will be covered with cortex. Platform preparation is normally not employed in this stage. Secondary-Reduced Cores (Stage 4): The knapper takes care during this stage to preserve (and, when necessary, to maintain or refurbish) the platform area(s). Platform preparation strengthens the platform and facilitates flake removal. The core typically shows several medium-sized flake scars and perhaps a minimal amount of platform preparation. Twenty-five percent or less of the core's surface area retains cortex. Tertiary-Reduced Cores (Stage 5): Great care is taken to preserve and maintain the platform area(s) of the core. Depending on the availability of raw material, extensive platform preparation may be present The core shows numerous medium-sized and small flake scars. Little or no cortex remains on the core. Biface Cores: This is a specialized type of core which does not lend itself readily to the staging concept summamed above. It consi$ts of a core or parent mass which has been systematically bifacially reduced for the specific purpose of producing a bifacially wo~ed implement, rather than for the systematic production of flakes and blades. As such, it approximates C-aUahan's (1979) "initially edged biface," yet it does not meet the criteria for inclusion in that category (see Bifaces and Biface Fragments, below). Specifically, biface cores are herein defined as a specialized type of tertiacy-redu~ core which: retains little or no cortex; exhibits numerous medium to small flake scars over most or all of its surfaces; has a continuous or near-continuous bifacially worked circumference; has a very wide lineal edge offset; and, most importantly, has a width/thickness ratio ofless than 2.00. In essence, the biface core, while it has been "initially edged," is still far too ''thick'' to qualify as a blank, preform, or biface. Worked/Formed Implements Worked/formed implements include not only "finished" pieces, but, also, blanks, preforms, and rejuvenated specimens. Specimens within this broad category may be manufactured on either cores or flakes. All specimens were initially modified to a desired configuration by various manufacturing techniques, used alone or in combination, including hard and soft hammer pemISSion and pressure flaking. On the basis of morphological and technological attnl>utes, worked/formed implements were classified into more-or-less traditional categories. Functional types, except in the case of projectile points, were intentionally avoided as a basis for classification. The primary subcategories of worked/formed implements utilized in this analysis consist of the following: projectile points and point fragments; bifaces and biface fragments; unifaces; and minimally modified flakes. Each of these subcategories is bri_efly discussed below. Projectile Points and Point Fragments Included here are all complete and fragmented specimens that are unifacially or bifacially modified to facilitate hafting as spear, lance, dart, or arrow points. The classifi~tion of a specimen as a projectile point, however, does not necessarily preclude a number of other possible cutting, slicing, piercing, and/or drilling usages. Multiple functions among so-called "projectile" points have been demonstrated in studies conducted, for example, by Ahler (1971) at Rodgers Shelter, Missouri. . Attributes recorded for specime!)S classified as projectile points consist of: presence or absence of thermal alteration; color; and (where applicable) length, blade width, thickness, stem length, stem width, basal width, weight, • and mean blade edge angle. Where possible, specimens were assigned to named projectile point types and/or chronological periods using standard references ( e.g., Prikryl 1990; Suhm and Jelks 1962; Turner and Hester 1993).

• Prehistoric Material Culture Remains 423 Bifaces and Biface Fragments This category includes all worked/fonned flaked stone implements (other than projectile points) that are bifacially flaked along one or more margin(s). Bifaces can be produced from either large or small flake blanks, core blanks, or core fragments. Attributes recorded for specimens classified as bifaces consist of: presence or absence of thermal alteration; color; and (where applicable) length, width, thickness, weight, and mean blade edge angle. Bifaces are divided into subcategories according to degree ofc ompleteness and morphological element represented. Finally, bifaces are identified according to various stages of the reduction process. The typology developed by Callahan (1979) for these purposes has been employed in this study and is briefly discussed below. Procurement (Stage 1): In this stage, the lithic raw material used in the reduction process is obtained. This material may be in the fonn of core trimming or biface thinning flakes, cobbles, nodules, etc. No modification of the raw material takes place during this stage. Imtial-Edged Bifaces (Stage 2): This stage refers to the creation of initial ridges (or arrises) by the alternate removal of flakes from both surfaces of the raw material. This initial edging facilitates the further thinning of the material by providing future striking platforms. Preparation for flake removal is minimal to absent At this stage, the biface exhibits a very sinuous lateral margin. Callahan (1979) terms this "sinuosity" lineal edge offset. This offset is essentially equivalent to the distance between the flake scar ridges, or troughs, on opposite surfaces of the specimen and is measured in.relative terms (i.e., wide, moderate, close). Bifaces in the earlier stages of the reduction process will tend to have more sinuous edges, and, consequently, a wider offset Bifaces in the later stages ofreduction will tend to have less sinuous or straighter edges, and thus, a closer offset Flake scars on initial-edged bifaces are widely spaced with a high degree of variability in flake scar morphology. Less than 50% of the biface width normally shows opposing flake scar contact The biface outline may be irregular, and the cross section of the piece may be thick and irregular. A width/thickness ratio of2.00-3.00 is expected at this stage; however, this may vary according to the form of the raw • material obtained in Stage 1. Primary-Thinned Bifaces (Stage 3): This stage represents the first attempt to thin the piece. Platform preparation is moderate to extensive. The biface shows a relatively moderate lineal edge offset. Flake ·scars are closely and semi regularly spaced with a moderate variability in flake scar morphology. Fifty to seventy percent of the biface width shows opposing flake scar contact. The biface outline may be semi-regular, and the cross section may be biconvex. A width/thickness ratio of3.00-4.00 is expected, again, depending on the original form of the raw material. Secondary-Thinned Bifaces (Stage 4): By this stage, the thinning process is well underway. Platform preparation is moderate to extensive. The biface shows a relatively close lineal edge offset. Flake scars are closely and regularly spaced with a low variability in flake scar morphology. Fifty to one hundred percent of the biface width shows opposing flake scar contact The biface outline is regular, and the cross section is flat and thin. A width/thickness ratio of 4.00- 5.00 is expected. Tertiary-Thinned or "Shaped" Bifaces (Staf!e 5): This staee reoresents the comnletion ofthP. thinnino nrnrPc:c:

The platform remnant, in the case of biface thinning flakes, represents a portion of an "old" edge and may exhibit use-related wear and/or grinding preparation. · Biface reduction debitage, like the bifaces from which it is removed, can be identified according to various stages of the reduction process (see Bifaces and Biface Fragments, above). The typology developed by Callahan (1979) for these purposes has been employed in this study and is briefly described below. Stage 1 refers to the procurement of raw material and, therefore, has no biface thinning flakes associated with it. Stage 2 {Initial Edging): Trimming and thinning flakes from this stage ofbiface reduction are removed during the initial edging of a blank and retain platform remnants from the original square-edged blank or rounded· cobble surface. Generally, lipped platform remnants are absent in this stage of reduction. The dorsal surfaces of flakes produced during this stage have coi.tex. or exhibit only a few scars from previous flake removals. Platform preparation on these flakes is almost always absent, except for occasional dragging to remove core overhang. The platform on Stage 2 flakes is composed either of cortex or concave areas, which were formed by the trough of a single flake scar. Stage 3 (Primary Thinning): Thinning flakes from this stage ofbiface reduction frequently can have what appear to be "soft-hammer" attributes, su~h as a diffuse/expanding bulb of applied force and a lip. Although dragging preparation is common, more complex forms of platform preparation (i.e., grinding or faceting) do not frequently occur on these specimens. Typically, the dorsal surface morphology on primary biface thinning flakes has three or more flake scars and preserves at least some cortex. Recovery techniques can be present on these specimens but usually do not occur with great frequency. In general, primary biface reduction debitage or thinning flakes are larger, thicker, and have greater obtuse platform angles than do secondary thinning flakes. Stage 4 (Secondary Thinning): Thinning flakes from this stage ofbiface reduction generally show what appear to be "soft-hammer'' attributes with greater frequency than do primary thinning flakes. Platfoqµ preparation and • dragging preparation is normally evident on these specimens, and their remnant platform morphology is usually dihedral (i.e., formed by the juncture of two flake scars). The flake size range in this class may overlap with that of primary flakes, but secondary thinning flakes are generally much thinner. The dorsal surfaces of these specimens have at least three converging flake scars and show recovery techniques from all possible directions. Stage 5 (Tertiary Thinning or Shaping): Debitage from this stage in the reduction sequence is confined principally to small pressure flakes and fragments thereof. Tertiary biface thinning flakes frequently have polyhedral platform remnants and bear evidence of grinding and dragging preparation. Such flakes are usually thin and flat, with many converging flake scars on their dorsal surface. Specimens of this type that represent proximal fragments of specimens, however, often have parallel flake scars. Nondiagnostic Shatter

Utllized Flakes and Flake Fragments L Five utilized flakes and flake fragments were recovered as a result of the archaeological investigations conducted in support of the SSC project As noted above (see Analytical Methodology), utilized flakes are, in a functional sense, intermediate between unmodified debitage and worked/fonned implements. They consist of trimming or thinning debitage which has subsequently been expediently utilized in the performance of a specific task or tasks ( e.g., cutting, scraping, planing, etc.) and then discarded. All of the recovered specimens exbtoit varying degrees of attrition use-wear along one or more margin(s) which has been described as light, medium, or heavy on a comparative basis (see Analytical Methodology, above). One of these specimens, an unusually large and thick biface thinning flake from 41EL153 (PS 2-3), may have been produced during the biface reduction process by an overzealous application of force • as the proximal end of the flake retains, in addition to the striking platform, a fairly extensive portion of the heavily ground, bifacially thinned edge of the parent biface. As such, this specimen could technlcally also be classified as a biface fragment (Figure 7.5f). None of the recovered specimens exhibits evidence of thermal alteration. Descriptive and metric data for these specimens are presented in Table 7 .3. Unmodified Debitage Two hundred nineteen (n=2 I 9) whole and fragmentary pieces of unmodified debitage ( excluding those identified as utilized flakes) were recovered as a result of the archaeological investigations conducted in support of the SSC project. The unmodified debitage was initially divided on the basis of reduction strategies into the following three technomorphological categories: core trimming flakes (n=1 79); biface thinning flakes (n= 12); and nondiagnostic shatter (n=28). ## Page 475

8. HISTORIC MATERIAL CULTURE REMAINS Judith E. Thomas with Contributions by Joseph L Yedlowski INTRODUCTION Joseph L Yedlowski Fifteen thousand five hundred and five (15,505) historic material culture remains were recovered as a result of the archaeological investigations conducted by the Archaeology Research Program (ARP) in support of the Superconducting Super Collider (SSC) project: 15,235 from archaeological sites (Table 8.1); and 270 from non-archaeological site project areas (see Table 62). Prior to any historic artifact analysis, however, the Department of Energy requested that the ARP make recommendations for analysis and permanent curation of the historic material culture remains. This was • in anticipation of the fact that funding levels would not be sufficient to allow for the analysis and permanent curation of all of the historic material culture remains since Congress had terminated funding of the SSC project. As a result, a two-staged analytical approach was developed to allow for such recommendations. The' first stage consisted of the inventory and tabulation of all SSC historic material culture remains. The second stage consisted of the in-depth analysis of a subset or sample of these artifacts. The latter forms the crux of this chapter. Inventory and tabulation of all SSC historic material culture remains was accomplished employing the same classification system (see Analytical Methodology, below) which was to subsequently be employed in the in-depth analysis (see Artifact Descriptions For The 11 Selected Sites By Class, below). The actual inventory and tabulation consisted of the completion of standardized attribute forms (see Appendix E, Data Sheets) for each specimen as well as entry of these data into an electronic database. ANALYTICAL METHODOLOGY "· Historic sites, in general, and single component households, in particular, contain a "profile" of local, regional, and national markets in the material culture remains which have been "deposited" in them (Riordan and Adams 1985: 16-17). The household's life cycle, income strategies, and size affect the purchasing choices of different social and economic groups (Klein 1991:88). This in turn affects the "profile" of each site. The majority of the present archaeological database in Texas and adjacent states is generated by the household (Deetz 1982:717). Rural households, in contrast to urban households, appear to have experienced fewer changes as a result of marketing practices (Klein 1991:87). Consequently, rural households tend to reflect traditional lifeways.and patterns of behavior more accurately and for a longer period than do urban households. The artifact classification system employed by the ARP and adopted by the Mercyhurst Archaeological Institute (MAI) is designed to provide a standardized analytical framework suitable for application to all types of historic sites as well as all social and economic groups. As such, it is also designed to be easily expanded, refmed, and/or modified as individual research projects warrant This classification system is also designed to accommodate the analysis of domestic, industrial, and other types of n;iaterial culture remains. The following subsections review some of the analytical and classificatory system developed by the ARP to identify and synthesize data on historic sites and historic artifact assemblages. • Artifact Classification System The classification system used for the historic material culture remains recovered from the SSC project essentially mirrored the system employed on the ARP's Richland Creek archaeological project in northern Freestone County (Jurney 1987) and refmed in subsequent projects throughout Texas. This classification system segregates historic material culture remains into 10 morphological/functional (morphofunctional) classes (architectural remains, ceramic [vessels], electrical parts, firearms and related remains, fuel remains, glass [vessels], hand tools and implements, horse and stable items, metal, and personal items) and one miscellaneous class (miscellaneous items). 'Many of these analytical classes are subdivided in several, or even numerous, important subclasses making the entire classification scheme comparatively detailed. Each of these classes undergoes a separate attribute oriented analysis which records pertinent data regarding artifact class, subclass, type, subtype, and variety as well as numerous attribute variations (see Appendix E, Data Sheets).

For example, the initial observation regarding a ceramic vessel/sherd assigned the specimen to one of five ceramic subclasses: stoneware, refined earthenware, coarse earthenware, porcelain, or yellowware. Age Many specimens can be placed into broadly bracketed temporal spans based upon diagnostic attributes such as maker's mmk, manufacturing processes (e.g., hand vs. machine, chemical composition, mold type, etc.), reaction to weathering (e.g., a change in color of certain glass when exposed to sun light), and under ideal conditions embossed data. These attributes can then be compared to manufacture's records and other archival documents to establish Beginning and Ending Dates for the availability of the original item. Since the hallmark of the ind~al revolution is mass production and mass marketing-in many instances on a global scale--a temporal bracket can often be refined .; .. ; based upon historical documentation regarding local (i.e., north-central Texas) availability. Thus, a probable period of use for a specimen can be determined, and when combined with other available temporal data from a site, a probable age of use can be effected for a site. General Observations As noted above, any data deemed important about a specimen but which was not included on the data sheet could be easily added under the ''Notes" section of the form. Finally, a determination of each specimen's "value" in addressing SSC research questions (see Chapter 4) was made and is reflected in the "Further Analysis/Possible Curation" check box on each data sheet

• Historic Material Culture Remains 457 Nails Nails were frequently used in the construction of dwellings, barns, various types of outbuildings, and fences and consequently are a common constituent of yard middens at most historic sites. At the earliest historic sites, however, large numbers of nails were not required since construction took the fonn of horizontal log buildings. Builders of early log structures on the Texas frontier were thought to have used other techniques such as pole-supported shake roofs and dirt floors that required fewer nails (Jordan 1978). Also, many early settlers lived in tents for several seasons prior to building their homesteads (Samuels and Knox 1980). The majority of historic sites examined to date in Texas date to after 1855. By this period, most frontier builders had access to sawn lwnber and construction hardware. It was common in the late nineteenth century to improve many log structures by adding sawn lumber as siding, thus increasing the number of nails in the entire building. Finally, mass planned frame buildings were constructed after 1890 and contained a much greater range and number of nail types. . -Nails enter the archaeological record through several mechanisms and are not simply the product of intentional discard. A few may be lost, bent, or discarded during initial construction. A substantial number enter as a result of yearly occupation. Wood structures endure daily and seasonal temperature and moisture fluctuations that play on the wood to loosen nails, gradually·working some of them out of their holes after several years (Jensen 1971; Sloane 1982). In other situations, nails are discarded when buildings are tom down, or moved to new locations. Other old buildings bum or collapse in place, leaving behind a clear concentration of nails. All of these factors contribute to a "rain" of nails entering the archaeological deposits; primarily shake roofmg nails (1.26 in (3.20 cm], I.SO in (3.80 cm)), wall board nails (2.48 in (6.30 cm]), and wall batten nails (2.17 in (5.5 cm]). If a structure remains in place for IO to 20 years, this nail rain will be substantial and will reflect, in a general way, the type(s) ofbuilding(s) and construction style(s) once standing. Systematic excavations ofhistoric sites provide samples of nail rains that can be used to reconstruct some of the fonner buildings no longer extant Specific intrasite provenience data coupled with nail sizes can be used to reconstruct • the type of structure/construction technique fonnerly present Nail densities and siz.e ratios for dwelling and outbuilding locations vary considerably from site to site and intrasite differences provided insight on 1'Je age, evolution, and types of buildings on a site. Various structural elements have been associated with specific nail siz.es (Jurney and Moir 1987), and a nail assemblage can be used to infer the structural type. For instance, log buildings contained few nails in roofing elements and window and door framing (small nails) and flooring. Once a log structure was sheathed in lumber, different ratios of nail sizes have been noted in the archaeological record. Braced frame and box frame construction also employed different ratios of nail sizes. The nail assemblages can also be used to determine whether a structure was a dwelling or outbuilding, whether the structure was remodeled, and whether the structure burned in place or was removed (and possibly recycled elsewhere). Many nails excavated from yard middens and former dwelling locations are broken. For these and whole nails, • !• 'I

Thus, ratios of cut to wire nails provide a rough seriation for building construction and use from the 1870 to 1910. Window Glass Wmdow panes and window frames contain important information about house construction and the socioeconomic rank of their initial owners. Historic archaeologists have seldom addressed the importance of window pane size and window frame styles beyond simply noting their temporal associations (e.g., Noel Hume 1970; Davies 1973; Wilson 1976). Architectural historians, however, have long recogni7.ed the important relationship between upper class window styles and household status (Isham and Brown 1900; Kelly 1924; Whiffen 1969). Windows were important status markers through the nineteenth century. Window configurations were often used to convey a message to others about the particular social rank held by a family. Windows provided a tangible and complementary medium for accenting exteriors, and were often closely matched to a dwelling's size and status. For example, a mid-nineteenth century plantation house would contain as much glass in a single window frame as one might find in an entire lower class dwelling. The frequency of window glass sherds in fannstead deposits can provide an empirical database that indicates strong socioeconomic differentiation among nineteenth century households. These differences diminished greatly for twentieth century Texas dwellings, and although window styles were significant, the frequency of window glass is much less important because all households could afford at least standard windows. Some general information on the evolution of window frames and panes is useful to set the background for interpreting the flat glass assemblages. In particular, the size of common window frames and panes for dwellings has changed considerably over the last three and one-half centuries. Basic developments in window frames have been recognized by architectural historians for over fifty years (e.g., Isham and Brown 1900; Kelly 1924; Kimball 1928; Whiffen 1% 9). These styles, however, only apply to lower and middle class rural dwellings located in moderately well settled areas and not houses built in early frontier settings. • Upper class dwellings do not follow a simple progression. Wealth and personal tastes for new styles make many exceptions to this ideal scheme and overall, they contributed to the use of much larger panes and frames in earlier periods. Sizes of window frames and size and number of panes for mid-to late-nineteenth century farmsteads in north central Texas vary dramatically. The most important point is the dramatic difference between the size of the windows associated with single pen log dwellings, and the sizes found in much larger dwellings oflog, frame, and braced frame construction. When these differences are added to differences in the number of windows typically associated with each class of structure, the total amount of window glass contained in each is dramatically different. ' The total surface area displaced by window panes provides one measure or index that can be correlated with general dwelling type or class for nineteenth century rural Texas. Several independent checks have been made using published data and have yielded similar results ( e.g., Huntington 1982; Lees 1977). There are, however, several important qualifications to these findings. Mean thickness for structures built earlier than 1810 or later than 1915 is a poor indicator of construction date. Changes in the methods of production of flat glass and changes in window styles make thickness of little use for deriving initial construction dates. In 1924, the United Stales government specifications for common window glass set thickness of single strength panes at 0.08 in to 0.1 O in (2.03 mm to 2.54 mm) and double strength at 0.10-in to 0.12 in (2.54 mm to 3.05 mm) (Monro 1926:95; Lees 1977; Roenke 1978). Consequently, thickness of common window glass by definition is restricted to values thinner than 0.13 in (3.30 mm) by the early twentieth centwy. Excluding sherds with thicknesses greater than 0.12 in (3.05 mm) filters out special varieties of flat glass (i.e., uncommon or pane glass of special flat glass for non-window pane functions), andyields more reliable results. Common window glass not used for window panes ( e.g., fumiture, mirror, fish tank, picture frames, etc.) can be filtered out by limiting assemblages to sherds found within 4 m (13.12 ft) of a structure. In summary, limiting flat glass samples to excavation units directly associated with architectural remains and excluding sherds thicker than 0.12 in (3.05 mm) help to filter out extraneous pane fragments and specialty flat glass to yield a more reliable assemblage for deriving chronological information. If these two precautions are followed, then an accurate (i.e., ±7 years) estimate of the initial construction date of a dwelling can be obtained in six out of ten cases. Sample sizes have to be reasonable and samples not collected from a single context Length of occupation also needs to be less than 60 years, and if structural additions are present, these need to be recognized and sampled separately. Last of all, upper class dwellings, urban dwellings, and specialized buildings are less likely to produce useful results, and the formula is not designed to be applied to these categories of buildings. • Context, or the precise intrasite provenience of each sherd of flat glass, is the single most important variable, • requiring exact control, in order to study change in thickness over time. Poor context generally under-represents correlations between most thickness indices and time. Other important elements are initial construction date, likelihood of structural additions, occupation span, site function, socioeconomic status of initial ·and subsequent occupants, minimum/maximum sherd count requirements, criteria for identification of flat glass, and criteria for removing atypical window glass or specialty flat glass from consideration. Initial beginning dates are much more useful for window glass studies, so long as length of occupation is under 70 years. These points have been recognized after reviewing regressions run on Roenke's (1978) data and also after looking at histograms for sites occupied for long periods (Moir 1982). The initial construction date is a much more realistic temporal reference point than mid-range of occupation for the following reasons. Wmdows, in most situations, are installed during the initial construction of a structure. Entire window replacement, costly for middle and lower class dwellings, does not seem to present problems that affect empirical evidence, until after 70 years of occupation.
