• Historic Material Culture Remains 461 Two final commentaries regarding refined earthenware and stoneware analysis warrant consideration as to their implications to this analytical schema, generally, and the SSC analysis in particular. Problems and Approaches to Post-A.D. 1850 Refm ed Earthenware Classif,cations There is no widely accepted classification system for categorizing refined earthenware dating after the fJJ"St quarter of the nineteenth century. The introduction oflead free glaz.es in the second quarter of the nineteenth century brought about a departure from true pearlwares and towards whitewares and ironstones (Hughes and Hughes 1968; Lofstrom 1976; Price 1979). At present, there are two schools of thought on categorizing nineteenth century refined earthenware. First, there are some individuals (e.g., Lofstrom 1976; Price 1979; Fawcett 1980; Garrow 1982, 1983; Geismer 1982) who have had moderate success with applying paste/glaz.e and decoration criteria and separating various tinted shades of blue or pwple from whitewares and common cream colored wares. These classification systems follow the ceramic approach developed by South (1972). More recently, however, there are other individuals who prefer to classify nineteenth century refined earthenware solely on their decorative indices. This second method follows closely the approach developed by Miller (1980). The ARP drew upon the particular strengths of both of these approaches in developing its analytical methodology. Multiple typologies were used to probe temporal and socioeconomic patterning. Classification of nineteenth century assemblages was easier once one became familiar with twentieth century wares. The importance of this point can be illustrated with the following example. One of the most unfortunate misunderstandings scattered throughout the literature is a belief in the continuation of true creamware beyond the 1840s. The very slight off-white refined earthenware of the 1870s, l 880s, or the 1890s in north-central Texas are quite pale in comparison to true creamware types of the 1780 to 1820 period. Cream-colored • sherds are evident, however, in ceramic assemblages dating to the very early twentieth century and,are fairly frequent in collections dating after 1910. The tints of many of these sherds are indistinguishable from some varieties of true creamware but the decorative motifs and vessel forms were twentieth century in date, not eighteenth or early nineteenth century. Without the recognition of these newer, lead free, ivory-tinted wares as twentieth century examples, the historic ceramicist would categorize these specimens as nineteenth century creamwares and place them into an artificially broad time bracket. Critics of glaz.e tints should look closely at tightly dated 1860 to 1900 assemblages before they defend a position of wide temporal associations for true creamwares. For north-central Texas, glaz.e tints contain useful temporal information and they are helpful in understanding ceramic acquisition. The last general remade about post-1850 refined earthenware classifications is the need to exercise caution once a system has been developed for an area. For example, shell edged ironstone and pearlware plates were excavated from an urban dump in New England with tight contexts of 1894 to 1911 (Cheney 1982:76). 462 Thomas Most pots from small local shops were destined to be used within about a one hundred mile radius of the pottery. Intensive study has shown that this surely was true of the small shops operating during the second and third quarters of the nineteenth century in Texas (Greer 1981:251). This pattern remained unchanged until the early twentieth century. By the 1890s industrializ.ed potteries in the Midwest began making inroads, shipping wares into Missouri, Arkansas, and Texas. Stonewares produced at small, nonindustrialized potteries in Texas were largely shipped only within the state, either by wagon or rail. Shipment by wagon was common until about 1930, when they w:ere largely replaced by trucks (Greer 1981:255). Other innovations reduced the need and use of stoneware storage vessels during the early twentieth century. Less expensive mass-produced metal and glass containers cut deeply into the market formerly held by local potteries. New food need preservation techniques including changes in canning, pickling, and refrigeration, slowly reduced the for large stoneware vessels. Stoneware vessel sherds recovered from sites within the project area thus provide an excellent opportunity for examining a diminishing (i.e., declining in frequency ovewime) artifact as well as regional marketing and distribution systems. Electrical Parts The classification system employed in the analysis of the material culture remains recovered from the SSC sites places all items associated in any way with electrical. power into this artifact class. These remains typically include battery parts, electrical wire, light bulb fragments, electrical motor parts, and insulators (glass and ceramic). Firearms And Related Items The classification system employed in the analysis of the material culture remains recovered from the SSC sites places all items associated in any way with firearms into this artifact class. These remains typically include rifle and pistol cartridges, shotgun shells, skeet fragments, bullets, plastic wadding from shells, and. gun parts. Fuel Remains The classification system employed in the analysis of the material culture remains recovered from the SSC sites places all items associated in any way with combustl"ble fuel into this artifact class. These remains typically include coal, coal slag, cinders, lignite, and charcoal. Glass

• Historic Material Culture Remains 465 assemblages attempted to determine the manufacturing process (i.e., wrought, cut, wire) and the nail size. Whole and bent nails were measured with the corresponding pennyweight (i.e., weight determined by keg [ d]) determined where possible. As discussed above (see Analytical Methodology), the ratio of cut nails to wire nails in an archaeological artifact assemblage has been used to provide chronological data for late nineteenth century structures. To reiterate, wire nails were negligible in national production and consumption prior to 1880; however, by 1892 wire nails constituted 50% oft he production, and by 1898, over 85% oft he nails were wire (Jurney, Green, and Young 1993:98). Absolute time markers for wire to cut nail ratios were successfully derived by Walker (1980) where sites with less than 20% wire nails dated prior to 1888, 75% wire nails dated a site after 1895, and 100% wire nails dated the site to after 1902. The application of this technique to the Richland Creek nail assemblage produced dates that were from five to 15 years too recent (Jurney 1987b:90). Seriation of the Richland Creek nails did, however, produce a pattern that closely paralleled other dating sources (material culture and documentary) for the Richland Creek area Jurney, Green, and Young (1993:99) suggest that although the ratio of cut nails to wire nails may not be an absolute time marker, the ratio can be a "rough chronological indicator" of a building's construction or repair. The ratios of cut nails to wire nails with the calculated dates of construction/repair for the 11 selected sites are presented in Table 8.4. According to the cut and wire nail ratios, one site ( 4lEL101) pre-dates 1880 and the remaining sites, with the exception of 4 IEL 199, date between 1888 and 1898. Site 4 lELl 99 yielded a single broken wire nail (see Table 8.4); hence, the cut to wire nail ratio index can not be applied. These dates will be integrated with additional material culture-based temporal data compiled for each site and will be presented below (see Site Discussions). Additional information concerning architectural sbuctures can be gleaned from an analysis of nail sizes. Extensive documentation of nail use in standing log and frame structures in the Richland Creek area has provided a data base for comparison with similar small rural farmsteads in north-central Texas (Jurney 1987b). • Historic Material Culture &mains 471 Vessel form was determined for 236 of the 267 refined earthenware sherds (see Table 8.8). The remaining 31 sherds are too small to determine vessel form or shape. Flatware (i.e., plates, saucers, serving platters) is the dominant vessel fonn (60.67% of the total refined earthenware assemblage) while hollowware items (i.e., cups, bowls, chamber pots) and the indeterminate sherds account for the remaining percentage. The dominance of flatware over hollowware is present in eight of the 11 selected sites (see Table 8.8). Refined earthenware was also classified according to decoration (fable 8.9). Although the majority of sherds are undecorated (73.78%), seven decorative varieties are present The most prevalent decoration in the combined refined earthenware assemblage is light, relief molded and embossed wares (n=31 ). Information retrieved from the Richland Creek study indicates that light, molded tablewares became popular on rural farmsteads in north-central Texas during the last decade of the nineteenth century (Jurney and Moir 1987:103-106). Gilding in gold and silver is the second most prevalent decorative motif in the total refined earthenware assemblage. Ostensibly, this contrasts with the fmdings of the Richland Creek area where gilded sherds were extremely rare J€ urney and Moir 1987:106). These gilded sherds, however, are decidedly skewed toward a single site (41EL100, the fonner Buena Vista school and church [see Chapter 5, Boz Quandrangle]) and when this bias is considered, the occurrence of gilded wares in the study area becomes similar to that of the Richland Creek area. Decalcomania is another form of decorated ware that became popular in north-central Texas after 1890 (Jurney and Moir 1987: 103). First appearing in over-the-glaze patterns of delicate sprigs, vines, and flowers in monochrome colors of blues and muted reds, under-the-glaze decalcomania became more popular because it was more enduring. After 1900, polychrome floral patterns were more predominant (Jurney and Moir 1987:104-105). 472 Thomas sherds with decalcomania designs over-the-glaze and under-the-glaze were recovered from five of the 11 selected sites (see Table 8.9). Transfer printed wares were recovered from five sites (see Table 8.9). In these assemblages, transfer prints occur only on white ironstone flatware (plates and saucers). The absence of transfer printed cups is in contrast to the Richland Creek findings where plates and cups were the most frequent vessel form (Jurney and Moir 1987:103). In the present analysis, transfer print designs consist of floral motifs in red; green, blue, or bluish-green with one sherd (41EL101) decorated with a brown rose design. Infrequently used decorations on refined earthenware include shell edged (n=2), hand painted (n=3), and a single specimen of spatterware with a floral design (see Table 8.9). The shell edged sherds (a plain rim and a cockle rim) and the spatterware sherd generally predate 1870. Stoneware As previously stated, stoneware is the second largest subclass of ceramic ware recovered from nine of the 11 selected sites (see Table 8.7). This utilitarian ceramic ware (i.e.,jugs, churns, milk pans.jars, crocks, etc.) was available locally as early as 1839 from numerous small potteries which were founded along the boundaries of the Wilcox-Sand Formation in north-central and east Texas {Lebo 1987:121-126). Isolated from eastern imports by prohtoitive costs and transportation limitations, the local settlers were supplied with utilitarian household items throughout the nineteenth century by these small family-owned potteries (Greer 1981:251). Changes in food storage and preservation as a result of the introduction of metal, modem glass, and plastic containers coupled with the improvements in refrigeration expedited the decline of the use of the large stoneware storage vessels beginning in the early twentieth century (Greer 1981:259; Lebo 1987:121). The aforementioned Richland Creek study of 32 farmsteads provided an excellent opportunity to document the decline of stoneware used in rural households through the late nineteenth and early twentieth centuries. Lebo (1987:127) notes the diminishing frequencies of stoneware found in the archaeological ~ecord as manifested in the number of vessels recovered from each site and the minimum number of vessels discarded per year significantly decreased over time. Based upon the relative stability of refined earthenware over time (Moir 1983:335), a comparison of stoneware and refined earthenware was used in the ~chland Creek study which produced an index of the relative frequency of the two ceramic subclasses. Application of this ratio index (calculated by stoneware/refined earthenware x 10, with 10 being the highest value possible) to the findings of the 32 Richland Creek sites established that ratios between 1:3.78 and 1:9.72 are indicative ofpre-1900 sites, while ratios between 1:0 and 1:5.3 are indicative post-1900 sites (Lebo 1987:127). It is important to note that there exists a significant overlap between the indices of 1:3.78 and I :5.3 which hinders the assignation ofa pre-1900 and post-1900 temporal period for sites that fall within this range of conflict. • Historic Material Culture Remains 475 natural clay slipped stoneware continued longer in this region until it was replaced, not by Bristol stoneware, but by the more modem twentieth century products. Porcelain Porcelain was recovered from nine of the 11 selected sites (see Table 8.7). _Analysis of the porcelain assemblage is based upon paste type, decoration, and vessel fonn determinations. The overwhelming majority of porcelain specimens are tinted pure white (n=29) while the remainder are an off-white (n=3) or tinted bluish-gray {n=l). Four decorative styles were identified in the assemblage: relief molded or embossed (n=6); floral decalcomania over glaze (n=2); hand painted (n=l); transfer printed (n=2); and plain or no decoration {n=28). Vessel form was determined for 28 of the porcelain sherds: hollowware (n=l9); and flatware (n=9). Four porcelain sherds were too small for identification and the4ifth was a statuary fragment The relatively low incidence of porcelain in the ceramic assemblage (8.87% of the total ceramic assemblage) is similar to other rural Texas households (Moir 1987; Jurney and Green 1993). The Richland Creek findings demonstrate that porcelain is not a reliable indicator of economic status or ethnicity; that it was present in small quantities at each of the 32 sites; and that porcelain in rural Texas households had a specializ.ed or restricted function, i.e., semi-decorative accent pieces such as tea cups and saucers (Moir 1987: 108-111). Consequently, porcelain as a highly-prized commodity would have been subject to careful curation and special handling, thereby contributing to its poor representation in the archaeological record. Electrical Parts • Six electrical parts were recovered from three of the 11 selected sites (see Table 8.2) and received in-depth analysis. These materials account for 0.20% of the total historic artifact assemblage from the 11 selected sites and constitute <225% of the individual site artifact assemblages. Electrical parts recovered consist of glass and porcelain insulators (n=4), a carbon battery pole, and a glass fuse. • Historic Material Culture Remains 483 SITE DISCUSSIONS 41EL72 4 lEL7 2, as discussed in Chapter 5 (Boz Quandrangle), consisted of a well and a scatter of artifacts. Although unrecorded by archival or informant research, preliminacy analysis of the artifacts implied that this site was probably occupied by a tenant or manager associated with the large T. J. Hines farm that operated ca. 1869-1902 (see Chapter 3). Information concerning the dwelling or outbuildings was not available either through informants or documents, thereby suggesting that the dwelling was removed in the first quarter of the twentieth centwy. The archaeological investigation conducted at 41EL72 (see Chapter 6, Boz Quadrangle) recovered 666 historic - material culture remains (see Table 8.2): architectural remains (n=185), ceramics (n=72), electrical items (n=l), fuel .. ..., remains (n=25), glass (n=297), horse and stable items (n=2), metal (n=73), miscellaneous items (n=2), and personal items (n=9). Interestingly, the relative frequencies of architectural remains, ceramics, and glass are slightly higher than the corresponding artifact categories from a typical north-central Texas historic ~fact assemblage dating ca. 1880- 1930. In the Richland Creek study, the artifact assemblages from 32 rural farmstead sites average 38% architectural remains, 7% ceramics, and 35% (vessel) glass (Moir and Jurney 1987b: 173). Moir notes that nineteenth centwy tenant farms with occupation less than 30 years generally had larger ceramic assemblages than did owner-occupied farms of the same time period (Moir and Jurney 1987b:171). Additionally, the ceramic frequency from 41EL72 is comparable with assemblages from 1840-1850 frontier farmsteads where ceramics generally constitute I 0-20% oft he total artifact assemblage (Jurney 1992:69). The variation in the relative artifact frequencies, particularly in the ceramic frequency, suggests that 4 IEL7 2 was occupied by tenants and possibly predates 1880. Additional temporal information can be obtained from several artifact indices that were presented above (see • Artifact Descriptions For The 11 Selected Sites By Class). The ratio of cut to wire nails (see Tabl~ 8.4) indicates that the house at 41 EL7 2 was initially constructed ca. 1888-1890. The window glass thickness (see Table 8.6), however, indicates a construction date of ca. 1906. The discrepancy between these construction dates correlates with Jurney's findings (Jurney 1987b:90) that the initial construction date calculated by the cut to wire nail index is generally five to 15 years earlier than the date generated by the window glass thickness index. Other temporal considerations are derived by the ratio of stoneware to refined earthenware (see Table 8.10) which suggests that occupation of the site continued into the twentieth centwy. The presence and quantity of manganese solarized (i.e., amethyst colored) glass bottles (see Table 8.14) also supports a nineteenth centwy and early twentieth centwy occupation. Recognized technological attributes oft he glass bottles recovered from 4 IEL7 2 reveal manufacturing dates from 1850-1900 (i.e., snap case bottles, post bottom plate mold bases, and bottles with finely tooled lip finishes that were turned in a lip mold); however, machine made bottles postdating 1910 are present. Within the ceramic assemblage, white ironstone and bluish tinted stoneware (see Table 8.8) are the only refined earthenware present on the site. The Richland Creek studv recomized

484 Thomas 41EL75 41EL75, as discussed in Chapter 5 (Boz Quandrangle), consisted ofa dwelling (built ca. 1855 and remodeled ca. 1876), a detached garage, a well house, the ruins of a second dwelling, and a weWcistem. This farmstead was owned and occupied by the Dunaway family from 1855-1991 (see Chapters 3 and 5). The homestead was the center ofa large estate amassed and managed by J. M. Dunaway and farmed by tenants. Although not located near a railhead, the Dunaway farm prospered throughout the nineteenth century. At the estate's partition in 1903 and the reduction of the home farm (41EL75), J. R. Dunaway inherited 41EL75 and continued to manage large land holdings that were often cultivated by tenants. The archaeological investigation conducted at 41EL75 (see Chapter 6, Boz Quadrangle) recovered 171 historic material culture remains (see Table 8.2): architectural remains (n= 106), ceramics (n=1 1 ), firearms and related remains (n=l), fuel remains (n=l), glass (n=37), horse and.atable items (n=l), metal (n=l3), and miscellaneous items (n=l). This artifact assemblage is heavily weighted by architectural remains (62%) and as such, is atypical of the Richland Creek ca. 1880-1930 fannstead artifact assemblage where the architectural remains class is generally ca. 3S8/4 oft he total assemblage (see 41EL72, above). The variance may reflect the degradation and/or dismantling of the second dwelling. Within the architectural remains assemblage, the ratio of cut to wire nails indicates a structure built ca. 1892-1895 (see Table 8.4). This date is much later than the documented ca. 1855 initial homesteading of 41EL75. As with the elevated frequency of architectural remains, the cut and wire ratio may be influenced by the construction of the second dwelling. The higher proportion of wire nails supports this supposition. The measurable nail size brackets (see Table 8.5) indicate that the nails supported wall boards and wainscot (63 cm (2.48 in]), galvanized metal roof (5.1 cm (2 in]), and a few nails may have anchored a heavy framing system (8.9 cm (3.5 in]). Unfortunately, the window glass sample size is insufficient to calculate the date of construction by means of the window glass thickness index (see Table 8.6). The ceramic assemblage corresponds and supports the temporal data presented by the architectural remains. The relatively high percentage of refined ~enware (72. 72%) compared to stoneware (9.09%) translates to a calculated index of 1.25 which is indicative of a twentieth century occupation (see Table 8.10). Within the refined earthenware · assemblage (see Table· 8.8), the presence of ironstone ware is indicative of nineteenth century occupation. The presence of ivory tinted ware and fiesta ware, however, reflects the twentieth century occupation. The single piece of stoneware has an alkaline glaz.e exterior (see Table 8.11) which is primarily a nineteenth century form of glazing in the south (see Artifact Descriptions For The 11 Selected Sites By Class, above). The single ceramic maker's mark (lronstone. .. Eng. . ) is incomplete and, unfortunately, provides no temporal data. The glw assemblage contains one table glass sherd that displays the manganese solarized condition of late nineteenth/early twentieth century glass (see Table 8.14). All of the bottles with identifiable technological attributes (machine made and continuous thread) were produced in the twentieth century. • I Historic Material Culture Remains 485 until her death in 1944. At that time, it was inherited by Macy H. Elliott, Forrester's granddaughter, who took up residence at 4 IEL7 7 and managed the large farming operation. The archaeological investigation conducted at 4 lEL7 7 (see Chapter 6, Boz Quadrangle) recovered 384 historic material culture remains (see Table 8.2): architectural remains (n=l3 l), ceramics (n=81), firearms and related remains (n=l), fuel remains (n=8), glass (n=l 17), hand tools and implements (n=l), horse and stable items (n=l), metal (n=36), miscellaneous items (n= 1) , and personal items (n=7). With the exception of ceramics, this artifact assemblage closely approximates a typical north-central Texas farmstead ca. 1880-1930 as discussed above (see 4 lEL7 2). The frequency of ceramic materials is notably greater than the projected 7%, and only slightly exceeds the 10%-20% n<;>ted by Jurney (1992:69) for 1840-1850 frontier farmsteads. As with 41 EL7 2, the elevated percentage of ceramics in the total artifact assemblage may reflect the documented 1870 origin of 4 IEL7 7. An examination of the architectural remains provides estimates of construction dates for the buildings at 41 EL7 7. The ratio of cut to wire nails suggests a construction date of ca. 1892-1895 (see Table 8.4). The calculated date of construction based upon window glass thickness is ca. 1898 (see Table 8.6). It is apparent that the "nail rain" (see Analytical Meth~ology, above) at 41EL77 reflects the additions to the farmstead as well as probable remodeling of the original dwelling. Additional temporal infonnation is provided by a comparison of the relative frequencies of stoneware and refined earthenwares. The stoneware ratio index of2.26 denotes an occupation that generally postdates 1900 (see Table 8.10). The stoneware glazes, however, are indicative of the last quarter of the nineteenth century (see Table 8.11) while the presence of ivory tinted and fiesta style ceramics reflects the twentieth century occupation. Further temporal refinement is provided by IO maker's marks identified in the refined earthenware assemblage (Table 8.19). The maker's marks indicate that at least these ironstone wares are from the last decades of the nineteenth century through the frrst decades of the twentieth century--a time period which spans both tenant and landowner occupation. Within the glass category, bottle sherds constitute 74.35% of the glass assemblage (see Table.8.13). The closure • category includes a bottle stopper _and two fruit jar insets made of white "milk" glass. The minimum number of bottles identified (n=42) include medicine (n=6) and beverage (n=3) bottles (see Table 8.15), Notably absent from the assemblage is spirit (i.e., wine, beer, liquor) bottles, possibly a reflection of the family presence and, particularly, the influence of the last landowner, Mrs. Elliott. A female presence is also strongly suggested in the jar assemblage (see Table 8.15) where the absence of snuffj ars is countered by the high incidence of fruit jars and the presence of a cosmetic jar. An examination of the technological attributes of the bottles recovered from 4 lEL7 7 reveal bottles that date ca. 1850-1900 (snap case, post bottom plate molded, fruit jars with continuous thread and ground lips, and finely tooled lip finish turned in lip mold) along with machine made bottles postdating 1910. One snap case aqua bottle has the maker's mark DOCX identifying it to the D. 0. Cunningham Glass Co. of Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, dating 1882-1937 (Toulouse 1971:163). Another bottle has the maker's mark.I. M Clark & Co. on its post bottom plate mold base.

·• ' Historic Material Culture Remains 487 The archaeological investigation conducted at 41EL8 l, Areas ID and IV, recovered 506 historic material culture remains (see Table 8.2): architectural remains (n=122), ceramics (n=49), firearms and related items (n=2), fuel remains (n=5), glass (n=277), hand tools and implements (n=4), horse and stable items (n=l), metal (n=32), miscellaneous items (n=6), and personal items (n=8). The architectural remains include wire nails (n=29), cut nails (n=21), brick fragments (n=22), window glass (n=40), concrete (n=8) (see Table 8.3). Other in Table 8.3 includes a silo tile and an agate door knob which was popular from 1860 through 1920. Nine of the brick fragments are hand made while the remaining brick items are machine-made bricks that postdate 1860. Architectural materials provide additional temporal infonnation. The ratio of cut nails to wire nails (see Table 8.4) calculates a construction date of the buildings ca. 1892-1895. This late nineteenth century date is supported by the date of 1898 as calculated by window glass thickness frequencies (see Table 8.6). The overwhelming majority of ceramic remains is refined earthenware (75.51 %) resulting in a stoneware index of 1.89 which suggests a post-1900 date (see Table 8.10). Oae of the stoneware fragments, however, is a nineteenth century blacking or ginger beer bottle. Personal items (see Table 8.18) consist of a ceramic four-hole button, a belt buckle, and two ceramic doll's legs. One of the doll's legs has molded "knickers." The material culture recovered from 41EL199 is supportive of the archival information. The assemblage· reflects a family with children occupying the site.atdhe beginning of the twentieth century. Materials postdating ca. 1920-1930s are absent, thereby, corroborating the documentary evidence that the farm was abandoned ca. 1935. As discussed above, the high incidence of stoneware suggests an earlier date than 1900 for 4 IEL 199. An alternative interpretation, however, postulates that the extended use of stoneware was an ethnic tradition maintained by the Czechoslovakian occupants. Unfortunately, the inadequate sample size prohibits any revealing or meaningful conclusions. • 9. VERTEBRATE FAUNAL REMAINS Cassandra Kuba and Dennis C Dirkmaat INTRODUCTION One hundred sixty-eight (168) fauna! remains were recovered as a result of the archaeological investigations conducted by the Archaeology Research Program (ARP) in support of the Superconducting Super Collider (SSC) project. These specimens consist almost exclusively of vertebrate faunal remains (n=l56). The remaining 12 specimens consist of 11 invertebrate fauna} remains and one very small egg shell fragment, which were catalogued but are not discussed herein. • ANALYTICAL METHODOLOGY The procedure by which a vertebrate fauna! assemblage is analyzed may vary in 'as many ways as there are zooarchaeologists. However, three primary steps are followed in all "professional" analyses. The first step is the acquisition of what Clason (1972) terms the "primary data." This is the raw data that is derived from the bones themselves. Minimally, it includes the identification of the animal taxon and specific bone elements represented, as well as the determination of age and sex, the collection of metric data, and recording of various forms of modification to those bone fragments from burning to butchering (Hesse and Wapnish 1985). The second step involves quantification of the data in order to address topics such as: relative importance of the various taxa to the diet; distribution of material through the site both in time and through time; and "kill" population profiles. 502 Kuba and Dirkmaat Bone fragments were first separated into unidentifiable and potentially identifiable categories. Unidentifiable remains are defined in this analysis as those bone specimens that exhibit no distinguishing morphology and cannot be placed into broad taxonomic categories below the family level. The number of modified specimens within the unidentifiable category (e .g., those exhibiting evidence of burning, butchering, and/or chewing) was noted and the total number of unidentifiable specimens in each assemblage was tabulated. Identification of the potentially identifiable fragments was made at the lowest taxon category possible, preferably at the genus and species level Taxonomic identification was accomplished through the comparison of each specimen to: illustrations presented in comparative osteoJogical publications and handbooks (including Brown and Gustafson 1979; Getty 1975; Gilbert 1973; Gilbert et al. 1981; Lawrence 1951; Olsen 1964, 1968a, 1968b, 1972, 1979; Schmid 1972); and comparative collections in the Laboratory for Osteological Research, Mercyhurst College. The most difficult taxonomic decision resided in the differentiation of the large bovid remains. Diagnostic features were not present on any of the fragmentary elements, thus the taxonomic designation Bos/Bison is used throughout this discussion, in Table 9.1 and in Appendix F. As discussed in the following descriptions of each assemblage, contextual information (e.g., historic vs. prehistoric) often allowed for a tentative assignment to one taxon over the other. The precise anatomical portion represented by each specimen (e.g., distal¼, lateral½) was noted as was side (i.e., left versus right), condition of the specimen (well preserved versus slightly eroded versus moderately eroded versus high)y eroded), gross age (immature versus adult), and evidence of modification including thermal alteration, gnathic modification, and butchering. Fragment and anatomical landmark descriptions follow terminology employed in Getty (1975) and Brown and Gustafson (1979). These data were incorporated into an electronic database for permanent storage and to facilitate statistical manipulation. Bone Modifications Thermal Alterations of Bone Bones directly related to subsistence activities of man include those discarded during the carcass reduction process and those associated with the meat component of the diet. Those specimens discarded during the butchering process are, in most cases, only thermally modified during a secondary episode, (e.g., they are thrown into a fire). Bone associated with consumable meat is expected to have been exposed to heat. Either the meat (and attached bone) was cooked in an oven or over an open flame (roasted) or the meat and bone was cooked in water (boiled). Bone surfaces exposed to an open flame will exhibit burned surfaces ranging from charred to calcined conditions. Bone that was involved in boiling-based cooking methods, however, will generalJy not exJu"bit any macroscopic changes nor color changes in the bone surface and thus will not be easily recognized as having been thermally altered. 1- ti. ...........n t '!lnahN>iC! ,f,.t,, nntPrl r.nnrP.ming thermallv altered soecimens included whether the remains were

• Vertebrate Fauna/ Remains 505 Evidence of Butchering Every specimen in each assemblage was carefully examined macroscopically under an intensity lamp for butchering evidence. Evidence ofb utchering ranged from cut marks to sawcuts (Guilday et al 1962; Gust 1983). Those specimens that exhibited macroscopic evidence of this form of modification were further studied under IX to IOX magnification using a Bausch and Lomb dissecting binocular microscope in order to differentiate actual butchering marks from other incidental marks. Quantification Methods Number of Identified Specimens Following the taxonomic identification and description of the skeletal elements, the easiest quantification method to accomplish requires only the tabulation of the number of bone elements within a given taxon (Klein and Cruz-Uribe 1984). This measure is termed the "Number ofldentified Specimens" (NISP) following Payne (1975), Casteel and Grayson (1977), and Grayson (1984). In its rawest form, the relative impor;tance of each taxa is assessed merely through a rank ordering of the taxa based on the number of elements of each taxon that have been identified. This method can be used regardless of the manner of division of a site into analytical units ( e.g., natural vs. arbitrary levels within individual strata [Klein and Cruz-Uribe 1984)). Quantification of Historic Site Zooarchaeological Assemblages At historic archaeological sites a dichotomy often exists between the manner by which lar~e vs. small animals entered the site. This may affect the decision as to which of the quantification methods will be used to study relative subsistence contributions. The remains oflarge animals such as cows were most likely brought onto the site in the form of retail cuts of meat Each bone specimen often represents a complete cut of meat Thus NISP totals of"larger species in well preserved assemblages will closely approximate numbers of meat segments represented in the bone assemblage. Smaller animais---especially fowl, but also possibly caprines and even pigs-may have been brought onto the site in segments of retail cuts, but more likely were killed and butchered at the site. One must first identify whether segments (representing retail cuts of meat) or entire carcasses were originally present at the site. An examination of the parts distributions of each taxon via skeletal silhouettes may be used to answer this first query. If butchering of these smaller animals was done on-site, "Minimum Number of Individuals" (MNl) calculations may have some utility. Therefore, when the assemblages contain both large and small animals, more than one form of quantification method may be

Thomas INTERNAL CORRELATIONS Introduction As originally envisioned, the Superconducting Super Collider (SSC) was to consist of a tunnel ca. 54 mi (86.90 km) in circumference with extensive but discontinuous above-ground facilities designed to service, maintain, monitor, and operate the Collider. A 304.80 m (1,000 ft) wide right-of-way (or restricted area) was centered on the tunnel ring and extended to and included the superjacent ground surface. Where the above-ground facilities were to be constructed, • the right-of-way was increased in size by actual land purchase (i.e., fee simple estate; see Chapter 1) to provide sufficient space to accommodate the individual buildings and other facilities. Taken collectively, these areas combined to form the SSC project footprint (see Chapter 1). Thus, the "final" SSC project area encompassed ca. 69.39 km2 (26.79 mi2) or 6,776.84 ha (16,745.96 acres) in the heart of Ellis County, Texas (see Figure 12). Considerable expense with an attendant high level of effort was expended in cultural resource management studies in support of the SSC over the seven year life history of the project This, the final chapter in the SSC cultural resource management saga, details the results of the archaeological investigations in a synthetic and synoptic fashion. As a result of heavy ground cover these four "ephemeral" sites where not precisely relocated during the East Campus parcel clearance. Therefore, subsurface investigations were conducted to investigate the "immediate vicinity" of these sites (see Chapter 6). These four sites range in defined size from ca. 2,096 m2 (22,558.47 ft2) ( 4 IELI 06) to ca. 2.80 ha (6.92 acres) (41EL118), with an mean size of ca. 1.12 ha (2.77 acres). Approximately 100 shovel test probes were excavated within the immediate vicinity of these four sites and no material culture remains were recovered. The recovered artifactual inventory, not smprisingly, reflects the overall preponderance of historic sites in the SSC study area. Of the 16,014 material cultural remains, only 337 (2.10%) are prehistoric (see Chapter 7) while 15,464 (96.56%) are ascribable to historic contexts (see Tables 6.1, 6.2, and Appendix E). The remainder of the inventory consists of213 ecofacts {1.33%) with a restricted range of both faunal (see Chapter 9 and Appendix F) and floral elements (see Appendix G). While this data base appears relatively massive at first glance, a careful perusal quickly reveals that it is amenable only to limited &Ad, unfortunately, very broad generalizations. This sorry circumstance is a direct consequence of the timing and implementation of the SSC project itself and the scope, scale, and scheduling of the attendant archaeological investigations. Specifically, during the initial pedestrian reconnaissance, all land was still under private ownership, and due to the possibility of crop damage, perceived mutilation or destruction of the landscape, and/or simple resistance to the SSC project, invasive testing (i.e., shovel probes) and even the surficial collection of artifacts was not permitted in many cases. Access problems were compounded by a ''hands off'' policy emplaced by the Texas National Research Laboratory Commission (TNRLC) which was responsible for making contracts with landowners, acquiring visitation permission and access, and undertaking the highly sensitive process of land acquisition. An already untenable position from an archaeological sampling perspective was further complicated by severely restricting the area of investigation on geobore loci in stratified subsurface fee estate (see Chapter 1). Specifically, any sites which were discovered in geobore areas could only be investigated within the boundaries of the boreholes and access routes (e.g., 41EL158; see Chapter 5). Finally, as indicated above, SSC. above-ground construction activities and all attendant archaeofogical subsurface investigations were limited exclusively to fee simple estate which constituted only 63.44% (4,299.49 ha [10,624.28 acres]) of the footprinL Of this fee simple estate, less than 33%, (1,314.31 ha [3,247.53 acres]) or a meager 7.85% of the total footprint received intensive ( or indeed, any!) subsurface archaeological investigation. As a result of all of the foregoing, the overall sample size and statistical representativeness of the SSC archaeological investigations were severely compromised. In addition to the problems cited above, such subsurface archaeological investigations as did occur were conducted • on a priority basis as determined by construction schedules and related activities. In the vernacular of the SSC project, invasive investigations were ''task oriented" (see Chapter 4). Individual project loci were subdivided into archaeologically high and low priority areas. Chronology In the total absence of radiocarbon dates from any of the SSC sites, as well as the extreme paucity of subsurface stratigraphic information cited above, any reconstruction of the chronology of aboriginal use of the study area must derive from the occurrence of cross-dated diagnostic lithics and ceramics. Fortunately, the SSC field _investigations produced a limited corpus of chronologically sensitive material (see Chapter 7) while the analyses of the Chandler, Oates, Lott, and Barton collections (see Appendices A and B) yielded a substantial body of data bearing on the temporal occupational trajectory of the study area. 'The.initial aboriginal use ot: or visitation to, the general study area is signaled by the occurrence of the proximal fragments of three Clovis points in the Chandler collection (see Tables A.3, A.18, and A.19). Though not directly dated anywhere in north-central Texas (see Chapter 2), Clovis style points are well dated elsewhere and are generally ascnbable to the time range of ca. I 0,000-9200 B.C. (11,950-11, 150 B.P.). Even if the more circumscribed temporal limits advocated by Haynes (1993:220) are employed, the three Chandler collection Clovis fragments indicate occupation/visitation of the general SSC study area probably no later than the mean date of9050 B.C. (11,000±200 B.P.) for the 21 14C assays on the Clovis components at Lehner and Murray Springs, Arizona. Despite the absence of Folsom points, a continuing Paleo-Indian point "presence" in the SSC study area is marked by the occurrence of several later Paleo-Indian point types in the Chandler and Lott collections. These minimally include two putative Plainviews, one Dalton, and one Golondrina from the Chandler collection (see Table A.21) and one San Patrice and two untyped but probably late Paleo-Indian lanceolates from the Lott collection (see Table B.l). • Most of the later Paleo-Indian point types from the general study area are ascribable to the Plaqo Horizon or style interval, and as such probably post-date the mid-ninth millennium B.C. initiation of that time segment Possible exceptions to this observation include the Plainview type, which may be as old as Folsoqi (cf. Collins 1995; Haynes 1993), and Daltons which are present in the Mississippi Valley and elsewhere in the Southeast by 8500 B.C. (10,450 B.P.) (Morse and Morse 1983). As noted by Collins (1995:382), ''true" (i.e., thin, carefully pressure flaked) Plainview points such as those recovered from the radiometrically undated type site and Bone Bed 2 at Bonfire Shelter are rare in central Texas but are probably "equally as old" as Folsom. If the Plainviews identified by Tomka (see Appendix A) are indeed representatives of that type, then they are not only among the very few examples recovered from north-central Texas, but are also of considerable antiquity. Elsewhere in central Texas, alleged Plainviews have been recovered from Hom Shelter 2 (Redder 1985) and Wilson-Leonard (Collins et al. 1993). These include Yarbrough, called Middle Archaic in Appendix B (Oates, n= 13; Lott, n=4; Barton, n=5) and Late Archaic in Appendix A (Chandler, N=53), Motley, labeled Late Archaic in Appendix A (Chandler, n=3) and Middle to Late Archaic in Appendix B (Oates, n=l), and Elam, ascribed to the Late Archaic in Appendix A (Chandler, n=3) and Middle Archaic in Appendix B (Oates, n=3; Barton; n=5). The time range spanned by the Late Archaic "collage" of types ranges from as early as ca. 3000-+ B.C. (495o+ B.P.) to ca. A.D. 700 (1250 B.P.) or later (see below). As noted above, a number of Late Archaic point types occur in dated contexts in north-central Texas while in central Texas they have recently (Collins 1995) been assigned to six sequence style intervals based largely on excavations and dated components at Youngsport (Shafer 1963), Anthen (Goode, n.d), Bull Pen, (Ensor and Mueller-Wille 1988) Loeve, Fox (Prewitt 1982), and 41TG91 (Creel 1990). Perhaps significantly, representations of all of these style intervals are documented for the greater SSC study area suggesting continuing utilization/visitation of • this area over the entire time span of the Late Archaic. • The penultimate aboriginal exploitation/visitation of the greater SSC study area occurs during the Late Prehistoric which, in the present context, is taken to begin ca. A.D. 700 (1250 B.P.). As many have noted (e.g., Collins 1995; Johnson and Goode 1994; Prewitt 1981), this date is to some extent arbitrary and is predicated largely on the appearance of a series of projectile point types whose dimensions and technical attributes suggest use on arrows rather than hand cast weapons. There is widespread agreement that the Late Prehistoric is sub-divisible into smaller time segments labeled Early and Late or Late Prehistoric I and II, and further, that these sub-periods are essentially synonymous with the sequent Austin and Toyah "manifestations." Temporal.diagnostics for the earlier portion of the Late Prehistoric (Late Prehistoric I), ca. A.D. 700-1300 (1250- 650 B.P.), include the persistence of Gary points and the appearance of a variety of Central and east Texas arrow point types. This soil series, which was heavily exploited in historic times (see below) presumably also supported highly productive floral regimes in the past. These plant communities could, in tum, have been exploited both by humans as well as potentially edible fauna Several other site selection factors may be operating in this area as well. Though elevation, per se, seems not to have been a factor in site selection, access to water, not surprisingly, is important. Virtually all of the sites in the Bardwell area are within 3 km (1.86 mi) of a third order or larger stream. Such streams are more likely to flow during periods of extended drought (see Chapter 1) , and therefore provide secure and reliable sources of drinking water for animals and humans, and also provide natural routes for the movement of both human and animal populations. This situation is not, of course, unique to the study area but also obtains for virtually all of north-central Texas if not the Desert West at large. With one possible exception, other potential site location factors such as defensibility, availability of atypical geomo,phological phenomena (i.e., caves and rockshelters), and/or ceremonial/religious considerations do not appear to be operative in or near the SSC footprint. There is no evidence to indicate that the SSC project area, or indeed any portion of Ellis County, was ever contested by ethnically distinct prehistoric populations, and the general similaricy of the relief militates against the existence of topographically unique defensive settings. Similarly, th~ugh ceremonial/religious consideration could have influenced site selection, there is absolutely no evidence to support such a scenario. Perhaps the only other factor which may have shaped at least part of the aboriginal site selection process is access to lithic raw material, though frankly, this consideration is fraught with problems. Virtually from the outset of this project, a series of interrelated assumptions was made by the original principal investigators about the relationship of prehistoric sites to Uvalde Gravel veneer deposits. The first assumption was that wherever a surface exposure of Uvalde Gravel was observed in conjunction with so-called ''tested cobbles" (see Chapter 5 and Table 11.1 ), a site was presumed to be present. Second, the site boundaries were determined a priori to be co • extensive with the margins of the surface exposures of Uvalde Gravel. For a variety of reasons articulated below, these assumptions are now considered to be tenuous at best and specious at worst Prior to July 1992, twenty-two prehistoric sites or components (41EL58, 4 IEL99, 4 lELl 06, 41EL108, 4 IELl 13, 4IEL114, 41EL116, 4IEL118, 4IEL119, 41EL155, 41EL156, 41EL158, 41EL162, 41EL177, 41EL179, 41EL180, 41EL182, 41EL185, 41EL201, 41EL205, 41EL207, and 41EL215 [see Chapter 5]) were defmed on the basis of the presence of"an area ofUvalde Gravel veneer with associated fractured chert nodules." Unfortunately, only 11 of the sites produced bona fide specimens of anthropogenically flaked stone (see Table 11.1 and Chapter 7). Furthermore, despite their often great surficial extent, seven of these 11 "sites" (41EL99, 41EL116, 41ELl19, 41EL158, 41EL162, 41EL177, and 41EL207) yielded three or fewer flaked stone artifacts. While these factors alone suggest that there is no one-to-one correlation between modem surface exposures of the Uvalde Gravel veneer and the presence of a prehistoric site, they do not exist in isolation. Two other observations are offered on the use of modem surface exposures of the Uvalde Gravel veneer deposits in the definition of prehistoric sitdcomponent boundaries. First, in all cases, modem surface exposures in Ellis County are, in large part, located in active or fallow agricultural fields and were exposed via plowing. It is impossible to determine how much, if any, of these modem exposures were represented as prehistoric exposures prior to plowing. Second, the Secretary of the Interior's Standards and Guidelines (National Parle Service 1983:44727) state that "boundaries should correspond as clearly as possible to the actual extent and configuration of the property and should be carefully selected to encompass, but not exceed (emphasis added) the extent of the significant resource(s). Arbitrary boundaries should not be chosen for ease of description. .." Future researchers in Ellis County are well advised to consider both of these points when modem surface exposures of the Uvalde Gravel veneer are encountered. Though it should be obvious at this point that there. iMlo absolute correlation between modem exposures of Uvalde Gravel veneers and aboriginal sites, it is equally apparent (see Chapter 7 and Appendices A and B) that raw material derived from some Uvalde Gravel outaops were used for aboriginal tool manufacture (McGregor 1987b; Mell7.el' and Slaughter 1971; Peter and McGregor 1988b; Prikryl 1990). Given the fact that these veneers are differentially composed of quartzite cobbles, chert nodules, and silicified wood, and further given the strong preponderance of cherts of apparently local provenience in the raw material sources enumerated in this volume, it may be assumed that the Uvalde sources most heavily exploited aboriginally were those which contained the greatest frequency of suitable chert nodules. Clearly, unless the data presented here and in Chapter 7 is erroneous, most of the Uvalde Gravel veneers sampled during the SSC field investigations were not suitable or preferred sources for lithic procurement This in turn suggests that these particular sources were not important in site selection considerations. However, some presently unspecified number of Uvalde Gravel outcrops were clearly utilized and may have played a role in attracting prehistoric populations to the greater SSC study area. It is suggested that such chert-rich gravels would have been even more attractive if they occurred in settings which, from the perspective of both soil and water, were also highly favored loci. This scenario is admittedly speculative since only one of the putative sites, 41EL182, appears to "fit'' ~e hypothetical parameters specified above. The clistnbution ofhistoric sites in the SSC footprint is much more circumscnbed than the incidence of prehistoric sites. Further, because of the availability of generally extensive written records for at least the last ca. 150 years, the observed pattern is much more representative of''reality." Almost half of the historic sites are concentrated on the west campus with a secondary concentration in the Bardwell Lake area. In virtually every case, the primary settlement consideration is access to deep well drained soils on flat to gently sloping topography with nearby access to water. These are the primary necessities in raising cotton and other cash crops and the general absence of historic sites in situations which lack these attractions further indicates their role in historic site placement. The limited suite of historic faunal remains, not surprisingly, is dominated by cow (Bos sp.), pig (Sus scrofa), and chicken (Gallus gal/us) with the occasional representation of sheep (Ovis aries) or goat (Capra hircus). With the exception of the dog and avian remains, the mammalian fauna could represent supplements to the domestic diet. General Character of Site and Areal Occupation The same limitations in the extant SSC data base which render reconstruction of subsistence and seasonality parameters almost impossible, also severely limit the ability to characteriz.e either the function(s ) of most prehistoric sites or the general character of aboriginal utiliution of the study area. Of the 42 prehistoric sites recorded during the SSC field investigations, 15 are assigned to the non-functional • category "isolated finds." This total includes not only those sites listed in Table 11.1 as isolated fin~, but also 41EL99, 41 EL 177, and 41EL201. 41 EL99 yielded three prehistoric material culture remains, two pieces of flaked stone debitage and an untyped projectile point (see Chapters 6 and 7). All three specimens were recov,ered from surface contexts; however, two pieces of flaked stone debitage were widely separated from the location of the projectile point The distal end of the projectile point is truncated by end shock presumably resulting from an impact fracture and one of the barbs is truncated and retouched (see Chapter 7). As hypothesized in Chapter 6, this specimen may have been lost during use (i.e., while hunting), which could also account for the impact fracture. Despite Tomka's comments on statistical representativeness (see Appendix A), the remaining Chandler sites, 41EL20, 41EL21, 41EL22, and 41EL24, contain a much more restricted array of materials representing a presumably more restricted array of behaviors. Though some or all of these sites could be habitations, the data is inconclusive. From reuse and duration of occupation perspectives, it is clear that many of the Chandler collection sites were revisited or reused over substantial periods of time. This is scarcely unexpected since many of these loci occur in the "prime" habitation, hunting, and collecting settings of Ellis and adjacent Navarro Counties. In the absence of stratigraphic data coupled with extensive horizontal exposures, it is not possible to determine duration of occupation parameters beyond noting that many of the Chandler sites probably supported quite short term bivouac-style camps for .. most of the Paleo-Indian, Early Archaic, and probably Mi<W.le Archaic periods. If the bulk of the associated lithic material from sites where Late Archaic points predominate is associated with these points, then these sites may represent base camps or longer term seasonal occupations during some or all of that time span. The permanence or duration of site use during the Late Prehistoric is-like so many other aspects of the SSC occupational record-problematic. The presence of ceramics in the Chandler collection and to a much lesser extent for the SSC field collections, implies a greater degree of sedentism but certainly does not guarantee it In the absence of residential structures at any of the Chandler sites, only the relatively dense concentrations of materials previously reported from 41EL1 l (Sorrow 1966) directly suggest that during the latest part of its history, at least this locus supported a near sedentary occupation. The range of activities which appear to be reflected on the prehistoric sites identified on or near the SSC footprint are, as noted above, relatively diverse or at least more diverse than suggested in the faunal research design (ARP 1992a). While some of these posited activities are clearly hypothetical and based on very limited eviden~e, others are more reliably and confidently suggested or inferred. Certainly, whatever its relationship to the Uvalde Gravel veneers, stone tool manufacture is documented both in and near the SSC footprint Unfortunately, the degree of documentation is · -. uneven and the composition of the lithic samples both from the SSC field studies and the studied private collections is scarcely reflective oft he full range of procurement, production, maintenance, or rejuvenation activities which must have been common at many of the SSC sites, specifically, and Ellis County sites, generally. The drastically under-represented debitage assemblages in the Chandler collections (n=l 17) are dominated by local fine grained chert (n=45; 38.5%) followed by local fine-grained quartzite (n=31; 26.5%). No debitage was analyzed from the Oates, Lott, and Barton collections. Collectively, all of the foregoing suggests extensive utilization oflocal sources with a clear preference for fine grained crypto-crystalline rock. Taken in conjunction with the information provided above, it clearly suggests that only the more chert-rich Uvalde Gravel veneers in and near the SSC footprint were the most favored source areas for local lithic procurement Other utilitarian activities documented either in the SSC sites or in the examined collections (see Chapter 7 and Appendices A and B) include: bunting and related processing, as reflected by a profusion of dart and arrow points, a variety of"scrapers" and "knives," and perhaps other unifaces and bifaces; woodworking or shaping, as suggested by the presence of adzes, gouges, gravers, and perhaps wedges; plant food and/or ochre-pigment processing as indicated by the limited suite of ground stone artifacts and the presence of two pieces of hematite; leathe1u0r hide working, as suggested by both the "scraper'' assemblage and the presence of perforators; bone tool production, as reflected by the two worked bone specimens, some of the ground stone, and perhaps, several of the "scraper'' and graver types; fishing, if the Waco sinkers are, indeed, used in conjunction with that activity; and, of course, ceramic production and related usage. In later time periods, non-utilitarian activities are probably reflected in the small presumed gorget/pendant fragment from 41EL19 and the limited suite of worked shell. In the absence of stratigraphic data, it is of course almost impossible to postulate which, if any, of the posited activities were time period specific, with the obvious exception of ceramic production. Likewise, in the absence of appropriate preservation conditions, it is virtually impossible to speculate on the range and diversity of fiber perishable items undoubtedly produced throughout the occupational record of this part of Texas. Taken as a whole, the meager prehistoric artifact assemblage from the SSC field studies, the restricted array of • sites, and the rather more extensive and diverse materials from the Chandler, Oates, Lott, and Bartoq collections, reflect .,_ a basic trajectory of settlement, technology, and related activities basically not dissimilar to that previously postulated either for north-central Texas, specifically, or central Texas, generally. The affinities, relationships, and coMections of the prehistoric SSC assemblages are addressed in greater detail in External Correlations. EXTERNAL CORRELATIONS Affinities, Relationships, and Interregional Interactions The archaeological and historic assemblages from the greater SSC study area exhibit a number of basic affinities to complexes, components, and/or collections from elsewhere in north-central Texas and, progressively further afield, central and east Texas, and ultimately, North America at large. These affinities vary in time and space and are predicated on stylistic and morphological resemblances of one or another of the SSC artifact classes or their constituents to similar materials from elsewhere. Though analysis oflithics recovered from the SSC sites (see Chapter 7) identified only one formally named type (Gary Barbed), analysis of the projectile points in the Chandler collection (Appendix A) identified'878 (616 dart and 262 arrow) specimens which could be assigned to 56 (40 dart and 16 arrow) previously names types. Additionally, analysis of the projectile points in the Oates, Lott, and Barton collections (see Appendix B) identified 324 (263 dart and 61 arrow) specimens which could be assigned to 50 (39 dart and 11 arrow) previously described types. The projectile points examined in these analyses, and to a much lesser extent the ceramic inventories, provide the principal basis for assessing changing affinities and relationships through time. As noted previously (see Internal Correlations), Paleo-Indian, Early Archaic, and Middle Archaic materials are restricted to the analyzed amateur collections. The Paleo-Indian points are, for the most part, local reflections and/or exemplars of cultural stages/time periods or "populations," which in the case of at least one constituent, Clovis, has continent-wide affinities. If the stylistic affinities posited above are accurate, and reflect aboriginal ''reality," it is unclear what kind of reality is represented. Changes in projectile point styles (and to a lesser extent ceramic types) could represent actual population movement (see below) or one of several kinds of diffusion as well as trade and exchange. Whatever factor or factors contributed to the occurrences of"shared'' point and pottery styles between north-central, central, and east Texas, they do indicate regional interaction as those tenns are nonnally defined. So also, in a very graphic and probably more direct way, does the occurrence of exotic or non-local lithic resources in Ellis County. The raw material identification scheme (see Appendix A) employed in the analysis of the SSC flaked stone assemblages only identified non-local cherts, assigning all quartzites to a local provenience. Of the non-local cherts, only two varieties were specifically identified, Pisgah Ridge chert and Bigfork chert. Based upon this analysis, the percentage ofnon-local raw materials to local raw materials is, as noted previously, overwhelmingly in favor oflocal provenience. The number offonned implements (i.e., projectile points, bifaces, unifaces, etc.) manufactured of non local chert (all of non-local fine-grained chert; n=4) is nearly identical to the number of formed implements manufactured oflocal chert (n=5). A single formed implement was manufactured of an unidentified chert (see Chapter 7). Seven specimens of unmodified flaked stone debitage of non-local chert (non-local fine-grained chert, n=2; Pisgah Ridge chert, n=4; and Bigfork chert, n=l) as well as six utilized and/or modified flakes of non-local chert (non-local fine-grained chert, n=4; and Pisgah Ridge chert, n=2) were recovered. The unmodified debitage split virtually equally between primary (n=4) and secondary (n=3) flaked stone technologies (see Chapter 7). These data suggest the movement of both unprocessed or minimally processed raw materials (i.e., cores and blanks [see Chapter 7 and Appendix DJ) and nearly or totally finished fonned implements onto these sites. Analysis of the Chandler collection (see Appendix A) identified the raw material for 3,099 formed tools (i.e., • projectile points, perforators, adzes, axes, knives, scrapers, multifunctional tools, and miscell~eous bifaces and ' unifaces). Of these, only ca. 6% (n=185) of the specimens were manufactured ofnon-local cherts (i.e., non-local fine grained chert, n= 174; Pisgah Ridge chert, n=4; and Bigfork chert, n=7). This collection contained only 117 pieces of unmodified flaked stone debitage, 28 of which (ca. 24%) were of non-local chert (i.e., non-local fine-grained chert, n=24; and Pisgah Ridge chert, n=4). Given the under-representation of debitage in the collection, the significance of this material disparity is unclear. What can be gleaned from these raw materials analyses is that some form of far ranging interregional interaction involved the SSC project area prehistorically. Fields et al. OVERVIEW: THE ARCHAEOLOGY OF THE SSC~ILK PURSES AND SOWS' EARS As originally conceived, both the Superconducting Super Collider itself as well as the attendant cultural resource management studies bad far-reaching, if not downright grandiose, goals. The objectives of the Supercollider are a matter ofpubli~ecord; the goals of the archaeological study were articulated in the research design (ARP 1992a). As it turned out, the Supercollider, was never built and none of its potential. to affect particle physics for the next half centwy, will ever reach fruition. For the Collider, there is, in effect, no future. Curiously, historians might say paradoxically, the SSC project still bas a past-not simply a past reflected in the history of a failed megatecb phenomenon, but a past explicit in the recovered prehistoric and historic data base detailed and discussed above. While none of the objectives of the project which triggered this research will ever be achieved, some of the objectives detailed in the archaeological research design of 1992 were, in fact, accomplished. Rather than reiterate what was learned or added to the prehistoric and historic record for north-central Texas, we prefer to address, for the last time as it were, the highly circumscribed nature of the SSC archaeological data base. As noted elsewhere in this report, and as discussed in the Research Design (ARP 1992a), a central theme of the proposed SSC archaeological and historic studies was marginality. In the Research Design (ARP 1992a), the marginality or relative isolation of the SSC project area, both prehistorically and historically (i.e., during the pre railroad/pre-1870's period), was accepted unconditionally (see Chapter 4). This marginality was defined as: ... neither "good" nor "bad," "significant'' nor "insignificant''. .. [it is] a condition or set of interactive conditions in which both the archaeological manifestations and the geoarchaeological settings in which they occur are different in degree and kind from their counterparts to the north and southwest and east. The sites ... are ephemeral and seem to reflect ( on the basis of surficial materials) transient utiliz.ation by highly mobile groups for short periods of times. Moreover, the array of distinct behavioral sets reflected by these sites, seems again on the basis of surface remains, to be highly circumscribed (ARP 1992a). The prehistoric sites and components recorded and investigated in support of the SSC project fulfill every aspect of the above defmition. • Conclusions 535 At least within the portions of the two floodplains dated herein, post-European contact agricultural practices may be the cause of the rapid erosion of upland surfaces with resultant and equally rapid valley bottom/floodplain aggradation. ## Page 562

536 Adovasio, Yedlowski, ShaunesS)I_, and Thomas If on the other hand, the success of the project is measured in the effective and efficient implementation of the archaeological investigations and the maximization of field effort and data recovery, then from an archaeological perspective the SSC project was less than totally successful. As indicated in Chapter 4, despite early attempts to define a project area which could be systematically investigated, several practical considerations hampered effective investigations. All lands, at the initiation of the field investigations, were still in private ownership. In fact some land slated for fee simple acquisition was still in private ownership at the time of congressional tennination of the project. Therefore, due to the possibility of crop damage, perceived mutilation of private property, or simple resistance to trespass, subsurface testing (i.e., shovel probes) and, more importantly, the collection of any artifacts was not pennitted in many cases. This initial "hands-off' policy resulted in the recordation of a number of sites for which no data was collected other than location and apparent character (i.e., estimated size, probable temporal affiliation, observed material culture remains, etc.). Additionally, the prioritization of archaeological investigations based on construction activities and schedules resulted in a number of sites and project areas being repeatedly reinvestigated (see Chapter 6). From a managerial and business perspective this was a perfectly rational approach. This approach to cultural resource management is not unique to the SSC project, TNRLC, or DOE, rather it is the nonn in publicly funded environmental impact studies. From an archaeological perspective this resulted in the inefficient use of time and personnel which must have impa¢:d the final cost effectiveness of the archaeological investigations. To what extent is impossible to quantify. The most·costeffective and efficient approach to the implementation of the archaeological investigations would have been to systematically conduct a total coverage, non-invasive pedestrian reconnaissance of the SSC footprint at which time all observed surface material culture remains would have been collected. This survey could have been supplemented by construction prioritized reconnaissance and subsurface investigations ( e.g., shovel test probing, geotechnical boreholes, etc.). After completion of this initial survey all lands slated for fee simple acquisition would have received systematic subsurface investigation. But all this is speculation with the acute clarity of hindsight. Ultimately, the success or failure of the archaeological and historical investigations conducted in support of the Superconducting Super Collider rest on the ability of ARP to produce (or morph!) a silk purse out of the sow's ear which was the de facto SSC field sample. The degree of that failure or success must ul~ately be judged by those agencies and individuals who review this report as well as those who employ its data base in future projects. While one could speculate endlessly on "could have beens and might have beens" both for the Superconducting Super Collider and the attendant archaeology, there is little to be gained from the exercise.

Sorrow 1966). As a result, the little that is _known of the prehistory of Ellis County has been reconstructed from a very limited database, while a larger corpus of information contained in privately held artifact collections has remained untapped. This appendix, along with the • following, taps that corpus of information to provide complementary data to that presented in Chapters 5 through I 0. Specifically, this appendix describes the results of analysis of 4,162 artifacts that form a portion of the Chandler Collection. Chandler 41EL5 is located on a fairly steep slope on the west side of Waxahachie Creek and on the north side of Highway 34 about 5 miles southwest of Ennis on the Loveless farm property. This site area slopes to the west bank of the Waxahachie Creek channel. There is a seep spring near the bottom of the slope, and much of this area was wet when the site was discovered and recorded. The site extends up the slope to the high level ground that was in cultivation. The sloping site area was below a dirt road that ran from the old Highway 34 to the Loveless homestead on the high • ground along Waxahachie Creek. Above this road, two Clovis basal fragments were collected in the cultivated area near a utility pole. _Nearly all the other artifacts were collected below the road along the slope toward the seep spring. -;£bese artifacts were all poorly made and heavily patinated. · 4 IELI I is on the west side of Waxahachie Creek about 0;66 mile north ofH ighway 34 on the Bo.zek farm property (now Waxahachie Creek State Park) at the end of the cultivated area where the land begins to slope sharply to the Waxahachie Creek channel. There is a permanent spring at the crest of this slope among some pecan trees. The area around and below the spring was fenced, and the sloping area occasionally was disked to retard water moving down the slope to the creek. This area was sometimes used as pasture. Most of the artifacts collected from this site were collected from around the spring and down the slope. The collection was made in the early 1960s prior to the building of Lake Bardwell and the excavation of 4 lELl 1. There was a straight public road from Highway 34 that ran north to the Bozek home, which was just across the road from 4 IELI I. This road curved to cross Waxahachie Creek and led east to Ennis. This road now terminates at the lake shore.

• The Chandler Collection, Prehistoric Artifacts from Ellis and Navarro Counties, Texas A. 7 hammerstones; mano/hammerstones; metates; Waco sinkers; worked hematite; boatstone; grooved stone; pitted stone; and a gorget fragment Morphofunctional Classification of Chipped Stone Artifacts The large size of the collection allowed a detailed examination of artifacts that often are poorly represented in archaeological investigations. This, in tum, affected the structure of the analyses conducted. Functional tool categories can be determined more easily when tool samples are large, so given this rare luxury in the case of the Chandler Collection, functionally specific categories were used when and where possible rather than dividing the collection into somewhat ambiguous morphological categories (e.g., bifaces, unifaces, cobble tools, etc.). This approach is reminiscent of the manner in which many archaeologjcal reports written in Texas in the 1960s and 1970s were organiz.ed (cf. Duffield 1963b; Jelks 1965; Shafer et al. 1964; Sorrow 1966; Story and Shafer 1965). It has the advantage of providing the reader with an immediate association of the artifacts being described with the activities in which these artifacts were employed ( e.g., knife, graver, adz.e, etc.). Methodologically, however, it places greater emphasis upon macroscopic and microscopic use-wear analysis and stresses the need to combine morphological features with use-wear characteristics in the definition of functional classes of artifacts. These functional classes were determined by observing each artifact under 20x magnification. Some artifacts for which no functional designation could be made also were investigated for use-wear traces under 80x magnification. Unfortunately, time and equipment limitations did not allow the scanning of larger numbers of artifacts at 80x in order to unambiguously determine the nature of use wear and the tool's function. Tools for which functional determinations could not be made based on macroscopic and microscopic wear analyses and morphological criteria were placed into two traditional morphological groups, miscellaneous bifaces and miscellaneous unifaces. Unifacially and/or bifacially flaked stemmed specimens with triangular-to leaf-shaped blade segments, sharply • pointed distal ends, sharp lateral blade edges, and barbed or shouldered proximal blade portions•were classified as projectile points. Although upon initial scanning numerous projectile points, especially dart points, exhibited use wear probably derived from their use as knives, these specimens were left in the projectile point functional category. This decision was adopted because the multifunctional nature of these tools has been well estabftshed (Ahler 1971). Additionally, it was not possible to determine with certainty if the multiple uses of these artifacts were concurrent or they functioned first as projectile points and next were recycled as knives. Artifacts with relatively long and narrow bifacially-flaked blades characterized by diamond-shaped transverse cross sections were classified as perforators. They exhibited use-related microflaking on either both faces of each edge or on alternate faces of opposite edges and also polish and rounding on the body of the blade. Artifacts with acute working edges, with or without unifacial and/or bifacial retouch, and exhibiting use wear in the form of flake scar ridge rounding, polish, and striations parallel to the longitudinal axis on both faces of the working ···-..1--..1 --..1 .. edge were classified as knives.
