## Page 606

A.8 Tomka Bifacially flaked artifacts with subtriangular outlines, irregular sinuous lateral edges and proximal ends, and gently convex, more-systematically flaked wide ends exhibiting haft wear along and on the narrow ends and moderate to heavy use wear on the distal ends were classified as axes. The haft wear consists of polish and rounding of protruding flake scar ridges on both faces of the proximal end. Use wear on the bifacially flaked working edge, centered in the middle of the transverse cross section of the tool, consists of some crushing and heavy rounding and polish of flake scar ridges and polish of lower-lying portions of both faces adjacent to flake scar ridges. Many specimens retain cortex on one or both faces and a slight to pronounced constriction near the wide end. These bifacial artifacts commonly have been referred to as Erath bifaces, a ''type" defined by Story and Shafer (1965) based on specimens recovered from Waco Reservoir sites in north-central Texas. Cobbles retaining a cortex-covered surface opposite a unifacially or bifacially flaked working edge and having an edge with substantial crushing, step fracturing, and/or rounding were classified as choppers. Wedges aq, morphologically similar to, although much smaller than, choppers. In addition, although they are backed by small corticate surfaces, their working edges only rarely exhtoit use-derived step fracturing and crushing and are never rounded. Some wedges might also retain signs of battering or crushing on their corticate proximal ends derived from pounding with a wooden baton or other hard material. Three specimens are identical in morphology to artifacts identified as "Perkin Pikes" by Jelks (1965:175-176, Figure 85) from McGee Bend sites. Unifacially flaked artifacts, including a few specimens with minimal bifacial flaking either along the working edge or the proximal end were classified as scrapers. They are characterized by relatively acute working edges and occasionally exhibit use-related microflaking (but only on a siQgle face), and more commonly exhibit edge rounding on either distal and/or lateral edges, with or without modification for hafting. Although, with the exception of the working-edge angle, most unifacially flaked gouges also fit this description, they are distinguished from the scrapers based on the differential distribution and extent of use wear derived from differences in the manner of use (i.e., p)aning=gouges, scraping=scrapers). Tools with use-related microflaking on the dorsal face of the working edge were classified as scrapers, while specimens that exhibit use wear primarily on the ventral face of the working edge were classified as gouges. Artifacts that have been intentionally retouched to form a point or projection, but exhibit minimal retouch or modification overall wese classified as gravers. This functional category also includes formal tools such as projectile points, bifaces, and other potential functional categories that contain utilized sharp projections derived either from purposeful reworking, use, or manufacture breakage. Unmodified debitage consists of the by-products of core preparation and reduction and tool manufacture, rejuvenation, and reworking. It includes all flakes and flake fragments that have not been retouched into previously mentioned tools and/or have not been utilized in an unretouched form as expedient tools. In addition to these broad functional categories, a number of morphological, functional, and/or typological subcategories are employed in the classification of projectile points, perforators, adz.es, axes, knives, gouges, scrapers, gravers. multifunctional tools, miscellaneous bifaces, and miscellaneous unifacial artifacts. Manufacture failed arrow and dart points that have sufficiently complete or well-finished stems were classified into an existing type and were considered preforms of the appropriate type. Projectile points that could not be classified into existing types were grouped into morphologically similar groups and subgroups based on stem and base morphology ( e.g., untyped expanding stem/straight base, Group I, Group II, etc.; untyped expending stem/convex base, Group I, Group Il, etc.). Two functional subcategories of perforators were distinguished: drills and reamers. Drills, specimens with sharp tips and narrow blades, are assumed to have been utilized to perforate materials. Reamers, perforators with a wider, more-rounded tip and broader blades, are assumed to have been used to enlarge already-existing holes. In addition, based on the degree of retouch employed in their manufacture, perforators were divided into three morphological subcategories: formal; minimally retouched; and expedient Specimens with bifacially flaked blades and stems were considered formal. This group may contain a variety of forms, including flakes with bifacially chipped blades and stems, as well as projectile points and/or bifaces reworked into perforators. Perforators made on flakes and exhibiting bifacial flaking only on the blade were classified as minimally retouched. Flakes with a fortuitous sharp protrusion employed as a perforator without prior retouch were considered expedient perforators. Adzes were divided into two morphological subcategories: formal; and minimally retouched. Bifacially flaked specimens that represent systematic shaping of the blank, are characteriz.ed by thin to moderately thin cross-sections, and have well-aligned edges were classified as formal adzes. Largely unifacially flaked specimens that are less extensively and regularly shaped than bifacially flaked specimens were classified as minimally retouched adzes. Two morphological subcategories of axes were present: stemmed; and notched. Subtriangular specimens that exhibit tapered or recurved concave lateral edges, and polish and rounding on flake scar ridges on both faces of the • proximal narrow end were considered stemmed axes. A single oval axe with an unmodified corticate base but two bifacially flaked notches on opposite lateral edges a short distance from the base was considered a notched axe. This specimen appears to be similar to two chipped stone axes from the Jonas Short Site ( 41SA101) investigated by Jelks (I 965: 179-180). Knives were divided into four morphological subcategories: formal; minimally retouched; expedient; and minimally retouched/expedient. Specimens that are bifacially flaked to the degree that the original shape of the parent material is totally altered were considered formal knives. These specimens might still retain a portion of the parent flake blank's ventral surface, but they are bifacially flaked along most or all of their circumference. Items with bifacial flaking distributed irregularly and only patchily along the margins of the parent material were considered minimally retouched. Blades and or flakes with no retouch but exhibiting use wear derived from the performance of cutting/slicing activities were considered expedient knives. ## Page 608

A.JO Tomka modification observed on these specimens derives solely from utilization as scrapers. Individual scrapers exhibiting a combination of minimally retouched and unretouched but use-worn working edges were classified into the combination minimally retouched/expedient scraper subcategory. In terms of location of edge retouch and working-edge use wear (i.e., on expedient unifaces), specimens in the three subcategories of scrapers were further divided into three subgroups: end scrapers; side scrapers; and combination end/side scrapers. In classifying a tool as an end or side scraper, the specimen is oriented parallel to the ·direction of force in which the parent flake was removed from the core. For example, specimens with use wear and/or modification on the distal end of the parent flake were classified as end scrapers. Scrapers on which the direction of force could not be determined were classified based on the location of the modification relative to the long axis of the specimen. Specimens with retouch and use wear on the short edges or distal ends were classified as end scrapers, while scrapers with flaking along the longer edges or sides of the parent flake were classified as side scrapers. Scrapers with flaking and use wear along both the distal and lateral edges were classified as combination end/side scrapers. Gravers also were classified into three morphological subcategories: formal; minimally retouched; and expedient Formal gravers are specimens on which the manufacture of the graver tip requires substantial retouching of the edges of the parent material being worked. Minimally retouched gravers are specimens on which the graver tip was made through the enhancement of naturally occurring protrusions on the parent material so that only minimal retouching was necessary to produce a functional ~ge. Expedient gravers represent tools on which the working edge is either a naturally occurring protrusion that was used without retouch or the working edge was produced accidentally or incidentally during the use of a functionally different tool. The latter subcategory includes projectile points, bifaces, and other tool forms which fail either in manufacture or use in such a fashion as to create edges suitable as gravers. Usually these edges need no retouching prior to use but often are rejuvenated/resharpened through burin removals as they become worn and less effective. With the exception of a single recycled ground stone tool for which the last function could not be determined, other artifacts or tools that have experienced two or more uses as a result of recycling while in the systemic behavioral context were categorized according to their last functional role. For instance, a projectile point reworked into a perforator was classified and discussed under perforators rather than projectile pomts. In the description of this category, however, it is mentioned that the specimen is a reworked projectile point Artifacts or tools that appear to have been used for the performance of two or more functionally distinct tasks or have two or more concurrently functioning working edges were classified as multifunctional tools. They differ from the above-mentioned recycled tools in that multifunctional tools might have been used in a variety of tasks without requiring the reworking of the working edges of the tool. Incomplete bifacially flaked artifacts and complete specimens with or without use wear that could not be assigned to a functional category were grouped into the broad morphological category of miscellaneous bifaces. These bifaces were further subdivided into six morphotypological subcategories: Bristol; Lutlcin Implements; small thin bifaces; rnrtPv-h:1r.ln'!i1 hifaces: binointed bifaces: and miscellaneous unclassifiable fragments. Miscellaneous unifacially flaked specimens consist of edge fragments that could not be placed confidently into any of the previous categories but represent unifacially flaked specimens that exhibit use wear derived from scraping. Ground/Battered Stone Artifact Subcategories Medium to large tabular limestone and/or sandstone specimens with a shallow to deeply concave surface exlnoiting an even smooth surface, often accompanied by polish and pecking derived from grinding-surface rejuvenation were considered metates. Small to medium-sized oval to rounded quartzite and/or sandstone nodules exhibiting smoothing, polish, and/or pecking were considered manos. Similarly shaped and sized nodules with pitting and crushing of the surfaces of the rock in addition to the smoothing, polish, and pecking noted on manos were classified as mano/hammerstones. Small to medium-sized tabular sandstone or limestone pieces and/or quartzite nodules with one or more artificially created depressions in the otherwise flat and sometimes ground surface were considered pitted stones (Turner and Hester 1993:308-309). Small sandstone or limestone nodules with one or more often parallel artificially formed V- or U-shaped grooves were classified as grooved stones (Davis 1991:352-353). A boatstone is a ''boat shaped" pecked and ground stone artifact with an oval plan view and a planoconvex longitudinal cross section and rounded ends (Davis 1991:286-287; Turner and Hester 1993:293-295). A deep hollow cavity is pecked and ground into the flat face making the artifact resemble a boat or a pita-bread pocket Waco sinkers are small to medium-sized oval to flat quartzite nodules with small notches pecked and ground in opposite ends (Davis 1991 :410-411; Turner and Hester 1993:316-317). They range from specimens with pecking and grinding evident on their entire surface to others with only very shallow notches at their ends. A thin oval to lenticular ground and polished stone with two or more perforations was considered a gorget (Davis 1991 :332; Turner and Hester 1993:305). Numerous examples of each of • these ground/battered stone artifact categories have been recovered from sites in north-central and east Texas (Duffield 1963a, 1963b; Jelks 1965; Sorrow 1966; Story 1965; Story and Shafer 1965). Analysis Attributes Ten attributes were recorded during the course of the analysis of the lithic (chipped and ground/battered stone) artifacts: raw material; tool morphology; core/blank characteristics; cause of fracture; size; cortex characteristics; working-edge characteristics; base and stem treatment; flake characteristics; and weight. Each of these 10 attributes is represented by one or more individual variations. Brief descriptions of these attribute definitions, the variations that each attribute can assume, and the subcategory of artifacts for which the attribute and/or variation was recorded are descussed below and presented in Table A.2.

## Page 611

C The Chandler Collection, Prehistoric Artifacts from Ellis and Navarro Counties, Texas A. J3 gravels in wide ranging areas such as Limestone, Freestone, Garza, and Kent counties. Based on their similarity to cherts found in Bosque, McLennan, Bell, and Coryell counties, specimens ranging from dark to light gray, white, cream and tan colors, and containing numerous light blue fossil inclusions ranging from 1 mm to 5-8 mm in diameter, were classified as nonlocal fine-grained cherts. Specimens classified as nonlocal were compared with cherts obtained from Bell and Coryell counties and illustrated specimens from Lake Waco (Story and Shafer 1965), Lake Belton (Shafer et al. 1964), and Hog Creek (Henry et al. 1980). Bigfork chert is a dark green to olive green opaque material which occurs in the western Ouachita Mountains of southeastern Oklahoma and in the Red River gravels below the mouth of tlie Muddy Boggy and Kiamichi rivers (Fields et al. 1991 :66). One of the unique characteristics oft his material is that when exposed it weathers to a dark brown color. Bigfork chert specimens of both colors are present in the collection. Pisgah Ridge chert is an easily identifiable dark gray, grayish brown to black opaque chert that contains numerous microfossils that give it a speckled appearance. It occurs as nodules and small seams in the Tehuacana limestone member of the Kincaid Formation on Pisgah Ridge, about 6 km west of Richland, Texas. The Tehuacana limestone itself outcrops discontinuously over a distance of approximately 200 km, but the Pisgah Ridge outcrop is the only known source of this visually distinctive chert (McGregor 1987:185). Quartzites are metamorphic rocks consisting mainly of recrystallized quartz (Bates and Jackson 1984:414). The majority of the archaeologically recovered specimens are characterized by fine-grained crystalline structures and light gray to yellowish green colors. The few coarse-grained quartzite specimens identified in the collection are characterized by grain sizes in excess of 1 mm in diameter, but have the color characteristics of the finer grained materials. Materials in which the original woody structure has been replaced by cryptocrystalline quartz are classified as silicified wood. Cryptocrystalline opaque materials that are distinguished from chert and chalcedony on the basis of a coarser texture and dull nontransparent appearance are classified as novaculite. Agate is a translucent cryptocrystalline chalcedony found in vugs in volcanic rocks and in cavities in some other rocks (Bates and Jackson 1984:9). Specimens with a multicolored mottled appearance and a deep natural-as opposed to resulting from heat treatment-luster and/or a • glassy translucency are classified as agate. Quartzarenite is a sandstone that is composed primarily(> 95%) of quartz grains. As such, although it resembles the metamorphic origin quartzites, quartzarenite is a sedimentary rock formed under quite different conditions (Bates and Jackson 1984). Chipped stone artifacts of quartzarenite have macroscopic quartz grains that give the material a lustrous sugary appearance. Toe material ranges from light gray to pinkish red and brownish tan and often contains numerous biotite inclusions. Materials formed of fine-to coarse-textured sand grains cemented by silica and lime are categorized as sandstone. A small number of specimens made of materials that did not fit into any. of the above categories or could not be confidently identified were classified as other/unidentified. These types were defined in order to distinguish between raw materials with dramatically different textural properties that influenced the potential knappability of a material or its use in the manufacture of functionally distinct tools with different edge-keeping properties. ## Page 612

A.14 Tomka characteristics that would have impeded their proper functioning were considered finished. All fragmentary specimens broken in use were considered to have been functional and finished at an earlier time. Complete arrow points and dart points that never reached a·functional state and specimens broken during manufacture were grouped into a preform category as long as their proximal ends exhibit evidence of stem manufacture. Specimens that exhibit modem (i.e., recent) flake scars, identified based on differential patina, were classified as recently flaked and were not typed. In contrast to the projectile points, the miscellaneous bifaces were subdivided into early, middle, and late reduction stage specimens. Bifaces with highly sinuous edges, few flake removals, corticate surfaces, and/or thick cross sections were considered early reduction stage. Specimens lacking deep flake scars, pronounced flake scar ridges, and cortex and exhibiting some patterning in flake removals and attempts to shape the core and/or flake blank were considered middle reduction stage bifaces. Relatively thin bifaces with well-aligned edges and exhibiting pressure flake scars and a substantial degree of shaping were considered late reduction stage specimens. Recognizing that many chipped lithics might be employed in the performance of certain tasks even if they have not been reduced to a late reduction stage, bifaces with use and/or haft wear were categorized as finished or functional specimens. Core/Blank Characteristics Two attributes were included in this group: number of flake removals; and nature of blank. The first attribute refers to the number of flake removals observed on cores, consisting of flake scars not resulting from platform crushing and excluding platform preparation scars 1-10 mm in length. The discussion of the expedient and minimally retouched knives and scrapers often refers to the nature of the blanks (i.e., flake, blade, bladelet) used for these tools. Complete debitage specimens that were twice as long as their width were classified as blades. Debitage fragments with parallel sides and one or more parallel dorsal ridges resulting from previous removals were also considered blades. Blades and blade fragments with maximum widths not exceeding 10 mm were referred to as bladelets. Other debitage specimens that do not meet these criteria were considered flakes. • Cause of Fracture This attribute identifies the cause of fracture of incomplete projectile points, perforators, knives, adzes, celts, choppers, wedges, scrapers, and multifunctional tools. Four types were distinguished: use; manufacture; post depositional; and indeterminate. Some use-generated fractures and a large variety of manufacturing fractures have been reproduced experimentally (Tomka 1986). Others are taken from studies of manufacture- and use-generated tool failures (e.g., Callahan 1979; Crabtree 1972; Johnson 1979, 1981; Muto 1971; Odell and Cowan 1986). The diagnostic morphologies defmed from these replications are the comparative bases used in identifying fracture causes on the archaeological specimens. • • The Chandler Collection, Prehistoric Arti[acts from Ellis and Navarro Counties, Texas A. I 5 and tertiary cortex categories related to flake/blade/bladelet blanks. Specimens with no cortex on their dorsal faces were considered tertiary blanks. Specimens with partially corticate dorsal faces were considered secondary blanks, while specimens with totally corticate dorsal faces were considered primary blanks. In each case, the categorization is made regardless of whether cortex is present or absent on their platfonn surfaces. Working-Edge Characteristics This group consists of three attributes: use wear presence/absence; number of working surfaces; and working edge angle. The presence/absence of use wear on grinding tools such as manos and manolhammerstones was established based on examination with a binocular microscope under 40x magnification. Specimens exhibiting macro or microscopic striations; polish; flat even surfaces; beveled, planoconcave, or ridged transverse cross sections; or evidence of working-surface rejuvenation (i.e., pecking) were classified as ground. These characteristics were readily observable on quartzite specimens. On sandstone specimens, striations and polish could not be observed at 40x magnification. Rather, specimens with characteristic flat surfaces and either diagnostic cross-sectional configurations or surface rejuvenation were classified as ground stones. Many ground stone tools were extensively weathered resulting in a conservative classification of ground stone tools. It was recorded as either unifacial, bifacial, or indeterminate. The second attribute is self-explanatory. It consists of the count of the number of modified (i.e., ground or pecked surfaces) working surfaces with or without use wear. Working-edge angles were recorded to gauge potential differences in working-edge characteristics between tool categories such as adz.es and gouges. The working edge on formal and/or minimally retouched tools is defined as the surface created by the juncture of the ventral face of the specimen and the retouched face that results from the manufacture of the tool and/or rejuvenation of an already worn working edge. The working-edge angle on expedient tools represents the angle formed by the ventral and dorsal faces. The edge angle was recorded with a Ward's contact • goniometer. • Base and Stem Treatment This attribute was recorded on projectile points (i.e., dart points only). It has two states: stem smoothing; and base smoothing. These attributes were recorded as present or absent Weight Weight was recorded to the nearest 0.1 g with an Ohaus electronic scale. Weight was recorded for complete arrow points, dart points, choppers, wedges, manos, mano/hammerstones, and Waco sinkers.

• The Chandler Collection, Prehistoric Artifacts from Ellis and Navarro Counties, Texas A.37 Ensor No. ofS pecimens: 1 complete specimen and 2 proximal fragments (Figure A.4c). Morphology. Small triangular points with relatively broad blades and broad highly expanding stems with convex bases; blade edges are straight to slightly convex and the stems and bases rarely are ground (Miller and Jelks 1952: 172, Plate 22, 2). Raw Material: 1 local fine-grained chert, 1 nonlocal fine-grained chert, and 1 quartz.arenite. Provenience: 4 lELl 1, 4 lELl 8, and 41EL21. Break Type: 2 specimens have use-related breaks. Stem/Base Treatment'. 1 has stem grinding only. &timated Age: Late Archaic II, ca. 200 B.C.-A.D. 600 (Turner and Hester 1993: 114; Johnson and Goode 1994). Distribution: Primari~ central, west (lower Pecos River area), and south-central Texas (Prewitt 1995:Figure 17); occurs frequently in most sections of Oklahoma and is also found in other parts of the United States (Bell 1960:34). Break Type: 1 specimens were broken in use, and 3 have indeterminate breaks. Estimated Age: Late Prehistoric I, AD. 800-1200 (Suhm et al. 1954:496). Raw Material: Local fine-grained chert. Provenience: 41NV15. Break Type: Manufacture broken. Estimated Age: Late Prehistoric I, A.O. 800-1200 (Suhm et al. 1954:496). Catahoula No. ofS pecimens: 1 complete specimen and 2 proximal :fragments (Figure A. I Of). · Morphology. • The Chandler Collection, Prehistoric Artifacts from Ellis and Navarro Counties, Texas A.71 Provenience: 2 from 4 IEL18 and 1 from 4 lELl 1. Huffaker No. ofS pecimens: 1, proximal fragment (Figure A:l0n). Morphology: Small but wide side-notched proximal fragment with concave base; the trapezoidal stem has the characteristic additional token notch on each side (Baerreis 1954:44). Raw Material: Local fine-grained chert. Provenience: 4 lELl 1. Break Type: Use broken. Estimated Age: Late Prehistoric, A.D. 1000-1500 (Bell 1960:58). Distribution: Scarce, but present in the Texas Panhandle and northern portions of Texas along the Red River valley (Prewitt 1995:Figure 25); most common in central and western Oklahoma (Bell 1960:58). Perdiz No. ofS pecimens: 28 complete specimens, 18 proximal fragments, 1 medial fragment missing only a small portion of its base, and 1 longitudinal fragment (Figure A. I I a-b) . Morphology: Small to medium-sized triangular points with contracting stems rounded to pointed bases; blade edges vary from straight to convex to concave; fine serration frequently is evident behind the tip, which often is • retouched to a fine point; blades exhibit moderately long downward-and outward-pointing barbs; 5UilDS range from long and narrow with a pointed base to somewhat wider and shorter with a rounded base(K.elley 1947a:122; Miller and Jelks 1952:177). Raw Material: 40 local fine-grained chert, I nonlocal fine-grained chert, and 7 fine-grained quartzite. Provenience: 29 from 41NV15, 15 from 41EL11, 3 from 41EL18, and 1 from 41EL19. Break Type: 12 specimens have use-related breaks, 1 was broken postdepositionally, and 7 have indeterminate break causes. Estimated Age: Late Prehistoric II, A.D. 1200-1700 (Suhm et al. 1954:504). Distribution: From the Rio Grande in west Texas to the Neches River in the east and from the Red River valley southward to the Gulf Coast (Suhm et al. 1954:504); rare in Texas Panhandle (Prewitt 1995:Figure 40); also occurs infrequently in the southern and central sections of Oklahoma (Bell 1960:78).

## Page 681

• The Chandler Collection, Prehistoric Artifacts from Ellis and Navarro Counties, Texas A.83 Axes Four hundred twenty axes were identified in the Chandler Collection. They are divided into two morphological subcategories: stemmed and notched (Table A.8}. All but one (n=419) of the specimens are stemmed axes. They range from subtriangular to rectangular and oval bifacially flaked artifacts with planoconvex to biconvex transverse cross sections (Figure A.14a-b) . They have convex working edges, and their proximal ends are often contracting. In a number of instances, the proximal ends have been shaped so that the stem and the blade of the tool are clearly distinguishable (Figure A.14c-e). In general, the stems of these axes resemble the range of stem shapes noted on Gary dart points. This point is raised simply to provide a visual impression for the reader rather than to suggest that these axes represent reworked, recycled Gary points. Many, if not all, of the bifacial artifacts included in the stemmed axe subcategory are specimens that archeologists working in east and east-central Texas would traditionally refer to as Erath bifaces (Story and.Shafez;.1965). The large majority (n=271 [64.52%)) of these are made of fine-grained quartzite. Axes made oflocal fine-grained ch~rt (n=79 (18.81%]) and quartzarenite (n=36 [8.57%]) are present but in lower numbers. Axes made ofsilicified wood (n=l l [2.62%]), coarse-grained quartzite (n=8 [1.90%]), agate (n=6 [1.43%)), unidentified materials (n=5 (1.190/o]), novaculite (n=3 (0.71%]), and Bigfork chert (n=l (0.24%]) are inftequenL It is clear from these figures that, in general, coarser grained materials (i.e., quartzites, novaculite and silicified wood; n=329 [78.33%]) were preferred over finer grained ones (i.e., chert, agate; n=86 [20.48%]) in the manufacture of axes. This bias probably arises from the fact that in heavy use contexts coarse-grained materials have better edge-keeping properties than finer grained, more highly silicified materials. Of the 419 stemmed axes, 224 (53.46%) are complete and 191 (45.58%) are distal fragments; 2 (0.48%) are proximal fragments missing only small portions of their working edges, and 2 (0.48%) are longitudinal fragments. The • majority (n=l 13 [57.95%]) of the 195 fragments were broken in use; the cause of break could not~ determined on the remaining 82 (42.%} specimens. Although the large majority (n=416 [99.28%]) of the stemmed axes are fmished specimens that exhibit use wear, three (0.72%} items lack use wear and represent two late and one middle reduction stage bifaces. They are included in the axe category because they already exhibit the general subtriangular shape and contracting stem noted on finished axes. The 226 specimens on which maximum length could be measured range from 24 to 84 mm (.=39.7, a=7.9) in length. The maximum width, which represents to maximum blade width, ranges from 20 to 64 mm (.=32.9, a=S.O, n=407). The maximum thickness of the 419 axes ranges from 6 to 29 mm (.=12.9, a=2.9, n=419). The single notched axe in the collection is an elongated, oval fine-grained quartzite nodule with bifacial retouch along the distal margins and two flaked notches on opposite edges near the proximal end (Figure A. l 4f). The body of the axe retains substantial cortex, and the proximal end, or the head of the axe. is entirelv corticate. The notched HYP.

## Page 685

• The Chandler Collection, Prehistoric Artifacts from Ellis and Navarro Counties, Tuas A.87 The similarities in morphology between the minimally retouched and expedient knives, especially in light of the two specimens that combine these edges on each specimen, indicates that rather than being a specific morphological type of their own, minimally retouched knives represent a specific point along the use-life trajectory of knives. That is, minimally retouched knives represent expedient specimens that were utilix.ed and resharpened once their working edges dulled. In contrast to these knives, the formal specimens represent entirely distinct manufacture sequences in that a fully bifacially flaked artifact is produced before the specimen is judged functional. It is likely that minimally retouched knives do not progress to formal bifacial knives with increased resharpening since these flakes and blades would be too small to serve as blanks for bifacial knives. Gouges One. hundred twenty-eight gouges were identified in the Chandler Collection. They are divided into two subcategories: formal gouges {n=72 [56.25%1); and minimally retouched gouges {n=56 (43.75%1) {Table A.10). The formal gouges consist of unifacially and/or bifacially flaked triangular to subtriangular specimens with unifacially beveled working edges (Figure A.16a-b). A total of 37 (51.39%} fine-grained quartzite specimens are identified compared to the 26 (36.11 %) local fine-grained chert gouges. Even the remaining nine are coarse materials; six (8.33%) are relatively poorly petrified silicified wood, two (2.78%) are quartzarenite, and one (1.39%) is coarse grained quartzite. Although the nature of the blank used in manufacture could not be determined on 35 (48.61%) specimens, 32 (44.44%) of the remaining formal gouges were made on flake blanks. Only the remaining 5 (6.94%) gouges were made on pebble cores. Cortex is present on 39 (54.17%) specimens and is absent on 33 (45.83%). Bifacially flaked specimens dominate the formal group (n=46 [63.89%]), while a little more than one-third (n=26 [36.11%1) are unifacially flaked. Of the 72 formal gouges, 60 (83.33%) are complete and 12 (16.67%) are distal • fragments. The incomplete specimens were broken in use. A.96 Tomka -~ ' Choppers Twenty-seven choppers were identified in the Chandler Collection. They are characteriz.ed by subtriangular to ovate shapes and bifacially flaked working edges commonly backed by corticate surfaces (Figure A.19e). The working edges exhibit substantial step fracturing and crushing that developed into smooth rounding in more heavily used portions of the edge. Twenty-five (92.59%) of the choppers are made on fine-grained quartzite nodules, one (3.70%) is of coarse grained quartzite, and one (3.70%} is of tabular limestone. Given the total absence of fine-grained materials, the choppers represent a clear example of the preference for coarse-grained materials in the manufacture of certain tool types. They also exemplify the relationship between the materials being worked and the characteristics of the tools employed, specifically in terms of edge-keeping properties. Of the 27 choppers, 26 (9630%) are complete tools and 1 (3.70%) is a distal fragment The incomplete specimen was broken in use. The 26 complete specimens range in length from 48 to 146 mm (,r=69.7, a=l8.5), in width from 13 to 110 mm (ir=56.8, a=l7.3}, and in thickness from 16 to 57 mm (ir=36.8, a=l0.8). Given that a heavy chopping tool might perform more efficiently than a light one and that below a certain weight a chopper might be relatively ineffective, the distribution of chopping tool weights is highly relevant to evaluate these assumptions. The distn"bution of weights among the 26 complete tools indicates that only 6 (23.08%} are lighter than 101 g, and no chopper is lighter than 43 g. The majority, (n=14 [53.85%]) weigh between 110 and 230 g, and 5 (19.23%) are between 270 and 460 g. This pattern suggests that perhaps the lightest choppers that might still be effective are no lighter than 40-50 g. On the other hand, although the majority of the choppers are between 100 and 230 g, the number of heavier choppers suggests that a broad range of materials were processed by these tools. Wedges Fourty-two wedges were identified in the Chandler Collection. They are small triangular to ovate bifacially flaked pebbles and flakes. Their working edges are backed by corticate surfaces (Figure A. l 9f-g) that represent either the unflaked surfaces of the pebbles or the corticate platform remnants of the flake blanks from which these tools are manufactured. The working edges may exhibit step fracturing, but lack the crushing and rounding present on choppers. Oft he 42 wedges, 28 (66.67%) are made on small pebbles, 9 (21.43%) are made on flake blanks, and the nature of the core cannot be determined on 5 (11.90%) specimens. In contrast to the choppers that are made exclusively of coarse-grained materials, the wedges are made ofa greater variety of raw materials. Nineteen (45.24%) are of local fine grained chert, 16 (38.10%) are offme-grained quartzite, 4 (9.52%) are ofsilicified wood, and 1 each (2.38%) is of coarse-grained quartzite, agate, and an unidentified raw material. The greater variability in raw materials and the nearly equal proportions of coarse-and fine-grained materials supports the classification of these tools as other than choppers. • The Chandler Collection, Prehistoric Artifticts from Ellis and Navarro Counties, Texas A.97 Gravers Twenty-six gravers were identified in the Chandler Collection. Most of these specimens (n=22 [84.62%)) are classified as expedient gravers (Table A.15). Three (11.54%) are categorized as formal gravers and the last specimen (3.85%) is a minimally retouched graver. Two (66.67%) of the three flake blanks used for the formal gravers are secondary flakes (Figure A.20a), with the third (33.33%) a tertiary flake. One of the gravers made ofa secondmy flake (Figure A.20b) might be an end scraper remanufactured into a graver. All are local fine-grained chert and all are complete specimens. They range in length from 44 to 51 mm (.=47.0, a=3.6), in width from 28 to 40 mm (.=34.7, a=6.l}, and in thickness from 8 to 11 mm (r9.7, a=l.5). The single minimally retouched graver is made on a small secondmy local fine-grained chert flake (Figure A.20c). The small graver tip is located on the distal end of the flake and was made by the removal of only 2-3 flakes on either side of the tip. It is 31 mm long, 21 mm wide, and 7 mm thick. The 22 expedient gravers represent hafted dart points utilized as gravers following the impact break of their distal ends (Figure A.20d-e). Thirteen (59.09%) of the dart points reused as gravers are typed specimens. Two (9.09%) each are Dawson, Gary, Godley, Kent, and Yarbrough points, while the others consist of an Edgewood, a Hoxie, and an Oletha type. The remaining nine (40.91%) consist of four untyped points with parallel stems and convex bases, three with parallel stems and straight bases, and two with expanding stems and straight bases. Twelve (54.55%) of the 22 dart points suffered transverse blade breaks, and the sharply pointed intersection between the break face and the bifacial edge was employed as a graver before resharpening by the removal of one or more burin flakes. On the other 10 (45.45%) specimens, burin-like flake scars originate from the tip of the points, suggesting that either these scars are impact break scars or that otherwise complete points were used as gravers and subsequently resharpened by burin flakes removed directly off the tips. Given that impact breaks often mimic burin removals, and since a bifacially flaked point tip might be a less effective graver than one that is burinated, it is assumed that on the latter 10 specimens the burin-like removal scars are actually impact breaks. Eleven (50%) oft he 22 expedient gravers are oflocal fine-grained chert, 8 (3636%) are of fine-grained quartzite, and 1 (4.55%) each is made of coarse-grained quartzite, silicified wood, and an unidentified raw material. The expedient gravers range in length from 20 to 58 mm (.=37.6, a=9.8), in maximum width from 14 to 29 mm (.=20.2, a=4.5), and in maximum thickness from 5 to 11 mm (ir=7.5, a=l.3). While some specimens are well shaped and carefully formed, others are simply lenticular or &t pebbles with poorly formed notches on each end. hi most instances, the shallow U-shaped notches in the ends of the specimens appear to have been pecked and then ground to final form. • The Chandler Collection, Prehistoric Artifacts from Ellis and Navarro Counties, Texas A.113 Seven variations of temper type are recorded in this analysis: grog, bone, shell, grog/bone, grog/white flecks, angular quartzite, and no identifiable temper. Grog can be defined as crushed fragments of sherds or particles of burned clay. Bone appears as white to bluish-black chunks with visible cell structure. Shell temper consists of white to grayish white thin platelike particles. White flecks are minute white particles that could be either bone or shell but could not be distinguished even under magnification although most are probably bone. Although many of the sherds have coarse to fine-grained sandy paste occurring along with the tempering materials, sand is not recorded as a temper since it is likely that it is a natural constituent of the clays chosen for vessel construction. This sand, however, appears stream rolled and in that respect differs from the angular quartzite temper type. Angular quartzite appears as rectilinear fragments measuring 0.5 to 1.0 mm across. This quartzite appears to be well sorted and is likely an additive tempering material. Ten decorative techniques are defined for this ceramic analysis. The definitions focus on the kind or combination of surface modifications used to form a decorative element or motif. The techniques are engraving, incising, stick punctations, stick punctations with incised/engraved lines, fingernail punctations, fingernail punctations with incised/engraved lines, pinching, pinching with incising/engraved lines, brushed, and surface roughened. Engraving is defined as a linear subtractive technique done on dry or fire-hardened clay, whereas incising is a similar technique employed on wet clay. Consequently, engraved lines can be distinguished by a ragged margin, while incising leaves a clean margin, sometimes with a lip ofc lay left along the margin. Stick punctations appear to have been made with a pointed or cylindrical tool. Fingernail punctations form semicircular impressions, some of which have a low lip of clay along the concave side of the semicircle. Pinching is distinguished from fingernail punctations in that pinching leaves two semicircular depressions on either side of a lip of clay. Brushing appears as drag marks likely resulting from wiping the moist clay surface with a cluster of fine sticks or grasses. A roughened surface also likely resulted from some method of adding texture to the moist clay body. Seventeen element/motif categories are used to record the decorative variations found in the ~ramie sample. An • element is used in this analysis as the smallest self-contained component of a design, while motif is a combination of several elements (Rice 1987:248). Emphasis in the element/motif analysis category is OJl identifying the motif, but because of the small size of many of the decorated sherds, in some instances only elements can be distinguished. The combination of the decorative technique and element/motif categories is an attempt to relate decorative style to established ceramic types. The 17 element/motif categories identified are: rows of punctations; zoned punctations; miscellaneous punctations; diagonal lines at the rim; parallel lines; field ofbrushing; intersecting parallel lines; broad crosshatching; curvilinear body motif; straight/curved hachured panel edges; pinched rows; random fingernail punctations; rectilinear body motif; tick marks suspended from lines; rows of short incisions; field of punctations; and tight linear punctations. A.JU Tomka organiz.e this discussion because the site samples are composed mainly of small undecorated sherds which do not lend themselves to type affiliation. The type affiliations that are made in this analysis are based ~n selected attributes. The element/motif category provided the best indication of type affiliations. Also, the presence of certain surface treatments such as red-slipping or tempering agents are used to provide some general temporal affiliations, although these are seen as more tentative than determinations made based on element/motif. For instance, shell tempering is often considered diagnostic of the late Caddoan period in extreme northeastern Texas along the Red River. However, whether shell tempered sherds in the Chandler Collection represent some connection to Red River late Caddoan cultural manifestations, or originated in a different context, such as with the late plains cultures of north-central Texas and central Oklahoma, can not be resolved by this analysis. Despite this uncertainity, the types that are suggested by some of the element/motifs h) the collection appear to be Caddoan ceramic types associated with east Texas. The temporal placement of these sherds has been made using the chronologies devised by Thurmond (1990) and Story (1990:333-334). Thus, the early Caddoan period 1 and 2 ranges from AD. 800-1300, the middle Caddoan period is AD. 1300-1400, and the late Caddoan period ranges from 1400-1680, and the historic Caddoan period is 1680-1860. 41EL5 The ceramic sample from 41EL5 includes twelve sherds which range in siz.e from 2-4 cm in diameter. They are generally well preserved with both interior and exterior walls intact In all, 10 (83.33%) sherds from this sample are grog tempered. These include nine body sherds and one flat base sherd. Five of the body sherds are decorated with brushing, while the remaining body and base sherds are undecorated. Two body sherds recovered from 41EL5 are bone tempered. One of these sherds has evidence of red-slip on the exterior surface while the other is undecorated. The brushed sherds may be considered to be part of utilitarian vessels associated with late Caddoan groups (Fields 1995:183). The ceramic types Bullard Brushed, La Rue Neck Banded and/or Maydell Incised include brushing as a main element/motif or decorative technique (Suhm and Jelks 1962). These types are common to northeast and east Texas and are considered late Caddoan period ceramics (Thurmond 1990:223-229). Red-slip was used on vessels during the middle to late Caddoan period but without other vessel characteristics is difficult to relate to a particular ceramic type (Fields et al. 1993:229; Thurmond 1990:227-228). 41EL11 The ceramic sample from 41EL11 includes 187 (93%) vessel body sherds, 2 vessel rims (1%), 10 vessel base sherds (5%) and 2 pipe bowl fragments (1%). Of these 201 sherds, only 10.95% (n=22) display some form of , decoration.

One fragment is a flat circular piece that is 4.8 cm wide and 1.2 cm thick. This piece is split along the edges as if it had been flattened from a spherical form while still wet. The second piece is oblong, 2.0 cm long and 0.98 cm thick. The surfaces of both display grass impressions. These fragments may be considered possible wasters from the ceramic manufacturing process that were fired incidentally. Summary A few suggestions can be offered regarding the ceramic type association for some of the element/motif categories present in this sherd sample. The categories of diagonal lines at rim, zoned punctations with parallel lines, and intersecting parallel lines are reminiscent of the type Maydelle Incised (Figure A29a-d). The element/motifs suggestive of Maydell Incised cross-cut the temper types grog, bone, and bone/grog.and are comprised of a total of nine, two, and three sherds respectively. Also, the category of straight/curved hachured panel edges, found on five grog-tempered sherds, is suggestive of the Poynor Engraved open-panel motif(Figure A29e-f). Two other ceramic types that may be represented in this sample are Weches Fingernail Impressed and Patton Engraved. These types are each represented respectively by one grog-tempered sherd with the categories of zoned (fingernail) punctations with parallel lines and tick marks suspended from lines (Figure A29g-h). The presence of sherds possibly associated with the ceramic types Maydelle Incised and Poynor Engraved are indicative of a site occupation during the late Caddoan period (Suhm and Jelks 1962:103, 123-125; Stokes and Woodring 1981:189-194; Thurmond 1990:228-229). These types are associated with Caddoan groups living in the upper Sabine and Neches river valleys of east Texas. Their vessels have often appeared as trade ware as far west as the Colorado River in central Texas (Suhm and Jelks 1962: 103, 123-125). Other element/motif categories in this collection are reminiscent oflate Caddoan types that are often found in association with Maydelle Incised and Poynor Engraved • (1hurmond 1990:228-229). For example, the pinched sherds could be from vessels of the type Killough Pinched, while brushed sherds may be parts of vessels typed as Bullard Brushed, La Rue Neck Banded, or again Maydelle Incised. La Rue Neck Banded could also account for the roughened element/motif in the sample. The shell-tempered sherds in this collection would also fit with a late site component (Bell 1984:318-323; Fields et al. 1993:176, 229-230). Additionally, red slipping occurs on vessels during late Caddoan period, though it also has middle Caddoan period antecedents (1hurmond 1990:227-228; Fields et al. 1993:229). Of the five sherds in this collection with red slip, three are grog tempered, one is shell tempered, and one has no visible temper. The multicomponent nature of 41NV15 is further hinted by the few sherds suggestive of the types Weches Fingernail Impressed and Patton Engraved. Weches Fingernail Impressed is associated with the early Caddoan period (Suhm and Jelks 1962: 153) and has occurred on east-central Texas sites radiocarbon dated to AD. 1000-1200 (Bruseth 1987:124-126). Patton Engraved is a marker type for the historical Hasinai, a Caddoan group occupying the upper

This conclusion is strengthened by the pinched and brushed element/motifs that are well represented at both sites. These element/motifs may be related to the Bullard Brushed, La Rue Neck Banded, and Killough Pinched late Caddoan ceramic types. Undecorated shell-tempered sherds are also well represented, making up the second largest temper type at each of the two sites. These sherds also indicate a late component that could have been influenced by Caddoan groups from the middle Red River or groups from north-central Texas and/or central Oklahoma. Sorrow (1966:62) suggested that the shell-tempered sherds he recovered from 4 IELl 1 may have originated in north-central Texas or Oklahoma because they are an undecorated ware. A few sherds from 41NV15 also suggest that the site is multicomponent They consist of a possible Weches Fingernail Impressed sherd and a Patton Engraved sherd. The former is an early Caddoan period type, while the latter is a historic Caddoan ceramic type. Red-slipped sherds were also recovered from both sites. The placement of these sherds in time is somewhat problematic, but they may best be considered middle to late Caddaon period specimens. The vessel forms represented in the larger collections from 4 lELl 1 and 41NV15 must be gleaned from both rim and base characteristics. Bowl forms appear to be present at both sites, as suggested by base to wall angles of 46• to so•. Carinated bowl forms appear to be limited, as only four sherds with carinations were recovered from 41NV15. At least one jar form may be represent at41NV15 by a base to wall angle of74•. Evertedrims and rounded lips are the most prevalent rim and lip forms at 41NV15. These forms also suggest that bowl and jar forms, that allow easy access and transfer of contents, were utilized at this site. The size of these vessels is difficult to estimate since only four rims are large enough for diameter measurements. However, two groups emerge with one set of three rims ranging 20- 31-cm in diameter, and a second consisting of the fourth sherd ranging 37-40 cm in diameter. Again all four of these rims are from the 4INVI5 sample. • MISCELLANEOUS PREIDSTORIC MATERIAL CULTURE REMAINS Introduction Only seven non-lithic or non-ceramic specimens were identified in the Chandler Collection: five worked shells; and two worked bones. • The Chandler Collection, Prehistoric Artifacts fr_om Ellis and Navarro Counties, Tuas A.123 Worked Bone Two worked bone specimens were identified in the Chandler Collection: a rather short and narrow pointed bone tool (Figure A.30e); and the modified proximal end of a mammalian long bone (Figure A.30f). Because of its sharply pointed tip and the polish present on its surface, it is likely that the first specimen was used as a pin or an awl Although it is rather short, its proximal end exhibits no breakage, but is rather rounded and polished. The specimen is 35 mm long, 6 mm wide, and 3 mm thick. It is identical in size and shape to bone artifacts found at The Pecan Springs Site (41EL11) and categorized as "pins" by Sorrow (1966:Figure 28f-g). The second specimen appears to be the proximal articular end of a small mammalian long bone. The articular end has been shaped into a headlike morphology through grinding and cutting. The head has been smoothed and polished, probably through use. It is 8 mm long, 14 mm wide, and 7 mm thick. The contracting bone shaft was grooved and snapped 10 mm below the head. The shaft is 8 mm wide and 5 mm thick at this break. It is unclear why the proximal end of what appears to have been an awl was removed. SUMMARY AND CONCLUSIONS This section provides a brief assessment of the artifact collections obtained from each site, summarizes the broad temporal framework within which these sites were occupied based on typeable projectile points and ceramic sherds, and compares and contrasts them with collections from neighboring regions and archaeological projects. In addition, three other topics are addressed including the summary of regional patterns of raw m~rial procurement and use, the analytical challenge of differentiating arrow points from dart points, and a brief evaluation of biface typologies viewed from a technological perspective. • Since these artifact collections are the product of random surface collections made over a number of years, their composition is biased by a number of factors such as the size and associated visibility of artifacts, the degree to which artifacts are formally flaked rather than expedient, the associated aesthetic value of th«t artifacts as defined by the person(s) making the collections, the surface visibility of the components, the number of visits made to the site, weather conditions during these visits, etc. As a result, few conclusions can be drawn from the composition of these artifact collections regarding the nature of the site occupations, the land use practices, and mobility patterns suggested by the collections. This conclusion is supported by the very high 0.94 correlation coefficient (R2 , p > 0.00001) obtained from _the regression of the logged sample sizes and richness, as defined by the number of artifact classes, within the collections from the 11 sites. This high correlation indicates that 94% of the variability in the numbers of artifact categories present in the samples from each site is the product of sample size variability rather than differences in site function and/or use. However, the proposition above also implies that, while points with broad necks could be hafted effectively into narrow split foreshafts, points with narrow necks could not be hafted effectively into split foreshafts that were wider than the neck of the point The distribution of neck widths among the preform and reworked dart points (n=928) ranges between 8 and 29 mm (.=13.9, a=2.7). However, 62.4% (n=579) of the points have neck widths between 12 and 15 mm. Only 15.4% (n=l43) of the dart points have neck widths below 12 mm, only 1.7% (n=l6) have necks narrower than 10 mm. Of the 16 dart points with neck widths below 10 mm, 2 are Dawson, 2 are Gary, 2 are Oletha, and the remainder are untyped expanding stemmed (n=4), parallel stemmed (n=3}, and untypeable (n=3} points. The distn"bution of neck widths among the nonpreform and nonreworked arrow points (n=353) ranges from 3 to 19 mm (.=6.6, a=2.l). However, no less than 95.2% (n=336) of the points have neck widths below 10 mm, and only the remaining 4.8% (n=17) have neck widths that overlap with the dart points. Of the 17 arrow points with neck widths greater than or equal to IO mm, 5 are Fresno, 4 m:e Young, and 3 are Granbury points (the latter two types representing preforms). The remaining five are two contracting stemmed, one parallel stemmed, and two untypeable arrow points. These patterns based on projectile point neck widths suggest that there is a relatively strong differentiation between dart points and arrow points with only a small percentage of the dart points overlapping with the arrow points and vice versa in terms of maximum neck widths. Given that arrow and dart points are subject to different degrees of stress, and as a result differential likelihood · of failure during use, another attribute that might allow the differentiation of arrow and dart points is their maximum thickness. Mean maximum thickness of the 953 finished dart points (i.e., not including preforms and reworked specimens) sufficiently large for measurement is 7.4 mm (a=l.6, min.=4, max.=18). A total of746 (78.3%) dart points have maximum thicknesses between 6 and 8 mm, and only 3 (0.3%) are 4 mm thick. These three consist of two Dawson points and an untypeable specimen. The mean thickness of the 426 arrow points (not including preforms and reworked specimens) is 3.6 mm (a=0.9, min.=2, max.=7). A total of 379 (89.0%) arrow points are between 2 and 4 mm in • maximum thickness. Although no arrow point is thicker than 7 mm, 47 (11.0%) are 5 mm or thicker and overlap with the thinner dart points. These include eight Scallorn, seven Cliffton, four Yowig, three Alba, two Granbury, two Fresno, one Colbert, one Steiner, and one Perdiz. The remainder are untyped (n=8), and untypeable (n=IO) specimens. These patterns indicate that there seems to be a minimum thickness of approximately 5 mm below which dart points do not fall. This value may in part reflect the thicker flake and/or pebble cores from which the reduction sequence begins or, more likely, a lower limit below which high use-failure rates might be experienced. Although no arrow point is thinner than 2 mm, this value may be a reflection of the difficulty of successfully pressure flaking a flake blank to a maximum thickness below 2 mm rather than being conditioned by functional requirements or parameters. Upper limits are weakly defined in both dart and arrow points in part because, within limits, thicker specimens would simply add greater resistance to breakage rather than diminishing performance. Performance is diminished due to thickness only if and when it results in so much added weight that projectile flight characteristics are dramatically affected.

A.130 Tomka they would serve well as hafted knives and, following sufficient resharpening, could be employed as projectile points once their weight was reduced. Such extended and perhaps multifunctional use lives would probably contribute a great deal of variation in projectile point attributes such as maximum width, maximum length, and weight In addition to these aspects, it also is interesting to consider projectile point weight in light of the weight of modem-day arrow points. Modem two-to four-bladed arrow point weights range from 4.9 grams (75 grains) to 9.7 grams (150 grains). These points are heavier than all of the arrow points in the Chandler Collection and interestingly, 247 (69.38%) of the 356 complete dart points in the collection fall within this weight range (5.0-9.9 grams). When attached to appropriately spined arrows, the combined weight of these modern-day aluminum projectiles is between 29 and 33 grams (or 450 to 510 grains). This combined weight is not unlike the weight of a recently examined historic arrow tipped with a metal point The overall weight of this partially fletched arrow is 31.6 grams (Elton R. Prewitt, personal communication to S. Tomka 1995), and it probably did not exceed 33 grams in its original working condition. These weights also agree well with Pope's (1909:44) statement that the avc;_rage weight of the American Indian arrow was around 30 grams. Available information suggests that historic and probably even prehistoric self-bows were as strong as most modern-day compound bows (Laubin and Laubin 1980; Pope 1962:14-15; Webb and McKinney 1975:104-105), which suggests that mechanically they were capable of shooting an arrow as heavy as the modem aluminum arrows tipped with points that weigh as much as many dart points. So then, does this mean that many dart points could have been used to tip arrows? From a mechanical standpoint, the answer appears to be yes and echoes conclusions arrived at experimentally. For instance-, experimental results obtained by Browne {1938, 1940) and Fenenga (1953) indicate that arrows tipped with smaller dart points perform just as effectively as arrows tipped with arrow points. Similarly, atlatl darts tipped with arrow points or even no points at all also perform equally effectively. Given these conclusions, were some so-called dart points actually arrow points, and, if so, what precipitated the shift in use to the more-slender projectiles we commonly refer to as arrow points? Would arrows tipped with so-called dart points perform equally well as those tipped with arrow points, and what performance changes would be incurred? Unfortunately, answers to many of these questions have not been pursued systematically, and interpretations of projectile point affiliation (i.e., dart or arrow point) continue to be based on subjective criteria As is the case of the present report, in the analysis of prehistoric artifact assemblages much analytical effort is devoted to the differentiation of functionally or stylistically homogeneous groupings or types. These groupings or types serve as the bases for our reconstructions of the range of activities carried out by the prehistoric inhabitants of a site, can inform us of the broad age or time period when the site was occupied, and are vestiges of regional interactions between prehistoric populations. Often, however, because specific classes of artifacts go through a number of morphological changes during their use lives, it is difficult to define and identify all of the members of a particular type because they may not share all of the common attributes. I 31 The preliminary sorting of the Chandler Collection artifacts initially identified a large number of Bristol bifaces and a relatively smaller number of Erath specimens. However, a closer examination of the two groups during the more detailed analytical stage revealed that many of the small circular and oval Bristol bifaces had unreworked fracture face remnants, differential flaking patterns along one edge, and macroscopic use wear along one or more edges characteristic of that noted on the Erath bifaces, here categorized as axes. Following the identification of these traits, many of the items previously identified as Bristol bifaces were reclassified as Erath bifaces or axes. This example illustrates how the construction of artifact typologies, especially on nonprojectile points, may lead in to undue splitting and the incorrect identification of types when one relies simply on differences morphological characteristics. A greater emphasis upon a technological perspective when examining artifacts may in some instances better track and explain morphological variability in classes of artifacts. Such a technologically based orientation, ~ided by the larger than archaeologically feasible sample ofbifacial artifacts, has allowed us to make an important clarification in the typology employed in classifying bifacial artifacts in the state. The results of this study suggest that Erath and Bristol bifaces are not two distinct types but rather represent morphological variability within the same artifact as it progresses from a new functional specimen (Erath biface), to one broken in use, and, finally, to one that is reworked into a newly functional specimen (Bristol biface). Finally, a few brief statements are necessary regarding the raw material composition of the Chandler Collection. Of the 3,447 chipped stone artifacts in the collection, a total of 1,510 (43.8%) are of fine-grained quartzite and 1,423 (41.3%) are oflocal fine-grained chert. Specimens that can be unequivocally identified as nonlocal fine-grained cherts constitute 5.7% (n=l98) of the collection, while other nonlocal materials such as novaculite (n=IS, 0.4%), Pisgah Ridge chert (n=8, 02%), and Bigfork chert (n=7, 0.2%) are relatively scarce. Other locally available raw materials, such as coarse-grained quartzite (n=37, 1.1%), silicified wood (n=91, 2.6%), and quartz.arenite (n=90, 2.6%) are also scarce probably due in part to their lesser quality. The 41 (1.2%) artifacts made of agate in the collection are uncertain • although jasper has been noted as a constituent element in residual Uvalde gravels (Byrd 1971 :9). • Given the earlier-mentioned similarity of nonlocal fine-grained cherts to cherts found in McLennan, Bosque, Corryell, and Bell counties, the raw material composition of the chipped stone tools from the Chandler Collection indicates strong connections with central Texas. This is evident both in the nonlocal fine-grained cherts and the presence of Pisgah Ridge cherts, presently known to outcrop only in Navarro County. On the other hand, the presence of Bigfork chert, probably derived from Red River gravels, and of novaculite indicate contact with the extreme northeastern part of the state and also southwest Arkansas. These interpretations parallel those derived from the evaluation of the overall and typological makeup of the collection. A more-detailed look at the distribution of the nonlocal raw materials among the different artifact categories (Table A26), indicates that with the exception of the unmodified debitage, the artifact category with the highest percentages of three of the four nonlocal origin raw materials is dart points. Future .:. analyses of unmodified debitage collections from this part of the county, coupled with comparative raw material collections such as the one obtained by Mercyhurst College archeologists, will go far in establishing the nature of raw material procurement and use by these prehistoric inhabitants. Overall, the analysis of the large Chandler Collection has allowed us to refocus analytical efforts and restructure data presentation toward the definition and discussion of artifact functional categories rather than the more commonly used morphological groupings. The in-depth technological analysis of selected bifacial artifacts, facilitated by the large sample si7.e, has allowed us to identify potential errors in the biface typology utili7.ed in the state. And, the variety of artifacts in the collection allowed us a first comprehensive look at the nature of prehistoric occupations in Ellis County. If it is reasonable to generali7.e to the region on the basis oft he artifact collections from these 11 sites, the materials investigated indicate the presence of rich Late Archaic II (600 B.C.-A.D. 600) and Late Prehistoric I (A.D. 700-1300) components with significantly fewer typeable and/or diagnostic artifacts dating to earlier time periods. The materials also indicate a moderately strong Late Prehistoric II (A.D. 1300-1750) presence in the region. These apparent trends may be the result of collection biases, may reflect the effects of geomorphological processes upon archaeological deposits, and/or mav be due to actual differences in occupation intensity (i.e., frequency and duration) through time. APPENDIX B. A PROJECTILE POINT ANALYSIS OF PORTIONS OF THE OATES, LOTT, AND BARTON COLLECTIONS FROM ELLIS COUNTY, TEXAS Elton R. Prewitt Ed/led by Joseph L Yed/owski INTRODUCTION This typological analysis of projectile points deals with parts of three artifact collections from Ellis County, Texas, and vicinity. The study was undertaken in connection with the research preparatory to the construction of the Superconducting Super Collider (SSC). The purposes of the study are to provide a general characterization of the typological affmities and the inferred ages of archeological materials that can be expected to occur in Ellis County. The specimens examined are from collections made by E. C. Oates, Sr., E. Lott, and C. Barton. None represent • whole collections. Permission was granted only to examine approximately I 00 specimens each from.the Lott and Barton collections. The Oates Collection, now in possession of the Ellis County Museum, repr~sents about one-half of the original collection. The remainder is in the possession of a surviving relative. The samples of the fonner two collections were made with a conscious attempt to illustrate the range of variability represented. Consequeµtly, this analysis is based on samples that may or may not accurately reflect styles and frequency of occurrence. Since this analysis is intended to be a general characterization, it is assumed for present purposes that the samples do indeed reflect local trends. By and large, the collections were made in Ellis or nearby counties. It is not possible to identify materials obtained relatively near, but not in, Ellis County. Exotic items from farther afield are somewhat easier to distinguish. Nevertheless, there is useful infonnation to be gained-from such collections, especially when specific sites, site clust - ers, o . r counties - are known . . B.2 Prewitt The 106 pieces in the Lott Collection, in contrast, contain at least 18 specimens that were not collected locally and another nine specimens that are fakes. While the remainder of the collection may be from Ellis County and vicinity, the very fact that 25.38% of the specimens are exotics or fakes erodes the confidence in the collection as a whole. The exotics span a broad range of origins from the Ohio River valley (a probable Jack's Reef point) to the Trans-Pecos region (a Duran point). The fakes consist mostly of distal biface fragments that have been recently rechipped into dart points although at least one dart point stem was rechipped and one arrow point was made from a flake. Fresh flake scars and odd morphologies are hallmarks of the fakes. A similar lack of integrity is found in the Oates Collection. While most of the 398 pieces of lithic material were collected from around Bardwell Lake and nearby Navarro, Johnson, and Tarrant counties, an unknown quantity came from farther afield in Polk County. Because of similarities in raw materials and cultural expressions, the Polk County specimens cannot be identified with confidence. Exotics collected from Arizona, New Mexico, and Mesoamerica are easier to detect, but only eight projectile points were noted from these extra regional locations. More bothersome are the 66 fake projectile points identified. As with the Lott Collection, these are made from genuine flakes and distal biface fragments that are recognizable by fresh tlake scars and nontraditional morphologies. Fakes represent in excess of 20% of all projectile points in this collection, and this does not include the 19 examples whose broken distal tips were rechipped so the points would appear to be whole and unbroken. · ARTIFACT ANALYSIS The artifact samples from the three collections were identified by morphological type (Table B. l ). Overall, there are no surprises either in the projectile point styles or the other tool types. Descriptions of most of the types can be found in Suhm and Jelks (1962) and/or Turner and Hester (1985). Exceptions are Axtell (Bryan 1936; Prewitt and Chandler, in press), Dixon (variety of Edgewood; Johnson 1962), Merrell (Campbell 1948; Prewitt, fmpublished notes), Yantis (Johnson 1962), and Perkin Pike (Jelks 1965). Identifiable ringers are termed "exotics" and are listed in Table B.2 along with presumed regions of origin. · Analysis of the chronological distributions of the projectile points (Table B.3) reveals a pattern similar to one developed for Central Texas (Prewitt 1985). There are differences, though. While the Central Texas percentage of projectile points peaks in the Middle Archaic and drops slightly in the Late Archaic, the Ellis County materials peak in the Late Archaic. The Late Prehistoric I figures are about the same, but the Late Prehistoric II percentage is only one third that of Central Texas. Whether this is sampling error or a real reflection of intensity of use during these periods is unknown. The assignment of projectile point types to chronological periods is shown in Table B.4. ## Page 741

• A Projectile Point_Analysis ofP ortions Oft he OaJes, Lott, and Barton Collections.from Ellis County, Texas B.3 Overall the total number of styles represented is .about equal between the two regions at 25 each. The total number of specimens, however, is clearly biased toward East Texas with 66.87% of the points being affiliated with that region. Thus, while regional influences do vary somewhat through time, East Texas really dominates the pattern beginning with the Middle Archaic period and extending through the Late Prehistoric. A generalized lithic source analysis is presented by projectile point type in Table B.5. Four source areas were utilized for this analysis. The first is the Uvalde Gravel which is common in and around the study area (Byrd 1971 ). Materials obtained from the Uvalde Gravel include abundant maroon to tan or yellow quartzite and minor quantities of silicified wood,jasper, chert. and chalcedony. The second source area is the Comanche Plateau physiographic region that extends to the west-southwest of Ellis County. The eroded Cretaceous limestones in that area produce good-quality cherts that are relatively abundant. The third source area is the Lampasas Cut Plain immediately south-southwest of the Comanche Plateau. This dissected region is a continuation of the Cretaceous limestones and is widely known for the abundant high-quality cherts that occur there. The final source area is simply "other." With one exception, these are specimens that can not readily oe identified to general area of origin. The one exception is a Dawson point in the Lott Collection that is made of Pisgah Ridge Chert descnoed by McGregor (1987) as originating in the Tehuacana Limestone in Navarro County. Identification of source areas was done on a visual basis only. This leaves ample opportunity for error, especially for distinguishing between Comanche Plateau and Lampasas Cut Plain materials since there is no sharp difference in materials as there is to a large extent with the Uvalde Gravel. A summary of the distnbution oflithic source areas by regional affiliation and chronological period is presented in Table B.6. Again, only those projectile points identified to type are used in the tabulation. Keeping in mind the previously expressed limitations of the data set, there are some very interesting patterns in regional affiliations and temporal associations. For those point styles generally associated with Central Texas, the material preferred is consistently the cherts from the Comanche Plateau and the Lampasas Cut Plain. The least clear preference is the Late Prehistoric I period, and this is not surprising in view of earlier comments regarding the distribution of Scallorn points • which crosscut regional boundaries. , ' A sharp contrast is seen in the East Texas types where the Early and Middle Archaic periods show a clear preference for Central Texas cherts. In the Late Archaic, the materials are split at about 50-50 but tend to favor the Uvalde Gravel, and this continues into the Late Prehistoric I period. In the Late Prehistoric II, the preference is once again the Cretaceous cherts. If the regional affiliations are disregarded (Table B.7), the same chronological trend of preference is indicated with a strong orientation toward the Central Texas cherts except during the Late Archaic and Late Prehistoric I periods. PALMER QUADRANGLE 41EL122 Location and Description 41EL122 is a historic site covering ca. 900 m2 (9,687.51 ft2) on the drainage divide between Brushy Creek and Red Oak Creek (Figure C2). The site is located ca. 1,066.80 m (3,500 ft) north of the intersection of Farrar Road with Sutton Road, immediately west of Sutton Road. The estate on which this site is located is off of the SSC footprint as well as outside of any associated parcel boundaries; however, limited access to this estate was acquired, on ~ehalf of the DOE, for the SSC project (see below). The site is located in an area of Houston Black clay, terrace, 0% to 1% slopes, at an elevation of ca. 152.4 m ( ca. 500 ft) above msl. The exact location is: U1M 14 713600 3594720; or 32•28'15" N, 96•43'39" W. The site was recorded in 1990 in conjunction with the geotechnical boring program. A standing structure was present at this location when the Palmer 7.5' Quadrangle was compiled in 1963; however, at the time this site was recorded the site consisted only of a dense scatter of artifacts. Archival and Informant Data • This site is located in the James M Riggs Survey, a Peters Colony grant which was surveyed'in 1853. The 1937 WPA survey indicates that 41EL122 was located on a 70 acre (28.33 ha) tract belonging to Miss Lena Andrews of Waxahachie, Texas, who leased'the property to tenants on a thirds and fourths rental basis. No structures are listed in the WPA survey, and the entire tract was planted in cotton. A farmstead is depicted at this location on all of the Ellis County highway maps from 1941 through 1964 (Texas State Highway Department 1952, 1957, 1961, and 1973) and a structure is depicted at this location on both the 1963 Palmer 7.5' Quadrangle and its 1978 photorevision. No additional background research was conducted for 41EL122 since this site is located outside of the SSC project area. Field Investigations No archaeological investigations were conducted since this site is located outside of the SSC project area.

BOZ QUADRANGLE 41EL141 Location and Description 41EL141 is a historic site covering ca. 3 ha (7.41 acres) in the drainage of Baker Branch. The site is located ca. 1,371.60 m (4,500 ft) south of the intersection of Dunaway Road with Bethel Road and is bisected by Bethel Road (Figure C.4). The estate on which this site is located is off Qf the SSC footprint as well as outside of any associated parcel boundaries. Therefore, no rights, fee simple or stratified subsurface fee, were purchased for this estate in conjunction with SSC construction. The site is located in an area of Austin silty clay, I% to 3% slopes, Eddy gravelly clay loam, 1% to 3% slopes, and Frio silty clay, frequently flooded. The elevation ranges from ca. 170.69 m ( ca. 560 ft) to ca. 182.88 m ( ca. 600 ft) above msl. The exact location is: UTM 14 696410 3574820; or 32°17'40" N, 96°54'50" W. The site was recorded in 1991 as a result of the initial SSC footprint archaeological survey. At tpat time the central features of the site were the Bethel United Methodist Church, the parsonage, a fellowship hall, an outdoor tabernacle, and a cemetery. These features were documented by Hardy-Heck-Moore, Inc. (1990). • ' APPENDIX D. GLOSSARY OF FLAKED STONE TERMINOLOGY Kevin J. Shaunessy The following brief glossary of terms is provided for the convenience of the anticipated non-archaeologically oriented reader. It is by no means exhaustive, but will hopefully provide clarification of some of the nomenclature that is not explicitly defined in the text of Chapter 7. Many of the "morphological terms" used in the text, in addition to being briefly defined below, are also depicted graphically in Figure D.l. Finally, terms used in the definitions below which are italicized are themselves defined in this glossary. Arris The ridge which results along the juncture of two intersectingjlake scars. The edge . of a concave flake scar (see Figure D.l). • Biface A flaked stone implement which has been intentionally modified along an edge or lateral margin via the removal of flakes from both surfaces. Blank "A useable piece of lithic material of adequate size and form for making a lithic artifact ... bearing little or no waste material, and suitable for assorted lithic artifact styles. The shape or form of the final product are not disclosed in the blank" (Crabtree 1972:42). Many workers distinguish a range of blanks from large, thick, and ( at least) initially edged "quany blanks" to more refined, thinner forms termed "cache bifaces" and "trade blanks" (e.g., Turner and Hester 1993:24-26). Not to be confused with preform.
