## Page 771

• Glossary ofF laked Stone Terminology D.3 Faceting Systematic removal of flakes on the platform which are initiated at the juncture of the platfmm and the dorsal surface of the intended flake. Intended to add purchase to the platform. Flake Scar A concave or "negative" impression left on the surface of a core or worked implement which results from the detachment of a flake or blade. A "concave plane of fracture" (Crabtree 1972:56) (see Figure D.l). Grinding A rounding and smoothing along the juncture of the platform and the dorsal surface of the intended flake and/or a scoring of the platform. Intended to strengthen the platform (smoothing) and/or add purchase to the platform (scoring). Hard Hammer A percussor of hard wood or stone used to detach flakes or blades from the parent mass via the percussion method. The harder the hammer, the shorter the interval of contact between percussor and the material to be flaked. See Soft Hammer. Hinge Fracture A fracture at the distal end of a flake or blade which prevents detachment of the flake at its proposed terminal point A hinge fracture terminates the flake at right angles to the longitudinal axis and the break is usually rounded or blunt (Crabtree 1972:68). Indirect Hammer Percussion A method of percussion flaking wherein an intermediate punch-like tool of stone, wood, bone, or antler is placed on the material to be flaked and receives the blow from • the percussor or "hammer." The force to detach flakes or blade$ is thereby applied "indirectly" to the material to be flaked. Knapper "One who forms stone implements by controlling the fracture of the material. An artificer. A stoneworker using material exhibiting a conchoidal fracture" (Crabtree 1972:65). Lineal Edge Offset The degree of sinuosity displayed on the lateral margin(s) of a biface. This offset is essentially equivalent to the distance between the flake scar ridges ( arrises) or troughs on opposite surfaces of the specimen and is measured in relative terms (i.e., wide, moderate, close). Bifaces in the earlier stages of the reduction process will tend to have more sinuous edges, and, consequently, a wider offset Bifaces in the later stages

D.4 §haunes~ :' \ Platfonn Preparation Modification of the striking platform on the parent mass in order to strengthen it or provide purchase prior to the application of force to remove a flake. See also Dragging, Grinding, and Faceting. Platform (Striking Platform) "The table or surface area receiving the force necessary to detach a flake or blade. Can be either natural or prepared" (Crabtree 1972:84). The portion of the platform remaining on the detached flake is called the "platform remnant"(see Figure D.l). Pot Lid "A piano-convex flake leaving a concave scar. Pot lids are the result of differential expansion and contraction of isotropic material but are min~ the compression rings of force lines usually associated with these conditions (Crabtree 1972:84)." See also Spall. Prefonn "Prefonning denotes the first shaping. Prefonn is an unfinished, unused form of the proposed artifact. It is larger than, and without the refinement of, the completed tool. ... Not to be confused with a 'blank'" (Crabtree 1972:85). Pressure Flaking "Process of fonning and sharpening stone by removing surplus material-in the fonn of flakes-from the artifact by a pressing force rather than by percussion" (Crabtree 1972:85). Proximal The margin opposite the ''working end" of a flaked stone artifact The basal element if the specimen is a projectile point or biface. The platform remnant if the specimen is an unmodified flake or blade (see Figure D.1 ). • Recovery Techniques Methods by which "mistakes" in the flaked stone reduction process or the finishing and refurbishing of flaked stone tools may be corrected or "cleaned up." For instance, if an inclusion or other impurity in the raw material of a core has resulted in imperfect flake removals, the knapper may elect to remove a much larger flake in order to undermine the area with the inclusion and provide a "clean" face on the core. Soft Hammer A percussor of sandstone, soft wood, antler, or bone used to detach flakes or blades from the parent mass via the percussion method. The softer the hammer, the longer the interval of contact between percussor and the material to be flaked. See Hard

Yedlowskl INTRODUCTION J.L Yedlowskl As indicated in the Introduction of Chapter 8, a two-staged analytical approach was employed for the analysis of the historic material culture remains. This approach was necessitated by the Department of Energy's (DOE) request of recommendations for in-depth analysis and permanent curation of the historic material culture remains prior to any • analysis. The first stage consisted of the inventory and tabulation of all Superconducting Super Collider (SSC) historic material culture remains. This was accomplished employing a classification system of _IO major techno-functional categories and one "catchall" or miscellaneous category: architectural remains; ceramic vessl remains; electrical items; fireanns and related remains; fuel remains; glass vessel remains; hand tools/implements; horse and stable items; metal items; personal items; and miscellaneous items. {A detailed description of the classification system employed can be found in Chapter 8.) During this inventory and tabulation attribute data was collected about each specimen which was entered into a database. This level of data collection was employed for two reasons. First, it was apparent that the historic artifact asseblages from every site would not receive in-depth analysis or permanent curation, since Congress had terminated funding of the SSC project. Therefore, in order to make recommendations for either ofDOE's requests "one had to know exactly what one had."
